1 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dietze


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


75 N.Y.2d 47; 549 N.E.2d 1166; 550 N.Y.S.2d 595; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 4417


October 17, 1989, Argued  
December 19, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the St. Lawrence County Court (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the Town Court of the Town of Norfolk (New York) convicting defendant of harassment under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.25.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of harassment under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.25 after cursing at a neighbor. The court reversed the conviction and dismissed the case because defendant's obnoxious behavior did not create an immediate likelihood of violence. The law defining the offense was overbroad and created an unconstitutional limitation on speech. Defendant had not made a real threat to commit an assault. Speech could not be forbidden merely because it was annoying. The court therefore held that N.Y. Penal Law § 240.25(2) was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the conviction and dismissed the case, holding that the harassment law under which defendant was convicted was an unconstitutional limitation on freedom of speech.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Harassment -- Use of "Abusive" Language with Intent to Harass -- Overbreadth

1. Penal Law § 240.25 (2), which proscribes the use of "abusive" language with the intent to "harass" or "annoy" another person, is invalid for overbreadth, under both the State (NY Const, art I, § 8) and Federal (U.S. Const 1st, 14th Amends) Constitutions because the statute, on its face, prohibits a substantial amount of constitutionally protected expression, and because its continued existence presents a significant risk of prosecution for the mere exercise of free speech. At the least, any proscription of pure speech must be sharply limited to words which, by their utterance alone, inflict injury or tend naturally to evoke immediate violence or other breach of the peace. However, the proscriptions of Penal Law § 240.25 (2) is not limited to such "fighting words"; it extends to any "abusive" language intended to "annoy", and no fair reading of the statute's unqualified terms supports or even suggests the constitutionally necessary limitations on its scope. Accordingly, an information, to the extent it charges defendant with harassment under section 240.25 (2), is dismissed.

Statutes -- Construction -- Limitations on Judicial Construction to Cure Unconstitutionally Overbroad Statute Regulating Speech

2. The unconstitutional overbreadth of Penal Law § 240.25 (2), which proscribes the use of "abusive" language with the intent to "harass" or "annoy" another person, cannot be cured by judicial construction restricting its reach to "fighting words" or other words which, by themselves, inflict substantial personal injury. Although a statute ought normally to be saved by construing it in accord with constitutional requirements, the very language of the statute must be fairly susceptible of such an interpretation. Here, the language of section 240.25 (2) simply does not even suggest a limitation to violence-provoking or substantial injury-inflicting utterances. An attempt by the court to so limit the statute would be tantamount to wholesale revision of the Legislature's enactment, rather than prudent judicial construction. Moreover, to so construe the statute would likely result in transforming an otherwise overbroad statute into an impermissibly vague one; the statutory language would signify one thing but, as a matter of judicial decision, would stand for something entirely different. Under those circumstances, persons of ordinary intelligence reading section 240.25 (2) could not know what it actually meant. Such a deficiency is especially intolerable in a statute regulating speech, since it chills the expressive freedom of those who believe the statute means what it says, and subjects individuals to arrest and prosecution, even if ultimately unsuccessful, by officials strictly enforcing the statute's prohibitions.

Crimes -- Harassment -- Threat of Physical Harm

3. The conviction of defendant for harassment under Penal Law § 240.25 (1), based upon her statement to the complainant that she would "beat the crap out of [complainant] some day or night in the street", is reversed. There is nothing in the record demonstrating that defendant's statement was either serious, should reasonably have been taken to be serious, or was confirmed by other words or acts showing that it was anything more than a crude outburst. While genuine threats of physical harm fall within the scope of the statute, such an outburst, without more, does not.

 

2 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


State by Abrams v. Ford Motor Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


74 N.Y.2d 495; 548 N.E.2d 906; 549 N.Y.S.2d 368; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 3309


October 12, 1989, Argued  
November 28, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant automaker sought review of the order of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which modified and affirmed a prior judgment that permanently enjoined the automaker from charging a deductible to customers, and requested restitution for those who had already paid it, pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(12), in favor of respondent state.


OVERVIEW: The automaker issued a two stage warranty for its new automobiles and light trucks. In its primary stage, the basic warranty covered the entire vehicle and was effective for the vehicle's first year or 12,000 miles, whichever occurred first. During the second stage, the automaker applied an extended warranty that charged a $ 100 deductible for the earlier of the vehicle's second year or 18,000 mile. The state sought to enjoin the automaker from charging the deductible and requested restitution for those who had already paid it, pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(12). The state argued that it violated the state's "Lemon Law." This law prohibited motor vehicle manufacturers from charging for warranty-covered repairs made during the earlier of the vehicle's first two years or 18,000 miles. N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 198-a(b). The court affirmed the order, holding that the deductible charging practices violated the Lemon Law, pursuant to the express language of the statute and the law's legislative history. The court further held that the Lemon Law was not unconstitutional because there was no attempt at direct regulation, no discriminatory effect, and no in-state favoritism.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order, which modified and affirmed a prior judgment that permanently enjoined the automaker from charging a deductible to customers, and requested restitution for those who had already paid it, in favor of the state, because such deductible charging practices violated the Lemon Law, pursuant to the express language of the statute and the law's legislative history.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Lemon Law -- New Car Lemon Law -- Validity of Deductible for Warranty-Covered Repairs

1. Appellant automaker's imposition against consumers of a $ 100 deductible for repairs to a vehicle's powertrain and other major components covered by an extended warranty, which applies to the earlier of the vehicle's second year or 18,000th mile, violates the provision of the Lemon Law prohibiting motor vehicle manufacturers from charging for warranty-covered repairs made during the earlier of the vehicle's first two years or 18,000 miles (General Business Law § 198-a [b]). The statute clearly and unambiguously provides that when a new motor vehicle does not conform to all express warranties for the earlier of its first two years or 18,000 miles, "[the] manufacturer * * * shall correct said nonconformity * * * at no charge to the consumer" (General Business Law § 198-a [b]). By the automaker's expressly warranting the performance of the powertrain and other major components during the extended portion of the statutory period, there arose by operation of the Lemon Law an unconditional duty by the automaker to repair any warranted nonconformities "at no charge" to the consumer. Even if the deductible can be legally transformed into a condition precedent as urged by the automaker, it would be in direct contravention of the legislative expression and intent found in the statute itself.

Courts -- Jurisdiction -- General and Plenary Jurisdiction of Appellate Division to Impose Discretionary Restitution Remedy

2. A proceeding pursuant to Executive Law § 63 (12) is not exempt from the general and plenary jurisdiction of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to impose a discretionary restitutionary remedy. Section 63 (12) is the procedural route by which the Attorney-General may apply to Supreme Court for an order enjoining repeated illegal or fraudulent acts. The statute expressly provides that such an injunction, if granted, may also direct restitution. Although an application by the Attorney-General for remedial orders under section 63 (12) is addressed to the sound judicial discretion of the Supreme Court, once that court makes its ruling the initial adjudication is reviewable in a plenary fashion by the appellate level of the Supreme Court itself. Thus, in a proceeding pursuant to Executive Law § 63 (12) in which Supreme Court declared that appellant automaker's practice of charging consumers a deductible for certain warranty-covered repairs to vehicles violated the express warranty provision of the Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a [b]), the Appellate Division, upon the appeal from Supreme Court's judgment, was authorized to review and to grant the discretionary remedy of restitution petitioned for by the Attorney-General.

Constitutional  Law -- Validity of Statute -- New Car Lemon Law Provision Requiring Repairs at No Charge to Consumer -- Commerce Clause

3. The express warranty provision of the Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a [b]), insofar as it prohibits the charging of a deductible for a warranty-covered repair during the statutory period of coverage, i.e., the earlier of a vehicle's first two years or 18,000 miles, does not violate the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8, cl 3), since there is no attempt at direct regulation, no discriminatory effect and no in-State favoritism by the statute's requirement that warranty-covered repairs be made "at no charge" as limited to vehicles sold and registered in New York State (General Business Law § 198-a [a] [2]). Further, the statute's burden on interstate commerce cannot be anything but incidental in the constitutional Commerce Clause sense.

Appeal -- Matters Reviewable -- Review by Court of Appeals of Constitutional Question on Appeal by Permission of Court of Appeals -- Constitutional Question Not Addressed by Appellate Division

4. On an appeal to the Court of Appeals, by permission of that court, from a judgment of Supreme Court, bringing up for review a prior nonfinal order of the Appellate Division which did not address the constitutionality of the Lemon Law (General Business Law § 198-a) in respect to appellant automaker's practice of charging a $ 100 deductible for certain warranty-covered repairs, on the ground that the issue was not properly before it, the Court of Appeals should resolve that issue as part of the appeal before it on the grant of the motion for leave to appeal, since the constitutional question in the particular aspect at issue in this case remains in the case in view of the constancy from the onset of the litigation of the constitutional challenge to the statutory prohibition of a $ 100 deductible.

 

3 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Medicon Diagnostic Laboratories, Inc. v. Perales


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


74 N.Y.2d 539; 549 N.E.2d 124; 549 N.Y.S.2d 933; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 3233


October 18, 1989, Argued  
November 28, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants providers challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a trial court determination in a declaratory judgment action that procedures used by respondent, the Commissioner of the Department of Social Services (DSS), pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, 518.7, were not unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The providers, two medical laboratories that provided services under the New York State Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid), were audited by the DSS and were found to have charged for services not performed; reimbursement payments to the providers were withheld by the DSS pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 518.7. The providers filed an action under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, seeking a declaratory judgment that the withholding of Medicaid reimbursement payments was arbitrary and capricious, and that the providers had been deprived of their property rights without due process of law. The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court. Applying the three-part test for determining whether a governmental action violated due process, the court concluded that the procedures for withholding payment of Medicaid reimbursement claims set forth in N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 518.7 were not unconstitutional. The procedures adequately safeguarded the private interests of the providers and minimized the risk of erroneous deprivation while serving a substantial government interest in safeguarding the integrity of the state's Medicaid program.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.


HEADNOTES

Health -- Medicaid Reimbursement Payments -- Constitutionality of Regulation Authorizing Withholding of Reimbursement Payments under Specified Circumstances -- Procedural Due Process

1. To the extent that providers in the Medicaid program may enjoy a constitutionally protected property right in the payment of their claims for reimbursement for services rendered, 18 NYCRR 518.7, which authorizes withholding payment of reimbursement claims under certain specified circumstances, provides adequate procedural due process and thus passes constitutional muster. The procedures for withholding payment of Medicaid reimbursement claims set forth in 18 NYCRR 518.7 adequately safeguard the private interests of petitioners, and minimize the risk of erroneous deprivation while serving the substantial government interest in safeguarding the integrity of the Medicaid program. Moreover, the regulations permit withholding payment only where there is "reliable information that a provider is involved in fraud or willful misrepresentation involving claims submitted to the program or has abused the program or committed unacceptable practices" (18 NYCRR 518.7 [a]). Notice of the withholding must be given to the provider promptly, within five days (18 NYCRR 518.7 [b]), and the notice must describe the reasons for the withholding and afford the provider an opportunity to make written submissions and arguments in opposition (18 NYCRR 518.7 [c] [4]). The withholding may not continue beyond 90 days unless a written report or notice of proposed agency action is given to the provider (18 NYCRR 518.7 [d]) in which event the provider would be entitled to request a hearing (18 NYCRR 518.7 [d] [2]; 518.8 [b]).

Health -- Medicaid Reimbursement Payments  -- Adequacy of Basis for Withholding Reimbursement Payments Pending Audit  and Review

2. In two CPLR article 78 proceedings commenced by petitioners, clinical medical laboratories enrolled as providers in the New York State Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid), challenging respondent's decision to withhold payment of petitioners' claims for reimbursement for services rendered pursuant to 18 NYCRR 518.7 pending review and verification of the reimbursement claims, petitioners' contention that respondent's decision to withhold payment was arbitrary and capricious is without merit. Respondent's decision to withhold payment pending the audit was based on "reliable information" -- written statements of several physicians indicating that some of petitioners' claims were improper, which provided an adequate basis for the withholding of payment pending audit and review.

 

4 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Seawall Associates v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


74 N.Y.2d 92; 542 N.E.2d 1059; 544 N.Y.S.2d 542; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 879


May 3, 1989, Argued  
July 6, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, Local Law No. 9 declared to be unconstitutional and defendants enjoined from implementing the local law's provisions.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) in which the court held that New York, N.Y. Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 was not unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs brought suit asserting that New York, N.Y. Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 (Local Law) was an unconstitutional taking of property without compensation. The lower court found that the local law was valid. Plaintiffs appealed. The appeals court reversed. The appeals court held that where owners are forced to accept the occupation of their properties by persons not already in residence, the resulting deprivation of rights was sufficient to constitute a physical taking for which compensation was required. The appeals court continued and held that when the adjustment of rights for the public good became so disproportionate that it could be said that the governmental action was forcing some people alone to bear public burdens which, in all fairness and justice, should be borne by the public as a whole, a regulatory taking of property occurred. According to the court, the burdens imposed did not substantially advance legitimate state interest.


OUTCOME: The appeals court reversed the lower court's judgment, holding that plaintiffs' were entitled to just compensation for their properties where plaintiffs' rights to use, possess, and transfer property was substantially impaired.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Taking of Property without Just Compensation -- Local Law Mandating Preservation of Single-Room Occupancy Properties in City of New York -- Physical Taking

1. Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 of the City of New York, which prohibits the demolition, alteration, or conversion of single-room occupancy (SRO) properties and obligates the owners to restore all units to habitable condition and lease them at controlled rents for an indefinite period, is facially invalid as a physical taking in violation of the Federal and State Constitutions (US Const 5th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 7) and is, therefore, null and void. Local Law No. 9 requires the owners to rent their rooms or be subject to severe penalties; it compels them to admit persons as tenants with all of the possessory and other rights that that status entails; it compels them to surrender the most basic attributes of private property, the rights of possession and exclusion. Where, as here, owners are forced to accept the occupation of their properties by persons not already in residence, the resulting deprivation of rights in those properties is sufficient to constitute a physical taking for which compensation is required.

Constitutional Law -- Taking of Property without Just Compensation -- Local Law Mandating Preservation of Single-Room Occupancy Properties in City of New York -- Regulatory Taking -- Denial of  Economically Viable Use of Property

2. Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 of the City of New York, which prohibits the demolition, alteration, or conversion of single-room occupancy (SRO) properties and obligates the owners to restore all units to habitable condition and lease them at controlled rents for an indefinite period, is facially invalid as a regulatory taking in violation of the Federal and State Constitutions (US Const 5th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 7) on the ground that it denies SRO owners economically viable use of their properties. The coerced rental provisions deprive owners the fundamental right to possess their properties. Moreover, these mandatory rental provisions -- together with the prohibition against demolition, alteration and conversion of the properties to other uses, and the requirement that uninhabitable units be refurbished -- deny owners of SRO buildings any right to use their properties as they see fit. In addition, Local Law No. 9, particularly in those provisions prohibiting redevelopment and mandating rental, inevitably impairs the ability of owners to sell their properties for any sums approaching their investments and, therefore, must also negatively affect the owners' right to dispose of their properties. Whether the property rights abolished or impaired are considered alone, or the values of these rights are compared with the values of the properties as a whole, the conclusion is inescapable that the effect of the local law's provisions is unconstitutionally to deprive owners of economically viable use of their properties.

Constitutional Law -- Taking of Property without Just Compensation -- Local Law Mandating Preservation of Single-Room Occupancy Properties in City of New York -- Regulatory Taking -- Failure to Substantially Advance Legitimate State Interest

3. Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 of the City of New York, which prohibits the demolition, alteration, or conversion of single-room occupancy (SRO) properties and obligates the owners to restore all units to habitable condition and lease them at controlled rents for an indefinite period, is facially invalid as a regulatory taking in violation of the Federal and State Constitutions (US Const 5th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 7) because the burdens imposed by the local law do not "substantially advance" its putative purpose of relieving homelessness. The nexus between the obligations placed on SRO property owners and the alleviation of the highly complex social problem of homelessness is indirect at best and conjectural. Such a tenuous connection between means and ends cannot justify singling out this group of property owners to bear the costs required by the law toward the cure of the homeless problem.

Constitutional Law -- Taking of Property without Just Compensation -- Local Law Mandating Preservation of Single-Room Occupancy Properties in City of New York -- Buy-Out, Replacement and Hardship Exemptions

4. The invidious effects of Local Laws, 1987, No. 9 of the City of New York, which prohibits the demolition, alteration, or conversion of singleroom occupancy (SRO) properties and obligates the owners to restore all units to habitable condition and lease them at controlled rents for an indefinite period, are not mitigated by the local law's buy-out, replacement and hardship exemptions so that the local law becomes constitutionally acceptable. The effect of the moratorium and antiwarehousing measures is unconstitutionally to deprive owners of their basic rights to possess and to make economically viable use of their properties; merely allowing the owners to purchase exemptions from the law by paying cash or by providing an equal number of replacement units cannot alter this conclusion. Nor can the hardship exemption, which can do no more than permit the Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development -- in the event that an owner could ever come within its provisions -- to exercise his discretion and lower the purchase price of escape from the law, make a difference. Local Law No. 9 creates an illegal taking notwithstanding the buy-out and replacement options; the local law does not become legal simply because an owner may, in some cases, buy his way out of the law by paying a lesser sum.

Courts -- Jurisdiction -- Facial Attack on Constitutionality of Land Use Regulation

5. It is entirely appropriate for a court to adjudge the facial validity of a land use regulation when challenged by a property owner claiming an unconstitutional "taking" or other deprivation of property rights.

 

5 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mahboubian


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


74 N.Y.2d 174; 543 N.E.2d 34; 544 N.Y.S.2d 769; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 681


April 27, 1989, Argued  
June 15, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants sought reversal of the ruling of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirming their convictions for burglary, attempted grand larceny, and conspiracy.


OVERVIEW: Defendants challenged their convictions for conspiracy to steal antiques. Defendants' convictions were affirmed by the state intermediate appellate court, and they took a further appeal. The state's highest court reversed due to erroneous denial of severance. The court reasoned that severance was compelled when the core of each defense was in irreconcilable conflict with the other and where there was a significant danger that the conflict alone would have led the jury to infer defendants' guilt. That was the case here, as one defendant's defense was complete denial and the other's was a claimed lack of intent to defraud. In addition, redaction of one defendant's pretrial statement, in order to protect the other defendant, deprived the first of a fair opportunity to use that statement in his defense. Since defendants' defenses were not only antagonistic but also mutually exclusive and irreconcilable, with a jury being unable to credit both, severance was required. The convictions were reversed and remanded for retrials.


OUTCOME: The convictions were reversed, and the cases were remanded for separate retrials. The trial court committed reversible error when it failed to grant appellants' motion for severance, given antagonistic, mutually exclusive, and irreconcilable defenses offered by defendants.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Conspiracy -- Verdict -- Sufficiency of Evidence

1. In the prosecution of defendants involving a staged theft from a warehouse of a collection of artifacts owned by one defendant, the evidence was sufficient for the jury to find that both defendants had conspired, as charged, to stage a burglary and fraudulent theft in order to collect the insurance proceeds covering the collection.

Crimes -- Consolidation and Severance -- Undue Prejudice -- Antagonistic Defenses

2. Antagonism in the defenses advanced by jointly tried defendants results in such prejudice under CPL 200.40 (1) as to compel severance where the core of each defense is in irreconcilable conflict with the other and where there is a significant danger, as both defenses are portrayed to the trial court, that the conflict alone would lead the jury to infer defendant's guilt. Accordingly, in the prosecution of two defendants for burglary, attempted grand larceny and conspiracy arising out of the staged theft from a warehouse of a collection of artifacts owned by one defendant, with the objective of recovering the insurance proceeds, where the defendant owner denied any participation in the crimes and the other defendant conceded the theft, but, in defense, claimed that there was no intent to defraud the insurer, the denial of defendants' motions pursuant to CPL 200.40 to be tried separately on the ground of undue prejudice was an abuse of discretion. The defendants' defenses were not only antagonistic but also mutually exclusive and irreconcilable. The jury could not have credited both defenses. The People's proof of the conspiracy and attempted grand larceny charges was largely circumstantial. In a case of directly conflicting defenses such as this, there was a significant possibility that the jury unjustifiably concluded by virtue of the conflict itself that both defenses were incredible and gave undue weight to the government's evidence. Under those circumstances, defendants were denied a full opportunity to present their defenses, and did not receive a fair trial.

Crimes -- Consolidation and Severance -- Undue Prejudice -- Redaction of One Defendant's Statement to District Attorney

3. In the prosecution of two defendants for burglary, attempted grand larceny and conspiracy, arising out of the staged theft from a warehouse of a collection of artifacts owned by one defendant, with the objective of recovering the insurance proceeds, defendant owner was unduly prejudiced at the joint trial, when, out of concern for a possible Bruton problem with respect to the other defendant, large portions of the defendant owner's statement to an Assistant District Attorney were redacted. It is not crucial that the excised portions of the statement, which defendant owner would have been entitled at a separate trial to have the jury consider in its entirety, were not "exculpatory" in the strictest sense. The redacted material supported the defendant owner's defense arguments and if believed, it explained much of the evidence against him. Given the circumstantial nature of the People's case against defendant owner, redaction of these areas of his statement, which would have provided the jury with an explanation for some of the evidence equally consistent with an inference of innocence as of guilt, was unduly prejudicial. The People's contention that the redaction actually favored defendant owner because a few details of the excised answers were arguably inconsistent with his trial strategy is not dispositive; the great bulk of defendant owner's statement was entirely consistent with and supported his defense.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review

4. On appeals to the Court of Appeals from Appellate Division orders affirming the judgments convicting defendants of attempted grand larceny, burglary and conspiracy, defendants' contentions that, even if the People proved all of the allegations of the indictment, the acts they were charged with committing did not amount to an attempt to commit grand larceny or to a burglary, were preserved for review by defendants' pretrial motions to dismiss on that precise ground, even though defendants did not specifically seek dismissal on that basis at the close of the People's evidence.

Crimes -- Attempt -- Conduct "Dangerously Near" Completion of Intended Crime -- Attempted Grand Larceny

5. Before liability can be imposed for the substantive crime of attempt (Penal Law § 110.00), a defendant's conduct must come "very near" or "dangerously near" completion of the intended crime. The defendant's act need not be the final one toward the completion of the intended crime. The necessity of further steps for the completion of the crime and the possibility of abandonment or renunciation are factors to be considered in evaluating whether conduct has come "dangerously close" to success, but are not dispositive. Accordingly, in the prosecution of defendants arising out of the staged theft from a warehouse of a collection of artifacts owned by one defendant, with the objective of recovering the insurance proceeds, where defendants had not yet reported any loss to the insurer or filed an insurance claim when police intervention put an end to their scheme, the defendants' actions reached the stage where they were "very near" or "dangerously near" completion of the larceny of the insurance proceeds so as to constitute an attempt. The fact that defendants had not yet taken the final step necessary to obtain the insurance money does not mean that the steps they had taken could not constitute an attempt to do so; nor does the theoretical possibility that defendants might yet have renounced the criminal venture obviate their liability for an attempt. The steps they had already taken were more than substantial: they had secured insurance, arranged for shipment of the goods from Europe and storage in a particular New York City warehouse, and hired thieves who actually broke in and removed the goods. These steps took defendants to the point where only a few comparatively minor acts -- all wholly within defendants' own power -- remained to be accomplished. Thus, in the circumstances of this crime and this case, defendants' conduct went sufficiently beyond mere preparation and, as the jury found, constituted attempted grand larceny.

Crimes -- Attempt -- Model Penal Code

6. The Court of Appeals does not adopt the Model Penal Code's definition of an attempt as a "substantial step" toward completion of crime (see, Model Penal Code § 5.01) in order to conclude that some acts -- even if preparatory in a dictionary sense -- go sufficiently beyond "mere preparation" as to be properly characterized as an attempt for which criminal liability may be imposed.

Crimes -- Burglary -- Intent to Commit Crime within Premises -- Criminal Facilitation -- Attempted Grand Larceny

7. In order to secure a conviction for burglary (Penal Law § 140.20), the People need only allege and prove a knowing and unlawful entry of the premises coupled with an intent to commit a crime therein. There is no requirement that the People allege or establish what particular crime was intended, or that the intended crime actually be committed. Thus, in the prosecution of defendants arising out of the staged theft from a warehouse of a collection of artifacts owned by one defendant, with the objective of recovering the insurance proceeds, there was sufficient proof that defendants intended that the crimes of criminal facilitation and attempted grand larceny be committed by their hired helpers in the warehouse to support defendants' convictions for burglary premised on their liability as accessories for the acts of their hired helpers in breaking into the warehouse and removing the artifacts. The evidence amply demonstrates that defendants intended that their hired helpers engage in conduct that would provide defendants with the means to commit the felony of grand larceny, as the theft of the artifacts was a necessary step in their scheme to recover the insurance proceeds. Thus, the conduct intended by defendants was the crime of facilitation (Penal Law § 115.00), and it took place within the premises their accomplices had entered illegally. Moreover, since it is not necessary that the intended crime be completed to sustain a burglary conviction, it is of no moment that the ultimate grand larceny never took place.

 

6 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Islip v. Caviglia


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 544; 540 N.E.2d 215; 542 N.Y.S.2d 139; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 485


February 14, 1989, Argued  
May 11, 1989, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended October 9, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner town sought to enjoin respondent owner from continuing operation of an adult bookstore in a prohibited zone in violation of the town's zoning ordinance. The court upheld the constitutionality of the ordinance and granted the town a permanent injunction. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) modified and affirmed. The owner appealed.


OVERVIEW: Town sought to enjoin owner from continuing operation of an adult bookstore in a prohibited zone in violation of the town's zoning ordinance. The ordinance differentiated between certain adult uses and limited the operation of adult uses to areas zoned Industrial I. It also provided that nonconforming adult uses should be amortized over a period of years based on a graduated scale of investment in the business. The court upheld the constitutionality of the ordinance and granted the town a permanent injunction. The appellate division modified the judgment by striking a provision of the ordinance that required proprietors to obtain a special permit before establishing an adult use in an Industrial I district. On appeal, the court affirmed holding that under the stipulated facts there remained ample space available for adult uses. The court held that the ordinance, as approved by the appellate division, was no broader than needed for the intended purpose and did not violate the State Constitution. The court opined that the amortization provisions were content-neutral under the federal and state constitutions. The court concluded that the ordinance was neither vague nor overbroad.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate division's modification and affirmation.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Regulation of "Adult Uses" under Zoning Power -- Federal Constitution

1. Under the Federal Constitution, municipalities are permitted to regulate adult bookstore and theater uses through the zoning power if they can establish that (1) the "predominant purpose" of the ordinance is not to control the content of the material purveyed but to control the "secondary effects" of such uses on the surrounding community, (2) the ordinance is designed to serve a substantial governmental interest, (3) it is narrowly tailored to affect only the category of uses that produce the unwanted effects, and (4) it allows for reasonable alternative avenues of expression. Thus, the zoning ordinance of the Town of Islip, insofar as it restricts certain adult uses, defined as those which exclude minors by reason of age, to areas zoned Industrial I, meets Federal constitutional standards. The "predominant purpose" of the Islip officials in enacting their ordinance was to eliminate the secondary effects of adult uses and to attempt to control future development in the business districts, not to regulate expression. The governmental interest supporting the ordinance is the eradication of the effects of urban blight and neighborhood deterioration and furtherance of the general underlying purpose of zoning, the enhancement of the quality of life for the Town's residents. The ordinance does not impose any limitation on the content of the material or the ability of the creators or sellers to distribute it and it does not restrict in any significant way those wishing to acquire adult books from doing so. Moreover, the ordinance is narrowly tailored to affect only those uses shown to produce the unwanted secondary effects, and it provides alternative locations within the Town for adult use businesses.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Regulation of "Adult Uses" under Zoning Power -- State Constitution

2. Under the NY State Constitution, regulation designed to carry out legitimate and important governmental objectives which incidentally burdens free expression may be sustained only if the State action is no broader than needed to achieve its purpose. Accordingly, the zoning ordinance of the Town of Islip, insofar as it restricts certain "adult uses", defined as those which exclude minors by reason of age, to areas zoned Industrial I, does not violate the State Constitution. Although the Town's zoning ordinance addresses only adult uses, it was not a purposeful attempt to regulate speech; the ordinance was enacted to correct the effects of adult uses on community development, and its effect on expression is only incidental. The adverse affects of adult uses on the Town's neighborhoods are not subject to direct attack and the Town's use of its zoning powers was the most appropriate means to address its substantive problems. Arguments can be advanced that different techniques should be used to address the problem, but that is not to say that they are constitutionally required. The ordinance adopted is an appropriate method for addressing existing problems; it is not overinclusive and it does not unduly restrict adult uses to limited or unsuitable areas of the Town. Accordingly, the ordinance, insofar as it restricts adult uses to the Industrial I zone, is no broader than needed for the intended purpose and does not, therefore, violate the State Constitution.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Regulation of "Adult Uses" under Zoning Power -- Validity of Amortization Provisions

3. A challenge by respondents, the owners of property within the Town of Islip upon which an adult bookstore is being operated, to the provisions of the zoning ordinance of the Town of Islip which require the termination of nonconforming adult uses through amortization over a period of 1 1/4 to 5 1/4 years, measured from the 1980 effective date of the ordinance, on the ground that those provisions are facially unconstitutional because they apply to preexisting uses, is rejected. In light of the intractable problem of eliminating nonconforming uses, amortization provisions of a zoning ordinance may be sustained if the period allowed to recapture the investment in the use is reasonable. Reasonableness is determined by examining all the facts, including the length of the amortization period in relation to the investment and the nature of the use. Presumptively, amortization provisions are valid unless the owner can demonstrate that the loss suffered is so substantial that it outweighs the public benefit gained by the exercise of the police power. Here, respondents failed to overcome that presumption, since they have continued to operate well past the maximum five-year amortization period and they have presented no evidence of economic loss which would establish unreasonableness. Conversely, the Town has established the damage caused to its neighborhoods by adult uses and the substantial investment it has made, particularly in the village where respondents' property is located, to overcome the blight caused in part by them.

Constitutional  Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Regulation of "Adult Uses" under Zoning Power -- Validity of Amortization Provisions -- Content-Based Regulation

4. A challenge by respondents, the owners of property within the Town of Islip upon which an adult bookstore is being operated, to the provision of the zoning ordinance of the Town of Islip which requires the termination of nonconforming adult uses through amortization over a period of 1 1/4 to 5 1/4 years, on the ground that amortization applied to uses enjoying constitutional free speech protection amounts to content-based regulation which must be prospective, or must "grandfather-in" existing uses, is rejected. Since the ordinance is content -neutral under both the Federal and State Constitutions, the amortization provisions rest upon the same legal foundation as such provisions generally and, on the facts presented, are valid.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Regulation of "Adult Uses" under Zoning Power -- Vagueness -- Overbreadth

5. The zoning ordinance of the Town of Islip, insofar as it restricts certain adult uses, defined as those which exclude minors by reason of age, to the Industrial I zone, is neither vague nor subject to attack for overbreadth.

 

7 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Deas v. Levitt


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 525; 539 N.E.2d 1086; 541 N.Y.S.2d 958; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 469


March 21, 1989, Argued  
May 4, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, Department of Personnel and director, sought review of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) which reversed the judgment of the trial court that dismissed petitioner's, city employee, application for an order to direct respondent to place petitioner on a special eligible list related to a promotion in the competitive classification of civil service.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner, city employee, sought a promotion in the competitive classification of the civil service and after his disqualification was reversed he sought to compel establishment of a special eligibility list since the eligible list on which his name previously appeared expired before respondent, Department of Personnel, had certified petitioner. Respondents, Department of Personnel and director, challenged the lower court's reversal of the trial court's order that dismissed petitioner's request for an order to place his name on a special eligible list. The court reversed the order of the lower court and reinstated the trial court's dismissal of petitioner's application, as petitioner did not attack the validity of the eligible list or commence a proceeding before the list expired. Petitioner failed to allege that the eligible list was constitutionally invalid, only that he was wrongfully denied certification. Dismissal of petitioner's claim was not violative of his due process rights, as successful completion of the civil service examination did not create a property interest in appointment to the position for which petitioner had applied.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the lower court that directed placement of petitioner, city employee, on a special eligible list and reinstated the trial court's dismissal of petitioner's application, as petitioner did not attack the validity of the list or commence a proceeding before the list expired and since petitioner had no property interest, failure to be certified was not a denial of due process of law.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Appointment and Promotion -- Entitlement to Creation of Special Eligible List

In a CPLR article 78 proceeding to compel the establishment of a special eligibility list for petitioner for promotion in the competitive classification of the civil service, arising out of respondent New York City Department of Personnel's refusal to certify petitioner for promotion because the eligible list on which his name appeared had expired before he was certified for promotion pursuant to a determination of the New York City Civil Service Commission that petitioner was medically eligible for promotion, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed a judgment of the Supreme Court dismissing the petition, granted the petition and directed that petitioner's name be placed on a special eligible list, is reversed, and the judgment of Supreme Court dismissing the petition is reinstated.

 

8 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sutka v. Conners


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 395; 538 N.E.2d 1012; 541 N.Y.S.2d 191; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 466


March 29, 1989, Argued  
May 2, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, a fire district commissioners' board chairman and others (board), appealed a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) which held that, under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 207-a and N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 363-a, petitioner firefighter was entitled to back pay due to his heart-related disability.


OVERVIEW: When the firefighter experienced chest pain after boating with his son, he sought medical treatment and was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and angina. The board denied the firefighter's ensuing application for disability benefits. The appellate court found the firefighter entitled to benefits and remanded the matter to the board for a calculation of the back pay due. On the board's appeal, the court held that: (1) an evaluation of statutory history and language revealed that N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 207-a and N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 363-a represented separate disability systems with differing coverages and consequences; (2) the legislature had refused to amend into N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 207-a the presumption that fire fighters incurred in the line of duty any condition of impairment of health caused by diseases of the heart resulting in disability or death; (3) the addition of such a line-of-duty presumption to N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 363-a did not operate to effect a similar implicit amendment to N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 207-a; and (4) consequently, the firefighter was not entitled to disability benefits under § 207-a.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court order in favor of the fire fighter, and directed that the board's determination be reinstated and the firefighter's petition be dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Firefighters -- Sick Leave Benefits -- Inapplicability of Line-of-Duty Presumption for Heart-Related Retirement Disability Benefits

The line-of-duty presumption for firefighters' heart-related retirement disability benefits (Retirement and Social Security Law § 363-a [1]) should not be read into General Municipal Law § 207-a, which generally governs firefighters' sick leave benefits. It cannot be assumed that the Legislature made a significant addition to General Municipal Law § 207-a by amending the Retirement and Social Security Law without acknowledging it somewhere. Sections 207-a and 363-a represent separate disability systems with differing coverage and consequences. From the face of the statutes, the 1973 amendment to section 363-a, which added to that section the line-of-duty presumption for New York City paid firefighters contained in General Municipal Law § 207-k, was not intended to increase the scope of coverage under section 207-a; it surely did not do so unambiguously. Moreover, the legislative history of the 1973 amendment contains no reference to General Municipal Law § 207-a, and does not evidence a legislative intent to apply the job-related disability presumption of section 363-a to section 207-a. Accordingly, the line-of-duty presumption of section 363-a (1) need not be read into an application by petitioner firefighter for sick leave benefits under section 207-a based upon petitioner's affliction with coronary artery disease and angina.

 

9 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hymowitz v. Eli Lilly & Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 487; 539 N.E.2d 1069; 541 N.Y.S.2d 941; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 389; CCH Prod. Liab. Rep. P12,182


February 15, 1989, Argued  
April 4, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Hymowitz v Lilly & Co. and Hanfling v Lilly & Co.: Order affirmed, etc.

In Tigue v Squibb & Sons and Dolan v Lilly & Co.: Order affirmed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appeals from decisions of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) denying summary judgment to defendant drug manufacturers in products liability action arising from injuries plaintiffs suffered as result of plaintiffs' mothers' use of diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs sued defendant drug manufacturers in three product liability actions, alleging injuries from use of diethylstilbestrol (DES) by plaintiffs' mothers during pregnancy. In all three cases, the trial court denied defendants summary judgment, and the appeals court affirmed. On appeal, defendant drug manufacturers argued that summary judgment was proper because plaintiffs could not identify the manufacturer of the drug that allegedly injured them and that state law, which revived time-barred DES claims, violated constitutional due process and equal protection principles. The court affirmed, adopting a national market-share theory for apportioning liability, and holding the statute was rationally based and constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the denial of summary judgment to defendant drug manufacturers, adopting a national market-share theory for apportioning liability and holding state statute reviving time-barred claims constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Products Liability -- Actions Involving Unidentifiable Manufacturers of DES for Pregnancy Use -- Market Share Theory of Liability and Apportionment of Damages -- Several Liability

1. In actions to recover damages for injuries allegedly sustained by plaintiffs due to their mothers' ingestion during pregnancy of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES), which was manufactured by defendants, liability and apportionment of damages in cases in which identification of the manufacturer of the specific drug that injured the plaintiff is impossible is to be determined by application of a market share theory, using a national market. Liability should be apportioned so as to correspond to the over-all culpability of each defendant, measured by the amount of risk of injury each defendant created to the public-at-large; a defendant cannot be held liable if it did not participate in the marketing of DES for pregnancy use. Use of a national market is a fair method of apportioning defendants' liabilities according to their total culpability in marketing DES for use during pregnancy. Under the circumstances, this is an equitable way to provide plaintiffs with the relief they deserve, while also rationally distributing the responsibility for plaintiffs' injuries among defendants. Further, the liability of DES producers is several only, and should not be inflated when all participants in the market are not before the court in a particular case.

Limitation of Actions -- Revival of Time-Barred Action -- Constitutionality of Statute Reviving Claims for Exposure to DES -- Due Process of Law

2. Laws of 1986 (ch 682, § 4) is not unconstitutional as a denial of due process under the State and Federal Constitutions (see, NY Const, art I, § 6; US Const, 14th Amend, § 1) insofar as it revived, for the period of one year, actions for damages caused by the latent effects of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES). The Legislature may constitutionally revive a personal cause of action where the circumstances are exceptional and are such as to satisfy the court that serious injustice would result to plaintiffs not guilty of any fault if the intentions of the Legislature were not affected. The latent nature of DES injuries is well known, and it is clear that in the past the court-maintained exposure rule for toxic substances prevented the bringing of timely actions for recovery. Thus, exceptional circumstances are presented, an injustice has been rectified, and the highest standard for determining whether the Legislature's revival of a personal cause of action satisfies due process has been met.

Limitation of Actions -- Revival of Time-Barred Action -- Exposure to DES -- Constitutionality of Application of Revival Statute to Plaintiffs Who Could Have Timely Sued under Original Limitations Period

3. Laws of 1986 (ch 682, § 4), insofar as it revived, for a period of one year, actions for damages caused by the latent effects of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES), is not unconstitutional as applied to cases in which the plaintiff could have sued before the original limitations period ran, but did not. Some plaintiffs may have known of their exposure, but did not develop injuries during the limitations period. Others may have known of some effect upon them of DES exposure, which became cancerous only after any action would have been time barred. Under these circumstances, the Legislature properly determined that it would be more fair for all plaintiffs to uniformly now have one year to bring their actions, rather than for the courts to begin drawing arbitrary lines transecting this area's shades of gray.

Limitation of Actions -- Revival of Time-Barred Action -- Constitutionality of Statute Reviving Claims for Exposure to Specified Toxic Substances -- Equal Protection of Laws

4. Laws of 1986 (ch 682, § 4), which revived, for a period of one year, actions for damages caused by the latent effects of five substances, does not violate equal protection (see, NY Const, art I, § 11; US Const, 14th Amend, § 1) because the Legislature designated only those five substances for revival including the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES), while instituting a prospective only discovery rule for other substances. That this categorization is the result of "political compromise" is no basis for finding the revival statute unconstitutional, since most, if not all legislation is the product of some compromise. Further, as it pertains to DES, the revival statute has a rational basis, and the Legislature acted within its broad range of discretion in enacting the law. The number of DES-caused injuries was relatively well known by the Legislature, which allowed for the ramifications of revival of DES claims, such as the effect on insurance interests, and the other costs, to be reasonably predicted. It was also well known that DES victims were prejudiced under current law. This is enough of a basis for the Legislature to revive DES claims now, and wait as to other substances until it is felt that these substances present a problem suitable for resolution. The Legislature does not violate equal protection by providing a rational piecemeal remedy for what may be a larger problem.

Products Liability -- Alternative Liability Doctrine -- Actions Involving Unidentifiable Manufacturers of DES for Pregnancy Use

5. In actions to recover damages for injuries allegedly sustained by plaintiffs due to their mothers' ingestion during pregnancy of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES), which was manufactured by defendants, the doctrine of alternative liability is unavailable as a basis for recovery where identification of the producer of the specific drug that caused the injury is impossible. Use of the alternative liability doctrine generally requires that the defendants have better access to information than does the plaintiff, and that all possible tort-feasors be before the court; further, alternative liability rests on the notion that where there is a small number of possible wrongdoers, all of whom breached a duty to the plaintiff, the likelihood that any one of them injured the plaintiff is relatively high, so that forcing them to exonerate themselves, or be held liable, is not unfair. However, in DES cases, the defendants are not in any better position than are plaintiffs to identify the manufacturer of the DES ingested in any given case, nor is there any real prospect of having all the possible producers before the court. Moreover, the fairness of employing alternative liability in cases involving only a small number of potential wrongdoers disappears with the decreasing probability that any one of the defendants actually caused the injury, particularly where, as here, the chance that a particular producer caused the injury is often very remote.

Products Liability -- Concerted Action Doctrine --  Actions Involving Unidentifiable Manufacturers of DES for Pregnancy Use

6. In actions to recover damages for injuries allegedly sustained by plaintiffs due to their mothers' ingestion during pregnancy of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES), which was manufactured by defendants, the doctrine of concerted action, in its pure form, does not supply a basis for recovery where identification of the producer of the specific drug that caused the injury is impossible. The concerted action doctrine provides for joint and several liability on the part of all defendants having an understanding, express or tacit, to participate in a common plan or design to commit a tortious act. However, there is nothing in the record beyond the drug companies' extensive parallel conduct in developing and marketing DES to show any agreement, tacit or otherwise, to market DES for pregnancy use without taking proper steps to ensure the drug's safety. Parallel activity, without more, is insufficient to establish the agreement element necessary to maintain a concerted action claim.

Products Liability -- Actions Involving Unidentifiable Manufacturers of DES for Pregnancy Use -- Judicial Formulation of Remedy 

7. In actions to recover damages for injuries allegedly sustained by plaintiffs due to their mothers' ingestion during pregnancy of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES), which was manufactured by defendants, where extant common-law doctrines, unmodified, do not provide a basis for recovery to a plaintiff who is unable to identify the manufacturer of the specific drug that injured her, the ever-evolving dictates of justice and fairness require formation of a remedy for injuries caused by DES; judicial action is required to overcome the inordinately difficult problems of proof caused by contemporary products and marketing techniques. The DES situation is a singular case, with manufacturers acting in a parallel manner to produce an identical, generically marketed product, which causes injury many years later, and which has evoked a legislative response reviving previously barred actions. Given this unusual scenario, it is more appropriate that the loss be borne by those that produced the drug for use during pregnancy, rather than by those who were injured by the use, even where the precise manufacturer of the drug cannot be identified in a particular action.

Products Liability -- Concerted Action Doctrine -- Substitution of Conscious Parallel Activity for Proof of Actual Agreement -- Prescription Drug Manufacturers

8. In actions to recover damages for injuries allegedly sustained by plaintiffs due to their mothers' ingestion during pregnancy of the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES), which was manufactured by defendants, a modified version of the concerted action doctrine, which, in effect, substitutes the fact of conscious parallel activity by manufacturers for the usual common-law requirement that there be proof of an actual agreement between actors to jointly act tortiously, does not provide a basis for recovery where identification of the manufacturer of the specific drug that caused the injury is impossible. Parallel behavior, the major justification for visiting liability caused by the product of one manufacturer upon the head of another under this analysis, is a common occurrence in industry generally. Therefore, inferring agreement from the fact of parallel activity alone improperly expands the concept of concerted action beyond a rational or fair limit; among other things, it potentially renders small manufacturers, in the case of DES and in countless other industries, jointly liable for all damages stemming from the defective products of an entire industry.

 

10 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wesley


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 351; 538 N.E.2d 76; 540 N.Y.S.2d 757; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 396


February 16, 1989, Argued  
April 4, 1989, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended October 9, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant's conviction for possession of marijuana and a gun, which were recovered in a search of his girlfriend's house, was reversed and the indictment dismissed, when the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) held that defendant had standing to file a motion to suppress evidence. The state appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with possession of marijuana and a gun, which were recovered in a search of his girlfriend's house. At trial, defendant's motion to suppress this evidence was denied for lack of standing, and defendant was convicted. The appellate court reversed defendant's conviction and dismissed the indictment, holding that since he had been charged with constructive possession of the contraband, he could not be deprived of standing to challenge the legality of the search. On appeal, the court reversed. The court held that a defendant seeking to challenge a search and seizure could not rest upon the fact that the people had charged him with possession, but was required to demonstrate a personal legitimate expectation of privacy in the searched premises. Since the lower court did not address whether defendant had a reasonable expectation of privacy, the court remitted for consideration of this issue.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the lower court. The court held that defendant failed to establish standing to challenge the search. The court remitted the case for reconsideration of whether defendant could have demonstrated a legitimate expectation of privacy in the searched premises.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Unlawful Search and Seizure -- Standing -- Constructive Possession

A defendant does not have standing to challenge a search that results in the discovery of contraband, based solely on his alleged constructive possession of that contraband; the defendant has the burden of demonstrating a personal legitimate expectation of privacy in the searched premises at the pretrial stage, protected by the rule that such testimony cannot be used to prove the charges. There is no anomaly endemic to constructive possession cases that requires departure from the long-established rule in New York that a defendant seeking suppression must assert personal standing. Further, the rule that a defendant who is charged with possession of a gun based on the statutory presumption in Penal Law § 265.15 (3), which attributes possession of a gun to the passengers in an automobile simply by their presence in the car where the gun is found, has a right to challenge the legality of the search regardless of whether the defendant is able to assert a cognizable Fourth Amendment interest, should not be extended to permit all defendants charged with constructive possession to claim standing for that reason alone. Accordingly, in the prosecution of defendant, who was charged with constructive possession of marihuana and weapons which were seized following the search of a house occupied by his girlfriend, defendant's claim of standing to seek suppression of the contraband, based solely on the fact that he is charged with constructive possession, is insufficient under the law.

 

11 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sheldon v. Highlands


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 304; 536 N.E.2d 1141; 539 N.Y.S.2d 722; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 382


February 8, 1989, Argued  
March 28, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, chapter 755 of the Laws of 1983 declared constitutional, and matter remitted to the Appellate Division, Second Department, for consideration of issues not reached on the appeal to that court.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent town sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which reversed the lower court's dismissal of petitioner landowner's complaint, alleging that an assessment was invalid, and which declared 1983 N.Y. Laws ch. 755 unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: To correct an error in the drawing of boundaries for a sewer system, the town submitted a request to the legislature for a home rule law. The legislature enacted chapter 755 to describe the property in the improvement area. The landowners, whose property was within the boundary, challenged the town's assessment, alleging that chapter 755 was invalid. The appellate court reversed the trial court's dismissal, and declared chapter 755 unconstitutional. On appeal, the court reversed the order, holding that the landowners were not entitled to notice or a hearing. The landowners were only entitled to notice and a hearing if a subordinate body, rather than the legislature, fixed the district boundaries. Because chapter 755 established the sewer boundaries, the landowners were not deprived due process. The court rejected the landowners' argument that chapter 755 was unconstitutional because the town created facts to support its request, holding that there was no judicial review of the validity of an act passed in accordance with a home rule request. The court declined to decide the landowners' challenge to the fairness of the assessment rate because the appellate court did not consider it.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's order that the landowners were entitled to notice and a hearing with respect to the assessments by the town in an improvement district.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Sewer Districts -- Constitutionality of Special Law Enacted by State Legislature Redefining Boundaries of Established Sewer District -- Due Process of Law

Petitioners, whose property was affected by the Legislature's enactment of Laws of 1983 (ch 755), which, in response to respondent Town's special home rule request, redefined the boundaries of an established sewer improvement district within the Town, were not denied due process of law because there was no notice or hearing prior to the Town's request for the special legislation or the Legislature's adoption of it. In a "legislative" proceeding, as here, where district boundaries are established by statute as an incident of the Legislature's power to determine that a public improvement should be made and to define the district to be benefited, a landowner is not entitled to notice or a hearing prior to the creation of a district that includes its property. Moreover, petitioners' contention that the statute is unconstitutional on the ground that there was no genuine basis for the Town Board's request for the enactment of a special law is expressly foreclosed by Municipal Home Rule Law § 40 and Legislative Law § 56; given these statutes, which are unchallenged, it must be accepted that the Legislature by its own act of adopting chapter 755 has certified that all requisite steps necessary for the passage of the law were properly carried out. Accordingly, Laws of 1983 (ch 755) is constitutional.

 

12 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ricardo B.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 228; 535 N.E.2d 1336; 538 N.Y.S.2d 796; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 264


January 4, 1989, Argued  
February 23, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a verdict of criminally negligent homicide, contending that trying defendant and a codefendant together before separate juries was unauthorized and unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted on a jury verdict of criminally negligent homicide, and on affirmation, appealed to the instant court, contending that the procedure employed by the trial court in trying him and a codefendant together before separate juries was unauthorized and unconstitutional. Defendant also asserted that the dual jury procedure was inherently prejudicial and the evidence was insufficient to establish his guilt. The reviewing court affirmed, holding that when a court was presented with the problem of inculpatory statements by codefendants, it had the options of deleting references to the codefendant in the statement, seeking a joint trial without the evidence, or ordering separate trials. The use of multiple juries, whether statutorily authorized or not, did not deny defendants their constitutional right to a jury trial or, in the absence of identified prejudice, to due process of law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Jury -- Multiple Juries at Joint Trial

1. In a prosecution for criminally negligent homicide, arising out of a motor vehicle accident in which the victim was killed when the automobile she was driving was struck by two vehicles, one operated by defendant and the other by his codefendant, who were engaged in a high-speed race, the Trial Justice exercised her discretion within permissible legal limits when she ordered two juries (one as to each defendant) and the procedure did not prejudice the defense. The right to trial by jury is guaranteed by both Federal and State Constitutions (US Const 6th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 2) and implemented by statute (CPL arts 260, 270), and there is nothing in the Constitutions, the statutes or decisions interpreting them, which expressly authorizes or prohibits the use of multiple juries in New York. The court's power to employ multiple juries, while not explicit in the statute, may logically be implied from its terms. In this case the People's evidence against the two defendants was the same except for defendant's inculpatory statement to a bystander. Under the circumstances, the harm to defendant, if any, resulting from the use of separate juries was little more than that occurring in the usual joint trial and existed only because of the logistics of managing two separate juries. The risk of error arising from the procedure was clearly outweighed by judicial economy, witness convenience and the possibility of prejudice or inconsistent verdicts which might result from sequential trials. Multiple juries should be used sparingly and then only after a full consideration of the impact the procedure will have on the defendant's due process rights and after thorough precautions have been taken to protect those rights; the Trial Justice properly did so in this case.

Crimes -- Criminally Negligent Homicide -- Sufficiency of Evidence

2. In a prosecution for criminally negligent homicide, arising out of a motor vehicle accident in which the victim was killed when her automobile was struck by two vehicles, one operated by defendant and the other by his codefendant, who were engaged in a high-speed race, the evidence, viewed in the light most favorable to the People, supported the jury's guilty verdict. Contrary to defendant's contention, the People proved more than excessive speed in this case. There was evidence introduced that defendant failed to observe a vehicle plainly visible in front of him or take steps to avoid it, and that his failure was caused by engaging in a race with another car on a busy divided highway in a metropolitan area. This evidence is sufficient to support the jury's verdict finding defendant guilty of criminally negligent homicide for failing to perceive a substantial and unjustifiable risk that death would result from his conduct (see, Penal Law §§ 125.10, 15.05 [4]).

 

13 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Campagna v. Shaffer


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 237; 536 N.E.2d 368; 538 N.Y.S.2d 933; 1989 N.Y. LEXIS 4953


January 5, 1989, Argued  
February 16, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner broker appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), dismissing his petition claiming that the nonsolicitation order prohibiting blockbusting and regulation restricting license relocation, both issued by respondent Secretary of State of the State of New York, were unconstitutional. The court applied N.Y. Exec. Law § 296(3-b) and N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 441-a(5).


OVERVIEW: The secretary issued a nonsolicitation order that prohibited brokers and salespersons of real estate from soliciting for sale residential realty. The secretary promulgated the regulation restricting the number of licensed brokers permitted to operate in areas. The broker petitioned for a declaratory ruling to eliminate those provisions, but the supreme court upheld them as constitutional. On appeal, the court reversed the supreme court's order and directed that the petition be granted to invalidate the regulation. The court rendered the decision on this ground and did not reach other or constitutional issues. The court found the order exceeded the statutory prohibition on blockbusting by administratively limiting all broker-initiated solicitation, not just the illegal solicitation banned by the legislature in § 296(3-b). The court also found the secretary made unlawful what the legislature had not made unlawful, which exceeded her statutory mandate and exercised a power that she lacked. The regulation establishing the requirement of preapproval by the secretary to the broker's relocation, which imposed conditions, exceeded the notification function of § 441-a(5) and was invalid.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the supreme court, which dismissed the broker's petition asserting that the nonsolicitation order preventing blockbusting and the regulation restricting license relocation, both issued by the secretary, were unconstitutional. The court followed the statutes. The court granted the petition to invalidate the regulation.


HEADNOTES

Brokers -- Real Estate Brokers -- Validity of Order Interdicting Solicitation by Real Estate Brokers in Eastern Bronx County

1. An order of the respondent Secretary of State which interdicts real estate brokers and salespersons from soliciting for sale residential realty in eastern Bronx County in furtherance of the Legislature's declared policy to ban blockbusting (Executive Law § 296 [3-b]) exceeded whatever authority the Secretary did have to regulate broker untrustworthiness flowing from unlawful discriminatory practice of blockbusting, as the Legislature has defined it, and the order is, therefore, invalid. The Legislature has explicitly enumerated the types of solicitation it views as forbidden blockbusting activity in section 296 (3-b). The nonsolicitation order at issue leaps well beyond that legislative articulation and interdicts administratively all broker-initiated solicitation, not just the illegal solicitation as targeted by the Legislature. Thus, the Secretary has gone beyond administering the written law and has, under color of regulatory authority, actually rewritten and extended the law. The agency cannot make unlawful what the Legislature still has on the books as lawful.

Brokers -- Real Estate Brokers -- Validity of Regulation -- Preapproval of Relocation by Real Estate Brokers

2. Real Property Law § 441-a (5) requires that the Secretary of State receive only notification of relocation by a real estate broker; thus, 19 NYCRR 175.20 (d), which establishes preapproval to the licensee's relocation and which in this case imposed conditions on petitioner broker's relocation, is invalid since it exceeds the notification function of the statute.

 

14 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Herzog Bros. Trucking, Inc. v. State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 720; 533 N.E.2d 255; 536 N.Y.S.2d 416; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 3535


November 17, 1988, Argued  
December 22, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Upon reargument, following remand from the Supreme Court of the United States, this court adheres to its May 7, 1987 decision of reversal (69 NY2d 536), without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff truckers sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which reversed the trial court's order granting the truckers a preliminary injunction restraining and enjoining defendant State Tax Commission (commission) from collecting motor fuel taxes and sales taxes on the sale of motor fuel by the truckers to Indians on Indian reservations.


OVERVIEW: After the court initially reversed the appellate court's order, the United States Supreme Court granted a writ of certiorari, vacated the court's judgment and remanded the case for reconsideration in light of the commission's proposed new regulations. The commission contended that the tax statutes as implemented by the new regulations imposed no unconstitutional burden on Indian traders. Upon reargument, the court adhered to its previous decision which reversed the appellate court's order reversing the trial court's grant of a preliminary injunction to the truckers. The court declined to express an opinion on whether the statutes as implemented by the new regulations generally met constitutional standards because a decision on their validity would have constituted an advisory opinion involving hypothetical future transactions of unknown parties. The court further declined an invitation to consider the validity of the commission's assessments in light of the Hayden-Cartwright Act, 4 U.S.C.S. § 104 because the statute was not cited on prior appeal to the court, not urged as a ground for reversal before the Supreme Court, and not identified as a matter for consideration on remand.
