OUTCOME: The court adhered to its prior decision, which reversed the appellate court's order reversing the trial court's order granting the truckers a preliminary injunction enjoining and restraining the commission from collecting motor fuel taxes and sales taxes on the sale of motor fuel by the truckers to Indians on Indian reservations.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Advisory Opinions -- Remand by United States Supreme Court to Court of Appeals for Reconsideration in Light of New Regulations Not before Court of Appeals on Prior Appeal -- Regulation of Sales of Motor Fuel to Indians on Indian Reservation

Upon reargument of an appeal, following remand by the United States Supreme Court, concerning the question whether the State may require the corporate plaintiff, a wholesale distributor of motor fuel to Seneca Indians on the Allegany and Cattaraugus Reservations, to prepay taxes on motor fuel delivered to the retailers for resale to Indian and non-Indian consumers, the Court of Appeals adheres to its prior determination that the Federal Indian trader laws preempted State regulation of the corporate plaintiff and that the Appellate Division erred, therefore, in denying the corporate plaintiff's application for an order preliminarily enjoining defendant State Tax Commission from proceeding against it. Inasmuch as the Supreme Court remanded the case for the Court of Appeals to reconsider its decision in light of new regulations proposed by the Commissioner of Taxation and Finance not before the Court of Appeals on the prior appeal, which apply only to sales of motor fuels after January 1, 1989, and it is not apparent from the record that plaintiff will continue to sell to the Indians, a decision on the validity of the new regulations upon the present record, even assuming there were no factual issues to be determined when applying them, would constitute an advisory opinion involving hypothetical future transactions of unknown parties. Accordingly, the Court of Appeals expresses no opinion on whether the statutes as implemented by the new regulations generally meet constitutional standards.

 

15 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hudy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


73 N.Y.2d 40; 535 N.E.2d 250; 538 N.Y.S.2d 197; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 3538


October 17, 1988, Argued  
December 22, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended October 9, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed his conviction for sexual abuse and child endangering. Defendant asserted that the trial court violated the Ex Post Facto Clause of the Constitution, U.S. Const. art I, § 10, cl. 1, by retroactively applying repeal of the corroboration rule of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 130.16, 260.11, and made erroneous evidentiary rulings.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a math teacher engaged in inappropriate sexual contact with pupils. Defendant was indicted on several counts of sexual abuse and child endangering. Prior to trial, defendant moved to dismiss 19 counts of alleged behavior which took place prior to the legislature's repeal of provisions of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 130.16, 260.11 requiring corroboration of the victim's testimony in certain sex-crimes, for violation of the Ex Post Facto Clause, U.S. Const. art. I, § 10. The court reversed the order affirming the conviction, and it remanded the case for a new trial. The court held that the Ex Post Facto Clause did not require that defendant be tried under the corroboration rules that existed at the time his alleged crimes were committed, the amended versions of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 130.16, 130.260.11 were properly applied, and the uncorroborated evidence was legally sufficient to support the jury's verdicts. However, the court held that the trial court's erroneous evidentiary rulings allowing prior act evidence, showing a "propensity" to do it again, and in foreclosing cross examination of officers on the manner of their questioning the children were highly prejudicial and improper.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded defendant's conviction for sexual abuse and child endangering because the trial court's erroneous evidentiary rulings regarding prior act evidence and cross examination of witnesses were highly prejudicial and improper. However, the court held that uncorroborated child-witness testimony was legally sufficient to support jury's verdicts and did not violate the Ex Post Facto Clause.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Corroboration as to Sex Offenses -- Ex Post Facto Law -- Retroactive Application of Law Repealing Corroboration Requirements for Underage Victims

1. The Ex Post Facto Clause of the United States Constitution (US Const, art I, § 10; see also, art I, § 9, cl 3) does not preclude the application of the legislative enactment repealing the statutory provisions requiring corroboration of the victim's testimony in certain sex-crime prosecutions involving underage victims (L 1984, ch 89, amending Penal Law §§ 130.16, 260.11) to prosecutions for crimes occurring before its effective date. Thus, in the prosecution of defendant for various sex-related crimes committed against young children, there was no constitutional impediment to applying the new statute and convicting defendant solely on the basis of the victims' testimony, even though the charged crimes occurred before the repealing legislation became effective. Defendant had ample notice that the conduct in which he engaged was prohibited and that, if convicted, he could be punished within certain legislatively prescribed guidelines. He had no legitimate right to rely on a procedural rule that affected neither his culpability nor his expected punishment but instead merely made the prosecution's case against him more difficult to prove. The repeal of the corroboration rule did nothing more than remove an obstacle arising out of a rule of evidence. Further, there is no claim that the legislative decision to repeal the corroboration rule applicable to defendant's case was arbitrary, vindictive or oppressive or that it was intended to single out defendant for particularly unfavorable treatment.

Crimes -- Proof of Other Crimes -- Prosecution for Sex-Related Crimes Involving Children -- Admissibility of Evidence of Prior Accusations of Sexual Misconduct.

2. Evidence of a defendant's prior criminal or immoral conduct has some minimal probative worth because of its tendency to demonstrate the defendant's bad character and general criminal propensity, but it is excluded as a matter of law when it has no additional relevance to a specific issue, because there is a very real danger that the trier of fact will overestimate its significance. Accordingly, in the prosecution of defendant, an elementary school teacher, for various sex-related crimes involving students under the age of 11, evidence concerning the accusations of a former student with respect to sexual misconduct by defendant, which were made more than one year before the accusations underlying the present prosecution were made, should have been excluded since it had no relevance to any material issue in the case and tended only to demonstrate defendant's general criminal propensity. The testimony of the former student was offered to show that the children's charges against defendant were not simply the product of rumor. However, while proof that the former student came forward and accused defendant of sexual misconduct before any rumors occurred, and may therefore have been telling the truth, may tend to support the credibility of that student's accusation, it throws no light upon the truthfulness of the other children who subsequently accused defendant -- except of course to the extent that defendant's misconduct toward the former student makes it more likely that he also engaged in similar misconduct with others.

Crimes -- Harmless and Prejudicial Error -- Proof of Other Crimes -- Evidence of Prior Accusations of Sexual Misconduct in Prosecution for Sex-Related Crimes Involving Children

3. In the prosecution of defendant, an elementary school teacher, for various sex-related crimes involving students under the age of 11, evidence concerning accusations by a former student of sexual misconduct by defendant, made more than one year before the accusations underlying the present prosecution, which was admitted in violation of the rule prohibiting the admission of evidence of defendant's bad character and general criminal propensity when it has no additional relevance to a specific issue, was highly prejudicial and therefore not harmless, despite the fact that eight other boys recounted essentially the same story. The evidence of accusations by the former student was qualitatively different from the testimony of the other boys, in that it was not subject to impeachment under the defense's theory that the current charges were the product of a rumor. Because of the relative strength of this evidence, particularly as it was bolstered by other corroborative testimony, there is a serious danger that the jury used it to draw the impermissible inference ("he did it before, so he probably did it this time too") and to resolve any doubts it might otherwise have had about the other boys' stories in the People's favor.

Crimes -- Evidence -- Extrinsic Proof of Reason to Fabricate -- Examination of Police Officers Who Questioned Child-Witnesses in Prosecution for Sex-Related Crimes -- Suggestive Comments by Police

4. Although trial courts have broad discretion to keep the proceedings within manageable limits and to curtail exploration of collateral matters, extrinsic proof tending to establish a reason to fabricate is never collateral and may not be excluded on that ground. Further, the trial court's discretion in this area is circumscribed by the defendant's constitutional rights to present a defense and confront his accusers. Accordingly, in the prosecution of defendant for various sex-related crimes involving boys under the age of 11, defendant was improperly denied the right to present his case in violation of both the constitutional and evidentiary rules by the trial court's ruling foreclosing examination of the two investigating police officers about the manner in which the child-witnesses were first questioned. The trial court's conclusion that the proposed line of questioning was "collateral" is obviously flawed, since the questioning concerned more than the credibility of the People's witnesses in general and went instead to a possible reason for fabrication by these impressionable witnesses -- i.e., the investigators' suggestive comments. That defendant had a limited opportunity to explore the matter during his cross-examination of the child-witnesses does not cure the error in the court's evidentiary ruling. Further, the information defense counsel sought to elicit from the investigating officers was not duplicative of the admissions he elicited from some of the child-witnesses that they had changed their stories after police questioning.

Crimes -- Harmless and Prejudicial Error -- Evidence -- Foreclosure of Examination of Police Officers Who Questioned Child-Witnesses in Prosecution Involving Sex-Related Crimes

5. In the prosecution of defendant for various sex-related crimes involving boys under the age of 11, the trial court's error in denying defendant the right to present his case by foreclosing examination of the two investigating police officers about the manner in which the child-witnesses were first questioned cannot be considered harmless. The issue of the manner in which the police had interviewed all of the young victims and the possibility that there had been a degree of suggestiveness in their approach went to the heart of defendant's case. The limited questioning which the court permitted concerning the manner in which one of the witnesses had been interviewed was no substitute for the broader inquiry that was improperly precluded. Further, because defendant was precluded from questioning the police officers about the manner in which the boys had been interviewed, his ability to develop the defense theory was seriously curtailed and the prosecutor was placed in a position to argue on summation that any defense contention concerning the victims' motive to falsify was purely speculative.

 

16 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Catalanotte


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 641; 532 N.E.2d 1244; 536 N.Y.S.2d 16; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 3470


October 20, 1988, Argued  
December 15, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order, insofar as appealed from, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirming his sentence as a second felony offender, asserting that a change in the law meant his first felony was obtained in violation of his constitutional rights.


OVERVIEW: Defendant appealed his sentence as a second felony offender, upon his conviction of attempted robbery, pursuant to his guilty plea. Defendant was determined to be a second felony offender based on his prior conviction for drug crimes. At his first trial, the judge closed the courtroom to the public when an undercover officer testified. After defendant's first conviction became final, that practice was held to be reversible error. Court rejected defendant's argument that his first conviction was obtained in violation of his constitutional rights and therefore could not serve as a predicate conviction for enhancement purposes. Court held that the standard applied was whether the conviction satisfied constitutional standards defined by the law up until the time that the conviction became final. Finding that defendant's conviction was constitutional at the time it was obtained and could serve as a predicate felony, court affirmed order.


OUTCOME: Court affirmed judgment against defendant, holding that for sentence enhancement purposes, a conviction must have been constitutional under the laws as defined until the conviction became final and that a later change in the law would not prevent conviction from being used as a predicate.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second Felony Offender -- What Constitutes Prior Conviction "Unconstitutionally Obtained"

For purposes of determining whether a prior conviction "was unconstitutionally obtained" ( CPL 400.21 [7] [b]) -- and thus may not be counted for predicate felony purposes -- the proper inquiry is to determine whether the conviction was obtained in violation of the defendant's rights as defined by the law at the time of the conviction or by present law which is properly applied to it under recognized principles of retroactivity. Under those principles of retroactivity, a defendant is entitled to the benefit of any change in the law if the change occurs before his conviction becomes final or, if the right at stake is such that the law has engrafted an exception to the traditional rule to permit collateral attack on judgments of conviction after they have become final. Thus, defendant's sentence as a second felony offender may be predicated upon a 1971 conviction which satisfied constitutional standards when obtained and has survived postconviction collateral attack, but was obtained by means which, if the indictment were tried now, would violate defendant's rights to a public trial under US Constitution 6th Amendment as presently applied by the courts. Defendant's 1971 conviction meets neither of the retroactivity criteria. It was not obtained in violation of defendant's rights because the closure of the courtroom during his trial complied with the existing legal requirements for a public trial as was held on defendant's direct appeal. That a similar procedure was subsequently declared unconstitutional in People v Jones (47 NY2d 409) does not make the Jones rule retroactive to prior convictions that have survived direct appeal, nor does it, in view of the plain language of CPL 400.21 (7) (b), require a finding that the predicate conviction "was unconstitutionally obtained."

 

17 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Alonzo M. v. New York City Dep't of Probation


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 662; 532 N.E.2d 1254; 536 N.Y.S.2d 26; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 3468


October 14, 1988, Argued  
December 15, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee juvenile sought appellant Department of Probation's (Probation) compliance with the requirements of N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 375.1 to keep the records of his favorably terminated cases sealed and not to reveal the existence and contents of those materials. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirmed the trial court's judgment in favor of juvenile. Probation appealed.


OVERVIEW: Probation reviewed sealed information of favorably terminated matters concerning juvenile and supplied protected data from its own records to the family court. Juvenile argued that Probation's actions violated N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 375.1. Probation claimed the invoked sealing provisions were inapplicable because it did not derive any information submitted to the family court from a review of sealed court records, but rather acquired the data from indexed case record materials or from an administrative folder it maintained for itself. The court determined that the Family Court Act was plain and unambiguous. The court concluded that Probation violated the sealing provisions of § 375.1 by releasing information concerning cases terminated in juvenile's favor.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower courts.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Juvenile Delinquents -- Sealing of Records -- Cases Terminated in Juvenile's Favor -- Use of Information Obtained from Sealed Records in Investigation and Report

The sealing provisions of Family Court Act § 375.1 are violated when a public agency, privy to and maintaining records and information concerning cases terminated in a juvenile's favor, divulges information resurrected from otherwise sealed records. However, the background facts to such matters, if relevant and material, may be disclosed in an Investigation and Report (I & R), a document prepared to assist a Family Court Judge in determining the appropriate disposition after adjudication of juvenile delinquency charges, if derived from sources other than sealed records and materials. Accordingly, where the New York City Department of Probation (Probation) reviewed sealed information of favorably terminated matters concerning petitioner juvenile and supplied protected data from its own separately maintained records to the Family Court in an updated I & R in connection with the disposition of petitioner's latest brush with the law, Probation violated the sealing protections of Family Court Act § 375.1 and the implementing judicial sealing orders. It is of no consequence that the source of the arrest and prosecution data, included within the I & R, was Probation's own indexed case record materials, cumulative case records, or administrative records. Indeed, this makes matters worse and more disturbing because it unmasks a concededly regularized evasion of the prophylactic law itself and of particular sealing orders.

 

18 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Med. Malpractice Ins. Ass'n v. Superintendent of Ins.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 753; 533 N.E.2d 1030; 537 N.Y.S.2d 1; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 3467


November 16, 1988, Argued  
December 15, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent superintendent of insurance appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) entered in petitioner nonprofit association's N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 action that affirmed a decision annulling a determination by the superintendent of insurance that established primary and excess premium rates for medical malpractice insurance.


OVERVIEW: A nonprofit association that provided medical malpractice insurance challenged the premium rates set by the superintendent of insurance pursuant to section 40 of the temporary insurance rate-stabilization program, 1986 N.Y. Laws, ch. 266, § 40. The nonprofit association contended that the state superintendent of insurance's interpretation of § 40 was unreasonable and resulted in rates that were not actuarially sound, that the rates were confiscatory, and that the rates would result in an unconstitutional taking of property. The lower court set aside the superintendent of insurance's determination, and an appellate court affirmed. On further appeal, the court reversed. The superintendent of insurance's determination that anticipated future surcharges, which were designated as income earned, should be considered both in determining present rates and in calculating the solvency of the nonprofit association was reasonable and should be sustained. A disagreement among actuaries was not evidence that acceptance of one set of conclusions was arbitrary, and the use of certain assumptions did not render the conclusions irrational.


OUTCOME: The court reversed an order that affirmed a decision in a nonprofit association's favor in its action to challenge a determination by the superintendent of insurance as to premium rates for medical malpractice insurance. The superintendent of insurance's interpretation of the law was reasonable, and the conclusions reached were not arbitrary or capricious.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Rate Setting -- Solvency of Medical Malpractice Insurance Association -- Consideration of Anticipated Future Surcharges

1. The respondent Superintendent of Insurance's interpretation of section 40 of the Medical Malpractice Reform Act of 1986 (L 1986, ch 266) so as to consider anticipated future surcharges, which are designated as income earned, both in determining present rates for medical malpractice insurance and in calculating the solvency of petitioner Medical Malpractice Insurance Association as required by Insurance Law §§ 2303 and 5505, is reasonable. If future surcharges were not to be accounted for until actually received beginning in 1989, then the last sentence of section 40, which provides that "[the] surcharges authorized herein shall be deemed to be income earned" for the purposes of Insurance Law § 2303, would be superfluous, since moneys actually received would undoubtedly be deemed income earned at that time. Thus, the Legislature must have intended that the future surcharges be considered on an accrual basis similar to the treatment of investment income. Further, it is clear that temporary rate stabilization is designed to complement the numerous remedial measures codified in 1985 and 1986 (L 1985, ch 294; L 1986, ch 266). Section 40 is designed to bridge the gap and allow the other reforms to start taking effect. Moreover, if the Superintendent cannot account for future surcharges in calculating present rates, section 40 would mean nothing and do nothing.

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Setting of Primary and Excess Premium Rates -- Rational Basis

2. Respondent Superintendent of Insurance's reliance upon his actuary's calculations in setting the 1985 through 1988 primary and excess premium rates for medical malpractice insurance was not arbitrary or capricious. Actuarial data existed, and the Superintendent's rate decisions were based on such data. Although the parties' actuaries disagreed on almost everything, a disagreement among actuaries is not evidence that the Superintendent's acceptance of one set of conclusions was arbitrary. Nor does the Superintendent's use of assumptions in his computation, including future interest rates, projected decreases in severity of claims due to accompanying legislative reforms, and the Superintendent's willingness to permit "adequate" increases beginning in 1988-1989 and the following years, render his conclusions irrational. Moreover, there is an adequate rational basis for the rates set by the Superintendent for layers of excess coverage. These rates were fixed as percentages of the rates approved for primary coverage, and the Superintendent's actuarial witness testified that, while excess programs at inadequate rate would increase the deficit, there would be greater surcharge income in future years, and that the two would offset each other. Further, the Regulatory Impact Statement, of which the court can take judicial notice ( CPLR 4511 [b], [c]) and which the Superintendent filed during the pendency of the case before the Supreme Court, explains how the same factors used by the actuaries in setting primary rates were also used in setting excess rates, and consequently supplies an adequate rational basis for the excess rates.

Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Rate Setting Which Results in Deficit for Medical Malpractice Insurance Association -- Rational Basis

3. That the respondent Superintendent of Insurance's interpretation of section 40 of the Medical Malpractice Reform Act (L 1986, ch 266) and his actuarial projections with respect to the setting of the 1985 through 1988 primary and excess premium rates for medical malpractice insurance may require petitioner Medical Malpractice Insurance Association (MMIA) to run at a continued deficit until the surcharges imposed pursuant to section 40 result in recoupment of that deficit in approximately the year 2000, does not render the Superintendent's decision arbitrary and capricious. This 15-year period for recoupment is not unreasonable, since according to respondent's chief actuary, the established rates coupled with the 8% surcharge after 1989 will enable MMIA to remain liquid and pay claims as they come due, at least through the year 2010. More importantly, medical malpractice claims are "long-tailed", so that claims made on policies written between 1985 and 1988 will not, on average, be payable until after 1995 through 1998. Thus, it is entirely conceivable that the deficit will be made up while some losses attributable to policies written and premiums collected in 1985 through 1988 are still unpaid. The combination of the "long-tailed" nature of medical malpractice claims along with the other statutory reforms promulgated under the 1985 and 1986 acts makes the long-term deficit entirely reasonable.

 Insurance -- Malpractice Insurance -- Rate Setting Which Results in Deficit for Medical Malpractice Insurance Association -- Confiscatory Taking

4. In a CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging the approach adopted by the Superintendent of Insurance in setting the 1985 through 1988 primary and excess premium rates for medical malpractice insurance, the claim of petitioner Medical Malpractice Insurance Association (MMIA) that section 40 of the Medical Malpractice Reform Act (L 1986, ch 266) is confiscatory as to it (US Const 5th, 14th Amends; NY Const, art I, §§ 6, 7) is rejected. MMIA is a creature of statute, and all of its rights, obligations and duties have been defined by the Legislature. Thus, since MMIA is a statutory entity created by the Legislature, the State's broad police power can be implemented to foster affordable medical malpractice coverage, with the possibility that MMIA will operate under a deficit. Indeed, such deficits were expressly contemplated in the enabling legislation. In this regard, even if MMIA will operate at a continued loss, such a loss is not confiscatory vis-a-vis MMIA.

 

19 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wittenberg v. New York


[No number in original]


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


73 N.Y.2d 753; 532 N.E.2d 1285; 536 N.Y.S.2d 57; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 3376


Argued October 12, 1988  
November 22, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [**1] As Amended October 9, 1989.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Retroactive Annual Fee from Owners of Rent-Stabilized Buildings

In an action to declare unconstitutional Local Laws, 1986, No. 66 of the City of New York, which imposed a one-year fee retroactive to April 1, 1984, on owners of rent-stabilized buildings in order to recoup an amount previously paid by the City to the State in reimbursement of the costs of administering the Rent Stabilization Law, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed an order and judgment granting summary judgment to plaintiffs, granted summary judgment to defendants, and declared Local Law No. 66 constitutional, is affirmed for reasons stated in the Appellate Division opinion, which concluded that Local Law No. 66 was not in conflict with the enabling statute (McKinney's Uncons Laws of NY § 8628), since the 1983 amendments to that statute took effect on April 1, 1984 and thus permitted the City to collect fees from that date at a rate of $ 10 per unit per year; that Local Law No. 66 did not discriminate against property owners who acquired title after October 1, 1984, since the City did not intend to impose the fee on those owners who purchased after October 1, 1984 but instead would seek payment for 1984-1985 from the prior owners, and that Local Law No. 66 was not void because of the two-year delay attending its passage, since owners of rent-stabilized buildings had actual notice of the fee imposition by virtue of the 1983 enabling statute, which explicitly provided for payment of the fee.

 

20 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 614; 532 N.E.2d 1229; 536 N.Y.S.2d 1; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 2698


September 13, 1988, Argued  
October 20, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended April 11, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the supreme court convicting defendant after a bench trial of murder in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of killing his girlfriend. The evidence against him included a statement he made in the police station approximately an hour after the police arrested him in his apartment without a warrant. Defendant contended that the statement should have been suppressed because it was obtained in violation of constitutional guarantees against illegal searches and seizures. After considering three factors to determine if a confession was the product of free will after an illegal arrest, the court held that defendant's statement must be suppressed as fruit of the poisonous tree. The causal link between the illegality and the confession was not attenuated. Defendant's statement one hour after the illegal arrest, coupled with the continuous police presence, indicated that the station house statement was no less a product of a U.S. Const. amend. IV violation than was the statement defendant made in his apartment. Moreover, the police illegality was knowing and intentional. They made no attempt to obtain a warrant even though five days had elapsed from the time of the killing and defendant's arrest.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate division, suppressed defendant's statement, and ordered a new trial. Defendant's statement was suppressed because it was tainted fruit of the illegal arrest and no sufficient attenuating factors were present to dissipate the taint caused by the illegal arrest.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Confession -- Confession Obtained after Illegal Arrest -- Attenuation of Causal Connection between Illegality and Statement

Where defendant was given Miranda warnings and freely made a written statement in the police station approximately one hour after the police had illegally arrested him in his apartment without a warrant, that statement should have been suppressed on Fourth Amendment grounds since the causal connection between the illegal arrest and the statement was not sufficiently attenuated. The temporal relationship between the illegal arrest and the statement is, at best, ambiguous; standing alone, it cannot serve to attenuate the illegality. Further, the short time period and the continuous police presence with defendant from the time he was arrested until the time he gave his statement, without any legally significant intervening event, indicate that the station house statement was no less a product of the Fourth Amendment violation than was the prior statement defendant made in his apartment which the courts below suppressed. Reading defendant his Miranda rights again, standing alone, could not attenuate the link between the Fourth Amendment violation and the statement. Nor does a consideration of the purpose and flagrancy of the official misconduct support a finding of attenuation. The police deliberately made an illegal arrest, according to the practice of that police department not to get warrants before making arrests in the home, to obtain a confession of defendant; there was no intervening event sufficient to attenuate that illegality. Moreover, the taint of the illegal arrest was not attenuated because the police had probable cause to make the arrest.

 

21 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hawkins v. Coughlin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 158; 527 N.E.2d 759; 531 N.Y.S.2d 881; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1673



July 12, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended April 11, 1989.



DISPOSITION: On review of submissions pursuant to section 500.4 of the Rules of the Court of Appeals (22 NYCRR 500.4), order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner prison inmate brought an action under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 against respondent state correctional officials, seeking to have jail time served for a prior conviction that was reversed and dismissed credited toward a current sentence. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirmed a trial court's judgment that denied the petition. The inmate appealed.


OVERVIEW: The inmate was convicted for a crime and served prison time. After release on parole, the inmate sought to have the original conviction dismissed. While on parole, the inmate was arrested for a second felony. After he was convicted for the second felony, he brought an action under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to require the state prison officials to credit the time that he had served for the first conviction, which had been dismissed, against his conviction for the second offense. The trial court denied the petition, and the appellate court affirmed. On review, the court affirmed and held that that N.Y. Penal Law § 70.30(3) did not apply to the situation where the second charge was lodged during an inmate's release on parole rather than while he was in actual custody on a pending charge. Thus the court held that the inmate's request for jail time credit was properly denied.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the appellate court, which affirmed the trial court's order denying the inmate's request for jail time credit on his second felony conviction.


HEADNOTES

Prisons and Prisoners -- Jail Time Credit -- What Constitutes "Custody" -- Dismissal Resulting from Successful Appeal of Judgment of Conviction

Petitioner, who was convicted of sodomy in the first degree while on parole after serving approximately 3 1/2 years of the sentence imposed upon his 1975 conviction for robbery, which was subsequently reversed as having been unconstitutionally obtained and the indictment dismissed, is not entitled pursuant to Penal Law § 70.30 (3) to credit for the time he served on the invalid robbery conviction toward satisfaction of the sentence imposed upon the sodomy conviction. The last paragraph of Penal Law § 70.30 (3), the so-called "dismissal-acquittal paragraph", provides that where a person has been in custody due to a charge that culminated in a dismissal or an acquittal, the amount of time that would have been credited against a sentence for such charge, had one been imposed, shall be credited against any sentence that is based on a charge for which a warrant or commitment was lodged during the pendency of such custody. The legislative history of Penal Law § 70.30 establishes that the term "custody" was intended to mean "confinement" or "detention" under guard and not "constructive custody" such as release on parole or bail. Further, the "dismissal-acquittal paragraph" clearly envisions that the "dismissal" of the first charge occur prior to the formal commencement of any sentence imposed on that charge and thus does not encompass dismissals that result as a consequence of a successful appeal from a judgment of conviction. The meaning of the term "custody", therefore, cannot be said to include the status of parole. Insofar as petitioner's "dismissal" resulted from a successful appeal subsequent to conviction and imposition of sentence, and because the second charge -- for sodomy -- was lodged during his release on parole rather than while he was in actual custody on a pending charge, petitioner's circumstances do not fall within those contemplated by the statute, and his request for jail time credit was properly denied.

 

22 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Asian Americans for Equality v. Koch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 121; 527 N.E.2d 265; 531 N.Y.S.2d 782; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1684


June 1, 1988, Argued  
July 7, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended April 11, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, not-for-profit corporation and individuals, appealed from a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) that dismissed three causes of action in the complaint. Plaintiffs sought reinstatement of their first and second causes of action in their challenge to an amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution that established the Special Manhattan Bridge District in Chinatown.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, not-for-profit corporation and individuals, filed an action against defendants, city, various officers and agencies, and private developer, to challenge an amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution, alleging that the amendment would displace residents who required low-income housing. The appellate division dismissed the complaint finding the first and second causes of action failed to state a claim and the third cause of action, seeking to enjoin development of a particular building, moot. On appeal, plaintiffs nevertheless contended that the amendment was invalid because the means adopted to achieve them were inadequate. The court held that the first cause of action did not state a legal claim for relief because plaintiffs failed to allege that the city failed to plan for the balanced and well-ordered development of the community. The court held that defendants had met the requirements for a well-considered plan, and plaintiffs failed to state a claim of exclusionary zoning. The court held that plaintiffs' allegations fail to state a cause of action entitling them to judicial relief and affirmed the order of the appellate division, with costs.


OUTCOME: The court held that defendants, city, various officers and agencies, and private developer, had met the requirements for a well-considered zoning plan, and plaintiffs, not-for-profit corporation and individuals, failed to state a claim of exclusionary zoning. The court held that plaintiffs' allegations failed to state a cause of action entitling them to judicial relief and affirmed the order of the appellate division, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- "Piecemeal" Zoning -- Special Manhattan Bridge District

1. The amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution which established the Special Manhattan Bridge District in Chinatown is not "piecemeal" legislation. Piecemeal zoning exists when only part of the land within a municipality is regulated by the zoning laws. However, the entire City of New York is zoned; the Special Manhattan Bridge District enactment is simply one of many amendments to the City's comprehensive zoning law.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Sufficiency of Allegations of Complaint Claiming Amendment to Zoning Resolution Not Part of "Well Considered Plan"

2. In an action challenging an amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution which established the Special Manhattan Bridge District in Chinatown, plaintiffs' first cause of action alleging that the amendment is "not comprehensive in outlook" and that the study on which it is based is not part of a well-considered plan does not state a legal claim for relief. The pleadings refer to the amendment only in this one conclusory assertion; the remaining several paragraphs of the cause of action challenge the planning study which preceded it. However, the validity of the amendment is not dependent solely upon the adequacy of the study of the Manhattan Bridge area, but on all the City's zoning policies and plans and nowhere in the complaint have plaintiffs alleged that the City has failed to plan for the balanced and well-ordered development of the community or that it has neglected to zone the City to provide for the needs of its inhabitants or those in the region.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Constitutionality of Amendment to Zoning Resolution -- "Well Considered Plan"

3. The power to zone must be exercised in the case of cities in accord with a "well considered plan" (General City Law § 20 [25]). If a zoning ordinance is adopted for a legitimate governmental purpose and there is a reasonable relation between the end sought to be achieved by the regulation and the means used to achieve that end, it will be upheld. An amendment which has been carefully studied, prepared and considered meets the general requirement for a well-considered plan and satisfies the statutory requirement. Thus, an amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution which established the Special Manhattan Bridge District in Chinatown is not unconstitutional because it was not enacted pursuant to a well-considered plan. This legislation was reasonably related to its goals: the development of needed housing and the rehabilitation of existing housing in one area of Chinatown. There is no allegation that it was not consistent with the City's general planning or that the City had failed to make provision for low-cost housing. That being so, and inasmuch as the amendment was enacted after study and consideration, it met the requirements for a well-considered plan.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Exclusionary Zoning -- Special Manhattan Bridge District

4. In an action challenging an amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution which established the Special Manhattan Bridge District in Chinatown for the purposes of encouraging construction of new residential facilities, rehabilitating existing structures and expanding community facilities, and which authorized development of mixed-income housing on land vacant or substantially vacant, and permitted increased density in new housing units for those developers who agree to either donate space for community facilities, construct low-income dwelling units or rehabilitate existing substandard housing, or to do a combination thereof, plaintiffs have not stated a claim of exclusionary zoning. The City does not now nor has it ever excluded low-cost housing in Chinatown or in the City generally. Low-income families now live in the District and will continue to live there, hopefully in rehabilitated or newly constructed low-cost housing, if the purposes of the amendment are fulfilled.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Special Manhattan Bridge District -- Availability of Injunctive Relief Compelling Provision of Low-Cost Housing

5. In an action challenging an amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution which established the Special Manhattan Bridge District in Chinatown for the purposes of encouraging construction of new residential facilities, rehabilitating existing structures and expanding community facilities, and which authorized development of mixed-income housing on land vacant or substantially vacant, and permitted increased density in new housing units for those developers who agreed to perform work in furtherance of the amendment's purposes, plaintiffs' cause of action alleging that the incentives offered will not provide sufficient low-cost housing and seeking a mandatory injunction compelling the City to amend the Special Manhattan Bridge District to provide low-cost housing fails to state a claim entitling them to judicial relief. Plaintiffs seek not to overcome exclusionary practices or to correct some past inequity, but to overturn the considered decision of the executive and legislative branches of New York City's government because they believe the City's chosen remedy for this established area will prove inadequate; plaintiffs seek a rewriting of the ordinance itself. However, those charged with the duty of addressing the problems of Chinatown chose to rezone the Manhattan Bridge area and provide housing incentives they deemed most suitable. They have attempted to use incentive zoning to provide realistic housing opportunities which include new apartments for the poor. Nothing in the legislative plan suggests that it will fail its purpose and plaintiffs do not allege that the solution is arbitrary or capricious or undertaken for an improper purpose, only that they would have zoned the area differently, or better, to avoid a potential future problem.

 

23 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gensler


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 239; 527 N.E.2d 1209; 532 N.Y.S.2d 72; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1662


May 27, 1988, Argued  
July 6, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended April 11, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed defendant's conviction, upon his guilty plea, for reckless endangerment in the first degree, robbery in the second degree, assault in the second degree, and grand larceny in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was ordered to undergo a competency examination prior to trial. Defendant was examined by two state psychiatrists and found to be competent. Defendant's privately retained psychiatrist deemed that defendant was incompetent, and so the trial judge ordered a re-examination by court-appointed psychiatrists, who had defendant committed. After defendant's brief stay at a psychiatric center, the center issued a notification to the court that defendant was no longer incapacitated. Defendant's attorney then asked the trial judge to hold a competency hearing on his own motion and the court refused, allowing defendant to make a plea of guilty. On appeal, the defense contended that the trial judge abused his discretion in proceeding without ordering a competency hearing sua sponte. On review of the appellate court decision affirming the trial court, the court held that in view of the information the trial court had before it, the court did not abuse its discretion in not ordering a competency hearing sua sponte. Defendant's conviction by guilty plea was affirmed.


OUTCOME: On review, the court held that in view of the information the trial court had before it, the court did not abuse its discretion in not ordering a competency hearing sua sponte. Defendant's conviction by guilty plea was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Fitness to Proceed to Trial -- Competency Hearing by Court Sua Sponte after Certification of Competence -- Due Process

In the prosecution of defendant for robbery and assault in the second degree and other felonies, the trial court did not commit reversible error in refusing to conduct, sua sponte, a competency-to-stand-trial hearing after the Director of Mid-Hudson Psychiatric Center certified defendant as competent following defendant's 14-day placement at the Center upon the trial court's initial finding of incapacity ( CPL 730.50). CPL 730.60 makes no provision for an in-all-instances hearing under CPL 730.30 (4) based on a difference between a precommitment finding of incapacity and a postcommitment declaration of fitness because the circumstances of each vary by their very nature. Although, following a determination of fitness to proceed ( CPL 730.60 [2]), the court must conduct a hearing to determine the issue of capacity upon motion therefore by defendant ( CPL 730.30 [2]), neither defendant nor his counsel affirmatively requested a hearing. Due process requires, in some instances, that the trial court inquire into a defendant's competence whether or not a request has been made for such an inquiry. The statute so requires ( CPL 730.30 [2]). Here, however, a detailed inquiry was made according to the dictates of CPL article 730 and the Judge had relevant and complete data consisting of expert evidentiary material and judicial observations before he made his factual and constitutionally satisfactory determination that defendant was competent to proceed and that an evidentiary hearing on the point was not required on the court's own motion. Moreover, defendant's extensive psychiatric record, coupled with the Trial Judge's progressive personal observations of defendant, wholly fail to establish that a "sufficient doubt" existed which would, independently of the applicable statutes, require the trial court to sua sponte order a hearing on constitutional due process grounds.

 

24 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Miller v. Schwartz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 869; 528 N.E.2d 507; 532 N.Y.S.2d 354; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1649


June 2, 1988, Argued  
July 6, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner driver challenged a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which reversed a judgment entered in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, and declared that 15 N.Y. C.R.R. 123.1 was not unconstitutional as applied to the driver.


OVERVIEW: The driver was charged with speeding and was adjudicated administratively. Before trial the driver's attorney requested from the Traffic Violations Bureau (bureau) certain documents and information pertaining to the type of radar used and its associated testing and operating procedures. The bureau denied the driver's request. In an N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding to compel reasonable discovery relating to the radar device, the driver claimed that 15 N.Y. C.R.R. 123.1 unconstitutionally deprived him of due process of law because without it he would be unable to conduct effective cross-examination. On review, the court determined his request was properly denied. The court found that there was no general constitutional right to discovery in criminal cases or administrative proceedings and that the driver had no statutory or regulatory right to pretrial discovery in such circumstances.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that the driver was not unconstitutionally deprived of due process of law.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Speeding -- Right to Disclosure at Administrative Proceeding

Appellant was charged with speeding in a county where such charges are adjudicated administratively. Appellant's pretrial request from the Traffic Violations Bureau for documents and information pertaining to the type of radar used, and its associated testing and operating procedures, was properly denied on the ground that under the relevant rule of the Division of Administrative [***2] Adjudication, the motion practice and discovery procedures set forth in the Civil Practice Law and Rules and Criminal Procedure Law were not applicable (see, 15 NYCRR 123.1). There is no general constitutional right to discovery in criminal cases or administrative proceedings. Such matters are regulated by statute or rule and appellant had no statutory or regulatory right to pretrial discovery here.

 

25 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


N.Y. State Pub. Emples. Fed'n v. Albany


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 96; 527 N.E.2d 253; 531 N.Y.S.2d 770; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1647


May 31, 1988, Argued  
June 30, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended April 11, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff public employee unions sought to enjoin enforcement of a city ordinance, which allowed residents of certain areas who purchased permits to park for unlimited periods but restricted nonresident parking to 90 minutes. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) declared the ordinance invalid for granting preferential treatment to the residents and granted summary judgment in favor of the unions. The city appealed.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the court affirmed. Residents of a community had no greater right to use the highways abutting their land, whether it be for travel or parking, than other members of the public and Albany, N.Y., Albany City Ordinance ch.XXV, div. 9, §§ 25-114 through 25-118, which conferred special parking advantages to residents of certain neighborhoods, violated that proscription. The court noted that while the legislature was free to create exceptions to the general rule or delegate the power to do so to the localities, it did not do so here. The court rejected the city's assertion that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 1640(a)(6), (15) and (16) authorized that ordinance. Section 1640(a)(6) authorized local parking restrictions but did not permit discrimination between residents and nonresidents. The language of § 1640(a)(15) made no mention of a distinction between residents and nonresidents and the purpose of the statute was simply to allow the city to phase out parking meters in favor of a permit plan. Moreover, under § 1640(a)(16) local highway regulations were deemed reasonable only if they pertained to public safety and were nondiscriminatory.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's reversal of the trial court's judgment and the grant of summary judgment in favor of the unions on the grounds that the ordinance was invalid.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Residential Permit Parking System -- Power of Locality to Restrict Highway Use Based upon Residency

1. Albany City Ordinance No. 5.11.86, which creates a program allowing residents of certain areas of the City of Albany who purchase permits to park in their neighborhoods for periods of unlimited duration but restricts nonresident parking in such areas during weekday business hours to 90 minutes, is ultra vires and void. Vehicle and Traffic Law §§ 1600 and 1604 prohibit localities from excluding persons from free use of the highways except to the extent such limitations are expressly authorized by statute. Further, case law makes clear the types of exclusions foreclosed by these statutes and reveals that in the absence of specific authorization from the Legislature, restrictions on highway use based upon residency -- such as that found in the contested ordinance -- are prohibited. The general rule with respect to the power of localities to restrict highway "use", which includes use for parking as well as travel purposes, is clear: residents of a community have no greater right to use the highways abutting their land -- whether it be for travel or parking -- than other members of the public and Albany City Ordinance No. 5.11.86, which confers special parking privileges to residents of certain neighborhoods, violates this proscription. Although the Legislature is free to create exceptions to the general rule or delegate the power to do so to the localities (see, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1604), it did neither here; none of the three provisions of the Vehicle and Traffic Law (§ 1640 [a] [6], [15], [16]), relied on by the City of Albany authorize Ordinance No. 5.11.86.

Municipal Corporations -- Residential Permit Parking System -- Vehicle and Traffic Law Does Not Authorize Restrictions on Highway Use Based upon Residency

2. In an action challenging the validity of Albany City Ordinance No. 5.11.86, which creates a program allowing residents of certain areas of the City of Albany who purchase permits to park in their neighborhoods for periods of unlimited duration but restricts nonresident parking in such areas during weekday business hours to 90 minutes, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640 (a) (6), (15) and (16) do not supersede the general rule proscribing localities from placing restrictions on highway use, whether for travel or parking, based upon residency, and none of those provisions authorize Ordinance No. 5.11.86. Paragraph (6) generally authorizes local parking restrictions such as the 90-minute time limit found in the contested ordinance, but it does not permit discrimination between residents and nonresidents, a distinction forbidden at common law (see also, Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1200). Paragraph (15) empowers the City of Albany to enact a prepaid parking permit program, but not one which confers preferred status to those in the community. The omnibus provision contained in paragraph (16) does not authorize regulations at odds with the laws of the State and New York common law forbids according local residents priority in the use of public streets. Moreover, no provision in section 1640 differentiates between residents and nonresidents, and such a "drastic" distinction should not be upheld based upon the omnibus provision. Finally, because the ordinance patently excludes nonresidents it violates the prohibition against discriminatory restrictions.

Municipal Corporations -- Residential Permit Parking System -- Lack of Involvement of Federal Constitutional Issue

3. In an action challenging the validity of Albany City Ordinance No. 5.11.86, which creates a program allowing residents of certain areas of the City of Albany who purchase permits to park in their neighborhoods for periods of unlimited duration but restricts nonresident parking in such areas during weekday business hours to 90 minutes, the question whether the contested plan could be enacted consistent with the Federal Constitution is not at issue. The question is one of power. While the Legislature could delegate to the localities power to enact such a plan, it has not done so and the ordinance is ultra vires.

 

26 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Arteaga v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 212; 527 N.E.2d 1194; 532 N.Y.S.2d 57; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1146


April 26, 1988, Argued  
June 9, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant inmates sought review of a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which dismissed their claims for damages from respondent state for unlawful confinement and loss of privileges resulting from the prosecution of disciplinary charges against them.


OVERVIEW: Both inmates were charged with conspiracy to escape and possession of a weapon, escape paraphernalia, and contraband. Inmates were found guilty and confined in special housing with the loss of privileges. The charges were based in part on statements by confidential informants. The charges were overturned. The inmates claimed that the sanctions imposed were unlawful and filed an action for malicious prosecution, false imprisonment, and violation of statutory rights. The suits were barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity. The court held that (1) the officers and employees responsible for filing the misbehavior reports against the inmates, conducting the hearings, and confining them before and after the hearing determinations acted entirely within their authority and in compliance with the applicable rules and regulations, (2) where state corrections employees acted under the authority of and in full compliance with the governing statutes and regulations, their actions constituted discretionary conduct of a quasi-judicial nature for which the state had absolute immunity, and (3) the appellate court correctly held that the actions were barred by sovereign immunity.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

State -- Claim against State -- Absolute Immunity -- Actions of Employees of Department of Correctional Services in Commencing and Conducting Formal Disciplinary Hearings against Inmates -- Quasi-Judicial Conduct

Where employees of the Department of Correctional Services act under the authority of and in full compliance with the governing statutes and regulations (Correction Law §§ 112, 137; 7 NYCRR parts 250-254) in commencing and conducting formal disciplinary hearings against inmates, their actions constitute discretionary conduct of a quasi-judicial nature for which the State has absolute immunity. The actions of Correction Department employees in preparing and filing misbehavior reports, confining inmates, and making dispositions following Superintendent's hearings entail discretionary decisions in furtherance of general policies and purposes where the exercise of reasoned judgment can produce different acceptable results. Thus, the actions of correction employees, in such circumstances, are quasi-judicial in nature and deserving of absolute immunity. In carrying out their duties relating to security and discipline in the difficult and sometimes highly stressful prison environment, correction employees, like other officials with quasi-judicial responsibilities, should not be inhibited because their conduct could be the basis of a damage claim. Accordingly, in separate claims against the State by inmates in a State correctional facility seeking damages for unlawful confinement and loss of privileges resulting from the prosecution of disciplinary charges against them, an Appellate Division order affirming the dismissal of the claims by the Court of Claims, is affirmed.

 

27 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kohl


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


72 N.Y.2d 191; 527 N.E.2d 1182; 532 N.Y.S.2d 45; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1133


March 24, 1988, Argued  
June 7, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended April 11, 1989.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the trial court convicting defendant of murder and assault.


OVERVIEW: Defendant appealed from the affirmation of his convictions for murder and assault, claiming that N.Y. Penal Law § 40.15, defining New York's affirmative defense of mental disease or defect, violated the New York State constitutional due process clause. Defendant argued that N.Y. Penal Law §25.00 (2) unconstitutionally placed the burden of proof by a preponderance of evidence on defendants for all affirmative defenses. The court concluded that there was no state constitutional violation because placing the burden on the defendant did not relieve or transform the people's primary and constant burden of proving, beyond a reasonable doubt, all the elements of the crimes charged, including proving all components of the applicable culpable mental state element. The court found that the people's proof and burden on the issue of criminal culpability established that defendant, at the time he fired the shots, "intended" his act. Defendant had a conscious objective to cause the result or to engage in the conduct, and acted "recklessly," with awareness of and conscious disregard of a substantial and unjustifiable risk that the result would occur or that the circumstances existed.


OUTCOME: The order affirming defendant's conviction for murder and assault was affirmed. Placing the burden on the defendant to prove the affirmative defense of mental disease or defect did not relieve or transform the people's primary and constant burden of proving, beyond a reasonable doubt, all the elements of the crimes charged, including proving all components of the applicable culpable mental state.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Insanity -- Mental Disease or Defect as Affirmative Defense -- Constitutionality of Placing Burden of Proof by Preponderance of Evidence on Defendant Asserting Affirmative Defense

1. Penal Law § 40.15, defining New York's affirmative defense of mental disease or defect, does not violate the State constitutional Due Process Clause because Penal Law § 25.00 (2) places the burden of proof by a preponderance of evidence on defendants for all affirmative defenses. Inasmuch as placing this burden on defendants does not relieve or transform the People's primary and constant burden of proving, beyond a reasonable doubt, all the elements of the crimes charged, including all components of the applicable culpable mental state element, there is no State constitutional violation.

Crimes -- Insanity -- Mental Disease or Defect as Affirmative Defense -- Potential Unconstitutional Application of Affirmative Defense Statute -- Safeguarding Jury Instructions

2. It may be legally impossible for a person who is unable to appreciate the nature and consequences of his conduct (Penal Law § 40.15) to form a "conscious objective" to kill the victim (Penal Law § 15.05 [1]; § 125.25 [1]) in cases where the concepts defined in those sections factually overlap with one another. Then, the affirmative defense statute suffers the potential of impermissibly shifting to defendant the burden of disproving the formation of conscious objective to kill another human being, and the statute as applied could be unconstitutional. This potentiality can be reasonably safeguarded by jury instructions which should emphasize the People's primary, ultimate, and nontransferable burden of proving all the elements of criminal intent beyond a reasonable doubt. Indeed, without transferring any burden to the defendant, the trial court should also, after the primary instructions, sequentially advise the jury that defendant bears a different burden on insanity, and that evidence of insanity relating to whether defendant knew what he was doing must be considered by the jury in its consideration of the People's nontransferable satisfaction of its burden to prove intent beyond a reasonable doubt.

Crimes -- Insanity -- Mental Disease or Defect as Affirmative Defense -- Presumption of Sanity

3. New York's presumption of sanity does not render unconstitutional Penal Law § 40.15, which, in defining mental disease or defect as an affirmative defense, places the burden of proof by a preponderance of the evidence on a defendant asserting the affirmative defense (Penal Law § 25.00 [2]). The presumption of sanity has never relieved the People of the burden of establishing beyond a reasonable doubt defendant's pertinent culpable mental state at the time the crime was committed, including those elements that may overlap with the affirmative defense of mental disease or defect.

 

28 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Civil Serv. Emples. Ass'n, Local 1000 v. Regan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 653; 525 N.E.2d 1; 529 N.Y.S.2d 461; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1005; 9 Employee Benefits Cas. (BNA) 2139


April 25, 1988, Argued  
May 31, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended November 8, 1988.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, public employees and union representative, sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which reversed an order that granted appellants' motion for summary judgment, denied summary judgment to appellees, state and comptroller, and declared that conversion of employees to Tier III benefits was unconstitutional under N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7.


OVERVIEW: The lower court held that the ultimate classification of the public employees as Tier III members was not unconstitutional. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that 1976 N.Y. Laws 890 did not violate that constitutional protection as to employees hired between July 27, 1976 and December 31, 1976 by conferring in a complementary prospective legislative package Tier II benefits only until December 31, 1976, at which time they matured into Tier III benefits. The court held that simultaneously prescribing Tier III status to public employees who were preliminarily afforded Tier II rights and benefits did not constitute an unconstitutional impairment or diminution of a fixed public retirement contractual right as to those entering between July 27, 1976, the date of signing of the statute. Inclusion of a complementary and prospective condition in a definite, known, and fixed pension package in such circumstances satisfied the constitutional protection.


OUTCOME: An order of the lower court finding a pension statute constitutional in a case brought by public employees and a union representative was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Retirement and Pension Benefits -- Impairment or Diminution of Fixed Public Retirement Contractual Rights -- Constitutionality of Complementary Prospective Legislative Package Simultaneously Prescribing Tier III Status to Public Employees Preliminarily Afforded Tier II Benefits

1. Laws of 1976 (ch 890), which conferred Tier II rights and benefits (Retirement and Social Security Law art 11) to public employees only until December 31, 1976, at which time they matured into Tier III benefits (Retirement and Social Security Law art 14), did not violate the protection provided by NY Constitution, article V, § 7 against diminishment or impairment of pension rights, which are fixed and determined by the laws and conditions in existence at the time membership in the pension system commences, as to employees hired between July 27, 1976, the date chapter 890 was signed into law, and December 31, 1976. The rights of public employees hired between those dates were fully established by the laws and conditions in effect when their membership commenced. Insofar as the staggered retirement package established the rights of those who acquired membership between July 27 and December 31, 1976, the automatic shift of such employees to Tier III rights in no way constitutes a diminishment or impairment of the contractual rights conferred at the time of membership. Inclusion of a complementary and prospective condition in a definite, known and fixed pension package in these circumstances satisfies the constitutional protection and Court of Appeals precedents.

Civil Service -- Retirement and Pension Benefits -- Retroactive Application of Law Simultaneously Prescribing Tier III Status to Public Employees Preliminarily Afforded Tier II Benefits -- Diminution of Rights Then in Existence

2. Although Laws of 1976 (ch 890), which conferred Tier II benefits to public employees only until December 31, 1976, at which time they matured into Tier III benefits, has a retroactive effective date of July 1, 1976, application of the law's provisions to Retirement System members prior to July 27, 1976, the date chapter 890 was signed into law, would be a forbidden retroactive application which would diminish the rights of persons under the Tier II provisions then in existence in violation of NY Constitution, article V, § 7.

 

29 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Love


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 711; 525 N.E.2d 701; 530 N.Y.S.2d 55; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 1013


April 22, 1988, Argued  
May 31, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the trial court, resentencing defendant as a first felony offender following his conviction for robbery and related offenses.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of robbery and related offenses, and based on his record of prior convictions, was originally sentenced as a second felony offender. On defendant's application, however, the trial court resentenced him as a first felony offender, concluding that he was not a second felony offender within the meaning of the applicable statutes. The appellate court affirmed and the state sought review. On appeal the court affirmed, holding that defendant's conviction within the 10 years prior to his robbery conviction was properly ignored in determining whether defendant could take advantage of N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06(1)(b)(iv), which provided that convictions older then 10 years could not be used as a predicate for sentence enhancement. Defendant had two prior convictions. One conviction was more than 10 years in the past and the other was not. However, the intervening conviction had to be ignored because it was found to have been in violation of the Sixth Amendment right to counsel, so that under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.21(7)(b), it could not be counted for purposes of second felony offender status. Thus, neither conviction could be used as a predicate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court that affirmed the trial court's judgment resentencing defendant as a first felony offender following his conviction for robbery and related offenses.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second Felony Offender -- Extension of 10-Year Limitation Period for Prior Felony Conviction -- No Exclusion for Unconstitutionally Obtained Conviction

A defendant convicted of robbery and related offenses in 1982 should not be sentenced as a second felony offender based on a prior 1968 conviction, when this can only be done by taking into account the fact that the defendant was incarcerated in 1972 on another conviction which concededly was obtained in violation of his constitutional rights. The Penal Law provides that a prior felony conviction cannot serve as a predicate for enhanced punishment if the sentence was imposed more than 10 years before the commission of the felony on which the defendant presently stands convicted (Penal Law § 70.06 [1] [b] [iv]), but that the period during which defendant has been incarcerated "for any reason between the time of commission of the previous felony and the time of commission of the present felony" shall be excluded in calculating the 10-year period (Penal Law § 70.06 [1] [b] [v]). However, CPL 400.21 (7) (b) provides that a previous conviction obtained in violation of a defendant's Federal constitutional rights "must not be counted in determining whether the defendant has been subjected to a predicate felony conviction". The various statutes provide an integrated legislative scheme, and all of the factors must be considered together to determine whether a prior conviction should be treated as a "predicate felony offense". Reading the statutes in that light, it is clear that defendant's 1968 conviction does not qualify because the 10-year limitation period had run when the defendant committed the current offenses, and it cannot be extended by taking into account defendant's incarceration on the 1972 conviction since that conviction was unconstitutionally obtained. In short, when the statute says that incarceration "for any reason" extends the limitations period, it contemplates at least that the defendant has not been imprisoned without reason or unconstitutionally.

 

30 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Doe v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 484; 522 N.E.2d 444; 527 N.Y.S.2d 368; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 191


February 10, 1988, Argued  
March 24, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the Commissioner of Health of the State of New York (commissioner), challenged a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which granted respondent physician's petition, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, and found that the commissioner had exceeded the scope of his authority in reversing the rulings of an administrative officer (AO) in a misconduct proceeding.


OVERVIEW: Misconduct charges were brought against the physician, a psychiatrist, based on patient complaints alleging sexual abuse by the physician during treatment. At a hearing before the State Board for Professional Medical Conduct (state board), the AO ordered the production of documentary evidence of prior complaints made by women against the physician. The commissioner reversed the rulings on the ground that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 230(11)(a) mandated that complaints to the state board remain confidential. The physician brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding in the nature of prohibition seeking to annul and vacate the order of the commissioner. On review, the court reversed and dismissed the petition. The court found that: 1) the matter had properly come to the commissioner in a manner consistent with N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 230; 2) the state board made clear that the AO's ruling had prevented it from making a final determination as the statute required; 3) the commissioner had broad powers concerning public health; and 4) relief of prohibition was not available to the physician where his challenge was only directed at an alleged evidentiary error committed within the proceeding.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that found the commissioner had exceeded his authority and dismissed the physician's petition.


HEADNOTES

Physicians and Surgeons -- Disciplinary Proceedings -- Power of Commissioner of Health to Reverse Evidentiary Rulings of Administrative Officer

1. The Commissioner of Health did not exceed his powers in reversing evidentiary rulings of an Administrative Officer made at a disciplinary hearing before a Committee of the State Board for Professional Medical Conduct, which rulings had effectively prevented the Committee from making a final determination in the matter. Nothing in the legislation creating the position of Administrative Officer (L 1980, ch 866) or its history suggests an intention that the limited authority given to an Administrative Officer should work to impede the disciplinary process or inhibit the Commissioner and the Board of Regents from effectively and expeditiously resolving complaints of misconduct in the medical profession. Given the broad powers conferred upon the Commissioner in matters concerning the public health, and more particularly in regulating professional medical conduct, it would be anomalous if the Commissioner, under the unusual facts of this case, did not have the power to make his independent determination of the issues. The power to do so is essential to the exercise of the far-reaching powers expressly granted to the Commissioner by the Legislature.

 Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition -- When Remedy Available -- Proceeding to Annul Commissioner of Health's Reversal of Evidentiary Rulings of Administrative Officer

2. Relief in the nature of prohibition is not available to petitioner physician in a proceeding to annul and vacate an order of the Commissioner of Health, which reversed evidentiary rulings of an Administrative Officer made at a disciplinary hearing before a Committee of the State Board for Professional Medical Conduct. Although petitioner urges that the Commissioner's determination gives rise to an issue of constitutional dimension, it does not follow that this proceeding is properly brought as a legitimate exception to the doctrine of exhaustion of administrative remedies.
