Petitioner's challenge is directed only to the alleged evidentiary error committed within the disciplinary proceeding; the writ of prohibition does not lie as a means of seeking collateral review of a mere error of law in the administrative process, no matter how egregious that error might be, and however cleverly the error may be characterized by counsel as an excess of jurisdiction or power. Petitioner has an adequate remedy in his right to institute a CPLR article 78 proceeding following a final agency determination.

 

31 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bright


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 376; 520 N.E.2d 1355; 526 N.Y.S.2d 66; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 90


January 6, 1988, Argued  
February 17, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People appealed orders from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which granted defendant thief's motion to suppress physical evidence following an arrest for loitering and reversed defendant drug addict's conviction of loitering, in actions where defendants asserted that N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35(7) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were arrested for loitering in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35(7). The People asserted that N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35(7) provided sufficient notice of the conduct it proscribed, contained explicit standards for its enforcement, and comported with constitutional requirements. Defendants asserted that the statute was void for vagueness and violated constitutional protections against unreasonable search and seizures and self-incrimination. The court held the statute was unconstitutionally vague, since it provided no legislative guidelines governing the determination as to whether a person was engaged in suspicious loitering in places of unrestricted public access. Also, since the facilities at issue here were "public places," N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35(7), as applied, did not satisfy due process, since it failed to give unequivocal notice to the unwary that an activity as innocuous as mere loitering was prohibited. Who would be stopped, questioned, and arrested under the statute was left solely up to the discretion of the police officer on the scene. Finally, the statute required one to impermissibly sacrifice his right against compulsory self-incrimination to avoid arrest.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the orders in both cases. The loitering statute was unconstitutionally vague under the Due Process Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions because it failed to give fair notice to the ordinary citizen that the prohibited conduct was illegal, it lacked minimal legislative guidelines, and it required that a citizen relinquish his constitutional right against compulsory self-incrimination in order to avoid arrest.


HEADNOTES

Crimes --  Loitering in Transportation Facility  -- Validity of Statute -- Due Process of Law

1. Penal Law § 240.35 (7), which provides that "[a] person is guilty of loitering when he * * * [loiters] or remains in any transportation facility, or is found sleeping therein, and is unable to give a satisfactory explanation of his presence", is unconstitutionally vague under the Due Process Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions because it fails to give fair notice to the ordinary citizen that the prohibited conduct is illegal, it lacks minimal legislative guidelines, thereby permitting arbitrary enforcement and, finally, it requires that a citizen relinquish his constitutional right against compulsory self-incrimination in order to avoid arrest. Accordingly, in separate prosecutions of two defendants who were charged with loitering (Penal Law § 240.35 [7]) in Pennsylvania Station and the Port Authority Bus Terminal, respectively, orders of the Appellate Division and Appellate Term which held that section 240.35 (7) was unconstitutionally vague, are affirmed.

Crimes -- Loitering in Transportation Facility -- Requirement That Suspect Provide "Satisfactory Explanation" to Avoid  Arrest -- Violation of Right to Remain Silent

2. The provision of Penal Law § 240.35 (7), which requires a person suspected of violating the loitering statute to provide a "satisfactory explanation" of his presence to avoid arrest, is violative of a citizen's constitutional right not to answer questions posed by law enforcement officers (US Const 5th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 6). A provision such as this one effectively deprives the citizen of his constitutional right to remain silent, since his failure to speak will result in certain arrest under the statute. It punishes a suspect for exercising his constitutional right to remain silent and impermissibly transforms the invocation of this right into a criminal act.

Crimes -- Loitering in Transportation Facility -- Unconstitutionality of Statute as Applied to Loitering in Pennsylvania Station and Port Authority Bus Terminal -- Due Process -- "Public Places"

3. Penal Law § 240.35 (7), which prohibits loitering "in any transportation facility", is unconstitutional as applied to defendants, who, in separate prosecutions, were charged with loitering in Pennsylvania Station and the Port Authority Bus Terminal, respectively. Under Penal Law § 240.00 (2), a "transportation facility" is defined in such a broad, all-encompassing manner so as to include some facilities that are more analogous to the public street than to a specific area of restricted public access that gives notice of its prohibition against loitering. The statutory definition that embraces "all appurtenances thereto" is also too vague and wide ranging in the context of this case. Since both transportation facilities at issue here are, in reality, "public places", the statute, as applied, does not satisfy due process, since it fails to give unequivocal notice to the unwary that an activity as innocuous as mere loitering is prohibited. Indeed, facilities such as Pennsylvania Station and Port Authority Bus Terminal are so public in nature, that they actually invite conduct that could be construed as loitering. Thus, in these two cases, the statute has the effect of prohibiting loitering in a public place and cannot withstand constitutional scrutiny.

 

32 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rochester Gas & Electric Corp. v. Public Service Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 313; 520 N.E.2d 528; 525 N.Y.S.2d 809; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 86


January 7, 1988, Argued  
February 11, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended November 8, 1988.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant natural gas company challenged on constitutional grounds the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed that N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 66-d requiring shared use of natural gas pipelines and respondent Public Service Commission's opinion were valid exercises of the state's police power and did not violate the United States Constitution or the New York Constitution.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Pub. Serv. Law § 66-d (2) gave the Public Service Commission (PSC) the authority to order, after notice and hearing, any natural gas producer to transport or contract with others to transport gas under contract for sale, provided that the gas company had available capacity for such transport and such transport did not impair the gas company's ability to render adequate service to its customers. The law permitted an affected gas company to charge for the service it was ordered to provide. The natural gas company was ordered by the PSC to provide access to its gas lines. The natural gas company challenged the order, which was affirmed at the trial and appellate levels. On appeal, the court affirmed because § 66-d (2) did not substantially interfere with the natural gas company's right to conduct its business or cause it to engage in business for which it had no authorization. It also held that § 66-d (2) did not result in a taking without just compensation when it forced the natural gas company, within specified circumstances, to transport other companies' gas through its pipelines. The law and the order of the PSC were valid exercises of the state's police powers.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed because the law did not require the natural gas company to engage in acts for which it was not licensed, nor did it result in an illegal taking of the company's property when it mandated that other suppliers use the pipelines for transportation of their gas supplies to customers within the state.


HEADNOTES

Public Utilities -- Validity of Statute Compelling Utilities to Transport Customer-Owned Natural Gas -- Substantive Due Process of Law

1. Public Service Law § 66-d (2) (as applied to plaintiff utility by Public Service Commission Opinion No. 85-6), which authorizes defendant Public Service Commission (PSC) to require certain utilities to transport customer-owned natural gas through their pipelines if the utility has excess capacity, receives reasonable compensation for doing so and if transportation of the customer-owned gas will not burden the utility or its ratepayers or impair the over-all quality of service to customers, does not substantially interfere with plaintiff's right to conduct its business, in violation of plaintiff's substantive due process rights. Inasmuch as plaintiff is a public utility, it is under an obligation to discharge duties which affect the community at large and the Legislature may amend such duties in furtherance of the public interest. Public Service Law § 66-d (2) does no more than compel the utility to provide access to its pipelines to New York State gas producers on occasions when it will not be burdensome to the utility or its remaining customers and upon payment of reasonable compensation. It is a reasonable regulation consistent with the public interest in developing the State's resources, furthering competition and controlling the cost of natural gas in the retail market. Accordingly, the Legislature acted well within constitutional limitations when it modified the manner in which plaintiff was required to satisfy its public obligations declaring that the public must be afforded reasonable access to the utility's pipeline network in the manner specified.

Public Utilities -- Validity of Statute Compelling Utilities to Transport Customer-Owned Natural Gas -- Substantive Due Process of Law -- Change of Utility Status from Private Carrier to Common Carrier

2. Public Service Law § 66-d (2) (as applied to plaintiff utility by Public Service Commission Opinion No. 85-6), which authorizes defendant Public Service Commission to compel certain utilities to provide access to its pipelines to New York State gas producers on occasions when it will not be burdensome to the utility or its remaining customers and upon payment of reasonable compensation, does not violate plaintiff utility's substantive due process rights on the ground that the statute changes its status from a private carrier to a common carrier. Inasmuch as even private corporations may be deemed affected with a public interest and subjected to reasonable regulation under the State's police power, plaintiff's status as public or private carrier is largely irrelevant under modern substantive due process rules. The dispositive question is whether the governmental exercise of its police powers is reasonable, and section 66-d (2) is a reasonable regulation consistent with the public interest in developing the State's resources, furthering competition and controlling the cost of natural gas in the retail market. Plaintiff is a public utility affected with a public interest and, thus, under either old or current notions of substantive due process public duties manifestly can be imposed on it.

Public Utilities -- Validity of Statute Compelling Utilities to Transport Customer-Owned Natural Gas -- Taking of Property without Just Compensation

3. Public Service Law § 66-d (2) (as applied to plaintiff utility by Public Service Commission Opinion No. 85-6), which authorizes defendant Public Service Commission to require certain utilities to transport customer-owned natural gas through their pipelines if the utility has excess capacity, receives reasonable compensation for doing so and if transportation of the customer-owned gas will not burden the utility or its ratepayers or impair the over-all quality of service to customers, does not effect an unconstitutional taking of plaintiff's property without just compensation (US Const 5th and 14th Amends; NY Const, art I, § 7). The statute appears to have little economic impact on plaintiff. Nor does it appear that the State's action had any adverse affect on plaintiff's investment-backed expectations. Further, the government's action involves only minimal, intermittent access to plaintiff's pipelines, under circumstances which will not interfere with plaintiff's regular business. No permanent appropriation of plaintiff's property rights is involved.

Public Utilities -- Validity of Statute Compelling Utilities to Transport Customer-Owned Natural Gas -- Taking of Property without Just Compensation -- Forced Undertaking of New Venture

4. Public Service Law § 66-d (2) (as applied to plaintiff utility by Public Service Commission Opinion No. 85-6), which authorizes defendant Public Service Commission to require certain utilities to transport customer-owned natural gas through their pipelines if the utility has excess capacity, receives reasonable compensation for doing so and if transportation of the customer-owned gas will not burden the utility or its ratepayers or impair the over-all quality of service to customers, does not effect an unconstitutional taking of plaintiff's property without just compensation (US Const 5th and 14th Amends; NY Const, art I, § 7) on the ground that, even though plaintiff has not been deprived of the property's use, it has been forced to undertake a new venture. Plaintiff is not being forced to provide services beyond its original commitment. It is being required to make some of the services it has always provided, transportation of gas, available to others.

Public Utilities -- Validity of Statute Compelling Utilities to Transport Customer-Owned Natural Gas -- "Gas Corporation" -- No Violation of Transportation Corporations Law

5. Public Service Law § 66-d (2) (as applied to plaintiff utility by Public Service Commission Opinion No. 85-6), which authorizes the Public Service Commission to require certain utilities to transport customer-owned natural gas through their pipelines if the utility has excess capacity, receives reasonable compensation for doing so and if transportation of the customer-owned gas will not burden the utility or its ratepayers or impair the over-all quality of service to customers, does not compel plaintiff utility, which was chartered as a "gas corporation" (see, Transportation Corporations Law § 10), to use its distribution system to operate in ways contrary to the provisions of the Transportation Corporations Law. The Legislature has defined the powers of corporations and it can redefine them by statutory amendment to promote the public interest. Moreover, plaintiff is not being compelled to offer service greater or different than authorized by its original charter. Gas corporations are charged with the duty of supplying gas for public use (see, Transportation Corporations Law § 10; see also, Public Service Law § 65) and none of the statutes regulating plaintiff indicate that duty is to be fulfilled only by selling its own gas (see, e.g., Public Service Law § 2 [10], [11]; §§ 64, 65). The transportation of customer-owned gas also results in gas being supplied to members of the public and is thus consistent with the general duties imposed upon gas corporations.

Public Utilities -- Validity of Statute Compelling Utilities to Transport Customer-Owned Natural Gas -- Effect of Utility's Franchises

6. There is nothing in plaintiff utility's franchises which inhibits defendant Public Service Commission (PSC) from implementing Public Service Law § 66-d (2) (as applied to plaintiff by PSC Opinion No. 85-6), which authorize the PSC to require certain utilities to transport customer-owned natural gas through their pipelines if the utility has excess capacity, receives reasonable compensation for doing so and if transportation of the customer-owned gas will not burden the utility or its ratepayers or impair the over-all quality of service to customers. Whether plaintiff's franchises specify that the gas it is to transport is to be owned by the franchisee or not, their terms may not be used to limit the State's lawful exercise of its police powers. The franchises are no more than commitments by various local governments to plaintiff to use public property in exchange for supplying a public service and the State may revoke or modify them to impose new service obligations on the franchisee to promote the public good.

 

33 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Parkview Associates v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 274; 519 N.E.2d 1372; 525 N.Y.S.2d 176; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 88


January 11, 1988, Argued  
February 9, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended November 8, 1988.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff builder appealed from a judgment of Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed the dismissal of plaintiff's petition for review of an administrative decision, which partially revoked plaintiff's building permit, against defendants.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff builder sought a permit to construct a new building near an area where the height of buildings was limited. When the building permit was issued, the issuer erroneously interpreted the map, finding plaintiff's location to fall outside the restricted area when in fact it was located within the restricted area. The Board of Standards and Appeals upheld the later partial revocation of plaintiff's building permit, and plaintiff sought judicial review. The trial court dismissed the petition, and the appellate court affirmed. Plaintiff appealed, and the court affirmed. There was no discretion to issue a building permit that failed to conform with applicable provisions of the law, and it was permissible to revoke a permit that had been issued in error when the conditions were such that the permit should not have been issued. Further, estoppel could not be invoked against a municipal agency to prevent it from discharging its statutory duties, including the enforcement of zoning laws.


OUTCOME: Judgment affirming the dismissal of plaintiff builder's complaint for judicial review of an administrative decision to partially revoke the building permit issued to it was affirmed. It was permissible to revoke a permit that had been issued in error and where the conditions were such that the permit should never have been issued. Estoppel could not be asserted against a municipal agency to prevent it from carrying out its statutory duties.


HEADNOTES

Estoppel -- Equitable Estoppel -- Estoppel Not Available to Preclude Enforcement of Provisions of Zoning Laws -- Mistaken or Erroneous Issuance of Building Permit -- Doctrine of Reasonable Diligence by Good-Faith Inquirer

1. Insofar as estoppel is not available to preclude a municipality from enforcing the provisions of its zoning laws and the mistaken or erroneous issuance of a permit does not estop a municipality from correcting errors, even where there are harsh results, respondent City of New York should not be estopped from revoking that portion of the original building permit issued to petitioner which violated the long-standing zoning limits imposed by the applicable Special Park Improvement District (P.I.D.) resolution with respect to the height of new buildings in that district, notwithstanding that petitioner's building has already been constructed in excess of the P.I.D. resolution's height limitations in reliance on the original permit. Even if there was municipal error in one zoning map and in the mistaken administrative issuance of the original permit, those factors would be completely outweighed in this case by the doctrine that reasonable diligence would have readily uncovered for a good-faith inquirer the existence of the unequivocal limitations of 150 feet in the original binding metes and bounds description of the enabling legislation, and that this boundary has never been changed by the Board of Estimate; thus, the rare exception to the unavailability of estoppel against governmental entities may not be invoked in this case.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- New York City Zoning Resolution -- Partial Revocation of Erroneously Issued Building Permit

2. The New York City Department of Buildings has no discretion to issue a building permit which fails to conform with applicable provisions of law and the Commissioner of Buildings may revoke a permit which "has been issued in error and conditions are such that a permit should not have been issued" (Administrative Code of City of New York §§ 27-191, 27-197). Further, discrepancies between the zoning map and the enabling resolution are controlled by the specifics of the resolution (New York City Zoning Resolution §§ 11-22, 12-01). Accordingly, the original building permit issued to petitioner was invalid where it authorized construction within the 150-foot Special Park Improvement District (P.I.D.) above 19 stories in violation of New York City Zoning Resolution § 92-06 and, therefore, the subsequent action of the Board of Standards and Appeals, in ratifying the decision of the Commissioner of Buildings partially revoking petitioner's permit to the extent that it authorized construction to a height of 31 stories within the 150-foot P.I.D., had a sound legal basis.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Partial Revocation of Building Permit -- Claim of Unconstitutional Taking -- Effect of Failure to Apply for Variance

3. In a proceeding pursuant to CPLR article 78, arising from respondent City of New York's partial revocation of a building permit erroneously issued to petitioner, pursuant to which petitioner had already constructed a building in excess of the height limitations of applicable zoning provisions, petitioner's claim that the City's action constitutes a taking without due process of law or just compensation may not be addressed by the Court of Appeals on petitioner's appeal from the Appellate Division's affirmance of the dismissal of the petition because petitioner had failed to apply for a variance.

 

34 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ruz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 942; 519 N.E.2d 614; 524 N.Y.S.2d 668; 1988 N.Y. LEXIS 3


January 5, 1988, Argued  
January 14, 1988, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Appellate Review

Defendant's contention that a surcharge imposed upon him pursuant to Penal Law § 60.35 was unconstitutional as applied to him since it violated the ex post facto prohibition in the US Constitution (art I, § 10 [cl 1]) was not preserved for review in the Court of Appeals inasmuch as it was not brought to the attention of the court at the time of sentence. Other constitutional challenges were similarly unpreserved.

Elizabeth J. Vila, Philip L. Weinstein, and Helen A. Marino for appellant.

Paul T. Gentile, District Attorney (David  [**2] K. Bertan and Billie Manning of counsel), for respondent.

 

35 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


McCann v. Scaduto


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 164; 519 N.E.2d 309; 524 N.Y.S.2d 398; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 19993


October 5, 1987, Argued  
December 23, 1987, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended November 8, 1988.



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order reversed, with costs, proceeding converted to a declaratory judgment action and judgment granted in favor of petitioners in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a consolidated action, petitioner former property owners challenged the forfeiture of their homes to defendant purchasers under the real estate tax collection provisions of the Nassau County N.Y. Admin. Code (Code). The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department determined that constructive notice of a tax deficiency was sufficient and purchasers could retain title. The former property owners appealed.


OVERVIEW: Under the provisions of the Code, unpaid property taxes became a lien against each property that could be purchased with only notice by publication. Nassau County, N.Y. Admin. Code § 5-37.0(a),(c). The purchasers served a notice to redeem to the record owner and if he or she failed to redeem, the purchaser took title. The former property owners contended that they were denied due process because they had not received actual notice of the tax lien sales, they had been denied any hearing before conveyance of the property, and that the notice they did receive was inadequate to inform them of the situation. The court held that due process required a balancing of the State's interests and the individual's interest in actually being informed of proceedings affecting rights or property. Because the interests of the former property owners was substantially affected by an act of government, and because the owner's name and address were known, due process required that actual notice be given. Further, N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law §§ 1002(4), 1014(3), 2006, required personal service upon the property owner of both the notice of sale of the tax lien and the notice to redeem.


OUTCOME: The court reversed each case and ordered that the proceedings be converted to declaratory judgment actions, the tax lien forfeiture provisions of the Code be declared unconstitutional, the deeds be declared a nullity and the former property owners be permitted to redeem their properties.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Former Real Estate Tax Collection Enforcement Provisions of Nassau County Administrative Code -- Due Process of Law -- No Actual Notice of Tax Lien Sale

1. Where the interest of a property owner will be substantially affected by an act of government, and where the owner's name and address are known, due process requires that actual notice be given. Accordingly, the failure of the former real estate tax collection enforcement provisions of the Nassau County Administrative Code to provide for actual notice to the property owner of a tax lien sale in that statutory scheme, constitutes a deprivation of due process and, therefore, those former provisions are unconstitutional. The Nassau County tax lien sale commences enforcement proceedings that may terminate 24 months later in forfeiture upon the mere request of the tax lien purchaser, without any requirement or opportunity for a hearing or any court intervention. The tax lien sale is a condition precedent to the transfer of title. Moreover, substantial interest, penalties and expenses accrue upon that sale. Thus, the tax lien sale, in the context of this Code, creates "momentous consequences" for the homeowner and -- balanced against these consequences -- requiring that a notice be mailed to a person whose name and address are known imposes a minimal burden on the County. Actual notice is therefore required.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Former Real Estate Tax Collection Enforcement Provisions of Nassau County Administrative Code -- Due Process of Law -- No Actual Notice of Tax Lien Sale -- Actual Notice of Notice to Redeem

2. The failure of the former real estate tax collection enforcement provisions of the Nassau County Administrative Code to provide property owners with actual notice of tax lien sales constitutes a deprivation of due process and, therefore, those provisions are unconstitutional. Further, the Nassau County statutory scheme cannot withstand constitutional scrutiny because the Code requires mailing of the notice to redeem to the property owner three months before the deed is conveyed to the purchaser of the tax lien. What is reasonable for purposes of notice is usually a legislative policy determination; however, whether legislative choice passes constitutional muster is a decision for the courts. The mechanism designed by the Nassau County legislators to provide what they deemed was adequate notice to property owners contemplated that before automatic forfeiture, there would be a 24-month redemption period. It is their failure to provide due process notice of the tax lien sale that has shrunk that period to a mere three months and defeated the legislative intention. Moreover, notice which does not afford a realistic opportunity to produce the funds necessary to avoid forfeiture of the title or sell the encumbered property does not afford due process. The truncated three-month period would in any event be troubling as satisfying the due process notice requirement, particularly where very large surpluses are at stake.

Taxation -- Tax Liens, Tax Sales and Tax Titles -- Declaration of Unconstitutionality of Former Real Estate Tax Collection Enforcement Provisions of Nassau County Administrative Code -- Retroactivity

3. Inasmuch as the Court of Appeals declaration that the former real estate tax collection enforcement provisions of the Nassau County Administrative Code are unconstitutional could have broad, unsettling effect on the marketability of otherwise settled titles to property, the court's decision is to have no general retroactive application and shall apply only to cases where tax titles are still in the normal litigating process.

 

36 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Matt v. Larocca


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 154; 518 N.E.2d 1172; 524 N.Y.S.2d 180; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 19884


November 13, 1987, Argued  
December 21, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the New York State Department of Transportation (department), sought review of a judgment of the Supreme Court of New York, which granted respondent employee's petition in his action under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 that challenged the department's determination to discharge the employee after he had refused to answer questions in his capacity as a supervisory employee in the department's investigation of wrongdoing.


OVERVIEW: The employee filed suit, asserting that his discharge violated his constitutionally guaranteed right against self-incrimination because he was not informed by the department at the investigatory proceeding under N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 61 that he was entitled by operation of law to immunity from the use of his answers in any subsequent criminal prosecution. The court found that the department did not have the power either to confer the immunity or to define or alter its breadth. The employee was assisted and advised by counsel that was present throughout the hearing, a situation that did not implicate the danger faced by witnesses testifying before a grand jury. Insofar as the employee was not requested to waive his right to immunity before answering questions specifically, directly, and narrowly relating to his official duties, his dismissal did not violate fundamental fairness or his privilege against self-incrimination. Moreover, there was substantial evidence to support the department's determination that the employee willfully refused to answer the questions posed, and dismissal was not so disproportionate as to be shocking to one's sense of fairness.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court and reinstated the department's determination.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Termination of Employment -- Refusal to Answer Questions Relating to Official Duties -- Failure of State to Inform Public Employee of Automatic Attachment of Immunity to Compelled Answers

1. When a public employee is compelled to answer questions or face removal upon refusing to do so, the responses are cloaked with immunity automatically, and neither the compelled statements nor their fruits may thereafter be used against the employee in a subsequent criminal prosecution. However, the State may compel any person enjoying a public trust to account for his activities and may terminate his services if he refuses to answer relevant questions, or furnishes information indicating that he is no longer entitled to public confidence. What is proscribed as unconstitutional is to condition public employment upon a waiver of the privilege against self-incrimination. Thus, insofar as petitioner, a supervisory employee with the Department of Transportation, was not requested to waive his right to immunity before answering questions specifically, directly and narrowly relating to his official duties in a civil proceeding instituted pursuant to Public Officers Law § 61 to investigate disciplinary charges of work-related misconduct, petitioner's dismissal for refusing to answer those questions did not violate fundamental fairness or his privilege against self-incrimination despite the State's failure to inform him that immunity automatically attached by operation of law before ordering him to answer the questions. As the Commissioner's representative at the investigatory proceeding did not have the power to confer immunity, or to modify the immunity to which petitioner was entitled, there is no basis for concluding that he nonetheless had an affirmative obligation to inform petitioner of the automatic attachment of immunity.

Civil Service -- Disciplinary Hearings -- Willful Refusal to Answer Questions Relating to Performance of Employee's Official Duties -- Substantial Evidence -- Excessiveness of Penalty

2. There is substantial evidence in the record to support the determination of the respondent Commissioner of the Department of Transportation that petitioner, a supervisory employee with 34 years of service in the Department's Waterways Division, willfully refused to answer questions directly relating to the performance of his official duties at a civil proceeding instituted pursuant to Public Officers Law § 61 to investigate disciplinary charges of work-related misconduct, and dismissal under the circumstances is not so disproportionate to the offense as to be shocking to one's sense of fairness.

 

37 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Boreali v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


71 N.Y.2d 1; 517 N.E.2d 1350; 523 N.Y.S.2d 464; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 19259; 13 OSHC (BNA) 1498; 2 I.E.R. Cas. (BNA) 1213; 1988 OSHD (CCH) P28,132; 108 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P55,850


October 13, 1987, Argued  
November 25, 1987, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended November 8, 1988.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the Commissioner of the State Department of Health, the Public Health Council (Council), and Council employees, challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a trial court's order finding that the smoking policies adopted by the Council were invalid and unenforceable.


OVERVIEW: The Council promulgated a comprehensive code to govern tobacco smoking in areas open to the public. The Legislature gave the Council broad authority to promulgate regulations on matters concerning the public health pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 225(5)(a). Appellees, affected businesses, groups, and individuals, asked for declaratory relief, and the trial court granted summary judgment, which was affirmed by the appellate division. The court affirmed the decisions of the lower courts. The broad grant of authority did not contravene the principle that the legislative branch of government cannot cede its fundamental policy-making responsibility to an administrative agency. The Council exceeded the permissible scope of its mandate by using it as a basis for engaging in inherently legislative activities. Enactments conferring authority on administrative agencies in broad or general terms must be interpreted in light of the limitations that the Constitution imposes (N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1). Striking the proper balance among health concerns, cost, and privacy interests was a uniquely legislative function.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate division, which affirmed the trial court's judgment that the anti-smoking regulations adopted by the Council were null and void.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law -- Validity of Regulation -- No-Smoking Regulations -- Separation of Powers

1. The Public Health Council (PHC) overstepped the boundaries of its lawfully delegated authority, running afoul of the constitutional separation of powers doctrine, when it promulgated a comprehensive code to govern tobacco smoking in areas that are open to the public (10 NYCRR part 25). While the Legislature has given the PHC broad authority to promulgate regulations on matters concerning the public health, the scope of the PHC's authority under its enabling statute (Public Health Law § 225 [5] [a]) must be deemed limited by its role as an administrative, rather than a legislative, body. The PHC usurped the latter role and thereby exceeded its legislative mandate, when, following the Legislature's inability to reach an acceptable balance, the Council weighed the concerns of nonsmokers, smokers, affected businesses and the general public and, without any legislative guidance, reached its own conclusions about the proper accommodation among those competing interests. In view of the political, social and economic, rather than technical, focus of the resulting regulatory scheme, the PHC's actions were ultra vires. Further, the "separability" provision of the PHC's rules (10 NYCRR 25.7) cannot be used to save those rules from the conclusion that, taken as a whole, they are invalid.

Administrative Law -- Validity of Regulation -- No-Smoking Regulations -- Preemption of Field by State Legislature

2. By enacting Public Health Law article 13-E, which imposes restrictions on smoking in a narrow class of public locations, the Legislature did not preempt the field of indoor smoking so as to preclude the Public Health Council's (PHC) promulgation of regulations prohibiting smoking in a wide variety of indoor areas that are open to the public (10 NYCRR part 25). The Legislature has given the PHC a wide field for the exercise of its regulatory authority (Public Health Law § 225 [5] [a]), and nothing in the Legislature's 1975 adoption of a limited antismoking provision (Public Health Law art 13-E) suggests a legislative intention to narrow the statutory mandate or exclude the area of smoking restrictions. Although the PHC's regulations prohibit smoking in a wider variety of indoor settings than do the Legislature's enactments on the subject, both the regulations and the relevant statutes have a common underlying policy objective -- minimizing nonsmokers' exposure to environmental tobacco smoke.

 

38 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Replan Dev., Inc. v. Department of Housing Preservation & Dev.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 451; 517 N.E.2d 200; 522 N.Y.S.2d 485; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 18969


October 6, 1987, Argued  
November 19, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner real estate developer brought an action in the trial court, challenging defendant city agency's determination that it was ineligible for a tax exemption. The trial court dismissed the real estate developer's suit, and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed the decision of the trial court. The real estate developer appealed.


OVERVIEW: The real estate developer argued that, because the law allowed a tax exemption at the time he purchased the property, a subsequent change deprived it of due process because it acted in reliance on the inducement contained in the law at the time of its purchase. Additionally, the real estate developer argued that retroactive application unconstitutionally deprived the real estate of due process. The court rejected the real estate developer's argument and noted that retroactivity provisions in tax statutes were valid especially when the retroactivity extended for only a short period. The court noted that the real estate developer had been forewarned of a change in the legislation, and thus, its reliance on the old law was unreasonable. The real estate developer also conceded that the length of the legislation's retroactivity was valid. The court also found that the legislation had a valid public purpose.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate division, which affirmed the order of the trial court that dismissed the real estate developer's action.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Exemptions -- Real Property Tax -- Conversion of Single Resident Occupancy Dwellings -- Retroactive Application of Statute Repealing Exemption -- Due Process

Petitioner, who commenced renovation of two single room occupancy (SRO) buildings in April 1983 was not unconstitutionally deprived of due process by the retroactive application of the amended version of Real Property Tax Law § 489 (L 1983, ch 401, eff June 30, 1983, retroactive to June 1, 1982) to prevent petitioner from qualifying for the receipt of the tax exemption for the renovation of SRO buildings provided by Administrative Code of the City of New York former § J51-2.5 pursuant to the enabling legislation of Real Property Tax Law former § 489, which expired on June 1, 1982. The one-year period of retroactivity is not excessive, and the objectives of the retroactive application -- to forestall the loss of SRO housing and to discourage the precipitous eviction of tenants -- are valid public purposes. More importantly, petitioner was forewarned that the State authorization for the exemption expired on June 1, 1982 thereby calling into question the continued validity of the Administrative Code provision after that date. Accordingly, petitioner may not now claim he entertained a settled reasonable expectation of entitlement to the City's exemption based upon renovations he did not commence until April 1983 and, since he could not have justifiably relied on the tax inducement as it existed in 1982, application of this particular retroactive provision to petitioner did not constitute an unconstitutional deprivation of due process.

 

39 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Scruggs-Leftwich v. Rivercross Tenants' Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 849; 517 N.E.2d 1337; 523 N.Y.S.2d 451; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 19061


October 15, 1987, Argued  
November 19, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant commissioner challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which reversed, on the law, a supreme court judgment permanently enjoining the shareholders of appellee tenants' corporation from selling their cooperative stock to prospective buyers not selected from a tenant waiting list and directing the tenants' corporation to establish such a list.


OVERVIEW: The tenants' corporation operated a residential apartment cooperative facility, and was subject to regulations governing what was commonly known as Mitchell-Lama housing, including 9 NYCRR 1727-1.1 and 1727-1.3, which provided that apartments could be resold only to prospective purchasers who were on a waiting list. After a prospectus disseminated by the Urban Development Corporation (UDC) provided that shareholders could sell their apartments to anyone they so desired, the commissioner of the UDC's successor, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, sought an injunction. The supreme court permanently enjoining the shareholders of the tenants' corporation from selling their cooperative stock to prospective buyers not selected from a tenant waiting list and directing the tenants' corporation to establish such a list. The court of appeals reversed, but the commissioner prevailed on appeal. The court ruled that the commissioner was acting in a governmental, not proprietary, capacity, and that estoppel could not be invoked against a municipal agency to prevent it from discharging its statutory duties.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate division that reversed the supreme court judgment permanently enjoining the shareholders of appellee tenants' corporation from selling their cooperative stock to prospective buyers not selected from a tenant waiting list and directing the tenants' corporation to establish such a list. The court reinstated the judgment of the supreme court.


HEADNOTES

Public Housing -- Limited-Profit Housing Companies -- Waiting List for Sales of Cooperative Stock

1. In a proceeding to enforce an order of the Commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) directing respondent State-assisted limited-profit housing company to establish a tenant waiting list for sales of stock allocated to its Mitchell-Lama cooperative apartments (9 NYCRR 1727-1.1 et seq.], an order of the Appellate Division, which dismissed the petition and annulled the DHCR's order, is reversed and the judgment of Supreme Court granting the petition is reinstated. Although the prospectus disseminated by the Urban Development Corporation (as predecessor to DHCR) provided that respondent's shareholders could sell their apartments to anyone they desired and that respondent did not have a right of first refusal, it also provided that to the extent there was any ambiguity in the terms of the offering plan or any conflict with laws and regulations governing respondent, such conflicts were to be resolved in favor of the applicable laws and regulations. Accordingly, since DHCR was acting in a governmental and not proprietary capacity in exercising its regulatory powers over respondent, and since estoppel generally may not be invoked against a municipal agency to prevent it from discharging its statutory duties, the factual setting in this case does not warrant an exception to that doctrine. The statements that all conflicts were to be resolved in favor of the laws and regulations were also contained in the proprietary leases and purchase agreements, and thus respondent's shareholders were on notice that they might be subject to the waiting list and other regulatory requirements.

Public Housing -- Limited-Profit Housing Companies -- Waiting Lists for Sales of Cooperative Stock

2. In a proceeding to enforce an order of the Commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal directing respondent State-assisted limited-profit housing company to establish a tenant waiting list for sales of stock allocated to its Mitchell-Lama cooperative apartments (9) NYCRR 1727-1.1 et seq.), wherein respondents alleged that the prospectus provided for resale of apartments to anyone the shareholders desired, the housing company's constitutional contract clause challenge lacks merit. The express terms of the contract between the shareholders and the cooperative corporation provided that the right to resell an apartment was subordinated to the applicable statutory and regulatory scheme. Inasmuch as the regulatory scheme provided that apartments must be resold to persons on a waiting list, there has been no impairment of the shareholders' contractual rights.

 

40 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hodes v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 364; 515 N.E.2d 612; 520 N.Y.S.2d 933; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 18891


September 3, 1987, Argued  
October 22, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Commissioner of Health of the State of New York (commissioner) filed an action against petitioner nursing home owners. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) affirmed a judgment of the lower court permanently enjoining the commissioner from revoking the nursing home owners' operating certificate as a result of their 1979 industry-related felony convictions. The commissioner appealed.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner contended that the administrative proceedings initiated against the nursing home owners were not barred under the doctrine of res judicata. The commissioner also contended that neither the prior final judgments nor the operating certificates themselves conferred on the nursing home owners constitutionally protected rights, which would have been impaired by the application to them of N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2806(5), as amended. The court stated that the vested rights doctrine did not preclude application of § 2806(5) to the nursing home owners. The court found that there was a strong public interest to be served by permitting § 2806(5) to be enforced as amended in 1983 and that the public interest overrode the nursing home owners' claimed constitutional objection. The court concluded that a second revocation proceeding was not unfair to nursing home owners in any sense that was protected by law because the proceeding was, to the contrary, supported by supervening considerations of public interest that have been properly balanced by the legislature. Thus, neither the vested rights doctrine nor res judicata foreclosed a second revocation proceeding under § 2806(5).


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment, with costs, and dismissed the nursing home owners' petition.


HEADNOTES

Health -- Nursing Homes -- Retroactive Application of Amended Statute to Revoke Operating Certificate -- Final Judgment under Prior Statute Denying Revocation -- Doctrine of Vested Rights

1. The doctrine of vested rights does not foreclose a second administrative proceeding pursuant to Public Health Law § 2806 (5), as amended in 1983 (L 1983, ch 584), for automatic revocation of petitioners' nursing home operating certificate owing to their industry-related felony convictions where the final judgment in the first revocation proceeding denied automatic revocation because the then applicable law (Public Health Law § 2806 [5], as amended by L 1981, ch 607) was impermissibly at odds with Correction Law § 701. The 1983 amendments to section 2806 (5) -- explicitly made retroactive by the Legislature -- were intended to apply to all licensed operators, even those like petitioners who had litigated the automatic revocation issue to a final judgment in their favor under preexisting law. The doctrine of vested rights, pursuant to which a judgment becomes an inviolable property right once all avenues of appeal have been exhausted which thereafter may not constitutionally be abridged by subsequent legislation, is, however, conclusory, and a fiction that hides many unmentioned considerations of fairness to the parties, reliance on preexisting law, the extent of retroactivity and the nature of the public interest to be served by the law. Balancing the various factors upon which the constitutionality of retroactive legislation depends, the vested rights doctrine does not preclude application of the amended statute to these petitioners. There is a strong public interest, that of policing the nursing home industry and removing persons convicted of industry-related felonies from the operation of nursing homes, to be served by permitting the law to be enforced as amended in 1983, and the public interest overrides petitioners' claimed constitutional objection.

Health -- Nursing Homes -- Retroactive Application of Amended Statute to Revoke Operating Certificate -- Final Judgment under Prior Statute Denying Revocation -- Res Judicata

2. The doctrine of res judicata does not foreclose a second administrative proceeding pursuant to Public Health Law § 2806 (5), as amended in 1983 (L 1983, ch 584), for automatic revocation of petitioners' nursing home operating certificate owing to their industry-related felony convictions where the final judgment in the first revocation proceeding denied automatic revocation because the then applicable law (Public Health Law § 2806 [5], as amended by L 1981, ch 607) was impermissibly at odds with Correction Law § 701. Although both revocation proceedings instituted against petitioners are based on the same felony convictions, seeking the same remedy, the statutory rights of the parties were altered between the first and second proceedings. This being so, the two proceedings against petitioners can be said to lack the requisite identity for application of res judicata. For compelling reasons in the public interest, the Legislature provided that all persons holding operating certificates at the time of the amended law should be equally subject to automatic forfeiture upon conviction of an industry-related felony. If the pending proceeding against petitioners under the amended statute were precluded by res judicata, petitioners would be left with a license to operate a public health facility despite their convictions and despite the fact that others operating comparable facilities automatically lose their licenses upon comparable convictions. A second revocation proceeding is not unfair to petitioners in any sense that is protected by law; this proceeding is, to the contrary, supported by supervening considerations of public interest that have been properly balanced by the Legislature.

 

41 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Diamond v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 338; 514 N.E.2d 1356; 520 N.Y.S.2d 732; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 18884; 45 Fair Empl. Prac. Cas. (BNA) 1562


October 12, 1987, Argued  
October 15, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff judges appealed a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which reversed a trial court order that declared that N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 25(b) and N.Y. Jud. Law § 23 violated the judges' rights to due process of law and equal protection of the laws in regard to the required retirement of judges and justices at age 70.


OVERVIEW: The administrative board determined that statutory protection required that appointed judges be allowed to continue to the end of their appointive terms, but that elected judges had to retire at age 70 because the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA), 29 U.S.C.S. § 623, did not apply to elected state officers. The judges contended that in view of the ADEA and the administrative board's interpretation thereof, the N.Y. Const. and N.Y. Jud. Law provisions denied them due process and equal protection. On appeal, the court held that age was not a suspect class and that the state policy requiring retirement of judges was not irrational. The state was free to pursue the policy to the extent that doing so was consistent with the ADEA.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appeals court's reversal of the trial court's findings in favor of the judges.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- Mandatory Retirement -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Age Discrimination in Employment Act -- Mandatory Retirement of Elected Judges at Age 70 -- No Mandatory Retirement Age for Appointed Judges

1. NY Constitution, article VI, § 25 (b) and Judiciary Law § 23, which require retirement of Judges and Justices of the Unified Court System at age 70, as applied to plaintiffs, various State Judges, do not deny them their constitutional right to equal protection of the laws because of the Administrative Board's interpretation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (29 USC § 623), which prohibits discrimination in employment based on age, against persons age 70 and above, to require that appointed Judges be allowed to continue to the end of their appointive terms, notwithstanding their age, but that elected Judges must retire at age 70 because the Federal statute, by its terms, does not apply to elected State officers (29 USC § 630 [f]). Age is not a suspect class and therefore the appropriate standard of review is whether the classifications created are rationally related to some State interest. Applying that standard, the Administrative Board did not err in applying the Federal statute as written, nor does any denial of plaintiffs' rights to equal protection of the laws result from the joint operation of the State and Federal statutes and the State constitutional provision. That the State policy requiring retirement of Judges is partially frustrated because the Federal statute preempts it with respect to appointed Judges does not render the policy irrational and the State is free to pursue that policy to the extent doing so is consistent with Federal law.

Judges -- Mandatory Retirement -- Exemption of Certificated Judges from Age Discrimination in Employment Act -- Mandatory Retirement at Age 70

2. Certificated Supreme Court Justices hold office by reason of their election to the Supreme Court, and are exempt from the provisions of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (29 USC § 623), which prohibits discrimination in employment based on age, against persons age 70 and above; consequently, their tenure is limited by Judiciary Law § 115. Further, such Justices' constitutional rights have not been abridged because they have been held elected, not appointed, officers who are exempt from the provisions of the Federal statute.

 

42 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


41 Kew Gardens Rd. Associates v. Tyburski


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 325; 514 N.E.2d 1114; 520 N.Y.S.2d 544; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 18652


September 1, 1987, Argued  
October 13, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee property owners brought a declaratory judgment action against appellant city challenging Local Law No. 63, City of New York, N.Y., Admin. Code of the City of New York § 11-208.1 (1986). The Supreme Court, Queens County (New York), granted the city's motion for summary judgment, denying city's cross motion, and declared the law invalid. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York) affirmed. The city appealed the order.


OVERVIEW: Local Law No. 63, City of New York, N.Y., Admin. Code of the City of New York § 11-208.1 (1986) required property owners to submit income and expense statements for income-producing properties to the city for preparation of assessments. The court held that the local law was facially valid. The court concluded that the city had express authority to enact the local law under N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(1)(ii)(c)(2) because the filing of income and expenses statement related essentially to the "preparation of assessments." The court found that the local law was neither vague nor violative of equal protection. The terms the property owner disputed were defined by judicial construction or were commonly used in other statutes without definition. The local law did not conflict with N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 1802, as they complement one another. The local law dealt with pre-assessment valuation information while § 1802 dealt with methods of assessment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the court of appeals, and granted the city's cross motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Home Rule Power of City of New York -- Validity of Local Law Requiring Owners of Income-Producing Property to Furnish Income and Expense Statements in Preparation for Assessment

1. Local Laws, 1986, No. 63 of the City of New York (Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-208.1) which, with certain exceptions, requires owners of income-producing property in New York City to furnish income and expense statements to the Commissioner of Finance in preparation for real property assessment, is a valid exercise of the City's home rule power. Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 (1) (ii) (c) (2) supplies the express authority to enact Local Law No. 63 because the filing of the income and expense statements relates essentially to the "preparation of assessments". Inasmuch as Local Law No. 63, by its terms, requires the filing of information related solely to the operation of the income-producing property, it is neither an exercise of impermissible in personam taxing jurisdiction over individual property owners nor is it inconsistent with the so-called in rem nature of the real property tax as defined by the State Legislature (see, RPTL 304). The filing requirement of this local law does not relieve a municipality, as an assessor, from its statutorily imposed nondelegable duty of determining the value of the property to be taxed, nor on its face does it unfairly or inappropriately shift the burden of doing so to the real property taxpayer. Moreover, the City's enactment does not conflict with RPTL 1802 because RPTL article 18 deals exclusively with methods of assessment and Local Law No. 63 deals with preassessment valuation information.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- New York City Local Law Requiring Owners of Income-Producing Property to Furnish Income and Expense Statements in Preparation for Assessment -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Due Process of Law

2. Local Laws, 1986, No. 63 of the City of New York (Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-208.1) which, with certain exceptions, requires owners of income-producing property in New York City to furnish income and expense statements to the Commissioner of Finance in preparation for real property assessment, is constitutional on its face. The local ordinance is not inconsistent with the State Constitution on equal protection grounds. While Local Law No. 63 distinguishes between taxpayers based on the size or value of the property, that does not per se render an enactment unconstitutional unless there is no rational basis for the classifications. The City advances several particular justifications for exempting and thus distinguishing smaller property owners from the filing requirements. Further, Local Law No. 63 is not unconstitutionally vague. Due process requires only a reasonable degree of certainty so that individuals of ordinary intelligence are not forced to guess at the meaning of statutory terms, and here that standard is satisfied because the disputed terms (e.g., "income", "expense", "assessed value" and "current fiscal year") are defined by judicial construction or are commonly used in other statutes without further definition.

Municipal Corporations -- Promulgation of Rules and Regulations by City of New York -- What Constitutes "Rules and Regulations"

3. In a declaratory judgment action involving the validity of Local Laws, 1986, No. 63 of the City of New York (Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-208.1) which, with certain exceptions, requires owners of income-producing property in New York City to furnish income and expense statements to the Commissioner of Finance in preparation for real property assessment, certain letters mailed to property owners, which did not create any new exemption or requirements, but merely informed non-"income-producing" property owners that they need not file a statement under Local Law No. 63, did not constitute official "rules and regulations" requiring promulgation pursuant to New York City Charter § 1105.

 

43 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Morell v. Balasubramanian


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 297; 514 N.E.2d 1101; 520 N.Y.S.2d 530; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 18649


September 9, 1987, Argued  
October 8, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff administrator appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which dismissed plaintiff's malpractice complaint against defendant state employees and held that the state was the real party in interest in such an action.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff administrator commenced two malpractice actions against the state and against defendant state employees. A lower court dismissed plaintiff's complaint against defendants, holding that the state was the real party in interest in such an action. The court reversed the lower court's order and denied defendants' motion to dismiss. The court held that defendants were the real parties in interest, not the state, and that, therefore, the lower court had subject matter jurisdiction. The court determined that a suit against a state officer would be held to be one which was really asserted against the state when it arose from actions or determinations of the officer made in his or her official role and involved rights asserted not against the officer individually but solely against the state. The court found further that N.Y. Pub. Off. Law §17 did not impose direct liability upon the state for the negligent acts or omissions of its employees or make the state the real party in interest in actions against them, and did not purport to diminish the remedies available to an injured party. The court concluded that there should have been a reversal and a reinstatement of the complaint.


OUTCOME: The court reversed a lower court's order dismissing plaintiff administrator's malpractice complaint against defendant state employees and holding that the state was the real party in interest because defendants were the real parties in interest, not the state, and therefore the lower court had subject matter jurisdiction where New York law did not impose direct liability upon the state for the negligent acts or omissions of its employees.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Jurisdiction -- Jurisdiction of Supreme Court to Entertain Negligence Action against State Employees -- Alleged Breach of Duty of Care Owed by State Employees Directly to Injured Party

Where a suit against a State agent or officer is in tort for damages arising from the breach of a duty owed individually by such agent or officer directly to the injured party, the employees are the real parties in interest -- not the State, even though it could be held secondarily liable for the tortious acts under respondeat superior -- and, therefore, Supreme Court has subject matter jurisdiction. Accordingly, in a malpractice action commenced in Supreme Court against defendants, State-employed physicians, to recover damages allegedly resulting from defendants' negligent medical treatment of plaintiff's decedent, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed Supreme Court's order denying defendants' motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction ( CPLR 3211 [a] [2]) and dismissed the complaint, is reversed and defendants' motion to dismiss the complaint is denied. Plaintiff's suit against defendants individually for an alleged breach of the duty of care owed by them directly to decedent was not one against State officers as representatives of the State in their official capacity which had to be brought in the Court of Claims. That plaintiff could have chosen to proceed in the Court of Claims directly against the State based on its vicarious responsibility for defendants' actions does not make the State the real party in interest in the suit against defendants in Supreme Court. Nothing in Public Officers Law § 17 (which provides for the defense and indemnification of State employees by the State for acts or omissions in the course of employment) imposes direct liability upon the State for the negligent acts or omissions of its employees or makes the State the real party in interest in actions against them; the statute does not purport to diminish the remedies available to an injured party.

 

44 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


McGee v. Korman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 225; 513 N.E.2d 236; 519 N.Y.S.2d 350; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 18003


August 26, 1987, Argued  
August 27, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of McGee v Korman: Order reversed, without costs, and judgment of Supreme Court, Bronx County, dismissing the petition to validate the McGee designating petition reinstated.

In Matter of Korman v Sachs: Order reversed, without costs, and judgment of Supreme Court, Bronx County, granting the petition to invalidate the Backal designating petition reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant prospective candidates sought review of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which declared N.Y. Elec. Law § 6-136(2)(b) unconstitutional, reversed the trial court's judgment dismissing the petition of the prospective candidates, and directed the names of the prospective candidates be paced on the ballot.


OVERVIEW: The prospective candidates filed designating petitions for nomination as the democratic candidate for the office of Surrogate. The petitions to validate and invalidate the designating petitions on various grounds were filed in the trial court. The prospective candidates raised a constitutional challenge to the 5,000-signature requirement of § 6-136(2)(b), as being unduly burdensome in light of the shortened time period for collecting signatures following the recent removal of the sitting surrogate. The trial court held the provision constitutional and the appellate division reversed. The court reversed and held that the equal protection ground upon which the prospective candidates ultimately prevailed was first advanced at the lower court. Thus, there was no evidence that any notice was provided to the attorney-general that the differing signature requirements based upon geographic location were being challenged as unconstitutional and that that failure not only ignored fundamental principles of separation of powers, but also adversely affected the judicial review process which required a full presentation and record upon which constitutional determinations could be based.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate division's decision declaring the election law unconstitutional and ordered that the trial court's judgment be reinstated.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Matters Reviewable -- Constitutionality of State Statute -- Declaration of Unconstitutionality by Appellate Division Based Upon Ground First Advanced at Appellate Division -- No Notification to Attorney-General

1. A determination of invalidity of an enactment of the Legislature -- with ramifications beyond the parties and their immediate dispute -- necessarily must be founded upon an adequate record, the parties having properly raised their contentions and presented their proof in the lower courts. Also important to the procedure for challenging the constitutionality of a State statute is notification to the Attorney-General (see, Executive Law § 71; CPLR 1012), which ensures that all of the people of the State may be represented when the constitutionality of their laws is put in issue and serves the additional function of ensuring the development of an adequate record upon which the court may base its determination. Accordingly, two orders of the Appellate Division, which declared Election Law § 6-136 (2) (b) unconstitutional on the ground that the statute denied equal protection by requiring candidates for the same elective office in counties of substantially equivalent population to collect different numbers of signatures, are reversed. The equal protection ground upon which candidates Backal and McGee ultimately prevailed was first advanced at the Appellate Division. Further, there is no evidence that any notice was provided to the Attorney-General that the differing signature requirements based upon geographic location were being challenged as unconstitutional. Thus, the mechanism designed to afford a necessary opportunity to examine fully particular challenges to the constitutionality of statutes was not set in motion and not satisfied. Such failure not only ignores fundamental principles of separation of powers, but also adversely affects the judicial review process which requires a full presentation and record upon which constitutional determinations must be based.

Elections -- Designating Petitions -- Office of Surrogate of Bronx County -- Constitutionality of 5,000-Signature Requirement -- Access to Ballot -- Shortened Time Period for Collecting Signatures

2. In election proceedings involving cross challenges to the designating petitions filed by respondents Backal and McGee for nomination as the Democratic candidate for the office of Surrogate of Bronx County in the September 15, 1987 Democratic primary election, which office became vacant on July 2, 1987, by virtue of the removal of the sitting Surrogate, respondents' contention that the 5,000-signature requirement of section 6-136 (2) (b) is unduly burdensome in light of the shortened time period for collecting signatures following the recent removal of the sitting Surrogate, and thus unconstitutionally impedes access to the ballot, is without merit.

 

45 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bloomingdale Bros., Div. of Federated Dep't Stores, Inc. v. Chu


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 218; 513 N.E.2d 233; 519 N.Y.S.2d 347; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 18002


May 28, 1987, Argued  
July 2, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, and certified question answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent state tax commission (commission) challenged the judgment of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which annulled a determination of the commission sustaining a sales tax assessment on sales made at petitioner department store's out-of-state stores to non-New York residents who directed the store to have the merchandise delivered by common carrier as gifts to New York residents.


OVERVIEW: The commission appealed the judgment of the trial court, which annulled a determination of the commission sustaining a sales tax assessment on sales made at the department store's out-of-state stores to non-New York residents who directed the store to have the merchandise delivered by common carrier as gifts to New York residents. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court finding that the transactions were deemed to have occurred wholly outside New York State and that, consequently, the New York State sales tax was inapplicable. The sale required consideration pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 1101(b)(5) and that was given by the purchaser out-of-state. The recipients of the gifts within the state were wholly unconnected with the out-of-state exchange of consideration for transfer of title and possession to the purchaser. Therefore, the events at issue were comprised of two transactions: out-of-state sales, followed by gifts to New York residents. Neither transaction justified imposition of New York's sales tax.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court annulling a determination of the commission sustaining a sales tax assessment on sales made at the department store's out-of-state stores to non-New York residents who directed the store to have the merchandise delivered by common carrier as gifts to New York residents.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes -- Sales Tax Inapplicable to Non-New York Resident's Out-of-State Purchase of Gift Which Seller Arranges to Have Delivered to New York Resident

A non-New York resident's out-of-State purchase of a gift from a store owned by petitioner, which also does business in New York, is not subject to New York State sales tax (Tax Law § 1105 [a]) solely because, at the customer's request, petitioner arranges to have the gift delivered by common carrier to the ultimate intended recipient in New York. In such circumstances, the transaction must be deemed to have occurred wholly outside New York State and, consequently, the New York State sales tax is inapplicable. The act of delivering a gift to a New York resident by a common carrier engaged by petitioner does not constitute a transfer of possession within New York under Tax Law § 1101 (b) (5), subjecting the transaction to sales tax. Although delivery in New York has often been listed as a major factor indicating that a taxable New York sale has occurred, it is only that delivery which transfers control of the merchandise for consideration which marks a taxable event. The transactions in this case are not taxable as the purchasers' only control over the property was exercised out of State when they directed petitioner to send the merchandise to New York donees after the sale was completed. Most importantly, it cannot be ignored that the only New York nexus to these transactions is the location of the passive recipients of gifts. Since the recipients of the gifts within New York were wholly unconnected with the out-of-State exchange of consideration for transfer of title and possession to the purchaser, the events at issue were comprised of two transactions: out-of-State sales, followed by gifts to New York donees. Neither transaction justifies imposition of New York's sales tax.

 

46 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Suffolk Housing Services v. Brookhaven


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


70 N.Y.2d 122; 511 N.E.2d 67; 517 N.Y.S.2d 924; 1987 N.Y. LEXIS 16833


April 27, 1987, Argued  
June 11, 1987, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, affordable housing associations, sought review of an order entered in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), that affirmed a judgment that declared defendant town's zoning ordinance was valid.


OVERVIEW: The court found that housing associations essentially sought judicial rezoning through their action and declined to perform this legislative function. The court affirmed the lower courts' conclusion that associations failed to overcome the presumption of constitutionality of the town's zoning ordinance. The court noted that associations had not demonstrated that the town's efforts caused a shortage of shelter. Additionally findings showed that the inadequate development of low-cost multi-family housing stemmed from a lack of developers, rather than from the town's regulations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appeals court's order.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Zoning Ordinance of Town of Brookhaven -- Proper Exercise of Town's Zoning Power to Enable Development of Sufficient Low-Cost Shelter -- No Legislative Intervention by Judiciary to Rezone Town

In an action by plaintiffs seeking a judgment, among other things, declaring the zoning ordinance of the Town of Brookhaven void in its entirety because of the Town's failure to exercise its zoning power (Town Law § 261) to enable development of sufficient low-cost shelter and ordering the Town to take affirmative action to rectify the perceived housing shortage, an order of the Appellate Division which affirmed a Supreme Court judgment holding that the Town properly exercised its land use authority and concluding that plaintiffs had failed to overcome the presumption of the constitutionality of the zoning ordinance, is affirmed. There are affirmed factual findings by the courts below, for which there is support in the record, that numerous developer applications for multifamily and subsidized housing were approved despite the special permit procedures contained in the ordinance for such housing.
