The court found that the claimant had not established that the time involved in her case differed significantly from other malpractice actions or that she had been prejudiced as a result of it. The court recognized that the N.Y. Constitution gave the claimant a right of access to the civil courts to plead and prove her wrongful death cause of action but stated that application of § 148-a did not violate substantive due process because the statute bore a rational relationship to the need to curb rising malpractice insurance rates.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court, which dismissed the claimant's petition, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Mandamus -- When Remedy Available -- Proceeding to Compel Assembly of Medical Malpractice Panel

1. Petitioner's contention that the application to her of Judiciary Law § 148-a and the Appellate Division Rules (22 NYCRR 636.1), which provide for the mediation of medical malpractice claims by a medical malpractice panel as a condition precedent to the trial of a medical malpractice action, deny her access to the courts because of the delay in assembling a hearing panel is properly raised in a CPLR article 78 proceeding seeking mandamus to compel respondents Administrative Judge of the First Judicial District and Clerk of the Medical Malpractice Part of Supreme Court, New York County, to assemble a medical malpractice panel to review and report on the claim petitioner has asserted in a pending medical malpractice action.

Constitutional Law -- Right of Access to Courts -- Wrongful Death Cause of Action

2. Although our State Constitution does not create a per se right of access to civil courts, it does prohibit the Legislature from abrogating the cause of action for wrongful death. Unless the Legislature removes jurisdiction of such causes of action from the civil courts and provides an alternative remedy, as it has for a limited number of other causes of action, plaintiff, the administratrix of the estate of her husband who died as the result of alleged medical malpractice, has, by implication, a right of access to the civil courts to plead and prove her wrongful death cause of action.

Physicians and Surgeons -- Medical Malpractice Panel -- Unconstitutional Deprivation of Access to Courts -- Due Process

3. Judiciary Law § 148-a and the Rules of the Appellate Division (22 NYCRR 636.1), which provide for the mediation of medical malpractice claims by a medical malpractice panel as a condition precedent to the trial of a medical malpractice action, do not unconstitutionally deprive petitioner of access to the courts in violation of the requirements of due process. Judiciary Law § 148-a was one of a series of legislative responses to rising medical malpractice insurance rates. Since the legislation bears a rational relationship to the need of reducing the cost of medical malpractice litigation and helping preserve quality health care in this State, it does not violate substantive due process concerns. Insofar as petitioner claims that the mediation process is procedurally unfair because it has delayed the trial of her medical malpractice action, petitioner has failed to demonstrate that her case has not moved toward hearing in timely fashion. Petitioner has not established that the time involved in her case differs significantly from other malpractice actions or that she has been prejudiced as a result of it. Even if petitioner could demonstrate egregious delay, any claimed constitutional violation would in most, if not all, cases be obviated by other remedies available to her. Although nothing in the statute appears to permit respondents to waive pretrial malpractice mediation, they may, in their discretion, transfer the matter to another county. The Appellate Division declined to exercise its discretion to do so in this case and there is no basis for petitioner's claim that its determination resulted in an unconstitutional denial of due process.

 

66 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Church of St. Paul & St. Andrew v. Barwick


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 510; 496 N.E.2d 183; 505 N.Y.S.2d 24; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 18952


February 4, 1986, Argued  
June 5, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant church sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed a judgment of the supreme court that an action under New York City Landmarks Preservation Law, New York, N.Y. Admin. Code ch. 8-A, § 205-1.0 et seq., was not ripe for judicial review and granted a motion by appellee preservation commission for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The church developed a rebuilding program, which included plans for the complete renovation and construction of a commercial high-rise condominium on part of the property. The commission designated the church and parish house as a landmark. The church contended that the Landmarks Law, as applied to it by virtue of the commission's designation, effected a taking of property without due process or just compensation and interfered with the free exercise of its religion in contravention of various provisions of the Federal and New York State Constitutions. On the commission's motion for summary judgment, the supreme court dismissed the declaratory judgment action as not ripe. The appellate division affirmed. The court of appeals determined that the church's claim of constitutional harm was not ripe. The court found that the issue was not appropriate for judicial review because neither the finality requirement, nor the requirement that the issue be purely legal was met. Neither did the church make the second showing that the impact of the administrative action would be direct and immediate and felt in a concrete way. The church's status as a religious organization had no relevance.


OUTCOME: The order of the appellate division was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Ripeness of Issue for Judicial Determination -- Effect of Landmarks Law on Rebuilding Program of Church

1. In a declaratory judgment action, plaintiff church's claim that the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, ch 8-A, § 205-1.0 et seq.), as made applicable to plaintiff by virtue of the designation of its property as a landmark, is unconstitutional as applied because of the effect of that statute in obstructing or interfering with plaintiff's rebuilding program and subjecting plaintiff to immediate repair and maintenance requirements which carry criminal sanctions, thereby interfering with plaintiff's ability to carry out its charitable purpose, is not ripe for judicial determination. The issue presented is not "appropriate" for judicial review. Finality is lacking because the effect on plaintiff of being subjected to the Landmarks Law is incomplete and undetermined. The effect cannot be measured until plaintiff has sought and the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission (Commission) has granted or denied a certificate of appropriateness (Administrative Code § 207-6.0) or other approval of plaintiff's rebuilding program. Further, the issue presented is not "purely legal". The ultimate resolution of this constitutional issue will require a careful examination of facts not yet developed pertaining to plaintiff's financial situation and to whatever action the Commission takes with respect to plaintiff's rebuilding program. Nor has plaintiff made the required showing that the impact of the administrative action be "direct and immediate" and "felt in a concrete way"; as yet, there can be no such harm for there has been no interference. Neither can plaintiff claim direct and immediate harm from the imposition of the Landmarks Law's repair and maintenance requirements. Plaintiff's plans, which it refuses to submit to the Commission for approval, include renovation of the interior and exterior of the church and would, if approved, result in compliance with the very statutory requirements plaintiff contends the Commission's designation causes it to violate.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Ripeness of Issue for Judicial Determination -- Theoretical Subjection of Church to Criminal Sanctions of Landmarks Law

2. Plaintiff church's declaratory judgment action does not present an issue ripe for judicial determination to the extent that it is based on plaintiff's claim that the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, ch 8-A, § 205-1.0 et seq.) , as made applicable to plaintiff by virtue of the designation of its property as a landmark, is unconstitutional because plaintiff is theoretically subject to criminal sanctions for noncompliance with the Landmarks Law's repair and maintenance requirements (see, Administrative Code §§ 207-10.0, 207-16.0). Plaintiff does not allege that these requirements have been enforced; nothing in the record suggests that imposition of criminal sanctions has been threatened or even intimated. Moreover, plaintiff's claim will require a resolution of factual issues; and where, as here, a claim of unconstitutional application of a criminal statute involves factual as well as legal questions, it should be determined within the criminal proceeding itself.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Ripeness of Issue for Judicial Determination -- Effect of Plaintiff's Status as Church -- Claim Based on Prospective Interference of Landmarks Law with Free Exercise of Religion

3. In a declaratory judgment action based on plaintiff church's claim that the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law (Administrative Code of City of New York, ch 8-A, § 205-1.0 et seq.), as made applicable to plaintiff by virtue of the designation of its property as a landmark, is unconstitutional as applied because of the effect of that statute in obstructing or interfering with plaintiff's rebuilding program and subjecting plaintiff to immediate repair and maintenance requirements which carry criminal sanctions, the decision that plaintiff's claim is not ripe for judicial determination should not be different because plaintiff is a church and bases its constitutional claim in part on prospective interference with its right of free exercise of religion (see, US Const 1st Amend; NY Const, art I, § 3). Irrespective of plaintiff's status as a church, the ultimate determination of the constitutional issue must depend on future developments and particularly on what action the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission takes with respect to plaintiff's renovation plans. What plaintiff must prove to establish its constitutional claim as a charity under the established standard is neither dependent upon nor peculiar to its religious character. Plaintiff's claim -- founded on alleged interference with its building program and its inability to afford the repair requirements of the Landmarks Law -- takes on incidental First Amendment overtones only because it is a church. That fact is simply not germane to the ripeness issue here.

 

67 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Brooklyn Union Gas Co. v. Commissioner of Dep't of Finance


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 1036; 494 N.E.2d 1383; 503 N.Y.S.2d 718; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 18685


April 30, 1986, Argued  
May 29, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and the determinations of the Department of Finance of the City of New York reinstated in a memorandum. Question certified not answered as unnecessary.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Commissioner of the Department of Finance of the City of New York appealed from an order of the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Judicial Department (New York), which granted petitioner public utility's request to annul the commissioner's determinations denying claims by the public utility for refunds of New York City utility taxes.


OVERVIEW: The public utility sought refunds for taxes it paid in excess of 1 percent for certain periods, contending that the commissioner lacked authority to adopt a law taxing the utility's gross income at 2.35 percent. The court declined to address the utility's claims that a retroactive income tax was unconstitutional, instead determining as a matter of statutory construction that the city was authorized to impose the 2.35 percent rate. The court concluded that the city's tax authorization statute had a cross reference to N.Y. Gen. City Law § 20-b, upon which the utility based its challenge to the 2.35 percent rate, but that the city's tax authorization actually derived not from § 20-b but rather a series of enabling acts. Moreover, the legislature had expressly exempted New York City from the 1 percent ceiling imposed on other cities by virtue of § 20-b. The court acknowledged that the cross reference in the city's tax authorization statutes to § 20-b was not a model of clarity, but concluded that the apparently conflicting provisions could be harmonized. Furthermore, it was improper to employ a construction that rendered the statutory provision stating the 2.35 percent a nullity.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate court and reinstated the commissioner's determinations that the utility's tax rate was 2.35 percent.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City Utility Tax -- Rate of Tax

In a proceeding to annul determinations of the Commissioner of the Department of Finance of the City of New York denying petitioner's claims for refunds of New York City utility taxes, an order of the Appellate Division, which annulled the determinations, should be reversed and the determinations reinstated. The apparently conflicting statutory provisions governing city utility taxes may be harmonized in order to give effect to all of their parts. Tax Law § 1201 may be read as fixing the rate ceiling for New York City at 2.35% and Tax Law § 1221 (and General City Law § 20-b) may be read as restricting the tax base for the city. So read, all of the provisions are given effect; if not so read, section 1221, which states that the rate is 2.35%, would be rendered a nullity, a construction that is not permissible. Moreover, a minor, unexplained omission of language expressly indicating that New York City was not subject to the 1% rate ceiling in connection with a general revision of the statute should not be construed as changing a long-standing rule in the absence of a clear manifestation of such intention particularly where, as here, an expressed intention of the 1965 revision was simply to incorporate and preserve existing tax powers. Accordingly, the determinations of the Department of Finance properly fixed petitioner's tax at the 2.35% rate and should be reinstated.

 

68 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Flowers v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 1012; 494 N.E.2d 455; 503 N.Y.S.2d 324; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 18630



May 13, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: Concur: Chief Judge WACHTLER and Judges MEYER, SIMONS, KAYE, ALEXANDER, TITONE and HANCOCK, JR.


HEADNOTES

Prisons and Prisoners -- Inmate Accounts -- Recoupment of Money for Excess Postage

In a proceeding challenging the recoupment of money from petitioner inmate's account by the Department of Correctional Services to cover the cost of postage expended on petitioner's behalf in excess of the five free first-class mailings provided each week by the Department, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed [**4] a judgment prohibiting the recoupment and ordering the return of money previously recouped, and dismissed the petition, is affirmed for the reasons stated in the memorandum at the Appellate Division, which concluded that none of petitioner's constitutional rights had been impinged; that regulations limiting the amount of free postage for prison inmates did not contravene their right to meaningful access to the courts, and that compelling inmates to reimburse the State for the cost of excess postage did not deprive them of their property without due process.

 

69 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Burger


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 338; 493 N.E.2d 926; 502 N.Y.S.2d 702; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 18061


March 19, 1986, Argued  
May 8, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed the trial court's determination that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a, which authorized warrantless inspections of vehicle dismantling businesses, was constitutional. The lower court thereby affirmed defendant's conviction for criminal possession of stolen property.


OVERVIEW: Defendant owned a junkyard, dismantled automobiles, and sold parts. Defendant did not have a record of all vehicles and parts in the possession of the vehicle dismantler, as required by N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5)(a). Police officers conducted a warrantless search of defendant's premises under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a and N.Y. City, N.Y., Charter § 436, which authorized warrantless inspections of vehicle dismantling businesses. The police admitted that the search was conducted solely to discover whether defendant was storing stolen property on his premises. Eventually defendant pleaded guilty to criminal possession of stolen property in the second degree, and the appellate court affirmed. After holding that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5)(a) and N.Y. City, N.Y., Charter § 436 violated the constitutional proscription against unreasonable searches and seizures, the court reversed the appellate court's decision, ordered defendant's guilty plea vacated, ordered defendant's motion to suppress granted, and remitted to the trial court for further proceedings pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 470.55(2).


OUTCOME: The court reversed because the search was undertaken solely to discover whether defendant was storing stolen property on his premises. The court declared that defendant's motion to suppress was granted, defendant's guilty plea was vacated, the counts of the indictment charging criminal possession of stolen property were dismissed, and the case was remitted to the trial court.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Statutes Authorizing Warrantless Searches of Vehicle Dismantling Businesses and Junkyards

Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a (5) (a), which authorizes warrantless inspections of vehicle dismantling businesses, and New York City Charter § 436, which authorizes warrantless searches of junkyards and other businesses storing used, discarded or secondhand merchandise, violate the constitutional proscription against unreasonable searches and seizures. The fundamental defect in the statutes is that they authorize searches undertaken solely to uncover evidence of criminality and not to enforce a comprehensive regulatory scheme. In conducting a search pursuant to section 436, the police clearly are not determining compliance with any administrative or regulatory scheme since the provision contains no record-keeping requirements, but rather, explicitly authorizes searches to be undertaken "in connection with the performance of any police duties". Although section 415-a does contain some suggestion of an administrative scheme by imposing licensing and record-keeping requirements, and it authorizes inspectors to make unannounced visits to regulated premises to examine required books and records, as it may properly do, it fails to satisfy the constitutional requirements for a valid, comprehensive regulatory scheme, inasmuch as it permits searches of vehicles and vehicle parts notwithstanding the absence of any records against which the findings of such a search could be compared. Furthermore, an otherwise invalid search of private property is not rendered reasonable merely because it is authorized by a statute.

 

70 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Pollenz


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 264; 493 N.E.2d 541; 502 N.Y.S.2d 417; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 18055


March 24, 1986, Argued  
May 6, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order reversed and case remitted to the Appellate Division, Second Department, for determination of the appeal.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of decisions from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) that dismissed, one on the motion of respondent and the other on the court's own motion, his appeals as of right, which challenged the excessiveness of a negotiated sentence imposed by a judgment rendered upon a guilty plea.


OVERVIEW: Appellant sought review of orders in two cases that dismissing his appeals as of right, in which he challenged the excessiveness of a negotiated sentence imposed by a judgment rendered upon a guilty plea. The court reversed the dismissals and remitted the appeals for determination. The court found that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 450.10, which prohibited appeals as of right when the sole issue was a challenge to the excessiveness of a negotiated sentence imposed by a judgment rendered upon a guilty plea, imposed a limitation or condition on the jurisdiction of the of the lower court in contravention of N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 4(k). The court determined that, fairly read, N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 4(k) permitted the legislature to expand the jurisdiction of the Appellate Division but not to contract it, except with regard to appeals from nonfinal orders. The court found that in those cases, the legislature was authorized to limit or condition Appellate Division jurisdiction, which implied that it could not so limit or condition the taking and deciding of appeals in any other instance.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decisions dismissing the appeals as of right taken by appellant and remitted them for determination. The court found that the statute in question, which disallowed an appeal as of right where the sole issue raised was the excessiveness of a negotiated sentence imposed by a judgment rendered upon a guilty plea, unconstitutionally curtailed appellate jurisdiction over appeals from final judgments.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Appeal -- Appeal of Right to Appellate Division from Negotiated Sentence Imposed upon Guilty Plea

CPL 450.10, as amended by Laws of 1984 (ch 671), in purporting to disallow an appeal as of right to the Appellate Division where the sole issue raised is the excessiveness of a negotiated sentence imposed by a judgment rendered upon a guilty plea, imposes a limitation or condition on the jurisdiction of the Appellate Division of Supreme Court in contravention of NY Constitution, article VI, § 4 (k). The controlling constitutional provision permits the Legislature to expand the jurisdiction of the Appellate Division but not contract it, except with regard to appeals from nonfinal orders. The statutory abrogation of the right to appeal, leaving only the right to seek leave of a single Justice, not even the court itself, to take an appeal, represents both a limitation and condition on the formerly existing right to appeal from a final judgment or sentence.

 

71 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Briggins v. McGuire


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 965; 494 N.E.2d 90; 502 N.Y.S.2d 985; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 18591


February 5, 1986, Argued  
May 6, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner police officer sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) that reversed an order that remanded the police officer's action to respondent police commissioner (commissioner) for a hearing, denied the police officer's motion to restore the matter to the calendar, and dismissed the police officer's petition seeking reinstatement.


OVERVIEW: In a prior proceeding, the police officer was convicted of two felony counts of criminal possession of a forged instrument in the second degree. The conviction was affirmed by the appellate division; however, the court of appeals reversed the conviction and dismissed the indictment. The police officer had been discharged from his position as a police officer and once his conviction was reversed he sought reinstatement to full duty with the police department. The commissioner denied the police officer's application and the police officer filed an action seeking reinstatement. The trial court granted the police officer's petition by remanding the matter to the commissioner for a hearing. On appeal the appellate court reversed the trial court's order, denied the police officer's motion to restore the proceeding to the calendar, and dismissed the petition. The police officer appealed and the court affirmed the appellate court's order and held that under the plain meaning of N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 30, once the police officer was convicted he was automatically terminated and he no longer had a protectable property interest in an office that mandated a reinstatement hearing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's order that reversed the trial court's remand to the commissioner for a hearing, denied the police officer's motion to restore the proceeding to the calendar, and dismissed the police officer's petition seeking reinstatement to full duty.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Police -- Denial of Reinstatement after Conviction for Felony

Constitutionally protected property rights in a public office are created and their dimensions defined by State law, and while the Civil Service Law creates a protected property interest in a police officer's position, Public Officers Law § 30 (1) (e) mandates that a public office automatically becomes vacant upon an officer's conviction of a felony; accordingly, when petitioner, a former police officer, was convicted of a felony, his position terminated and under State law he no longer had a protectable property interest in the office that would mandate a reinstatement hearing, notwithstanding the fact that his conviction was reversed upon appeal. The Legislature has yet to alter the law and carve out a statutory exception in cases where a public officer has been wrongfully convicted.

 

72 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Associated Builders & Contractors, Inc. v. Rochester


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 854; 492 N.E.2d 781; 501 N.Y.S.2d 653; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 17597


February 6, 1986, Argued  
March 27, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, 50 contractors, challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which denied contractors' motion for summary judgment, and granting respondent city's cross motion for summary judgment, and holding that Ordinance 82-450 was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: Ordinance 82-450 established a precondition to the award of a contract to the lowest responsible bidder, and was inconsistent with N. Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 103 and, therefore, invalid. The court held that the predominate purpose of the State Legislature was the protection of the public fisc by requiring competitive bidding pursuant to § 103, and that apprentice training, while a desirable end, was not intended by the State Legislature to affect the qualification of an otherwise responsible low bidder, and that, therefore, Ordinance 82-450 was invalid because in conflict with § 103.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and denied the cross motion of city, granted the motion for summary judgment, and remitted to the Supreme Court, for entry of judgment declaring the ordinance invalid and enjoining its enforcement.


HEADNOTES

Labor -- Apprenticeship Training Preference -- Municipal Contracts

City of Rochester Ordinance 82-450, which provides for preferences to be given to bidders on municipal contracts where the bidders' employees participate in a State-approved apprenticeship program for certain trades, is invalid as violative of General Municipal Law § 103 and similar legislative enactments requiring competitive bidding; although the State's public policy, embodied in Labor Law §§ 220, 810 and 817, is to encourage sound apprenticeship training standards and to equalize minimum labor costs between union contractors and nonunion employers, the apprenticeship programs are undertaken voluntarily, and the prevailing rate of wages statute is fulfilled when a contractor pays in cash, totally or partially, the cost of prevailing supplemental benefits to his employees. The predominate purpose of the Legislature was the protection of the public fisc by requiring competitive bidding, and while apprentice training is a desirable end, it was not intended to affect the qualification of an otherwise responsible low bidder.

 

73 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Cibro Petroleum Prods. v. Chu


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 806; 492 N.E.2d 394; 501 N.Y.S.2d 321; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 17525


February 7, 1986, Argued  
March 20, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Tax on Petroleum Businesses -- Constitutionality -- Matters Reviewable

In an action to declare unconstitutional Tax Law § 301 (a), which imposed a gross receipts tax on petroleum businesses, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed a judgment declaring the tax unconstitutional as applied to plaintiff and declared that plaintiff's sale of jet fuel to the Federal Government was properly taxable under the statute, should be affirmed for the reasons stated in the memorandum at the Appellate Division. In addition, the legislative history establishes that the tax was intended to apply to all competing petroleum businesses, and, with the exception of residential fuel and petrochemical feedstocks, to virtually all petroleum sold in the State. Therefore, "aviation fuel", as used in Tax Law § 300 (b), covers the fuel sold by plaintiff to the Federal Government notwithstanding that its chemical composition differs from that of commercial aviation fuel. Plaintiff's various constitutional theories, newly advanced in the Court of Appeals, shall not be considered even though they were within the constitutional concepts presented in the complaint, since plaintiff conceded that they were not argued in the courts below, and, thus, they have not been preserved for review in the Court of Appeals.

 

74 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


D'Angelo v. Cole


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 65; 490 N.E.2d 819; 499 N.Y.S.2d 900; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 16605


January 10, 1986, Argued  
February 19, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee landowner brought an action against appellant village, asserting that an ordinance that allowed the village to recover costs of a street improvement in a civil action was unconstitutional. The village brought a counterclaim to recover the costs of the improvements. The trial court rendered judgment for the village. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) reversed. The village appealed.


OVERVIEW: The village enacted a maintenance standard for private roads through a local ordinance. Under the ordinance, the village was empowered to bring the roadway to standard and recover the cost from the owner in a civil action. The village served notice on a landowner that his roadway was improperly maintained. When the landowner failed to correct the condition, the village constructed a fully complying road. The trial court held that the ordinance was constitutional and found for the village on its counterclaim. The appellate court held that the maintenance standards were not reasonably necessary and dismissed the village's counterclaim. On appeal, the court held that the village was empowered to enact standards for the maintenance of roads, and thus the ordinance was not unconstitutional. However, the court held that to the extent that the recoupment provisions of the ordinance conflicted with its enabling statute, N.Y. Village Law § 4-414, the ordinance was invalid. In addition, the court held that the village was required to comply with the competitive bidding procedures under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law §103.


OUTCOME: The court modified the appellate court's order by deleting the provision declaring the entire ordinance unconstitutional and substituting a provision declaring the ordinance constitutional to the extent that it authorized repairs to private roads and invalid to the extent that its recoupment provisions conflicted with the state enabling statute. The court affirmed the order as modified.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Village Ordinance Establishing Maintenance Standards for Private Roads -- Recoupment of Funds Expended by Village to Bring Roadway to Standard

1. The Avon Village Ordinance, which sets "Maintenance Standards" for private roads and empowers the Village to expend funds to bring the roadway to standard and recover the cost from the owner in a civil suit if the owner fails to comply with the provisions of the ordinance within 10 days of the notice given by the Village to do so, is constitutional to the extent that it authorizes repairs to private roads. The Village may constitutionally impose strict maintenance standards upon private road owners; the expressed legislative judgment, presumptively the product of appropriate investigation and study, that properly maintained private roads are essential to the health and safety of the community, may not, without more, be overridden by the judiciary. Nonetheless, the ordinance is invalid to the extent that its recoupment provisions conflict with Village Law § 4-414, the enabling State legislation, which contemplates an in rem proceeding involving a three-step process of first making an assessment and then a levy, before the costs may be collected.

Municipal Corporations -- Bids and Bidders -- Failure of Village to Follow Statutorily Required Bid Procedure -- Liability of Third Party for Expenditures of Village under Void Contract

2. Where, pursuant to the Avon Village Ordinance, the Village served notice upon plaintiff that his private roadway was improperly maintained and, upon plaintiff's failure to correct the condition within 10 days, the Village constructed a fully complying road at an expense of $ 8,374.49, the failure of the Village to comply with the requisites of the competitive bidding statutes would preclude the Village from recovering the cost of the repairs from the landowner. General Municipal Law § 103 requires projects greater than $ 5,000 to be submitted to competitive bidding; when, as here, competitive bidding is statutorily required, and the municipality fails to follow that procedure, the contract is completely, not partially, void. In such circumstances, a third party should not be forced to reimburse a municipality for expenditures it has advanced in connection with a void contract. The public fisc is still protected because the municipality is excused from any payment under the void contract, and, indeed, may recover any moneys already paid, even if performance under the contract has been completed and return of the material and labor is impossible.

 

75 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Sheehan v. County of Suffolk


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


67 N.Y.2d 52; 490 N.E.2d 523; 499 N.Y.S.2d 656; 1986 N.Y. LEXIS 16656


January 9, 1986, Argued  
February 13, 1986, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court consolidated two cases for review that involved taxpayers who urged their due process rights were violated because defendant counties failed to inform them that tax liens against their properties would not be sold at a competitive bidding, and that plaintiffs would not receive any surplus from the ultimate proceeds. The judgments appealed from were entered in the Supreme Courts of Suffolk and Sullivan Counties (New York).


OVERVIEW: The court held that real property tax schemes that required notice to taxpayers of taxes due, notice of delinquent taxes, notice of a tax lien sale, a tax sale without competitive bidding, a redemption period and notice of impending expiration of the redemption period before resale of the property, and retention of surplus proceeds by the county, did not deprive taxpayers of property without due process of law or constitute a taking without just compensation. The court found that taxpayers' failure to inform themselves of the relevant competitive bidding and forfeiture statutes, rather than the challenged statutory provisions, resulted in the consequences complained of.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower courts' judgments.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Tax Liens, Tax Sales and Tax Titles -- Sale without Competitive Bidding -- Retention of Surplus of Resale by County -- Due Process -- Taking without Just Compensation

A real property tax scheme which requires notice to a taxpayer of taxes due, notice of delinquent taxes, notice of a tax lien sale, a tax sale without competitive bidding, a redemption period and notice of the impending expiration of the redemption period before the resale of the property at public auction and retention of any surplus by the county, does not deprive a taxpayer of property without due process of law or constitute a taking without just compensation. Once taxpayers are provided with notice and an opportunity to be heard on the adjudicative facts concerning the valuation of properties subject to tax, as was done here, they have received all the process that is due. There is no unfairness, much less a deprivation of due process, in the county's retention of any surplus. A three-year redemption period, as set forth in the challenged statutes, gives sufficient opportunity for a taxpayer to reclaim the property. There is no constitutional prohibition against a full forfeiture which has already occurred upon the taxpayer's failure to redeem the property before it has been resold. Finally, there is no constitutional requirement that tax liens be sold only through competitive bidding.

 

76 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


McMinn v. Oyster Bay


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


66 N.Y.2d 544; 488 N.E.2d 1240; 498 N.Y.S.2d 128; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 17940


October 10, 1985, Submitted  
December 26, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant town sought review from an order of the Supreme Court in Nassau County (New York), which declared a building zone ordinance invalid after an action was brought by respondent homeowners claiming a provision of the ordinance violated N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 6, 11, and N.Y. Exec. Law § 296.


OVERVIEW: A building ordinance passed by the town was found to be unconstitutional to the extent that it prohibited occupancy of a single-family dwelling by occupants were not married to each other and by two persons who were not related by blood. The town contended that single-family zoning was a reasonable legislative choice and did not conflict with the human rights laws. The homeowners contended that the ordinance was invalid on its face, arbitrary, unreasonable, and did not accomplish a legitimate public purpose. The court held that the homeowners proved beyond a reasonable doubt that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The ordinance, by limiting occupancy of single-family homes to persons related by blood, marriage, or adoption or to only two unrelated persons of a certain age, excluded many households who posed no threat to the goal of preserving the character of the traditional single-family neighborhood. Therefore, the ordinance's provision failed to satisfy the rational relationship test.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment that a provision of the town's building ordinance was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Restriction of Occupancy of Single-Family Homes to Persons Related by Blood, Marriage or Adoption or to Two Unrelated Persons of Certain Age -- Due Process of Law

The definition of "family" contained in Town of Oyster Bay Building Zone Ordinance, article I, § 1, as any number of persons related by blood, marriage or legal adoption or two persons not so related both of whom are 62 years of age or older, on its face infringes upon the due process protections embodied in NY Constitution, article I, § 6. Manifestly, restricting occupancy of single-family housing based generally on the biological or legal relationships between its inhabitants bears no reasonable relationship to the legitimate governmental purposes in enacting this ordinance of reducing parking and traffic problems, controlling population density and preventing noise and disturbance. Further, this ordinance, by limiting occupancy of single-family homes to persons related by blood, marriage or adoption or to only two unrelated persons of a certain age, excludes many households who pose no threat to the legitimate governmental objective of preserving the character of the traditional single-family neighborhood, and thus fails the rational relationship test. Although article I, § 1 (a) of the ordinance, which defines family as "[any] number of persons, related by blood, marriage, or legal adoption", is not per se unconstitutional, provided the ordinance contains an alternative definition of family as any number of unrelated persons living together who meet the indicia for the functional equivalent of a traditional family; however, because the only alternative definition contained in this ordinance (art I, § 1 [b]) is more restrictive, both as to the number of unrelated persons and their ages, than is constitutionally permissible, the entire definition of family contained in the ordinance violates our State constitutional guarantee that no person shall be deprived of property without due process of law.

 

77 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dunlea v. Anderson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


66 N.Y.2d 265; 487 N.E.2d 263; 496 N.Y.S.2d 406; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 17208


October 17, 1985, Argued  
November 21, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sought review of a decision from the Supreme Court at Special Term in Albany County (New York), which granted respondent legislators' motion for summary judgment in the taxpayers' action alleging that the legislators had violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 6 by approving an increase in legislative salaries and allowances for the next legislative term. The trial court also denied the taxpayers' request for an injunction.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers claimed that the legislators were prohibited by N.Y. Const. art. III, § 6 from increasing their salaries and that 1934 N.Y. Laws ch. 986, §§ 18, 19 were unconstitutional. The legislators claimed that they passed §§ 18, 19 after the fall election but before the new legislature was in place, which was not a violation of N.Y. Const. art. III, § 6. The court affirmed the trial court's summary judgment for the legislators. The court held that by passing the increase in the legislative salaries before the new legislature was seated that the legislators had not violated the prohibition against increasing their salaries because the legislators had voted to increase the salary of the next legislature, which was prospective in nature. Thus, the statutory provisions at issue were not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the summary judgment in favor of the legislators in the taxpayers' action that alleged that legislation increasing the salaries for the next legislative term was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Legislative Salary Increase -- One Legislature Increasing Salaries of Next Term's Members Subsequent to Election

Laws of 1984 (ch 986, §§ 18, 19), passed by the State Senate and Assembly on December 6, 1984, which, inter alia, increased the salaries of the members of the Legislature of the 1985-1986 term, are not violative of NY Constitution, article III, § 6, which provides that "[neither] the salary of any [legislator] nor any other allowance * * * may be increased or diminished during, and with respect to, the term for which he shall have been elected"; the provisions of sections 18 and 19 raising salaries and allowances for members of the 1985-1986 Legislature are clearly prospective and thus do not violate section 6 of article III of the Constitution; that section does not prohibit one Legislature, subsequent to the elective designation of its successor body, from increasing the salaries of the next term's members.

 

78 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Forbes, Inc. v. Department of Finance


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


66 N.Y.2d 243; 487 N.E.2d 251; 496 N.Y.S.2d 394; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 17205


October 10, 1985, Argued  
November 19, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, with costs, petition granted, determination of respondent Department of Finance annulled, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, with directions to remand to respondent for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review from the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which unanimously confirmed respondent city's decision to assess a general corporation tax deficiency against the taxpayer for the years 1977, 1978, and 1979.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer argued that the city's tax was unconstitutional because it conflicted with 31 U.S.C.S. § 742, renumbered 31 U.S.C.S. § 3124, which provided that all stocks, bonds, treasury notes, and other obligations of the United States should be exempt from taxation by state or municipal or local authority. The taxpayer contended that the city's tax was a franchise tax that impermissibly discriminated against obligations of the United States by excluding federal obligations from the denominator of the investment allocation percentage, while including obligations of other states. The court agreed and reversed the judgment. Section 742 was established to prevent taxes which diminished the market value or the investment attractiveness of obligations issued by the United States in an effort to secure necessary credit, by providing an exemption for federal obligations. A franchise tax was constitutional so long as it remained the same whatever the character of the corporate assets might be. However, a state tax that imposed a greater burden on holders of federal property than on holders of similar state property impermissibly discriminated against federal obligations.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in favor of the city, with costs, and granted the taxpayer's petition. The court also annulled the determination of the city and remitted the matter for readjustment of the taxpayer's tax liability for the tax years in issue.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- New York City General Corporation Tax -- Constitutionality -- Discrimination against Federal Obligations -- Nondiscriminatory Franchise Taxes -- Supremacy Clause

By rendering investments in obligations of the Federal Government less attractive than other investments, in the calculation of taxes due under New York City's General Corporation Tax (Administrative Code of City of New York § R46-3.0 et seq.), the City tax discriminates against Federal obligations within the meaning of the Federal statute permitting only nondiscriminatory franchise taxes to be levied on United States obligations (31 USC § 742 [renum § 3124]), and therefore violates the supremacy clause of the United States Constitution (US Const, art VI, cl 2); the City tax law places a greater burden on taxpayers holding Federal obligations, thus making them less attractive investments in two ways, (1) the law discriminates in favor of the obligations of the other 49 States, and (2) the law discriminates in favor of corporate obligations; excluding Federal obligations from the denominator of the fraction used to determine a taxpayer's investment allocation percentage (Administrative Code § R46-4.0 [3] [b]), while including obligations of other States, effectively places a greater tax on the former than on the latter; the 18% rule compounds the problem, by disadvantaging taxpayers who invest 82% or more of the value of their portfolios in obligations other than those of corporations with low business allocation percentages, including Federal obligations; that the disparities may be rational for due process or equal protection purposes is not relevant under former section 742; it is also beside the point that the tax scheme does not discriminate in favor of obligations of the State of New York.

 

79 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Lower Manhattan Loft Tenants v. New York City Loft Bd.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


66 N.Y.2d 298; 487 N.E.2d 889; 496 N.Y.S.2d 979; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 17258


October 14, 1985, Argued  
November 19, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents, board and landlords, appealed a judgment that declared Regulation J(1)(a), issued by the board, invalid, voided notices to terminate tenancies issued to petitioner tenants, and enjoined the landlords from proceeding any further. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) reversed and declared the regulation valid. The tenants appealed.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to Regulation J(1)(a), the landlords, who owned interim multiple dwellings registered with the board, proceeded to evict the tenants who did not have a lease or rental agreement with the landlord, and whom were not using the unit as their primary residence. The regulation was not an unauthorized extension of article 7-C of the N.Y. Mult. Dwell. Law because evident from the history of the enactment of article 7-C, and from the legislative findings in N.Y. Mult. Dwell. Law § 280, was the legislative purpose to protect the residential aspect of occupancy of an interim multiple dwelling rather than to shield the tenant whose use was essentially commercial and only incidentally residential. The court read the statutes and regulation in pari materia because each involved the same subject and there was no legislative purpose clearly shown, in support of its conclusion. Therefore, the fact that article 7-C of N.Y. Mult. Dwell. Law, did not reference primary residence, as did the regulation, did not change the legislative purpose nor invalidate the board's authority to issue the regulation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Loft Law -- Validity of Loft Board Regulation -- Eviction of Residential Occupant Based upon Nonprimary Residence

Regulation J (1) (a) issued by the New York City Loft Board, which permits the landlord of an interim multiple dwelling registered with the Board pursuant to article 7-C of the Multiple Dwelling Law to evict a residential occupant of a unit, who has no lease or rental agreement with the landlord, on the ground "that the unit is not the primary residence of such residential occupant," was within the Board's authority to issue under article 7-C and is valid; that article 7-C refers to a "residential occupant qualified for protection" but nowhere makes "primary residence" a qualification, and in defining an "interim multiple dwelling" refers to "residence or home," does not constitute the regulation an unauthorized extension of the statute; the legislative purpose to protect the residential aspect of occupancy of an interim multiple dwelling rather than to shield the tenant whose use is essentially commercial and only incidentally residential is evident from the history of the enactment of article 7-C and from the legislative findings in Multiple Dwelling Law § 280; the phrase "the residence or home" as used in Multiple Dwelling Law § 281 cannot properly be construed to exclude primary residence as a measure of its protection; further, to permit eviction of a nonprimary resident prior to the time a tenant has received the benefits of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act (L 1974, ch 576, as amended) in the form of a residential lease would not frustrate the intent of the Legislature to encourage prompt legalization of substandard housing.

 

80 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Sarah K.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


66 N.Y.2d 223; 487 N.E.2d 241; 496 N.Y.S.2d 384; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 17204


October 14, 1985, Argued  
November 14, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant adoptive parents sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which vacated an order of the family court granting appellants' petition for adoption of respondent biological parents' infant and remitted the matter to the family court for entry of an order providing for the transfer of the infant's custody from appellants to respondents as expeditiously as possible.


OVERVIEW: After respondent biological parents consented to the adoption of their infant by appellant adoptive parents, respondents attempted to revoke the consent they had given three months earlier and regain custody of the child. The family court determined that respondents had no right to revoke and that the baby's best interests would be served by adoption by appellants. The appellate division reversed, and on appeal, the court reversed the appellate court. The court held that respondents were afforded proper notice of the operation and effect of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 115-b, which provided a 30-day period for revocation from the date respondents were notified of the commencement of the adoption proceeding. Respondents had no standing to complain about the statute's legality because they suffered no injury, notwithstanding their receipt of notice of the scheduled adoption proceeding a month after it had been commenced and the fact that the extrajudicial consent they had signed failed to advise them of the consequences of revocation. Further, respondents failed to establish fraud, duress, or coercion in the execution of the consent, as required to avoid the application of § 115-b.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate division and granted appellant adoptive parents' petition for adoption because respondent biological parents, having failed to make any effort to revoke within 30 days of notification of the adoption proceeding, were bound by their consent to the adoption.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Extrajudicial Consent to Private-Placement Adoption -- Revocation Period

Domestic Relations Law § 115-b requires that extrajudicial consents to private-placement adoptions notify the biological parents of the limited nature of their right of revocation, and their 30-day revocation period runs from notice to them of the commencement of an adoption proceeding. Accordingly, respondent natural parents' "irrevocable consent" to adoption must be honored and the petition for adoption granted where, although respondents did not receive notice of the adoption proceeding until a month after it had been commenced, and although the extrajudicial consent respondents signed failed to advise them of the consequences of a timely revocation, respondents suffered no injury as a result of either omission; respondents were notified by Family Court on January 23, 1984 that there would be a preliminary hearing in connection with the adoption; respondents' right to revoke therefore must be measured from that date, and it ended 30 days later, on February 23, 1984; respondents' revocation on February 29, 1984 was plainly untimely and, thus, having failed to revoke their consent within the 30-day statutory period, respondents cannot complain of a failure to advise them of what the consequences of a timely revocation would have been; further, the language contained in the judicial and extrajudicial consent to adoption forms signed by respondents in and of itself was not misleading, complied with the statute, and accurately conveyed the time limitation placed on revocation by Domestic Relations Law § 115-b (1) (d) (i); moreover, neither emotional distress nor mistake on respondents' part is a ground for vitiating consent under Domestic Relations Law § 115-b (4).

 

81 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Savings Bank of Utica v. New York State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


66 N.Y.2d 769; 488 N.E.2d 114; 497 N.Y.S.2d 368; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 17912


October 8, 1985, Argued  
November 12, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Concur: Chief Judge WACHTLER [**4] and Judges JASEN, MEYER, KAYE, ALEXANDER and TITONE. Taking no part: Judge SIMONS.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Banking Corporations -- Different Alternative Minimum Tax Treatment for Savings and Commercial Banks

In an action challenging the constitutionality of Tax Law § 1455 (b), which provides that the alternative minimum tax for savings banks shall be based on a percentage of interest or dividends credited to depositors or shareholders, while the minimum tax for commercial banks shall be based on an assessment of an institution's par value of stock, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed an order and judgment declaring that the State's method of imposing franchise taxes on banking corporations was constitutional, is affirmed for reasons stated in the opinion at the Appellate Division, which concluded the different treatment had a rational basis and that although there may be a discrepancy with respect to the alternative minimum tax, most commercial banks pay the basic tax, with the result that each type of bank pays a franchise tax roughly proportional to its share of assets.

 

82 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Fossella v. Dinkins


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


66 N.Y.2d 162; 485 N.E.2d 1017; 495 N.Y.S.2d 352; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 20044


October 28, 1985, Argued  
October 30, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [**1] Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: An action was brought to have the board of elections remove from the ballot a proposed referendum to amend the city charter. A trial court (New York) entered a judgment finding the proposed amendment unconstitutional. An appellate court affirmed the judgment. Review of that decision was sought.


OVERVIEW: The proposed amendment prohibited the board of estimate from approving the disposition of city property for the development of a federal military facility designed to carry or store nuclear weapons. The court held that it was unnecessary to reach the issue of the constitutionality of the amendment because it was invalid on state statutory grounds. The court found that the amendment was facially invalid to the extent that it sought to preclude the city from approving any disposition of city property for a federal military installation because it was in direct conflict with N.Y. State L. §50(2). Because that portion of the proposed amendment sought to deprive the city authorities of a right and power which the legislature held could not be alienated, by city charter provisions or otherwise, it could have no effect in the event it were enacted. The court concluded that it would have been inappropriate to submit the proposition to the electorate in a redacted and possibly confusing form because it was manifestly invalid in a substantive respect.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court upholding the trial court's decision that the proposed amendment was invalid.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Justiciable Controversy -- Removal of Proposed Referendum from Ballot -- Conflict with State Statute

1. A proceeding to have the Board of Elections remove from the ballot a pro posed referendum, which would amend New York City Charter § 67 in relation to the use of city property and funds in connection with a military installation by the Federal Government any component of which is designed to carry or store nuclear weapons, presents a justiciable controversy; although it is generally inappropriate for the courts to consider the validity of proposed legislation, they may do so in a case such as this where a proposed referendum sought to be re moved from the ballot is in direct conflict with a State statute (State Law § 50 [2]); the court may grant the relief sought, the rule being one of prudence rather than one of power.

Municipal Corporations -- Power to Dispose of City Land to United States -- Validity of Referendum Amending City Charter to Preclude Disposition of Property for Federal Military Installation

2. A proposed referendum, which would amend New York City Charter § 67 in relation to the use of city property and funds [**2] in connection with a military installation by the Federal Government any component of which is designed to carry or store nuclear weapons, is stricken from the ballot; the proposed amendment is invalid to the extent it seeks to amend the City Charter to preclude the city from approving "any sale, lease, exchange or other disposition" of city property for a Federal military installation because State Law § 50(2) expressly provides that "every * * * city * * * is hereby authorized and empowered to sell, lease, exchange, donate or otherwise dispose of" city land to the United States for use as a military reservation "notwithstanding the provisions of any charter or any other statute"; thus, the stated portion of the proposed amendment is invalid on its face and could have no effect in the event it were enacted. Further, there is no need to consider whether any or all remaining provisions are valid; inasmuch as the resolution is manifestly invalid in a substantive respect, since the disposition and use of city land is at the core of the controversy, it would be inappropriate to submit the proposition to the electorate in a redacted and possibly confusing form.

Parties -- Standing  [**3] -- Waiver of Objections

3. In a proceeding to have the Board of Elections remove from the ballot a proposed referendum which would amend New York City Charter § 67, the intervenors' challenge to standing was waived because it was not raised as an affirmative defense, or by way of motion to dismiss, at Special Term ( CPLR 3018 [b]; 3211 [e]).

 

83 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


FGL & L Property Corp. v. Rye


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


66 N.Y.2d 111; 485 N.E.2d 986; 495 N.Y.S.2d 321; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 17179


September 11, 1985, Argued  
October 24, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent landowner brought an action against appellant city and sought to have a zoning ordinance declared unconstitutional. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) reversed the trial court's grant of summary judgment in favor of the city. The city sought review of the judgment.


OVERVIEW: The landowner owned property that was zoned for single family housing. The city rezoned the property, limited its use to condominiums, and mandated that the outside of the property was to be restored to its historic state. The appellate court declared the zoning ordinance invalid on the ground that it constituted an improper regulation of the form of ownership of the property. Upon review, the court held that there was nothing in the historical preservation provisions of the law or the city's code that empowered the city to enact the zoning ordinance. The court held that neither the enabling provision for residential zoning, N.Y. Gen. City Law § 20(24), nor N.Y. Gen. City Law § 37 gave the city the power to require condominium ownership. The court held that as the laws were written the city was not authorized to impose restoration costs solely on the landowner.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the appellate court in favor of the landowner.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Historical Preservation -- Power of City to Mandate Manner of Ownership of Property

Nothing in the zoning enabling provisions of the General City Law ( § 20 [24]; § 37), the historical preservation provisions of the General Municipal Law (art 5-K; § 96-a) or the Landmarks Preservation provisions of the Rye City Code (ch 117) empowers the City to mandate the manner in which property may be owned or held or to impose upon the owner of a tract containing historic structures, or purchasers of properties neighboring the tract, the cost of rehabilitation or enhancement of the properties; thus, the City was not authorized to enact Rye City Code § 197-13.2, which creates the Alansten Landmarks Preservation District, consisting solely of the 22-acre property owned by plaintiff, and mandates that the entire district remain in single ownership, imposes upon the developer the duty of rehabilitating the exteriors of two historic structures on the property, proscribes the use of any new dwelling unit until that has been done, thus effectively requiring that the cost of rehabilitation be shared by owners in the district of units other than the two historic structures, and, by dictating condominium ownership of the entire district, imposes the cost of maintenance of the exteriors of the historic structures upon owners of such units as well.

 

84 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Clark v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


66 N.Y.2d 185; 486 N.E.2d 794; 495 N.Y.S.2d 936; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 17187


September 9, 1985, Argued  
October 22, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Defendants' cross appeal dismissed, without costs. Defendants' oral motion for leave to appeal granted. Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, a state committee chairman (chairman), and defendants, the Governor of New York and a task force (collectively Governor), cross-appealed from the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Judicial Department (New York), which reversed an order declaring an executive order unconstitutional, declared it constitutional, and enjoined the Governor from providing receptacles for completed voter registration forms.


OVERVIEW: The Governor issued an executive order that established a voter registration program and the task force. The chairman contended that the executive order violated the doctrine of separation of powers and N.Y. Const. art II, § 8 because it infringed upon the mandate that the legislature provide by law for systems of registration under N.Y. Const. art. II, § 6. The Governor challenged the injunction with respect to the receptacles. The court held that the executive order did not nullify legislative action. The program was not registering anyone to vote in contravention of any statute or constitutional delegation of authority but was merely facilitating the distribution and filling out of forms, only the first step toward registration. The executive order, when implemented in conjunction with the injunction against providing locked receptacles, did not violate the constitutional mandate and did not implicate the constitutional requirement of bipartisan representation. The presence of the registration forms, however, in the control of state agency employees increased the potential for mischief, and the court sustained the injunction against the provision of the locked receptacles.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appeals court's finding that the executive order was constitutional. The court sustained so much of the injunction as applied to the use of locked receptacles for completed voter registration forms.


HEADNOTES

Elections -- Registration -- Authority of Governor to Establish State Program for Voter Registration

Executive Order No. 43 (9 NYCRR 4.43), which established a program of voter registration by making registration forms and assistance available at State agencies, does not violate the constitutional principle of separation of powers, since it is only when the Executive acts inconsistently with the Legislature, or usurps its prerogatives, that the doctrine is violated, and the program established by Executive Order No. 43 is not registering anyone to vote in contravention of any statute or constitutional delegation of authority, but is merely facilitating the distribution and filling out of forms, which is only the first step toward registration, and the Executive is merely implementing the policy of the Legislature in a manner which in no way treads on its prerogatives; nor does the executive order violate NY Constitution, article II, § 8, since it is not a law and because the personnel who implement it do not register voters, distribute ballots or receive, record or count votes at elections. However, the provision of receptacles for completed registration forms in the offices that distribute the forms is enjoined; the presence of such forms in boxes which in some cases are in the control of agency employees too closely approaches the critical stage of delivery to the local Board of Elections, thus rendering the agency, for all intents and purposes, a "branch office" of the Board.

 

85 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Treyball v. Clark


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 589; 483 N.E.2d 1136; 493 N.Y.S.2d 1004; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15928



September 12, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: On review of the submissions pursuant to section 500.4 of the Rules of the Court of Appeals (22 NYCRR 500.4), order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, as an individual and as a representative of a decedent's estate, sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, which affirmed the judgment in favor of appellees, a hospital and physicians, in her medical malpractice action. The individual challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Jud. Law § 148-a(8).


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Jud. Law § 148-a(8) authorized any party to a medical malpractice action to admit into evidence the unanimous recommendation of a medical malpractice mediation panel as to the question of liability. The individual alleged that § 148-a(8) deprived her of the right to a jury trial on the issue of liability as well as the right to due process of law. Upon review, the court found under the express terms of the statute, the panel's recommendation was not binding upon the trier of fact and was only to be accorded such weight as the trier of fact chose to ascribe to it. Thus, it was merely a guide to the jury, and its admission into evidence did not impermissibly burden or nullify the individual's constitutional right to a meaningful jury trial. The court observed the § 148-a(8) was enacted to combat the problem of increasing malpractice rates and to better equip parties to mediate a settlement. Because § 148-a(8) had some fair, just, and reasonable connection to promoting the health, comfort, safety, and welfare of society, it did not violate the individual's right to due process of law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment in favor of appellees in the individual's medical malpractice action.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Authorizing Admission in Evidence of Unanimous Recommendation of Medical Malpractice Mediation Panel

 Judiciary Law § 148-a (8), which authorizes any party to a medical malpractice action to admit in evidence the unanimous recommendation of a medical malpractice mediation panel as to the question of liability, is not unconstitutional on the grounds that it deprives plaintiff of the right to a jury trial on the issue of liability (NY Const, art I, § 2), as well as the right to due process of law (NY Const, art I, § 6; US Const 14th Amend); the unanimous, nonbinding recommendation of the medical malpractice mediation panel serves merely as a guide to the jury, and its admission as evidence does not impermissibly burden or nullify plaintiff's constitutional right to a meaningful jury trial; moreover, since the challenged statute manifestly has some fair, just and reasonable connection with the promotion of the health, comfort, safety and welfare of society, Judiciary Law § 148-a (8) does not violate plaintiff's right to due process of law.

 

86 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Miller


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 502; 482 N.E.2d 892; 493 N.Y.S.2d 96; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15390


May 29, 1985, Argued  
July 11, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following conviction of rape in the first degree and sentencing to an indeterminate term of 7 to 21 years from the trial court, which was affirmed by an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), defendant contended that the sentence was presumptively vindictive because the sentence following trial was heavier than after he entered a plea agreement.


OVERVIEW: A heavier sentence was imposed following trial than was imposed following defendant's earlier conviction of first-degree rape based on his guilty plea. Defendant asserted that the heavier sentence imposed violated his Sixth Amendment right to confrontation. On appeal, the court held that the heavier sentence imposed after trial was constitutionally permissible, limitation of the scope of the second Wade hearing was proper, and the in-court identification by the victim was properly allowed. No actual vindictiveness was established regarding the imposition of the heavier sentence. Once defendant's sentence based upon the plea agreement was reversed, the slate was wiped clean and the prosecution began anew. The consideration for defendant's plea agreement failed when defendant successfully appealed and went to trial and the victim was compelled to testify. Moreover, the acceptance of the plea negotiation as a legitimate process, in the course of which defendant was discouraged from asserting trial rights and forced to choose between the certainty of leniency in return for a plea or a heavier penalty if those trial rights are asserted, involved no due process violation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order convicting defendant of rape in the first degree and imposition of the heavier sentence following trial because there was no violation of defendant's right to due process or to confront the witness against him, it having been stated during both sentencing proceedings that the lesser sentence following the guilty plea was imposed to spare the victim the necessity of recounting the experience at a public trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Imposition of Heavier Sentence Following Retrial -- Due Process

1. That a heavier sentence is imposed following trial than was imposed following defendant's earlier conviction, thereafter reversed, of first degree rape based on his guilty plea, involves no violation of defendant's right to due process (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 6), it having been stated during both sentencing proceedings that the lesser sentence following the guilty plea was imposed to spare the victim the necessity of recounting the experience at a public trial; having accepted the exercise of discretion to lower the original sentence in return for a plea in order to protect the victim, the defendant should not be heard to complain that a higher sentence is imposed after conviction following a retrial at which, by requiring that the victim testify, he has removed from consideration the element of discretion involved. Also, there is less likelihood of self-vindication or recrimination and the chance of improper motivation is reduced since a different judge presided over the trial and sentencing after trial than took the original plea and imposed sentence on the basis of it.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Imposition of Heavier Sentence Following Retrial -- Right of Confrontation

2. That a heavier sentence is imposed following trial than was imposed following defendant's earlier conviction, thereafter reversed, for first degree rape based on his guilty plea, involves no violation of defendant's right to confront the witnesses against him (US Const 6th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 6; Civil Rights Law § 12), it having been stated during both sentencing proceedings that the lesser sentence following the guilty plea was imposed to spare the victim the necessity of recounting the experience at a public trial. The acceptance of plea negotiation as a legitimate process, in the course of which a defendant may be discouraged from asserting trial rights and forced to choose between certainty of leniency in return for a plea or a heavier penalty if those trial rights are asserted, involves no constitutional violation; defendant was made aware as part of the plea bargaining process that the leniency being accorded him involved foregoing both the right to trial and to confrontation of the victim; the possibility of a heavier sentence after trial following his successful appeal did not impermissibly burden his confrontation rights.

Crimes -- Suppression Hearing -- Retrial -- Relitigation of Issues Affirmed on Prior Appeal

3. The reversal of defendant's guilty plea conviction did not entitle him to relitigate the issue of suggestiveness decided against him prior to that conviction during the first preplea suppression hearing and not reversed on appeal. CPL 710.60 (4), which calls for a hearing on a suppression motion, does not mandate reconsideration at the required hearing of issues the disposition of which was affirmed on the prior appeal; although CPL 710.40 (4) vests the trial court with discretion to reopen such a hearing on grounds previously unavailable to defendant, denial of such a motion under the circumstances of this case involves no abuse of discretion. Moreover, the words "pre-pleading status" in CPL 470.55 (2), which provides that upon an appellate court reversal of a judgment based upon a guilty plea, in the absence of express appellate court direction to the contrary, the criminal action is "restored to its pre-pleading status", can only be read to refer to the status of the case prior to the "plea of guilty"; although cases construing the predecessor section, Code of Criminal Procedure § 544, permitted motions to be made on remand after appeal, none involved relitigation of an issue litigated and decided prior to reversal.

Crimes -- Identification of Defendant -- Independent Source

4. The hearing judge's finding of independent source for an in-court identification of defendant, affirmed by the Appellate Division, was based on sufficient evidence where the rape victim not only testified that she was able to get a good look at defendant's face at various times during the four hours they were together, but also testified that during the sexual assault his face was but a few inches from hers; therefore, the issue is beyond the review of the Court of Appeals.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Imposition of Greater Sentence after Retrial -- Presumption of Vindictiveness

5.
