When a greater sentence is imposed following retrial after appeal than was imposed after the original trial, the opportunity to retaliate for the successful appeal and to deter others from similar appeals is present and the likelihood that retaliation or deterrence or both constitute the motivation for the additional time required to be served is sufficient to engage the presumption of vindictiveness in resentencing; the presumption may be overcome by evidence that the higher sentence rests upon a legitimate and reasoned basis.

 

87 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Elmwood-Utica Houses, Inc. v. Buffalo Sewer Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 489; 482 N.E.2d 549; 492 N.Y.S.2d 931; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 16180


May 28, 1985, Argued  
July 11, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review modified, with costs to defendant and intervenors, and case remitted to Supreme Court, Erie County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff housing project, defendant sewer authority, and intervenor defendant churches cross appealed from a judgment of the Supreme Court (New York), which modified and affirmed, as modified, an order that awarded the sewer authority a sum of money on its counterclaim against the housing project.


OVERVIEW: The sewer authority was authorized by statute to establish a schedule of rates, rentals, or charges to be collected from all real property served by its facilities. The sewer authority had historically exempted certain real property from its ad valorem portion of assessing these rents. The housing project was not one of these properties and filed an action claiming that the sewer authority had no authority to exempt any property users of its facilities from sewer rentals. The housing project withheld payment of the ad valorem portion of its sewer rental fee. The housing project contended that the law was unconstitutional and that the sewer authority's method of assessing the ad valorem component of its sewer rents was not authorized by the statute. The court rejected the sewer authority's position and held that the law as interpreted and applied by the sewer authority was constitutional. The court found that the classification employed by the sewer authority was not a fundamental interest or suspect classification and thus, did not offend the constitution because it had some reasonable basis.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment to provide that the sewer authority's method of calculating sewer rents was valid and affirmed the remainder of the judgment as modified.


HEADNOTES

Public Authorities -- Buffalo Sewer Authority -- Sewer Rents -- Constitutionality of Exemption from Ad Valorem Component

1. Chapter 862 of the Laws of 1981, which amended Public Authorities Law § 1180, to create a specific statutory exemption from the ad valorem component of the sewer rent assessment levied by defendant Buffalo Sewer Authority (BSA) for those properties that are exempt from real property taxation pursuant to enumerated sections of Real Property Tax Law article 4, is constitutional. Since a "fundamental interest" or "suspect" classification is not involved in BSA's fixing of sewer rents, section 1180, as amended, and BSA's interpretation of the statute in classifying properties that are subject to or exempt from the ad valorem sewer levy are to be tested by a rational basis standard of review; the classification employed here easily meets the rational basis test since entities that are tax exempt, such as governments and charitable and religious organizations, may properly be considered less able to pay for a sewer system, especially insofar as the system redounds to the common benefit of all property rather than to one specific parcel; in addition, while all property values are enhanced by a sewer system, holders of tax-exempt properties may be in a different classification because generally they do not share the objective of commercial and residential property owners, the enjoyment of their property's market appreciation and the realization of profit thereon upon resale.

Public Authorities -- Buffalo Sewer Authority -- Sewer Rents -- Exemption of Tax-Exempt Properties -- "Equitable Basis" Test

2. As a matter of statutory interpretation, defendant Buffalo Sewer Authority's (BSA) long practice of exempting tax-exempt properties from the ad valorem component of the sewer rent assessment authorized by Public Authorities Law § 1180 is a fair and rational application of the "equitable basis" test provided in section 1180; while classifications fixing different rates must relate to the benefits received, here it cannot be said that governmental, charitable and religious institutions obtain the same value, in terms of over-all market appreciation, from the entire sewer system as commercial and residential property owners; nor is it irrational to exempt them from those charges designed to defray the costs of the public benefit services supplied by BSA's system.

 

88 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Top Tile Bldg. Supply Corp. v. New York State Tax Com.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 895; 482 N.E.2d 1227; 493 N.Y.S.2d 311; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15836



July 9, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes

In a proceeding to review a determination of the State Tax Commission in which petitioners asserted [**4] that certain assessments of sales and use taxes were fictitious and made solely to extend a limitations period, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed the dismissal of the proceeding, is affirmed for the reasons stated in the memorandum of the Appellate Division, which concluded that the record was devoid of any support for petitioners' contention.

 

89 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. P.J. Video, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 566; 483 N.E.2d 1120; 493 N.Y.S.2d 988; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15927


May 1, 1985, Argued  
July 5, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The people appealed an order from the Erie County Court (New York) in which the court granted the defendant's motion to suppress materials seized as obscene.


OVERVIEW: The appeals court affirmed the lower court's findings that the search warrants were not supported by probable cause. The appeals court held that the failure of the affidavits in this case to contain sufficient information to permit the court to determine whether the material sought to be seized was obscene as defined in N.Y. Penal Law § 235.00. According to the appeals court, probable cause could not be determined from the title of a film or by brief descriptions of sexual activity. The appeals court held that the necessity for sufficient information was to protect against the court interposing its personal view as to what was obscene. The appeals court held that the task of the issuing magistrate was not to decide guilt or innocence but to determine in a preliminary way from the information submitted and available to him whether there was probable cause to believe that the material to be seized was obscene. The appeals court held that while a copy of the film was not required to be annexed to the affidavit, the information was lacking for the magistrate to make a determination of whether there was probable cause.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed because the affidavits lacked sufficient information for the magistrate to make a determination of whether there was probable cause that the materials sought to be seized were obscene.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Search Warrant -- Jurisdiction of Justice Court to Entertain Motion to Suppress -- Warrant Issued by Supreme Court Justice

1. In proceedings instituted in a Village Justice Court charging defendants with six counts of obscenity in the third degree based upon their possession of allegedly obscene video cassette movies, a motion to suppress the seized films on the ground that the warrant authorizing their seizure, which was issued by Supreme Court, a superior court ( CPL 10.10 [2], [3]), was not based on probable cause, was properly entertained by the Justice Court, a local criminal court. The Constitution provides that local courts "shall have the jurisdiction prescribed by the legislature" (NY Const, art VI, § 17 [a]) and the Legislature has provided that when an information is pending in a local criminal court, as these informations were, a motion to suppress "must be made in such court" ( CPL 710.50 [1] [c]). Moreover, Justice Court had such jurisdiction even though the warrant was issued by a Supreme Court Justice; CPL 690.05 provides that warrants shall be issued by local criminal courts, but the Supreme Court Justice was authorized to issue this warrant because at the time he did so he was exercising preliminary, not trial, jurisdiction of the local criminal court as permitted by CPL 10.10 (3) (f). Thus, Justice Court acted properly when it reviewed his probable cause determination.

Crimes -- Search Warrant -- Probable Cause -- Obscene Films -- Sufficiency of Affidavits Supporting Warrant Application

2. The magistrate who issued the warrant authorizing the seizure of allegedly obscene films did not have sufficient information submitted and available to him to determine in a preliminary way whether there was probable cause to believe that the material to be seized was obscene within the tripartite definition of Penal Law § 235.00 and, therefore, the seized films are suppressed; because the record does not indicate whether the magistrate viewed the films or questioned the investigators who did view the films, the warrant authorization must be judged solely on the allegations contained in the papers submitted to him, which consisted of affidavits executed by the investigator who viewed the films identifying the film by title, indicating the time required to view it, and describing the sexual activity shown in some of the scenes. None of the affidavits permit an inference that the scenes described are more than a catalog of offensive parts of the whole; further, the statements relied upon are conclusory and patently ambiguous and, therefore, the magistrate was required to inquire and clarify the affidavits' meaning and the record does not establish that he did so; although the affidavits need not describe the full content of the movie, they must contain enough information to permit the issuing magistrate, applying contemporary community standards, to judge the films as a whole and determine that they are within the statutory definitions of obscenity and thus are not entitled to constitutional protection; probable cause cannot be inferred from the title of an hour and a half long film or from the description of a few scenes from it, even when the scenes described portray conduct enumerated in Penal Law § 235.00 (1) (b).

 

90 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Under 21, Catholic Home Bureau for Dependent Children v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 344; 482 N.E.2d 1; 492 N.Y.S.2d 522; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15387; 37 Empl. Prac. Dec. (CCH) P35,477


June 4, 1985, Argued  
June 28, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to appellants, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, not-for-profit corporations (corporations), filed an action against defendants, city and city officials, to invalidate Exec. Order No. 50, promulgated by the city's Mayor. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) found for the city and city officials. The corporations appealed.


OVERVIEW: The mayor promulgated Exec. Order No. 50, which prohibited employment discrimination by city contractors on the basis of sexual orientation or affectional preference. The court invalidated the order because the mayor lacked the power to promulgate it. Only the city council, as the city's legislative body, could have promulgated such an enactment under the separation of powers doctrine pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Charter ch. 2, § 21. The mayor could not have used the order to enforce any laws or constitutional requirements to prohibit the discrimination because there was no legal prohibition of such discrimination. U.S. Const. art. XIV, § 1, N.Y. Const. art. I, § 1, Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, codified at 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000e, New York State Human Rights Law, New York City Human Rights Act, located at Administrative Code of City of New York, N.Y. § B1-7.0, or Administrative Code of the City of New York, N.Y. § 343-8.0 did not prohibit such discrimination. There was no state action in the corporations' contracts with the city so that there was no city participation in the corporations' discrimination.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision for the city and city officials and ruled for the corporations in an action to invalidate the mayor's executive order.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Executive Power of Mayor -- Usurpation of Legislative Function -- Prohibition of Employment Discrimination Based on "Sexual Orientation or Affectional Preference"

1. The power of the Mayor of the City of New York to regulate the terms of city contracts (New York City Charter § 8 [a]) did not give the Mayor the authority to promulgate the challenged portion of Executive Order No. 50 which prohibits employment discrimination by city contractors on the basis of "sexual orientation or affectional preference". An executive may not usurp the legislative function by enacting social policies not adopted by the Legislature, and there is no legislative enactment prohibiting employment discrimination on such a basis; an attempt by the Mayor to broaden the class of persons protected from discrimination by private employers, or to require that all employment decisions be merit-based, however commendable, is an enactment of policy which the New York City Charter leaves to the City Council; accordingly, the challenged portion of Executive Order No. 50 does not fall within the Mayor's Charter-conferred power to regulate the terms of city contracts.

Municipal Corporations -- Executive Power of Mayor -- Duty to Prevent Violations of Equal Protection -- Prohibition of Employment Discrimination Based on "Sexual Orientation or Affectional Preference"

2. The power or duty of the Mayor of the City of New York to prevent the city from engaging in or funding discriminatory conduct which violates the equal protection clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 11) did not give the Mayor the authority to promulgate the challenged portion of Executive Order No. 50 which prohibits employment discrimination by city contractors on the basis of "sexual orientation or affectional preference". In order for a court to conclude that there is "State action", thus making equal protection requirements applicable, the alleged discriminatory conduct of a private employer must be fairly attributable to the State; there are no facts or circumstances pointed to by defendants or otherwise apparent which could make the city responsible for the employment decisions of the plaintiff contractors or of city contractors generally; thus, Executive Order No. 50, in prohibiting discrimination by city contractors on the basis of "sexual orientation or affectional preference," is not prohibiting conduct covered by the 14th Amendment. Moreover, the equal protection clause does not ordinarily prevent the city from contracting with private employers who discriminate on this basis, as the existence of the contract would not, by itself, make the city "responsible" for the private employment decisions so as to invoke constitutional protections.

 

91 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Arcara v. Cloud Books, Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 324; 480 N.E.2d 1089; 491 N.Y.S.2d 307; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15082


May 2, 1985, Argued  
June 13, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed. Questions certified answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent state brought a nuisance action against appellant company under N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2320 to enjoin and abate any conduct constituting lewdness, assignation, or prostitution at a bookstore. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) denied the company's motion for partial summary judgment and granted its motion for leave to appeal. The company appealed.


OVERVIEW: The company operated a bookstore, which sold books and magazines of a sexually frank nature and contained coin-operated movie machines showing sexually explicit material. Lewd and illegal activities, which the company permitted, were observed in the bookstore. The company argued that the denial of partial summary judgment was improper because § 2320 was intended to cover only houses of prostitution, and, hence, inapplicable. The company also argued that the order of abatement constituted prohibited prior restraint. The court held that: (1) § 2320 applied to enjoin a nuisance on premises other than a house of prostitution because there was no legislative intent to restrict its application to such function; (2) § 2320 did not require the state to show that the primary purpose of the bookstore was for lewdness or prostitution; (3) the prosecution was required to show a pattern of conduct sufficient to prove that the premises were employed for a proscribed use; and (4) closure constituted prior restraint because it was not essential to further the purpose of enjoining a nuisance under § 2320.


OUTCOME: The court modified the appellate court's grant of partial summary judgment for the company by dismissing the portions of the action seeking an order to permanently enjoin conduct constituting a nuisance or to close the bookstore. The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment as modified.


HEADNOTES

Nuisance -- Lewd and Illegal Behavior at Bookstore -- Injunction

1. Public Health Law, article 23, title II, entitled "Houses of Prostitution: Injunction and Abatement" is applicable to enjoin a nuisance in the form of lewd and illegal acts occurring at a bookstore which sells books and magazines of a sexually frank nature and contains several coin-operated movie machines showing sexually explicit material; Public Health Law § 2320, which includes in its definition of conduct constituting a nuisance any building used for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution as well as a building in which any such conduct occurs, is unambiguously broader in reach than the title of title II and the People need not show that the "primary purpose" for which the building in question is being used is lewdness, assignation or prostitution. Plaintiff's allegations raise a question of fact as to the applicability of title II; the People will have to show a consistent pattern of conduct sufficient to prove that the premises are being employed for a proscribed use; the most significant factors in making this factual determination will be the frequency of the conduct, the knowledge or even encouragement by the defendant of its existence, and the extent of the benefit, direct or indirect, derived by defendant from such activity.

Nuisance -- Lewd and Illegal Behavior at Bookstore -- Mandatory Closure Constitutes Prior Restraint

2. The mandatory closure provisions of Public Health Law, article 23, title II, which provide for the enjoining and abatement of any conduct constituting lewdness, assignation or prostitution occurring at premises, constitute an impermissible prior restraint and an infringement upon the First Amendment rights of the operator of a bookstore which sells books and magazines of a sexually frank nature and contains several coin-operated movie machines showing sexually explicit material, at which premises it is alleged that a nuisance in the form of lewd and illegal acts committed by patrons is occurring. Although a statute aimed at the abatement of a public nuisance is certainly within the police power of the State, restriction of the conduct alleged in the complaint furthers an important governmental interest, and the interest in restricting this conduct is clearly unrelated to the suppression of free expression; however, closure of defendant's bookstore is not essential to the furtherance of the purposes underlying title II, there have been no "less restrictive" remedial measures imposed which have failed to abate the nuisance, nor has the District Attorney demonstrated that the injunctive relief provided for in title II would be insufficient to abate the nuisance.

 

92 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Foss v. Rochester


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 247; 480 N.E.2d 717; 491 N.Y.S.2d 128; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 14286


May 28, 1985, Argued  
June 6, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to appellant, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which granted summary judgment to appellee city and dismissed the action of the property owner to declare N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 305 and art. 19 unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: A property owner brought a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of § 305 and art. 19, which pertained to the assessing, levying, and collection of real property taxes, claiming they deprived him of rights to due process and equal protection of the law. The trial court granted the city's motion for summary judgment, and the property owner appealed. The court affirmed the dismissal of the challenge to § 305, finding that it was not impermissibly vague because judicial construction of the statute put the property owner on notice that the use of "value" in the statute referred to "market value." The court modified the order by determining that art. 19, as applied to the property owner, violated the equal protection clause because it impermissibly created geographic classifications that resulted in unequal tax treatment of similarly situated properties. The court concluded that the property owner's non-homestead property within the city limits was being improperly taxed at a different rate than non-homestead property outside the city limits but still within the same county.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order granting the city summary judgment by dismissing the constitutional challenge to the statute permitting fractional assessment of real property, but modified the order by concluding that the legislation that permitted a dual rate tax structure violated the equal protection clauses of the federal and state constitutions by permitting similarly situated properties to be taxed unequally.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Real Property Tax -- Fractional Assessment -- Due Process of Law

1. Real Property Tax Law § 305 is not void for vagueness in violation of constitutional due process notice requirements either because it permits assessments at less than full value or because it permits fractional assessments to be made without specifying a fraction; due process requires only a reasonable degree of certainty so that individuals of ordinary intelligence are not forced to guess at the meaning of statutory terms; section 305 satisfies that standard because plaintiff has notice by established judicial construction of the term "value" that it means "market value" and because, even though the statute itself does not prescribe the uniform ratio by which all property is to be assessed, proof of such ratio is readily available in any certiorari proceeding based on valuation by use of the ratio found by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. Moreover, plaintiff received ample, albeit constructive, notice of the value relied upon in this case when the City of Rochester reassessed all property on its rolls at the uniform rate of full value.

Taxation -- Real Property Tax -- Assessment -- Fractional Assessment

2. In an action challenging the real property tax imposed by the City of Rochester pursuant to the standard of assessment mandated by Real Property Tax Law § 305, which provides for assessment "at a uniform percentage of value (fractional assessment)", plaintiff's first cause of action, to the extent that it can be inferred to allege that the Constitution requires that all assessments must be made at full market value, must fail, because his property was assessed at full market value and because the former requirement of full value assessment was statutory, not constitutional.

Taxation -- Real Property Tax -- Delegation of Legislative Authority to Tax

3. Real Property Tax Law article 19 does not constitute an improper delegation of legislative authority to tax; the article does not, by its terms or otherwise, permit local assessing units to set tax rates; rather, the Legislature has delegated the authority to tax to local legislative bodies, as it may, to be exercised by them within prescribed discretionary limits; once the local legislature adopts the statute, the assessor may classify property into residential and commercial classes by partitioning them as they appeared on the previous years' assessment rolls. The decision to adopt article 19, however, and the permissible options for varying the base proportions (Real Property Tax Law § 1903 [2] [b] [i], [ii]) remain matters entrusted to the local legislative body.

Taxation -- Real Property Tax -- Assessment -- Homestead and Non-homestead Property Classes -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Disparity in Tax Imposed upon Similarly Situated Properties

4. Local Laws, 1983, No. 6 of City of Rochester, by which the city adopted the provisions of Real Property Tax Law article 19, and article 19 itself, which permits a city or town which has undergone a revaluation of all its real property in compliance with standards imposed by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment to adopt a dual tax rate structure (Real Property Tax Law § 1901 [d]; § 1903), deny plaintiff equal protection of the laws under the Federal and State Constitutions because their application results in a disparity in county taxes imposed upon plaintiff's non-homestead property located in the City of Rochester and similar properties located outside the city. The classification of properties within the City of Rochester as homestead and non-homestead and the imposition of different tax rates on each is reasonable because arguably greater services may be required for non-homestead properties within the city than for homestead properties; however, when county taxes are applied to non-homestead properties in the city and non-homestead properties which are located outside of the city, the taxes levied result in invidious discrimination between owners of similar properties in different assessing units; Monroe County taxes non-homestead property in Rochester at a higher rate than similar non-homestead properties outside of the City of Rochester simply because, under the provisions of article 19, Rochester imposes a higher share of the tax levy on non-homestead properties than do the other towns in the county. Inasmuch as no rational demographic basis is suggested or apparent for deliberately imposing the demonstrably different tax burdens on similar properties because of their different geographic locations, the statute is unconstitutional.

Taxation -- Real Property Tax -- Invalidation of Tax Statute -- Retroactivity of Invalidation

5. Although Local Law, 1983, No. 6 of City of Rochester and Real Property Tax Law article 19 are invalid since their application violates the equal protection clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions by permitting non-homestead properties in the City of Rochester and like properties in other parts of Monroe County to be taxed unequally by the county, the fact remains that the City of Rochester relied upon the revenues derived from implementing the local law and would suffer an undue burden if it had to refund the taxes collected and, therefore, the invalidation of the statute will not be applied retroactively; thus, recovery of taxes previously paid pursuant to the legislation for the 1984-1985 tax year a now invalidated will not be permitted.

 

93 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Dougal v. County of Suffolk


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 668; 481 N.E.2d 254; 491 N.Y.S.2d 622; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 14775


May 2, 1985, Argued  
May 30, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Local Laws -- Preemption by State -- Sale of Drug Paraphernalia

In an action to declare unconstitutional Local Laws of the Town of Islip and the County of Suffolk which forbade the sale of certain drug-related paraphernalia, as preempted by State legislation, an order of the Appellate Division which affirmed a judgment declaring said Local Laws unconstitutional, is affirmed for reasons stated in the Appellate Division opinion.

 

94 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gless v. New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 669; 481 N.E.2d 254; 491 N.Y.S.2d 622; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 14776


May 2, 1985, Argued  
May 30, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Local Laws -- Preemption by State -- Sale of Drug Paraphernalia

In an action to declare unconstitutional a Local Law of the City of New York which forbade the sale of certain drug paraphernalia, as preempted by State legislation, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed a judgment in favor of plaintiffs and declared said Local Law unconstitutional, is affirmed (Dougal v County of Suffolk, 65 NY2d 668).

 

95 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Glenwood TV, Inc. v. Ratner


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 642; 481 N.E.2d 252; 491 N.Y.S.2d 620; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 14762


April 25, 1985, Argued  
May 28, 1985, Decided

HEADNOTES

Administrative Law -- Warrantless Inspection of Business Records -- Radio and Television Repair Shops

In proceedings challenging as unconstitutional provisions of New York City's regulatory scheme providing for the warrantless inspection of records required to be kept by radio and television repair shops (Administrative Code of City of New York § B32-472.0; § 773-13.0), an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed judgments finding said provisions unconstitutional and restoring the licenses of petitioners who had refused to comply with such inspections, dismissed the proceedings and declared that the statutes in question were constitutional, is affirmed for the reasons stated in so much of the opinion at the Appellate Division as dealt with the constitutional issue.

 

96 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Baird v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 655; 481 N.E.2d 253; 491 N.Y.S.2d 621; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 14768


April 23, 1985, Argued

DISPOSITION: Affirmed.

Hospitals and Asylums -- Establishment -- Public Need

In a proceeding to review a determination of the Commissioner of Health denying petitioner's [**3] application to construct two additional beds for his skilled nursing facility, which had never participated in either the Medicare or Medicaid program, a judgment of the Appellate Division, which confirmed the Commissioner's determination and dismissed the petition, is affirmed for the reasons stated in the memorandum of the Appellate Division.

 

97 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Joyce T.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 39; 478 N.E.2d 1306; 489 N.Y.S.2d 705; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15846


March 27, 1985, Argued  
May 7, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parents of a minor child sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed termination of their parental rights.


OVERVIEW: Appellant parents of a minor child had their parental rights terminated because the trial and appellate court found that they were unable, by reason of mental retardation, to properly care for the child, at the present or in the foreseeable future. On appeal, the court affirmed the order, holding that where such inability had been shown by clear and convincing evidence, there was no requirement that appellants be allowed a separate dispositional hearing for consideration of long-term foster care. The court held foster care in this instance was not in the best interest of the child, and thus she should be freed by termination of parental rights to be adopted.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed an order terminating the parental rights of appellant parents of a minor child. Where appellants' inability to care properly for the child in the present and for the foreseeable future by reason of mental retardation had been shown by clear and convincing evidence, there was no requirement that appellants be allowed a separate dispositional hearing for consideration of long-term foster care.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights -- Mental Retardation

Where a child has been in the care of an authorized agency for more than a year prior to a petition to commit guardianship and custody to the agency, and where by clear and convincing evidence the child's parents are shown to be presently and for the foreseeable future unable, by reason of mental retardation, to provide proper and adequate care for the child, there is no per se requirement of a separate dispositional hearing for consideration of long-term foster care. The particularized testimony from medical and lay witnesses who had known, examined and worked with the parents over a long period, supporting their conclusions as to the parents' retardation and inability to parent for the foreseeable future, with no countervailing evidence of the parents' alleged recent progress (Social Services Law § 384-b [6] [e]) constitutes clear and convincing proof of the statutory standards; a separate dispositional hearing for consideration of long-term foster care would be a redundancy not mandated by statute; the best interests of the child are served by freeing her for the permanence and stability of adoption; and Social Services Law § 384-b (4) (c) is not an unconstitutional infringement on the fundamental rights of intellectually limited parents without a justifiable compelling State interest or a rational basis.

 

98 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rochester v. Chiarella


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 92; 479 N.E.2d 810; 490 N.Y.S.2d 174; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15737


March 18, 1985, Argued  
May 2, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city and defendants, nonprotester taxpayers and protester taxpayers who favored refunds to nonprotester taxpayers, challenged the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), reversing the trial court's order and granting partial summary judgment to defendants, protester taxpayers who opposed refunds to nonprotester taxpayers, on their counterclaim in the city's class action.


OVERVIEW: The city initiated a class action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 9 in order to resolve all claims against it for overpayment of taxes. The trial court certified the class action and designated several subclasses. A subclass consisting of protester taxpayers who opposed refunds to nonprotester taxpayers filed a counterclaim and a motion for partial summary judgment and to dismiss pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(b), 3212. The trial court denied the motion. The intermediate appellate court reversed the trial court's order. The court reversed the intermediate appellate court's order and remanded the case. It held that the motion preceded joinder of issue and was untimely because the city had not replied to the counterclaim. The court reasoned that a Rule 3211(b) motion was unavailable to the protester taxpayer subclass because there had been no reply and the motion could not be used to anticipate defenses based upon the general denials of liability in the city's complaint.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the intermediate appellate court, which granted the motion for partial summary judgment of the protester taxpayers who opposed refunds to nonprotester taxpayers in the city's class action, and remanded the case.


HEADNOTES

Actions -- Class Actions -- Illegally Assessed Taxes -- Authority and Standing of Subclass Representatives to Seek Summary Judgment on Counterclaim for Refunds

1. Defendants, representatives of a subclass of taxpayers who protested payment of taxes determined to have been illegally assessed against them by plaintiff city, did not lack standing or authority to pursue summary judgment on their counterclaim for refunds in plaintiff's preemptive class action commenced to resolve all claims of both protesters and nonprotesters in one forum. A class representative acts as principal to the other class members and owes them a fiduciary duty to vigorously protect their interests; that responsibility clearly encompasses the duty to act affirmatively to secure the class members' rights as well as to oppose the adverse interests asserted by others; although the order appointing defendants directed them to oppose payments to nonprotesting claimants, that did not limit their authority to make this motion.

Judgments -- Summary Judgment -- Motion Made on Counterclaim before Reply -- Foreclosing Responsive Pleading

2. In a preemptive class action commenced by plaintiff city to resolve all claims by city taxpayers to obtain refunds for taxes illegally assessed against them by plaintiff, a motion by defendants, representatives of a subclass of taxpayers who protested payment of such taxes, to dismiss and for partial summary judgment pursuant to CPLR 3211 (b) and 3212 on their counterclaim for refunds was premature and Special Term properly denied it. Because plaintiff had not replied to defendants' counterclaim, their 3212 motion for summary judgment preceded joinder of issue and was untimely; a CPLR 3211 (b) motion may be addressed to a reply but that motion was not available to defendants because there had been no reply to their counterclaim and the motion could not be used to anticipate defenses based upon the general denials of liability alleged in the complaint; finally, the motion available to a party attacking a pleading who has not pleaded yet under CPLR 3211 (c), which permits the court, on notice to the parties, to treat a motion to dismiss made pursuant to subdivision (a) or (b) as a motion for summary judgment before issue is joined, may not be used by a pleader such as defendants to foreclose a responsive pleading before an opponent has had a chance to answer the claim.

Taxation -- Refund of Unconstitutionally Levied Taxes -- Source of Payment for Protesting Taxpayers -- Special Fund

3. Where the City of Rochester adopted an ordinance permitting the city to pay from a special fund the claims of nonprotesting taxpayers for city taxes illegally assessed against them, taxpayers who are entitled to refunds for taxes illegally assessed against them by the city and which they paid under protest are not limited to satisfying their claims from the assets of the special fund; the protesting taxpayers' claims are a matter of legal right, whereas the nonprotesters' claims have been created by the city as a matter of grace where none existed before; the city can limit the right of the nonprotesters to recover, as it did here, by directing that nonprotesters be paid solely from the city's special fund for tax refunds but it cannot restrict the source of payment of the protesters' claims or make payment of their judgments contingent on the moneys available in the special fund any more than it could limit the rights of other judgment creditors.

 

99 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Trump v. Chu


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 20; 478 N.E.2d 971; 489 N.Y.S.2d 455; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15852


March 21, 1985, Argued  
April 30, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, with costs to defendant, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs sought a judgment declaring that N.Y. Tax Law § 31-B violated the equal protection clauses of both the United States Constitution and the New York State Constitution, and a permanent injunction prohibiting defendant commissioner of the Department of Taxation and Finance from enforcing it. The Supreme Court, New York County (New York) upheld the statute and plaintiffs appealed from its judgment.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff real estate developers sought a judgment declaring N.Y. Tax Law §§ 1440 - 1449-c, which imposed a 10 percent tax on gains derived from real property transfers, violated the equal protection clause. The lower court upheld the statute and plaintiffs appealed. The court affirmed the holding, but modified the judgment to declare the tax law at issue did not violate either the state or federal constitutions. The court held that the legislature could establish an exemption for transfers of real property for less than $ 1 million because generally, profits increased as the amounts of gross consideration received increases. The court also held that administrative convenience and expense in the collection or measurement of the tax were alone a sufficient justification for the difference between the treatment of small incomes or small taxpayers and that meted out to others. The court held that considering the different tax treatment of condominium and cooperative developers on the one hand and subdivided improved realty on the other, it was apparent that the classification employed was rationally related to legitimate state purposes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's holding, but modified the judgment to declare that the challenged tax law did not violate either the state or federal constitutions. The court held that the classification employed was rationally related to the legitimate state purpose of raising the revenues necessary to finance the state budget and provided needed government services.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Gains Tax on Real Property Transfers -- Exemption of Transfers for Less Than One Million Dollars

1. Tax Law article 31-B, which imposes a 10% tax on gains derived from real property transfers, does not violate the equal protection clause of either the United States Constitution (US Const 14th amend) or the New York State Constitution (NY Const, art I, § 11) by exempting transfers for less than one million dollars. The taxpayers' assertion that by exempting transfers for less than one million dollars the gains tax treats identically situated taxpayers differently on the basis of varying levels of gross receipts and the gross receipts have no rational correlation to the amount of the gain, is without merit. Although liability for the tax imposed by article 31-B is determined by the amount of gross consideration, the actual calculation of the tax due depends entirely on the gain realized from the real property transfer; the gross consideration of one million dollars or more merely sets the parameters of the class of property subject to the tax; the tax imposed is not on the gross consideration received but rather on the gain that results when the consideration received for the transfer exceeds the original purchase price of the real property (see, Tax Law § 1440 [3]).

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Gains Tax -- Exemption of Transfers for Less Than One Million Dollars

2. The Legislature may establish an exemption from Tax Law article 31-B, which imposes a tax of 10% on gains derived from the transfer of real property within the State payable by the transferor (see, Tax Law §§ 1441, 1442), for transfers in which the consideration is one million dollars or less (see, Tax Law § 1443 [1]), despite the inequalities that may result; so long as it taxes only net gains, it could rationally believe that "generally speaking" profits increase as the amount of gross consideration received increases. Additionally, administrative convenience and expense in the collection or measurement of the tax are alone a sufficient justification for the difference between the treatment of small incomes or small taxpayers and that meted out to others; since the Legislature may exempt some taxpayers on this basis, where it draws the line is peculiarly a question for legislative decision especially in the field of taxation where, even more than in other fields, legislatures possess the greatest freedom in classification.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Real Property Transfer Gains Tax -- Different Treatment of Condominium and Cooperative Developers and Subdivided Improved Realty

3. The gains tax imposed on real property transfers by Tax Law article 31-B does not unconstitutionally discriminate against developers of condominiums and cooperative dwellings by requiring the aggregation of consideration in connection with the sale of condominium and cooperative dwellings for purposes of meeting the one million dollar taxing threshold, but not for the sale of subdivided parcels with improved residences. The classification employed is rationally related to the legitimate State purpose of raising the revenues necessary to finance the State budget and provide needed government services; condominium and cooperative developments involve greater administrative cost to State government than does subdivided improved realty and, because they are more likely to occur in urban areas than subdivisions, make greater demands on needed public services; treating sales of condominium and cooperative units as separate tax transactions would entail greater administrative costs than in the case of subdivided realty, thereby reducing the net revenue produced by the tax. In addition, the Legislature rationally could have believed that the challenged classification would further the conceivable purposes of encouraging the development of individually owned residences while at the same time discouraging the rapid conversion of scarce rental apartments to condominiums and cooperatives.

Taxation -- Real Property Transfer Gains Tax -- Basis of Real Property -- Original Purchase Price

4. The statutory definition of "original purchase price" utilized in Tax Law article 31-B, which imposes a 10% tax on gains derived from real property transfers, adequately reflects the basis of the real property and will not lead to imposition of the tax when a net loss is sustained. The statute defines "gain" as the difference between "consideration" (after deduction of brokerage fees) and the original purchase price (see, Tax Law § 1140 [1], [3], [5]), and the regulations promulgated to implement the statute make it clear that all customary, reasonable and necessary costs related to the acquisition and improvement of real property are included in the original purchase price so that the tax will be imposed only in the case of a net profit (see, 20 NYCRR part 590).

 

100 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Taylor


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


65 N.Y.2d 1; 478 N.E.2d 755; 489 N.Y.S.2d 152; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 16989


March 21, 1985, Argued  
April 30, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) affirming his conviction, upon his plea of guilty, for forgery in the second degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted, upon his plea of guilty, of forgery in the second degree. On appeal, defendant contended that the People failed to provide adequate notice under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 710.30 that they intended to offer certain evidence at trial. The intermediate court affirmed his conviction and held that the People's failure to provide adequate statutory notice did not require reversal because the procedure employed in the case satisfied the goal of the statute and afforded defendant adequate time in preparing his case. The court also affirmed but on different grounds. It held that, by pleading guilty, defendant forfeited his right to seek reversal of his conviction on the ground that identification testimony or evidence of prior statements was inadmissible because the prosecution failed to provide the required notice of intention to offer such evidence at trial.


OUTCOME: The appellate court affirmed defendant's conviction for forgery in the second degree.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Plea of Guilty -- Forfeiture of Right to Raise Certain Issues on Appeal

By pleading guilty, a defendant forfeits his right to seek reversal of his conviction on the ground that identification testimony or evidence of prior statements is inadmissible because the prosecution failed to provide the required notice of intention to offer such evidence at trial; the prosecutor's failure to provide timely notice of intent to introduce evidence at trial does not affect the court's jurisdiction, and it does not impinge on rights of constitutional dimension. Defendant's efforts to invoke a statutory right designed to facilitate the introduction into evidence of trustworthy statements and identifications at a trial on the issue of guilt cannot be resuscitated on appeal without express statutory authorization, since, by his guilty plea, defendant has removed the issue of his factual guilt from the case. (See, CPL 710.20, 710.30.)

 

101 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Ten Hoeve v. Board of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 1036; 478 N.E.2d 200; 489 N.Y.S.2d 59; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 16948


February 6, 1985, Argued  
April 4, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment denied, and case remitted to Supreme Court, Albany County, for further proceedings in accordance with the memorandum herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action for age discrimination arising from plaintiff employee's involuntary retirement, defendant employer appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) that modified an order of the trial court, ruled that 8 N.Y. C.R.R. 156.3(b) conflicted with N.Y Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 501(15), and granted the employee summary disposition.


OVERVIEW: The employer involuntarily retired the employee, who was a bus driver, because he was over age 65. 8 N.Y. C.R.R. 156.3(b) provided that a bus driver could not be over age 65. N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 501 (15) provided that age 70 was the mandatory retirement age. The court reversed the order granting the employee summary disposition and remitted for further proceedings. The court held that the Retirement and Social Security Law and N.Y. Exec. Law § 296 (3-a) required remittitur to determine if the employee's age was a bona fide occupational qualification for school bus drivers, and the employee's entitlement to back pay and other benefits, if any, that may have resulted from his involuntary retirement at age 65.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment granting the employee summary disposition of his age discrimination claim and remitted to determine if the employee's age was a bona fide occupation qualification.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- Bus Drivers -- Mandatory Retirement Age

In an action challenging the validity of plaintiff's termination as a school bus driver upon his reaching the age of 65 pursuant to a regulation of the Commissioner of Education, an order of the Appellate Division, which modified an order granting plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, directing plaintiff's reinstatement with back pay and declaring that 8 NYCRR 156.3 (b) was statutorily and constitutionally invalid, by declaring that the regulation in question was invalid only as in conflict with a State statute, is reversed, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment denied, and the matter remitted to Supreme Court. During the pendency of the instant appeal, Executive Law § 296 (3-a) (d) was amended to permit termination of employment because of age if age is a bona fide occupational qualification "reasonably necessary" to the performance of the employee's duties (see also, Retirement and Social Security Law § 530 [c]); the amended statute applies to the instant litigation and requires remittitur for a determination of whether age is a bona fide occupational qualification for school bus drivers and plaintiff's entitlement to back pay and other benefits, if any, which may have resulted from his involuntary retirement at age 65.

 

102 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Brown-Forman Distillers Corp. v. State Liquor Authority


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 479; 479 N.E.2d 764; 490 N.Y.S.2d 128; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15720


January 2, 1985, Argued  
April 2, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, producer and importer of distilled spirits, appealed the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) confirming a determination by respondent, State Liquor Authority, that they had violated N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law §101-b (3)[d].


OVERVIEW: Respondent, New York State Liquor Authority, found that appellant, a producer and importer of distilled spirits, sold products in New York at prices in excess of its prices elsewhere, in violation of N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law §101-b (3)[d]. Appellant was required to file an affirmation showing that the wholesale prices charged in New York were no higher that in other states. Appellant gave lump sum payments to state managers in other states, thereby effectively reducing the wholesale price in those states. Appellant failed to take into account the allowances granted under that program in filing its New York affirmation. Petitioner appealed, and alleged that respondent's determination was unsupported by substantial evidence, and that the New York affirmation statute burdened interstate commerce, in violation of the United States Constitution. The Court of Appeals affirmed the judgment of the Appellate Division, holding that the determination was supported by substantial evidence; that petitioner had not established beyond a reasonable doubt that the affirmation requirements were on their face unconstitutional or as applied to the particular facts and circumstances.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment, holding that the determination of the Authority was supported by substantial evidence; that appellant had not established beyond a reasonable doubt that the affirmation requirements of N.Y. Alco. Bev. Cont. Law §101-b (3)[d] were on their face, or as applied, unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Intoxicating Liquors -- Prices -- Affirmation Statute -- Promotional Allowances

1. A determination of respondent State Liquor Authority that petitioner violated the lowest-price affirmation provisions of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, by failing to take into account promotional allowances given to wholesalers outside New York in its affirmed price schedules, is supported by substantial evidence and is sustained. The evidence considered by the Authority supported its conclusion that the allowances in practical application reduce the prices petitioner charges wholesalers; continued availability of the allowances is keyed to a wholesaler's purchases and its actual use of the credits; petitioner's wholesalers are expected to discount their prices, and in fact do so; the allowances are calculated on a per-case dollar figure, and while that figure may not correspond precisely to per-item discounts based on actual sales, projections are fixed by petitioner with the wholesaler, based on experience and other factors, the obvious purpose being to make them accurate. Any real or apparent problem in ascertaining the precise per-item discount for purposes of the lowest-price affirmation is a difficulty built into the design of the program by petitioner itself and cannot weigh in its favor.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Liquor Price Affirmation Statute -- Commerce Clause

2. The statutory requirement that distillers affirm that they will not sell liquor to wholesalers in New York State at a higher price than the lowest price at which the same item is being sold in any other State (Alcoholic Beverage Control Law § 101-b [3]), does not contravene the Commerce Clause of the Federal Constitution (US Const, art I, § 8). When, as here, legitimate State objectives are credibly advanced in support of the statute, where no patent discrimination against interstate trade exists, and where there is only an incidental impact on interstate commerce, a flexible approach is employed in determining whether the State statute impermissibly burdens interstate commerce. The New York liquor-price affirmation statute was enacted to end discrimination against New York customers in the price of liquor; there was no showing that in either purpose or effect the New York statute advanced State revenue interests and discriminated against out-of-State businesses; and the impact of the New York statute on interstate commerce is slight, since the statute is nationwide in scope, is imitated by approximately 20 other States throughout the Nation and relates to a commodity where prices already are highly regulated.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Liquor Price Affirmation Statute -- Commerce Clause

3. The affirmation statute (Alcoholic Beverage Control Law § 101-b [3]), which requires that distillers affirm that they will not sell liquor to wholesalers in New York State at a price higher than the lowest price at which it is sold in any other State, does not violate the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8) as applied to the particular facts and circumstances of this case because of New York's unique treatment of the promotional allowances provided by petitioner distiller to its wholesalers; New York alone refuses to allow petitioner to conduct the program because the discounts are not within Alcoholic Beverage Control Law § 101-b (2) (b), and of all the affirmation States New York alone treats the credits as allowances to be taken into account in preparing the affirmed price schedule. In analyzing State statutes challenged under the Commerce Clause, the principal focus of inquiry must be the practical operation of the statute, since the validity of State laws must be judged chiefly in terms of their probable effects; it is certainly reasonable to expect that other States will recognize that the prices on petitioner's New York schedules have been adjusted, because of New York's statutory requirements, to take into account the effect of credits enjoyed by wholesalers elsewhere -- credits which the other States receiving the tangible benefits of petitioner's program apparently have already chosen not to consider in determining the affirmed price. Thus, petitioner has failed to demonstrate beyond a reasonable doubt that the threatened mechanical application of liquor laws by other affirmation States will occur or that a downward price spiral would be precipitated.

 

103 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Empire State Pharmaceutical Soc. v. New York State Dep't of Education


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 942; 477 N.E.2d 1104; 488 N.Y.S.2d 650; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 16267


February 5, 1985, Argued  
March 21, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Drugs and Druggists -- Disciplinary Proceedings

In a proceeding brought by pharmacists and a pharmacists' organization to challenge the procedures utilized by the State Department of Education (Education Law § 6510 [2] [c]) for disciplining minor or technical misconduct as violative of petitioners' constitutional rights to due process, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed a judgment granting the application and dismissed the petition, is affirmed for reasons stated in the memorandum thereat.

 

104 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn v. State Ins. Fund


No. 5


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 365; 476 N.E.2d 304; 486 N.Y.S.2d 905; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 14155


January 2, 1985, Argued  
February 21, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Both parties appealed the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which denied plaintiff employers' summary judgment motion; granted the cross motion for summary judgment by defendants, state comptroller, state commissioner of taxation and finance, and the State; and declared constitutionally valid the provisions of chapters 55 and 404 of the N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law.


OVERVIEW: The employers, insured by the state insurance fund (SIF), filed an action challenging the constitutionality of the transfer of moneys from the SIF to the state's general fund. The court held that the SIF was a state agency rather than a mutual insurance company because (1) nothing in article 6 of the N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law expressly established the SIF as a mutual insurance organization; (2) there were more dissimilarities than likenesses between the SIF and a mutual insurance company; (3) the SIF was created and existed as a state agency; and (4) the state was liable for all the SIF's liabilities. The court ruled that the transfer of the disputed moneys from the SIF to the general fund did not violate either the U.S. or New York Constitutions because (1) the policyholders had no property interest in SIF's surplus; (2) the transfer was an exercise of the state's prerogative as owner of the surplus funds; (3) the transfer was simply a pledge or earnest of the state's intention to carry out its obligations to the policyholders, if necessary; and (4) payment of the amount appropriated had to be made within the required two-year period.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate division, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Transfer of Funds from State Insurance Fund -- Property or Contractual Interest of Policyhoders in Fund Surplus -- Impairment of Contractual Obligations -- De Facto Tax

1. The State Insurance Fund (SIF) is a State agency for all of whose liabilities the State is responsible, rather, than a mutual insurance pool; thus, SIF policyholhers have no property or contractual interest in the surplus of the Fund, short of the actual declaration of a dividend by the Commissioners who administer the Fund. Accordingly, section 92 (2) of chapter of the Laws of 1982, which directed SIF to transfer to the State's general fund $ 190 million by March 1, 1983, is not unconstitutional because it impairs constractual obligations in violation of article I, § 10 (1) of the Federal Constitution. Nothing in the applicable statutory provisions or in Workers' Compensation Law $ 89's direction that "premiums in the state fund shall be fixed at the lowest posisible rates consistent with the maintenance of a solvent fund and of reasonable reserves and surplus" rises to the level of language susceptible to no other reasonable construction than the a contract was intended. Likewise, there being neither property nor contract interest of policyholders in surplus, the effect upon them of loss to the SIF of interest on the $ 190 million transferred cannot constitute a de facto tax on employers in violation of article III of the New York Constitution.

Constitutional Law -- Transfer of Funds from State Insurance Fund -- Separation of Powers -- Improper Loan of State Credit

2. By transferring $ 190 million from the State Insurance fund to the State's general fund pursuant to chapter 55 of the Laws of 1982, the State has relieved the Funds' Commissioners of the necessity of exercising investment discretion with respect to part of the funds previously entrusted to them, but has done so in the exercise of its prerogative as owner of the surplus funds and, therefore, without infringing upon separation of powers. Nor by doing so has the State improperly loaned its credit to itself, or created a debt to itself; rather it has simply given a pledge or earnest of its intention to carry out its obligations with respect to Fund policyholders should that become necessary.

Constitutional Law -- Transfer of Funds from State Insurance Fund -- Appropriation Not Required to be Expended within Two Years -- Appropriation Fixed by Reference to Other Laws

3. Chapter 55 of the Laws of 1982, which directed the State Insurance Fund (SIF) to transfer to the State's general fund $ 190 million by March 1, 1983, does not violate the provisions of article VII, § 7 of the State Consititution governing appropriation bills. Worker's Compensation Law § 87-f (1), which establishes the mechanism for annual "dry" appropriation to the SIF of $ 190 million, itself makes no appropriation. The appropriations have been made in each year by separate act, each of which, without reference to any other law, fixes the amount appropriated and specifies the purpose to which the sum appropriated is to be applied. That the moneys appropriated are not available for expenditure without approval of the Director of the Division of the Budget and that no expenditure may be made of the funds if the other assets of the SIF not part of reserves for claims or losses are available does no violence to the constitutional inhibition. And payment within two years next after passage of the appropriation act is assured by the provision of section 87-f (1) that requires payment of the amount appropriated in any given fiscal year if the Governor fails to budget or the Legislature fails to appropriate such an amount for the succeeding fiscal year. Because such payment must be made on July 1 of the succeeding fiscal year, payment will be made, if al all, within the required two-year period.

Workers' Compensation -- State Insurance Fund -- Fund as State Agency

4. The State Insurance Fund (SIF) is a State agency for all of whose liabilities the State is responsible, rather than a mutual insurance pool. Nothing in article 6 of the Workers' Compensation Law expressly establishes the SIF as a mutual insurance organization. Unlike mutual insurance companies, the SIF was created and exists as a State agency within the Department of Labor (Workers' Compensation Law § 76 [1]), its policyholders are not members and have no vote or say in administration; policyholders in the SIF not only have no responsibility to contribute to losses, as do some mutual insureds, but also are protected, as no other mutual insured is, from all claims predicated on employee injury even if the SIF, as a fund, were to become insolvent. Moreover, dividends to policyholders are discretionary, not mandatory (Workers' Compensation Law § 90).

Workers' Compensation -- State Insurance Fund -- Property Interest of Policyholders in Surplus

5. The provisions of Workers' Compensation Law § 76 (1) descriptive of the State Insurance Fund do not indicate a legislative intent that policyholders have a property interest in its surplus. The statement of what the Fund shall consist of and what expenses may be paid from it simply do not deal with what is to be done with surplus, and it is equally consistent with those descriptive provisions, when considered together with the facts that dividends are discretionary and that the State, and only the State, is responsible for payment of awards resulting from employee injury or death, either through its agency, the Fund, or from other State moneys, that such surplus as may exist after payment of discretionary dividends belongs to the State, not to policyholders. That the State has seen fit instead to assure the solvency of the Fund through the dry appropriation mechanism established by Workers' Compensation Law § 87-f is not inconsistent with that conclusion; it is rather a pledge or earnest of the State's intention to carry out the obligation which it has borne since the sentence, "[such] fund shall be administered * * * without liability on the part of the state beyond the amount of such fund was deleted from Workers' Compensation Law § 76 (1) in 1922.

 

105 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


American Ins. Asso. v. Chu


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 379; 476 N.E.2d 637; 487 N.Y.S.2d 311; 1985 N.Y. LEXIS 15875


January 2, 1985, Argued  
February 21, 1985, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, insurance associations, insurers, policyholders, and beneficiaries, challenged an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) that modified a trial court's order denying plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and granting a cross-motion by respondents, state insurance officials, for summary judgment and dismissing the complaint.


OVERVIEW: A state established a fund into which an employer or compensation carrier could pay the present value of future periodic benefits payable to compensation claimants. Two other funds were established to protect claimants from the insolvency of insurers. Insurance associations, along with insurers, policyholders, and beneficiaries, brought a declaratory judgment action against state insurance officials to have a law directing the transfer of moneys from the funds into a state fund. Plaintiffs and insurance officials brought motions for summary judgment. The trial court found that no real and present controversy existed and dismissed the suit. The appellate court modified the order, finding that plaintiffs had standing, but that the law was constitutional. On appeal, the court struck the declaration and dismissed the case. The court ruled that a justiciable controversy required plaintiffs to have an interest sufficient to constitute standing. Further, the controversy was required to involve present, rather than hypothetical, contingent, or remote prejudice to plaintiffs. Because the controversies were not ripe for determination, a declaratory judgment could not be rendered.


OUTCOME: The court modified the appellate court's order and affirmed, without costs.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Justiciable Controversy -- Present Prejudice to Plaintiffs -- Declaratory Judgments -- Constitutionality of Transfer of Moneys Into State's General Fund

1. The "justiciable controversy" upon which a declaratory judgment may be rendered requires not only that the plaintiffs in such an action have an interest sufficient to constitute standing to maintain the action but also that the controversy involve present, rather than hypothetical, contingent or remote, prejudice to plaintiffs. Thus, in an action to obtain judgment declaring unconstitutional section 92 of chapter 55 of the Laws of 1982, insofar as it directs transfer into the State's general fund of $ 50 million from the Aggregate Trust Fund (ATF), $ 67 million from the Stock Workers' Compensation Security Fund (SWCF) and $ 87 million from the Property and Liability Insurance Security Fund (PLIS) and enjoining such transfers or requiring return of the funds if transferred, the declaration that chapter 55 was constitutional is stricken and the complaint dismissed. That the balance in each of the funds has been reduced by the transfers directed by section 92 creates no risk that plaintiffs paid from the ATF will not be paid or the plaintiff interested in the other two funds will be left unprotected by insolvency of a carrier in view of the appropriations made by sections 84, 88 and 90 of chapter 55 and by chapter 404. The possibility that a subsequent Legislature may omit the required appropriation for a given year and repeal both the prior year's appropriation and the provisions of chapter 55 that annual appropriations be made, is a future event beyond the control of the parties to the action which may never occur and, thus, beyond the reach of a declaratory judgment. Moreover, the possibility that because the SWCF and PLIS will, as a result of the transfers, be earning less interest, plaintiffs may be required to contribute additional moneys to those funds is nothing more than speculation in light of the history of the funds.

Appeal -- Relief to Nonappealing Party -- Declaratory Judgment Action -- Nonjusticiable Controversy

2. On an appeal by plaintiffs from an Appellate Division order, which declared chapter 55 of the Laws of 1982 constitutional, the Court of Appeals struck the declaration of constitutionality and dismissed the complaint, despite the fact that defendants, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance and Superintendent of Insurance, were nonappealing parties, since the relief granted is incidental to the restraint upon the court against rendering an advisory determination and, having concluded that the controversy is nonjusticiable, the court cannot allow the declaration to stand.

 

106 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Maresca v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 242; 475 N.E.2d 95; 485 N.Y.S.2d 724; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4859; 45 Fair Empl. Prac. Cas. (BNA) 1606; 48 Empl. Prac. Dec. (CCH) P28,525


December 29, 1984, Argued  
December 31, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to respondents, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff judges appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which granted the cross motion of respondent state officials to dismiss and reversed the judgment of the trial court that the state constitution's mandatory retirement provisions for judges violated the due process and equal protection clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff judges, nearing mandatory retirement age, brought suit to declare N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 25(b) and N.Y. Jud. Law § 23, which mandated mandatory retirement for some judges, unconstitutional under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the federal constitution. The trial court granted the motion for a preliminary injunction, denied respondents state officials' motion to dismiss, enjoined state officials from retiring the judges, and directed that state officials retain the judges in their capacities. The appellate court reversed the decision of the trial court and granted state officials' cross motion to dismiss the complaint. On appeal, the court affirmed the order of the appellate court on the grounds that the mandatory retirement provisions were subject to the rational basis standard of review for equal protection, that mandatory retirement manifestly had a rational basis, and that equal protection did not invalidate the provisions even where other provisions permitted other judges to be certified beyond retirement age. Due process also was not violated because due process and equal protection irrebuttable presumptions were co-extensive.


OUTCOME: The court modified and affirmed the order of the appellate court, finding that the state statutes that required plaintiff judges to retire were constitutional under both the equal protection and due process clauses of the federal constitution. The court determined that the statute was subject to a rational basis equal protection standard of review and that the age limit did have a rational basis.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- Disqualification -- "Rule of Necessity"

1. The members of the Court of Appeals are not required to recuse themselves from participating in an appeal, taken as of right, challenging the State constitutional and statutory requirements that certain Judges of the State retire at age 70, even though they may be affected by the outcome of the appeal; inasmuch as the Court of Appeals has exclusive jurisdiction under the State Constitution to hear this appeal and no other judicial body exists to which this appeal could be referred for disposition, the present members of the court are required to hear and dispose of it under the Rule of Necessity.

Courts -- Role of Judiciary -- Wisdom of State Constitutional and Statutory Provisions Mandating Retirement of Certain Judges

2. It is not within the province of the judiciary to balance the wisdom of a lawfully implemented public policy against the hardship or illogic it may be said to impose. This is especially true in the instant case where the policy at issue, expressed in a constitutional provision mandating that certain Judges of the State retire at age 70 (NY Const, art VI, § 25, subd b), directly manifests the will of the electorate of the State of New York. The Court of Appeals is fully cognizant of the arguments that can be made against the wisdom of the challenged mandatory retirement provisions (NY Const, art VI, § 25, subd b; Judiciary Law, § 23); however, for the repeal of such provisions, appeal lies to the ballot and to the legislative processes of democratic government, not to the courts, and this constitutes the very core of the democratic process which, under law, proscribes only unconstitutional action.

Judges -- Mandatory Retirement -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Suspect Class -- Fundamental Right -- Mandatory Retirement of Certain Judges at Age 70

3. Judges who have attained the age of 70 do not constitute a suspect class for purposes of equal protection analysis; nor do the constitutional and statutory age restrictions that require certain Judges of the State to retire at age 70 (NY Const, art VI, § 25, subd b; Judiciary Law, § 23) impermissibly interfere with the exercise of a fundamental right. Thus, said constitutional and statutory provisions challenged by plaintiffs are not to be subjected to strict judicial scrutiny, but, rather, to a rational basis standard of review.

Judges -- Mandatory Retirement -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Rational Basis -- Mandatory Retirement of Certain Judges at Age 70

4. Pursuant to traditional rational basis analysis, a legislative enactment will pass constitutional muster if the governmental classification is based upon some conceivable and legitimate State interest. The mandatory retirement age limitation for State Judges (NY Const, art VI, § 25, subd b; Judiciary Law, § 23) is rationally related to the promotion of several State interests including the advancement of general considerations of judicial efficiency, significant reasons of fiscal concern and the proper administration of the courts. Thus, the challenged statutory and constitutional provisions mandating retirement for Judges and Justices at the end of the year in which age 70 is reached manifestly have a rational basis, and do not violate the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.

Judges -- Mandatory Retirement -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Mandatory Retirement of Certain Judges at Age 70 -- Certification of Certain Judges for Service until Age 76

5.
