The State constitutional and statutory provisions which mandate that certain Judges of the State retire at age 70 (NY Const, art VI, § 25, subd b; Judiciary Law, § 23) do not violate the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution upon the ground that an associated provision permits Justices of the Supreme Court and Judges of the Court of Appeals to receive certification for further judicial service until the age of 76, in contrast to those members of the judiciary who serve upon the Civil Court, Criminal Court, Family Court, County Court, Surrogate's Court and Court of Claims, none of whom may be so certified. Due to the complexity and diversity of the judicial grist of the Supreme Court (NY Const, art VI, § 7), certification of Supreme Court Justices and Court of Appeals Judges for service in the Supreme Court is warranted to retain Judges with experience and to insure an adequate supply of judicial personnel to meet the press of Supreme Court business. The complexity of Supreme Court matters may rationally be deemed to require greater experience and manpower than are necessary in other courts. Where, as here, significant reasons of fiscal concern and the proper administration of the courts exist, or could conceivably exist, to justify distinctions between judicial offices, the lack of mathematical symmetry within the unified court system shall be disregarded.

Judges -- Mandatory Retirement -- Due Process of Law -- Doctrine of Irrebuttable Presumptions -- Mandatory Retirement of Certain Judges at Age 70

6. Plaintiffs' claim that the State constitutional and statutory provisions which require that certain Judges of the State retire at age 70 (NY Const, art VI, § 25, subd b; Judiciary Law, § 23) violate the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, by creating an irrebuttable presumption that Judges over the age of 70 are physically or mentally incapable, is without merit. The due process doctrine of irrebuttable presumptions is coextensive with the equal protection clause, and equal protection analysis demonstrates a rational basis for the age limitation upon judicial tenure.

 

107 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Action Electrical Contractors Co. v. Goldin


No. 638


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 213; 474 N.E.2d 601; 485 N.Y.S.2d 241; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4920; 27 Wage & Hour Cas. (BNA) 217; 114 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P56,189


November 20, 1984, Argued  
December 27, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, with costs, determination of respondent Comptroller of the City of New York annulled, and matter remitted to the Appellate Division, First Department, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent city comptroller and others adopted the findings, report, and recommendation of the hearing officer that petitioner electrical contractor had failed to pay the prevailing rage of wages to and to provide certain prevailing supplements to some employees, in violation of N.Y. Lab. Law § 220. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed. The electrical contractor appealed.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Lab. Law § 220(3) required contractors on public projects to pay employees supplemental benefits in accordance with the prevailing practices in the same trade. The electrical contractor paid employees cash in lieu of some of the specific benefits provided under the prevailing practices for electrical workers. Nothing in § 220 expressly prohibited an employer from providing the prevailing supplements either totally or partially by payments in cash. The court held that the electrical contractor's payment of cash in lieu of specific benefits was permissible under the statute and that the city comptroller's interpretation of § 220 was arbitrary and irrational. Supplements could also be any payments which were not wages such as life insurance, health, disability, or vacation benefits, or holiday pay. The court also based such decision on a review of the legislative history, which reflected that § 220 was added to the statute only to address concerns about equalizing contractors' minimum labor costs. Such apparent purpose could be fulfilled when a contractor paid in cash, totally or partially, the cost of prevailing supplemental benefits to employees.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate division, with costs, annulled the determination of respondent Comptroller of the City of New York, and remitted the matter remitted to the appellate division for determination of the issue not passed upon by that court with respect to the New York City Housing Authority.


HEADNOTES

Labor -- Hours and Wages -- Employees Engaged in Public Works Projects -- Prevailing Supplemental Fringe Benefits -- Cash Equivalent of Cost -- Combination of Benefits and Cash Equal to Cost

Under subdivision 3 of section 220 of the Labor Law, supplemental fringe benefits must be provided to employees engaged in public works projects "in accordance with the prevailing practices in the same trade or occupation in the locality within the state" where the public work is located. This requirement will be fulfilled when employees are supplied with the cash equivalent of the cost of obtaining the prevailing benefits or by providing an equivalent benefits plan, or by a combination of benefits and cash equal to the cost of the prevailing benefits. The apparent purpose of the statutory provision is to equalize contractors' minimum labor costs; the legislative history of section 220 does not disclose any concern to protect workers from their possible failure to put their additional cash towards a benefit plan. Thus, this provision should not be interpreted to require that the employer maintain or contribute directly to a benefits plan equivalent in kind to the prevailing one in order to comply with the statute. Accordingly, the determination of the respondent Comptroller of the City of New York that petitioner had violated subdivision 3 of section 220 of the Labor Law by not providing its laborers and electricians with the prevailing supplemental benefits as set forth in respondent's benefits schedule or with an equivalent benefits plan, cannot be sustained; respondent evaluated petitioner's compliance with the statute according to the erroneous standard that no cash payments could be made to employees as a means of providing the prevailing supplements.

 

108 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Parsa v. State


No. 612


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 143; 474 N.E.2d 235; 485 N.Y.S.2d 27; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4933


November 15, 1984, Argued  
December 27, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, remaining claims dismissed and question certified answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which modified the judgment of the lower court and determined that respondent physician's action to recover certain money had and received by the state hospital for the physician's medical services did not attempt to circumvent the provisions of N.Y. Fin. Law § 112.


OVERVIEW: The State challenged the appellate court's order, which modified the lower court's judgment and determined that the physician's action to recover money had and received by the state hospital for the physician's medical services did not attempt to circumvent the provisions of N.Y. Fin. Law § 112. The appellate court believed that the state hospital was merely acting as a conduit in receiving Medicare funds representing compensation for the physician's services and that the funds belonged to the physician. The court reversed the order of the appellate court and held that the State had not received, nor was it holding, sums of money to which the physician was entitled any more than any of the several physicians or therapists that were entitled to the itemized sums listed on the hospital's bill for various services that they supplied to in-patients and which, in the aggregate, constituted the hospital's total charge. Inasmuch as the physician could not establish that the State was wrongfully withholding sums from him to which he was entitled under § 112, he failed to state a cause of action for money had and received.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate court.


HEADNOTES

State -- Claim against State -- Court of Claims -- Jurisdiction to Entertain Action for Money Had and Received

1. Subdivision 2 of section 9 of the Court of Claims Act gives that court jurisdiction to determine claims for "breach of contract, express or implied". The Court of Claims has jurisdiction to adjudicate claimant's claim for money had and received, therefore, because it states a legal cause of action for money damages founded upon an implied in law contract. The action is not barred by section 112 of the State Finance Law because claimant is not seeking to enforce an agreement; he is seeking to recover funds from the State which he alleges belong to him and which the State is wrongfully withholding from him.

State -- Claim against State -- Action for Money Had and Received -- Entitlement of Physician to Medicare Funds Paid to Downstate College of Medicine

2. Claimant physician, who performed salaried services in Downstate College of Medicine's kidney transplant program, has not stated a right to recover in his action against the State for money had and received predicated on a claim that he is entitled to further compensation equalling $ 290,000 of the Medicare funds paid by the Federal Government to Downstate for patients of the kidney transplant program, and that he has been wrongfully deprived of the money. Claimant's claim concerns benefits paid for hospital services under the provisions of part A of the Medicare program (US Code, tit 42, §§ 1395c-1395i); physicians and therapists are not entitled to payment under part A because they are not providers, i.e., "a hospital, skilled nursing facility * * * or home health agency" (US Code, tit 42, § 1395x, subd [u]). Payment for staff physicians' services are matters of private contract between the provider and the physician; insofar as the Medicare statute refers to charges made by the provider which may include reasonable physician's services, it states a formula for computing the provider's charges, it does not set aside fees which the physician is entitled to receive as a matter of law. Thus, the State has not received nor is it holding sums of money to which claimant is entitled; inasmuch as claimant cannot establish that the State is wrongfully withholding sums from him to which he is entitled under the Federal statute, he has failed to state a cause of action for money had and received.

 

109 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Liberta


No. 597


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 152; 474 N.E.2d 567; 485 N.Y.S.2d 207; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4916


November 13, 1984, Argued  
December 20, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) affirming his conviction for rape and sodomy.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, while living separate from his wife and after a temporary order of protection had been issued to his wife, forced her to have intercourse and perform fellatio on him. He appealed his convictions of rape under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.35 and sodomy under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.50 on the basis of his being married to his wife at the time and on equal protection grounds. The court affirmed, striking down the marital exemptions to the rape and sodomy statutes as having no rational basis. The court determined that the equal protection argument required the court to either eliminate the statutes or to make the statutes gender neutral. The court determined that making the statutes gender neutral would have addressed the equal protection concerns and would have been a better result than declaring the statutes a nullity because of the effect such a declaration would have had on public safety.


OUTCOME: Defendant's convictions for rape and sodomy were affirmed. The court struck down the marital exemptions for these crimes and also made the rape statute gender neutral by making it effective against women as well as men.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Rape -- Sodomy -- Marital Exemption -- Gender Exemption -- Remedy for Constitutionally Defective Statute

1. When a statute is constitutionally defective because of underinclusion, a court may either strike the statute, and thus make it applicable to nobody, or extend the coverage of the statute to those formerly excluded; in making such a decision the court must discern what course the Legislature would have chosen to follow if it had foreseen the court's conclusions as to underinclusiveness. Thus, the statutes for rape in the first degree and sodomy in the first degree having been found to be unconstitutionally underinclusive, the marital exemption is stricken from sections 130.35 and 130.50 of the Penal Law and the gender exemption from section 130.35 of the Penal Law, so that it is now the law of this State that any person who engages in sexual intercourse or deviate sexual intercourse with any other person by forcible compulsion is guilty of either rape in the first degree or sodomy in the first degree. Statutes prohibiting forcible sexual assaults are of the utmost importance, and to declare such statutes a nullity would have a disastrous effect on the public interest and safety; the inevitable conclusion is that the Legislature would prefer to eliminate the exemptions and thereby preserve the statutes. Because the statutes under which defendant was convicted of rape in the first degree and sodomy in the first degree are not being struck down, his conviction is affirmed.

Crimes -- Rape -- Sodomy -- Marital Exemption -- Parties Living Apart Pursuant to Court Order

2. A defendant who, while living apart from his wife pursuant to a Family Court order of protection, forcibly raped and sodomized her, may be prosecuted for either crime since he was properly found to have been statutorily "not married" to his wife at the time of the rape and sodomy and, thus, he did not come within the "marital exemption" to rape and sodomy. The subject order of protection falls squarely within the definition of "not married" which includes those cases where the husband and wife were living apart pursuant to a court order "which by its terms or in its effect requires such living apart" (Penal Law, § 130.00, subd 4); the plain language of the statute indicates that an order of protection is within the meaning of an order "which by its terms or in its effect requires [the spouses to live] apart".

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Standing -- Husband Convicted of Rape and Sodomy of Wife

3. Where defendant was convicted of rape in the first degree and sodomy in the first degree, based upon the forcible rape and sodomy of his wife, while living apart from her pursuant to a Family Court order of protection, his constitutional challenges to the rape and sodomy statutes premised on his being considered "not married" to his wife, are properly before the court. Defendant's claim is that both statutes violate equal protection because they are underinclusive classifications which burden him, but not others similarly situated. A litigant has standing to raise this claim even though he does not contend that under no circumstances could the burden of the statute be imposed upon him; this rule of standing applies as well to a defendant in a criminal prosecution who, while conceding that it is within the power of a State to make criminal the behavior covered by a statute, asserts that the statute he is prosecuted under violates equal protection because it burdens him but not others.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Rape -- Sodomy -- Marital Exemption

4. The "marital exemption" to sections 130.35 and 130.50 of the Penal Law under which a married man ordinarily cannot be convicted of forcibly raping or sodomizing his wife, lacks a rational basis for distinguishing between marital rape and nonmarital rape and, therefore, violates the equal protection clauses of both the Federal and State Constitutions (US Const, 14th Amdt, § 1; NY Const, art I, § 11). The various rationales which have been asserted in defense of the exemption are either based upon archaic notions about the consent and property rights incident to marriage or are simply unable to withstand even the slightest scrutiny.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Exemption of Females from Criminal Liability for Forcible Rape -- Gender Exemption

5. Section 130.35 of the Penal Law violates equal protection because it applies to males who forcibly rape females but exempts females from criminal liability for forcible rape of males. To meet their burden of showing that a gender-based law is substantially related to an important governmental objective the People must set forth an "exceedingly persuasive justification" for the classification which requires, among other things, a showing that the gender-based law serves the governmental objective better than would a gender-neutral law. The fact that the act of a female forcibly raping a male may be a difficult or rare occurrence does not mean that the gender exemption satisfies the constitutional test; a gender-neutral law would indisputably better serve, even if only marginally, the objective of deterring and punishing forcible sexual assaults. The only persons "benefitted" by the gender exemption are females who forcibly rape males; a gender-based classification which, as compared to a gender-neutral one, generates additional benefits only for those it has no reason to prefer cannot survive equal protection scrutiny.

Constitutional Law -- Due Process of Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Husband Convicted of Rape and Sodomy of Wife -- Affirmance of Conviction after Striking of Marital and Gender Exemptions from Statutes

6. The Court of Appeals decision to retain the statutes prohibiting rape in the first degree and sodomy in the first degree, while striking the marital exemption from sections 130.35 and 130.50 of the Penal Law and the gender exemption from section 130.35 of the Penal Law, and thereby affirm defendant's conviction of rape in the first degree and sodomy in the first degree, arising out of the forcible rape and sodomy of his wife while living apart from her pursuant to a Family Court order of protection, does not deny him due process of the law. Defendant did not come within any of the exemptions which have been stricken, and thus his conduct was covered by the statutes as they existed at the time of his attack on his wife. Neither can it be said that by the affirmance of his conviction that defendant is deprived of a constitutionally protected right to equal protection; for purposes of choosing the proper remedy for the underinclusiveness of the rape and sodomy statutes, the defendant is simply not similarly situated to those persons who were not within the scope of the statutes as they existed prior to the court's decision.

 

110 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Islip v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 50; 473 N.E.2d 756; 484 N.Y.S.2d 528; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4775; 22 ERC (BNA) 1568


November 15, 1984, Argued  
December 18, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, with costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, Suffolk County, with directions to enter partial summary judgment and for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State sought review of an order of a Court of Appeals (New York), in favor of respondent Town, which reversed a judgment of the trial court. The trial court held that N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 was enacted in violation of N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(b)(2).


OVERVIEW: The State passed legislation to protect the ground water by limiting the Town's ability to utilize landfills for waste disposal. The Town contended that N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 violated of N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(b)(2), the home rule provisions of the State Constitution. The court held that the trial court erred when it held N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 conflicted with the home rule provisions of the constitution because N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 3(a)(3) declared that nothing in the home rule provisions impaired the Legislature in relation to matters other than the property, affairs, or government of the Town. The court held that although N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 was a special law that affected the Town's property, its purpose was the protection of the sole aquifer for Nassau, Suffolk, and part of Queens from pollution, which was a matter of State concern. Therefore, it was within the power of the Legislature under N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 3(a)(3) to enact N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704 without the request or message of necessity referred to in under N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(b)(2).


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court, which held that a restriction on the Town's use of its landfills violated constitutional home rule provisions, was reversed. The case was remitted to the trial court for a partial summary judgment in favor of the State on the issue of the constitutionality of the subject statute, and for further proceedings in accordance with the court's opinion.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of State Statute under Home Rule Article of State Constitution -- Statute Limiting Disposal of Solid Waste by Landfill in Nassau and Suffolk Counties -- Special Law -- Matter of State Concern

The limitation upon the power of the Legislature to act by special law in relation to the property, affairs or government of a local government contained in article IX (§ 2, par [b], cl [2]) of the New York Constitution must be read together with section 3 (par [a], cl [3]) of the same article, which declares that, "Except as expressly provided, nothing in this article shall restrict or impair any power of the legislature in relation to: * * * [matters] other than property, affairs or government of a local government"; so read, the limitation applies only to a special law which is directly concerned with the property, affairs or government of a local government and unrelated to a matter of proper concern to State government. Although ECL 27-0704, which limits disposal of solid waste by landfill in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, is a special law which affects town property (the continued use of existing landfills and the use of presently owned town property for new landfills), its purpose is the protection of the sole source aquifer for Nassau, Suffolk and part of Queens from pollution, a matter of State concern. It was, therefore, within the power of the Legislature under article IX (§ 3, par [a], cl [3]) to enact ECL 27-0704 without the request or message of necessity referred to in section 2 (par [b], cl [2]) of that article.

 

111 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


New York State Coalition for Criminal Justice, Inc. v. Coughlin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 660; 474 N.E.2d 607; 485 N.Y.S.2d 247; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4923


November 12, 1984, Argued  
December 11, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, special interest groups, individual citizens, and taxpayers, appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the supreme court that granted a motion for summary judgment to defendants, the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Correctional Services and others, and denied plaintiffs' application for a preliminary injunction.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs argued that the Prison Construction Act, 1983 N.Y. Laws 56, which authorized the issuance of bonds and notes to finance construction of a prison, was null and void because is violated N.Y. Const. Art. VIII, §§ 1, 3. The trial court severed plaintiffs' claim dealing with affirmative action and found that plaintiffs lacked standing to maintain the action. The appellate court concluded that the Act did not violate the constitution. On appeal the court found that plaintiffs lacked standing pursuant to N.Y. State Fin. Law § 123-b(1), which did not confer standing on taxpayers challenging bond issues or notes issued in anticipation thereof by the state or its agencies. To confer standing to plaintiffs would render the statutory exception a nullity and ignore the express legislative policy to the contrary.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order that dismissed plaintiffs' complaint.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Standing -- Issuance of Bonds for Prison Construction

Plaintiff taxpayers lack standing to challenge the issuance of bonds and notes by the State Urban Development Corporation for the construction of additional prisons in the State (see State Finance Law, § 123-b, subd 1; see, also, Wein v Comptroller of State of N. Y., 46 NY2d 394, which noted clear legislative intent to prevent taxpayer challenges with respect to a State "bond issue or notes issued in anticipation thereof").

 

112 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Birkeland v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 663; 474 N.E.2d 608; 485 N.Y.S.2d 248; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4924


November 14, 1984, Argued  
December 11, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Nonjudicial Personnel -- Provisional Employees

In an action to declare unconstitutional chapter 846 of the Laws of 1980, which conferred permanent competitive class status on certain provisional employees of the Unified Court System in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed an order declaring chapter 846 constitutional, should be affirmed for the reasons stated in the opinions at Special Term and the Appellate Division (116 Misc 2d 1, affd 98 AD2d 395). The Legislature's enactment of chapter 846 occurred in the aftermath of the reorganization of the State court system and was parallel with similar legislation applicable, State-wide, to other judicial districts; in view of this particular situation and the express finding by the Legislature that the normal competitive procedures would greatly disrupt the functioning of the court system, the statute cannot be said to offend the constitutional mandate for competitive examinations (NY Const, art V, § 6).

 

113 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Burrows v. Board of Assessors


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


64 N.Y.2d 33; 473 N.E.2d 748; 484 N.Y.S.2d 520; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4772


October 11, 1984, Argued  
November 29, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order modified, with costs to appellants, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed judgments of the Supreme Court at Special Term entered in Columbia County.


OVERVIEW: The court declared N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 458(5) unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection clauses of the New York Constitution, N.Y. Const. art I, § 11, and the United States Constitution, U.S. Const. amend. XIV. While recognizing that the Legislature was accorded broad latitude in the establishment of tax classifications and that a discriminatory tax classification would pass constitutional muster if any conceivable state of facts supported the classification, a statute should nevertheless be declared unconstitutional if the difference in treatment constituted invidious discrimination or was palpably arbitrary. The disparate treatment of similarly situated veterans resulting from the classification created by N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 458(5) lacked a rational basis.


OUTCOME: The lower court order, in each case, was modified, with costs to appellants, by declaring invalid two sections of the New York Real Property Tax Law, and as so modified, the lower court's order was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Exemptions -- Veterans' Exemption

Section 458 (subd 5) of the Real Property Tax Law, which provides in paragraph (a) for a mandatory proportionate increase (or decrease) in the veterans' exemption if a local taxing jurisdiction's change in the manner of assessing real property was caused by court-ordered full value assessment, and in paragraph (b) that the local taxing jurisdiction had the option of providing by local law for such a proportionate increase (or decrease) in the veterans' exemption where the change in the manner of assessing was caused by other than court-ordered full value assessment, is unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection clauses of the New York Constitution and the United States Constitution, since the disparate treatment of similarly situated veterans resulting from the classification created by the statute lacks a rational basis. Subdivision 5 of section 458 must be invalidated in its totality since paragraphs (a) and (b) together constitute a single expression of legislative policy regarding the increase of veterans' real property tax exemptions; the unity of purpose which exists between paragraph (a) and paragraph (b) precludes the severance of paragraph (b) from the statute so as to grant all veterans, irrespective of local policy preferences, mandatory increases in real property exemptions. The policy decision to grant or deny increases in veterans' real property tax exemptions properly rests within the discretion of the local and State Legislatures.

 

114 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rivera v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


63 N.Y.2d 501; 472 N.E.2d 1015; 483 N.Y.S.2d 187; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4684


October 16, 1984, Argued  
November 27, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant correctional facility appealed an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment declaring that performance of a pat frisk by a female officer violated the religious rights of respondent, a male, Muslim inmate, and ordered that any reference to reports relating to the incident be expunged from the inmate's institutional records.


OVERVIEW: The male prison inmate, who was Muslim, was selected along with two or three other inmates at random for a pat frisk. The inmate objected to the female officer who approached him to conduct the frisk. The inmate expressed his concern to a sergeant, and was written up in a misbehavior report. The inmate sought an order, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, declaring that Directive 4910 of the Department of Correctional Services, which governed frisks of inmates, was unconstitutional. He also sought expungement from his record the write-up of his refusal to submit to the frisk. The trial court found that a pat frisk conducted by a female officer involved sufficient physical contact to violate a male Muslim's religious beliefs, which prohibit physical contact between the sexes outside of marriage. The trial court held that where searches were carried out as a routine precaution or were conducted at random, male correction officers were to be used to pat frisk Muslims. The court agreed with the trial court, but held that it was error for the trial court to have ordered that references to the incident be expunged from the inmate's institutional records.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order by eliminating the expunging of the inmate's institutional record and, as so modified, affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Prisons and Prisoners -- Freedom of Worship -- Pat Frisk of Male Muslim Inmate by Female Correction Officer

1. Under section 3 of article I of the New York Constitution and section 610 of the Correction Law, it would have been a violation of the right of a Muslim inmate to free exercise of his religious beliefs, in the limited circumstances of this case, for him to have been subjected to a random pat frisk performed by a correction officer of the opposite sex; this intrusion on the prisoner's religious beliefs would not have been justified here by the State's interests in maintaining prison security or in providing equal opportunity for women to serve as prison guards. It was not established that legitimate security interests call for the use of female prison guards to perform random pat frisks of male Muslim inmates in violation of the latters' religious beliefs; when petitioner, a male Muslim inmate, was approached by the female correction officer for a random pat frisk there were other male officers in the vicinity who could have performed the search, and the delay required to respond to a Muslim's objection to a pat frisk by an officer of the opposite sex would be minimal. Nor was it shown that the State's interest in providing equal employment opportunity to women justified a pat frisk of petitioner by the female correction officer; any one correction officer does not have the absolute right to pat frisk any single inmate of his or her selection; accommodating the religious beliefs of Muslim inmates in this instance could be attained with only a minimal impact on job assignments.

Prisons and Prisoners -- Refusal of Inmate to Carry Out Illegal Order of Correction Officer -- Expunging Institutional Records

2. It was error to order references to an incident involving a refusal by petitioner, a male Muslim inmate, to submit to a random pat frisk by a female correction officer, expunged from the inmate's institutional records following the court's determination that such pat frisk would have violated petitioner's right under New York law to the free exercise of his religious beliefs. In view of the characteristics of the correctional system and the compelling interests of the State in the preservation of security and order within correctional facilities, the recognition and enforcement even of constitutional rights may have to await resolution in administrative or judicial proceedings; self-help by the inmate cannot be recognized as an acceptable remedy. The risks inescapably attendant on the refusal of an inmate to carry out even an illegal order of a correction officer are such as to require compliance at the time with the right of retrospective administrative or judicial determination as to the legality of the order.

Appeal -- Court of Appeals -- Matters Reviewable -- Finding of Supreme Court Affirmed by Appellate Division

3. Inasmuch as the Appellate Division affirmed the Supreme Court findings that petitioner's Muslim beliefs compelled him to avoid contact with members of the opposite sex outside of marriage which view was supported by testimony that the Qu'ran requires Muslims to avoid such physical contact, even when clothed, but that the "sin" of such contact might be forgiven if one's will to prevent it is violated in an emergency, these factual determinations are beyond the scope of the Court of Appeals review; moreover, the Appellate Division having affirmed the Supreme Court finding that a pat frisk by a female correction officer involves physical contact which is violative of the religious creed of a male Muslim inmate, such finding, too, is not reviewable in the Court of Appeals, there being evidence for its support in the record.

 

115 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Adoption of Daniel C.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


63 N.Y.2d 927; 473 N.E.2d 31; 483 N.Y.S.2d 679; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4723


September 12, 1984, Argued  
October 30, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Consent -- Revocation -- Standing

An order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed an order of the Surrogate's Court holding that the best interests of a child would be served by his adoption by the adoptive parents and that the natural mother's revocation of consent to the adoption should be denied any further force and effect, should be affirmed. It is not necessary to reach the question whether section 115-b of the Domestic Relations Law requires that a consent form recite the effect of a notice of revocation set forth in subdivision 1 (par [d], cl [ii]) of that section or appellant's contention that a consent form which fails to do so is constitutionally infirm; by reason of appellant's counsel's concession that she did not claim to have been misled by the form, the adoptive parents were foreclosed from introducing evidence of her awareness of the provisions of the statute, and therefore she is without standing to raise the above issues.

 

116 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Westinghouse Electric Corp. v. Tully


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


63 N.Y.2d 191; 470 N.E.2d 853; 481 N.Y.S.2d 55; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4612


September 10, 1984, Argued  
October 18, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: On reargument following remand by the Supreme Court of the United States, judgment modified, with costs to petitioner, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, Albany County, with directions to remand to the Tax Commission for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The United States Supreme Court reversed and remanded to the court a judgment annulling a determination of respondent commission sustaining the imposition of corporate franchise tax assessments against petitioner taxpayer and held that the manner in which the state allowed corporations a tax credit on the accumulated income of their subsidiary domestic international sales corporations violated the commerce clause.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was assessed tax deficiencies because it failed to include in its entire net income accumulated income from its wholly owned subsidiary. The court held that certain clauses of the applicable statute were unconstitutional, but the remainder were valid, and thus affirmed the judgment as modified. The court found that the effect of its ruling was to extend the tax credit formerly available only to New York exports to all of the applicable accumulated income attributable to a parent corporation, without regard to the exports' place of shipment. The court determined that the statute, as so interpreted, promoted the legislature's intent to provide a strong incentive for the continuation and expansion of export-related business in New York by lowering the effective tax rate of any business that owned a domestic international sales corporation and it also advanced the legislature's purpose of minimizing losses because, even with an extension of the credit, the law continued to produce substantial tax revenues.


OUTCOME: The judgment holding that the tax credit allowance violated the commerce clause was modified to hold that only certain clauses of the applicable statute were unconstitutional and, as modified, the judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Income of "DISC" Subsidiary

Although clauses (2) and (3) of section 210 (subd 13, par [a]) of the Tax Law, relating to taxation of domestic international sales corporations (DISCs) are unconstitutional because they authorize credits which favor exports shipped from New York and discriminate against exports shipped from other States, the invalid portion may be severed from the valid and the remainder of the statute preserved on the authority of section 208 (subd 9, par [i], cl [B], subcl [3]) of the Tax Law which requires that DISC shareholders continue to be taxed, consistent with Federal law, on deemed distributions in the event taxation of accumulated income is invalidated and expresses the intention of the Legislature to salvage some revenues from the taxation of DISCs even if the statute was subsequently impaired. Accordingly, only that portion of the tax credit that discriminates against exports shipped from outside of New York is invalidated, thus effectively extending the DISC tax credit formerly available only to New York exports to all of the DISC accumulated income attributable to the parent corporation, without regard to the exports' place of shipment.

 

117 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re von Wiegen


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


63 N.Y.2d 163; 470 N.E.2d 838; 481 N.Y.S.2d 40; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4610


September 6, 1984, Argued  
October 16, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified and matter remitted to the Appellate Division, Third Department, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent attorney appealed an order of the Appellate Division, Supreme Court, Third Department (New York) in a disciplinary proceeding commenced by the Committee on Professional Standards. A referee had sustained one charge. The Appellate Division confirmed the referee's report with respect to that charge, and confirmed portions of another charge. The issue concerned attorney's right to solicit accident victims by mail.


OVERVIEW: This was a lawyer disciplinary proceeding which resulted in attorney's suspension from the practice of law for six months. Attorney had solicited by mail the victims and families of the 250 persons injured when a sky-walk collapsed at a Kansas City hotel. Attorney solicited business by letters that were false and misleading and, in unrelated advertising, used a trade name. The court agreed with the referee's determinations. Two charges could be dismissed in their entirety but the charge was sustained that the references in the solicitation letter to a committee and to the fact that many victims had retained attorney were misleading. There was ample support in the record for the interpretation of petitioner that attorney's actions justified suspension and there was no need to establish that the letters actually mislead the recipients. It was the potential for deception which was significant in the unique situation of lawyer mailings to accident victims.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order and remitted the matter to the Appellate Division, Third Department, and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs. The court agreed generally with the determinations of the referee and dismissed charges I and III and affirmed the determination on charge II that the references in attorney's solicitation letter to a committee and to the fact that many victims had retained attorney were misleading.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Disciplinary Proceedings -- Direct Mail Solicitation of Potential Clients

1. A charge that respondent attorney violated section 479 of the Judiciary Law and the Code of Professional Responsibility by engaging in direct mail solicitation of the victim's and/or their families of the Hyatt Regency Hotel disaster in Kansas City, Missouri, is dismissed. Inasmuch as the State seeks to regulate respondent's letter, not because of the involvement of third parties, but because of the subject matter of the communication -- the fact that respondent seeks to be retained to represent accident victims and their families, the regulation is plainly content-based; accordingly, since the State cannot establish interests of sufficient magnitude to override the public's interest in receiving information on the availability of legal services and the danger of deception presented by the mailing may be controlled by the filing requirement, the blanket prohibition of mail solicitation of accident victims violates respondent's rights of expression under the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.

Attorney and Client -- Disciplinary Proceedings -- Deception and Misrepresentation

2. Petitioner Committee on Professional Standards presented sufficient evidence to support allegations that respondent attorney employed deception and misrepresentation in letters mailed to victims and/or their families of the Hyatt Regency Hotel disaster in Kansas City, Missouri, seeking to be retained by them, which letters contained statements that a litigation coordinating committee had been formed to assist the victims and that many of the victims or their families had requested representation by respondent. Petitioner satisfied its burden of proof by introducing the letters themselves, which, when interpreted in a commonsense manner, contained two deceptive statements; testimony by recipients of the mailings was not necessary before the writing could be found deceptive. Moreover, there was no need to establish that the letters actually mislead the recipients; it is the potential for deception which is significant.

Attorney and Client -- Disciplinary Proceedings -- Use of Trade Name

3. The use of the motto "The Country Lawyer" in flyers advertising respondent attorney's services did not constitute a violation of the prohibition against use of a trade name contained in DR 2-102 (B). Inasmuch as respondent's name was inserted apart from the motto, the use of the motto did not deceive the public about his identity, responsibility and status.

 

118 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Adoption of Robert Paul P.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


63 N.Y.2d 233; 471 N.E.2d 424; 481 N.Y.S.2d 652; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4628; 42 A.L.R.4th 765


September 7, 1984, Argued  
October 16, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant homosexuals sought review of a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order of the trial court that denied their application for the older partner to adopt the younger partner in an attempt to legalize their homosexual relationship.


OVERVIEW: A homosexual couple sought to have the older partner adopt the younger partner in an effort to legalize their homosexual relationship. The lower court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that denied their adoption application. The homosexuals contended that, because New York recognized adoption of adults, the lower court erred in denying their application for adoption. The court disagreed, and affirmed the judgment of the lower court. The court held that where the homosexuals were living together in a homosexual relationship and where no incidents of a parent-child relationship were evidenced or even remotely within the parties' intentions, no fair interpretation of N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 110 could permit a granting of the petition. Adoption, the court held, was not a means of obtaining a legal status for a nonmarital sexual relationship, whether homosexual or heterosexual.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the lower court, which held that the trial court properly denied the adoption petition of a homosexual couple because it was not the intention of the New York Legislature that adoption statutes be employed to legitimize homosexual relationships.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Adult Adoption -- Adoption of One Homosexual by Another

It was not error for Family Court to deny the petition of a 57-year-old male to adopt a 50-year-old male with whom he shares a homosexual relationship; adoption is "the legal proceeding whereby a person takes another person into the relation of child and thereby acquires the rights and incurs the responsibilities of parent" (Domestic Relations Law, § 110), and where the relationship between the adult parties is utterly incompatible with the creation of a parent-child relationship between them, the adoption process is not the proper vehicle by which to formalize their partnership in the eyes of the law. Adoption is not a quasi-matrimonial vehicle to provide nonmarried partners with a legal imprimatur for their sexual relationship, and because adoption is entirely statutory and is in derogation of common law, the legislative purposes and mandates must be strictly observed; while there are no special restrictions on adult adoptions under the provisions of the Domestic Relations Law, the Legislature could not have intended that the statute be employed to arrive at an unreasonable or absurd result.

 

119 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rochester v. Chiarella


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


63 N.Y.2d 857; 472 N.E.2d 46; 482 N.Y.S.2d 270; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4656


September 13, 1984, Argued  
October 11, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Refund of Real Property Tax to Nonprotesting Taxpayers

In a class action involving the payment of unconstitutionally levied real property taxes in the City of Rochester, where, following a determination that there was no legal right to recovery of taxes paid without formal protest, the city enacted an ordinance providing for payment of tax refunds to nonprotesting taxpayers, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed an order adjudging the ordinance to be lawful and constitutional, is affirmed for the reasons stated in the opinion at the Appellate Division, which concluded that Ordinance No. 83-162 does nothing more than recognize the claims of the nonprotestors as equitable claims and provide that any compromise with nonprotestors be limited to the amount available in the city's special fund for tax refunds; that the effect of the ordinance is to give the nonprotestors [**4] standing to remain in the class action; that under the facts here presented, the enactment of the ordinance was a proper exercise of the legislative function by the City Council without violating the Constitution, and that nothing in the ordinance affects the legal claims of the protestors against the city which have been established earlier.

 

120 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bell


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


63 N.Y.2d 796; 471 N.E.2d 137; 481 N.Y.S.2d 324; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4623


September 5, 1984, Argued  
October 9, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed his conviction of attempted murder in the second degree, robbery in the first degree, and assault in the first degree. He argued that his in-court identification was unfair and prejudicial, that he was denied his right to a fair trial, and that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 650.20(1) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of attempted murder, robbery, and assault in the stabbing of a liquor store co-owner. The appellate court's affirmation of the trial court's judgment of conviction was upheld on further appeal. Even if defendant's contention that the proper test for admissibility of photographs of a victim being attended in the hospital was a balancing of the inflammatory nature of the photographs against their materiality and relevance, the court found no abuse of discretion regarding their admission. Although the trial court should have articulated findings before trial as to the victim's in-court identification of defendant, no objection was made. The admission of the identification was beyond the court's power to review where there was evidence in the record sustaining the conclusion that there was an independent basis for the identification and there was no taint sufficient to constitute a substantial likelihood of misidentification. The court declined to reach defendant's argument that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 650.20, was unconstitutional insofar as it exempts from its operation an out-of-state witness being held under sentence of death.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Evidence -- Photographs of Victim

1. Even if the court were to accept defendant's contention that the proper test for admissibility of photographs of a victim being attended in the hospital is a balancing of the inflammatory nature of the photographs against their materiality and relevance to the prosecution's case, there was no abuse of discretion in the admission of the photographs here in question. They were not gory, the lacerations they show having either been cleaned up or bandaged, and while the knife remaining embedded in the victim's back was startling in the sense of being unusual, the picture it presented of the knife was less unnerving than the oral testimony concerning it; nor did the "startling" nature of the photographs so far outweigh their relevance to defendant's complicity in the crime as to constitute an abuse of discretion as a matter of law.

Crimes -- Identification of Defendant

2. With respect to the victim's in-court identification of defendant, the ruling implicit in the admission of the identification in court is, after affirmance by the Appellate Division, beyond the Court of Appeals power of review, there being evidence in the record to sustain the conclusions that there was an independent basis for the identification and no taint sufficient to constitute a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.

 

121 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


La Rossa, Axenfeld & Mitchell v. Abrams


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 583; 468 N.E.2d 19; 479 N.Y.S.2d 181; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4452; 1984-2 Trade Cas. (CCH) P66,263


June 6, 1984, Argued  
July 3, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment, insofar as appealed from, reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, Attorney-General, appealed a judgment of the Supreme Court at Special Term in New York County (New York) that declared unconstitutional the provision of N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 343, punishing noncompliance with a subpoena issued thereunder as a misdemeanor, insofar as it applies to any person who has previously commenced proceedings pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 2304 seeking an order quashing or modifying such a subpoena.


OVERVIEW: In connection with an antitrust investigation of the ready-mix concrete industry in New York City, the appellant, New York Attorney-General, served subpoenas on plaintiffs pursuant to N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 343. Plaintiffs moved pursuant to N.Y.C.P.L.R. 2304 to quash or modify the subpoenas. Appellant appealed the trial court's grant of injunctive relief to the Appellate Division and thereby obtained an automatic stay. Plaintiffs never moved to vacate or modify that stay. Plaintiffs commenced an action alleging that § 343 was violative of plaintiffs' due process rights. The court held that, after balancing the competing interests of plaintiffs and appellant and the degree of protection which existing safeguards provided for plaintiffs in light of the particular facts and circumstances of the case, appellant was entitled, consistent with due process, to commence a criminal prosecution against plaintiffs for refusing to comply with the issued subpoenas even though a motion to quash the subpoenas was pending.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed, and § 343 was declared constitutional insofar as it applies to persons who began a proceeding to quash or modify a subpoena prior to commencement of a criminal prosecution.


HEADNOTES

Attorney-General -- Subpoenas -- Motion to Quash -- Penalty for Failure to Comply with Subpoena -- Due Process of Law

The Attorney-General was entitled, consistent with due process, to commence a criminal prosecution against plaintiffs pursuant to section 343 of the General Business Law for refusing to comply with subpoenas issued in connection with an antitrust investigation, even though a motion by plaintiffs pursuant to CPLR 2304 to quash the subpoenas was pending. Although plaintiffs have substantial private interests at stake, since they face civil and criminal penalties should they be convicted of wrongfully refusing to obey the subject subpoenas, the government's interest in maintaining the Attorney-General's investigatory powers free from unnecessary hindrance is also substantial, and the adequacy of procedural remedies to protect plaintiffs from civil or criminal penalties establishes the reasonableness of the Attorney-General's action. According to the express provisions of section 343 of the General Business Law, plaintiffs cannot be held criminally or civilly liable for refusing to comply with the Attorney-General's subpoenas unless they have done so "without good cause", and this opportunity to challenge the propriety of the subpoenas in a criminal proceeding is an adequate procedural safeguard to insulate an individual from an erroneous deprivation of liberty or property. In addition, while plaintiffs did move under CPLR 2304 to quash the subpoenas and successfully requested preliminary injunctive relief, the orders granting said relief were automatically stayed pursuant to CPLR 5519 by virtue of the Attorney-General's appeal to the Appellate Division and at no time did plaintiffs seek to vacate the statutory automatic stays; accordingly, plaintiffs failed to avail themselves of an additional opportunity to prevent accrual of penalties.

 

122 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


63 N.Y.2d 41; 468 N.E.2d 879; 479 N.Y.S.2d 706; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4533


April 23, 1984, Argued  
July 2, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified and case remitted to Supreme Court, Dutchess County, for resentencing in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant inmate sought review from a judgment of the Supreme Court (New York), on a guilty verdict for first degree murder, sentencing him to death as required by N.Y. Penal Law § 60.06, arguing trial court error, insufficient evidence to prove guilt, and unconstitutionality of mandatory death penalty statute.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was charged and convicted of the murder of a corrections officer pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27. Appellant's motion to set aside the guilty verdict was denied, and he was sentenced to death as required by N.Y. Penal Law § 60.06, which imposed a mandatory death sentence. Appellant sought review, arguing insufficient evidence to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, trial court errors depriving him of his right to fair trial, and unconstitutionality of the state death penalty statute. The court held that guilt beyond a reasonable doubt was adequately proven and no reversible errors had been committed by trial court. However, that the mandatory death penalty statute was unconstitutional because of its failure to provide for the consideration of individual circumstances.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the sentence of death, holding that the mandatory state death penalty law was unconstitutional, but affirmed the judgment otherwise and remanded the case for resentencing in accordance with the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Murder -- Killing of Person by Prisoner Serving Life Sentence -- Evidence

1. There is proof beyond a reasonable doubt of murder in the first degree (Penal Law, § 125.27, subd 1, par [a], cl [iii]) to support the conviction of a defendant who, while serving an indeterminate sentence of from 25 years to life, killed a corrections officer; the evidence linked defendant to a bite mark on the corrections officer's body, and the remaining circumstantial evidence established that defendant had both the opportunity, and access to the materials, for killing the corrections officer and disposing of her body.

Constitutional Law -- Mandatory Death Penalty -- Mitigating Circumstances

2. New York's mandatory death penalty statute (Penal Law, § 60.06) for a person convicted of murder while "confined in a state correctional institution * * * upon a sentence for an indeterminate term the minimum of which was at least fifteen years and the maximum of which was natural life" (Penal Law, § 125.27, subd 1, par [a], cl [iii]) contravenes the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Federal Constitution as applied to defendant because of its failure to provide for consideration by the sentencer of the relevant individual circumstances of the defendant's character and record and the circumstances of the offense.

Crimes -- Capital Cases -- Scope of Review

3. Under the State Constitution, in capital cases in which the sentence of death has been imposed, the Court of Appeals is empowered to review the facts (NY Const, art VI, §§ 3, 5) and must examine the evidence to determine whether it has been sufficient to make out a case of murder beyond a reasonable doubt. However, even in a capital case the Court of Appeals should not readily interfere with the verdicts of jurors who have had the advantage of seeing and hearing witnesses.

Crimes -- Evidence -- Photograph of Bite Mark on Body of Another Murder Victim

4. At the trial of a defendant charged with first degree murder for the killing of a corrections officer in 1981 while serving a life sentence, the trial court, after conducting a hearing out of the presence of the jury, properly held that a black and white photograph of a bite mark allegedly made by defendant in 1977 on the nose of another murder victim, Marilee Wilson, redacted so as to show little more than a jagged line representing the teeth marks, could be admitted into evidence and a comparison made to a photograph of a bite mark on the subject corrections officer's body. Defendant's confession to the Wilson homicide was not obtained in violation of his constitutional rights; accordingly, the trial court properly found that there was independent basis for concluding that defendant was responsible for the Wilson bite mark. Given the acceptability of photographs for comparisons of bite marks on a single victim and the other evidence, including expert testimony that a photo comparison of bite marks on different persons was a reliable and accepted procedure among forensic odontologists, the trial court did not err in permitting a photo-to-photo comparison of the Wilson bite mark with the bite mark on the corrections officer. Finally, the probative value of the photograph of the Wilson bite mark outweighed its potential for unfair prejudice; the parties were required, in the presence of the jury, to refer to the Wilson photograph only as defendant's known bite mark in human tissue; and given the fact that the defense vigorously disputed the identification of the bite mark on the corrections officer's body by comparing it with models of defendant's teeth and elicited testimony that human skin was an ideal medium for bite mark identification, the identification of the bite mark through the photo comparison procedure cannot be dismissed as cumulative.

Crimes -- Evidence -- Newly Discovered Evidence -- Review by Court of Appeals

5. In a noncapital case, the power to review a discretionary order denying a motion to vacate a judgment upon the ground of newly discovered evidence ceases at the Appellate Division; even in a capital case, the Court of Appeals has been most reluctant to substitute its discretion to overturn the lower courts' exercise of discretion in denying a motion for a new trial upon the ground of newly discovered evidence.

Crimes -- Fair Trial -- Duty to Disclose Exculpatory Evidence

6. In a prosecution for first degree murder arising out of the killing of a corrections officer by a prisoner serving a life sentence, the prosecutor did not breach his duty to disclose exculpatory material in failing to disclose a "Chronological Report on Inmates Assigned to Special Housing Unit -- Downstate Correctional Facility"; defendant's request did not put the prosecution on notice that this specific document existed and the record is devoid of any indication of prosecutorial bad faith or negligence; thus, a new trial would be required only if the material were obviously exculpatory and created a reasonable doubt not otherwise existing, and the subject report satisfies neither requirement.

Crimes -- Fair Trial -- Duty to Disclose Exculpatory Evidence -- Correction of Error

7. Any error in the prosecutor's nondisclosure of an "unusual incident" report, obtained by the defense from a third party in the midst of the prosecutor's summation, was cured when the trial court interrupted the People's summation, allowed defense counsel to recall the witness and place this evidence before the jury, and permitted defense counsel to address the jury on this issue before the prosecutor resumed his summation.

Judges -- Disqualification

8. The Trial Judge's impartiality was not undermined merely by his appointment of the prosecutor whose conduct with respect to the submission of evidence to the Grand Jury was being questioned, the Trial Judge did not exhibit bias in denying several pretrial motions, and the decision on a recusal motion is generally a matter of personal conscience. While it may have been the better practice for the Trial Judge to insure that defense counsel was aware of his previous relationship with the Special District Attorney, whom he had hired as an Assistant District Attorney when he was District Attorney of Dutchess County, the association was not so substantial that the Trial Judge abused his discretion in presiding over the trial.

Crimes -- Right to Counsel -- Delay in Appointing Counsel -- Disparity in Funding between Prosecution and Defense

9. In order to prevail on his appeal from a first degree murder conviction and death sentence arising from the May 15, 1981 death of a corrections officer, defendant must show that his defense was ineffective as a result of the delay in appointing his present counsel or the disparity in funding between the prosecution and defense. Where defendant's present counsel first appeared for him on June 10, 1981 and declared he would serve without compensation, was replaced by the Public Defender in March 1982, after a funding impasse developed, and then in September 1982 was appointed defendant's counsel with compensation at the established rates for defense counsel, defendant has not shown that his defense was ineffective as a result of the delay or disparate funding. The Court of Appeals cannot presume that the alleged errors resulted in a denial of meaningful representation where its independent review of the record belied this contention.

Crimes -- Venue

10. There was no error in the Appellate Division's conclusion that defendant's motion for a change of venue, made prior to jury selection, should have awaited the results of voir dire; since defendant failed to renew the motion following voir dire, there is no other ruling for the Court of Appeals to review.

Crimes -- Instructions -- Hypnotized Witness Charge

11. Defendant failed to request a hypnotized witness instruction, and its absence from the charge does not warrant reversal in the interest of justice where, although several prosecution witnesses were hypnotized, the trial court determined that it would limit their testimony to events recalled prior to hypnosis, and defendant admits that the hypnosis issue was not a major factor before the jury.

Crimes -- Witnesses -- Cross-Examination of Witness Regarding Collateral Crime

12. In a first degree murder trial, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in prohibiting defense counsel from cross-examining a witness more extensively about the details of his testimony at his own murder trial; counsel had already mounted a substantial attack on the credibility of this witness and the limits placed on cross-examination regarding a collateral crime were not unreasonable.

Statutes -- Presumption of Constitutionality

13. To prevail on his claim that the State statute imposing the death penalty (Penal Law, § 60.06) for first degree murder (Penal Law, § 125.27) is unconstitutional, defendant must overcome the strong presumption of constitutionality which attaches to legislative enactments.

Constitutional Law -- Mandatory Death Penalty -- Remission for Consideration of Mitigating Circumstances

14. On defendant's appeal from a conviction of first degree murder (Penal Law, § 125.27) and sentence of death, the Attorney-General's alternative argument that the Court of Appeals should deem the mandatory death penalty statute (Penal Law, § 60.06) to include a provision for consideration of mitigating circumstances and remit for a hearing, is rejected. Section 60.06 of the Penal Law provides that "the court shall sentence the defendant to death" upon a first degree murder conviction, and the Attorney-General's suggested interpretation is at odds with the wording of the statute and would require the Court of Appeals to rewrite the statute, which the court cannot do.

Crimes -- Sentence -- First Degree Murder -- Authorized Disposition Following Determination that Mandatory Death Penalty  Statute is Unconstitutional

15. Based upon its determination that defendant's guilt of murder in the first degree (Penal Law, § 125.27, subd 1, par [a], cl [iii]) had been established, but that New York's mandatory death penalty statute (Penal Law, § 60.06) is unconstitutional as applied to defendant, the Court of Appeals modified the judgment by vacating the sentence of death and remitting the case to Supreme Court for resentencing in accordance with section 70.00 of the Penal Law (see Penal Law, § 60.05, subd 2).

 

123 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Public Employees Federation v. Cuomo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 450; 467 N.E.2d 236; 478 N.Y.S.2d 588; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4407


June 5, 1984, Argued  
June 29, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Judgment modified in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed, with costs to plaintiffs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff public employee advocates and defendant state officials filed cross appeals of consolidated actions in New York trial courts which declared that N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 613(c) violated N.Y. Const. art. V § 7 because it unconstitutionally diminished the benefits of certain public employees, but that N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 606(c) did not.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 613(c) limited the right of certain state employees, known as Tier III employees, to withdraw contributions from the retirement system. N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 606(c) amended the formula for determining the ordinary death benefits paid on the death of Tier III employees. The public employees' associations sought judgments from various trial courts declaring that both statutes were unconstitutional under N.Y. Const. art. V § 7, which prohibited the impairment of benefits of membership in the state retirement system. Both sides appealed. On appeal, the court modified the consolidated judgments and affirmed. The court held that § 613(c), which limited the right of Tier III employees to recover their contributions to the retirement system, was unconstitutional because the legislature could not impair pension benefits by limiting the duration of the statute creating them. The court held that § 606(c) was unconstitutional despite the fact that employees did not contribute to death benefits because death benefits were a benefit of membership in the retirement system and could not be impaired.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment of the trial court to find that a statute that reduced the benefits payable on the death of certain public employees was unconstitutional because it retroactively reduced a statutorily conferred benefit and affirmed the modified judgment, which held that both that statute and a statute which limited the right of certain public employees to the return of retirement contributions were unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Retirement and Pension Benefits -- Limitation on Withdrawal of Tier III Member Contributions

1. Benefits statutorily conferred upon members of ancy pension or retirement system of the State or of any division thereof must be interpreted as permanent, despite any provision of the statute limiting its duration, inasmuch as a contrary interpretation would render such a provision an unconstitutional impairment of contractual rights protected by section 7 of article V of the New York State Constitution by conferring a benefit and then, upon the expiration of the statute, taking it away. Accordingly, subdivision c of section 613 of article 15 of the Retirement and Social Security Law, which became effective on September 1, 1983 (L 1983, ch 414, § 1) violates section 7 of article V of the New York State Constitution and is unconstitutional insofar as it purports to abrogate the rights of employees hired on or after July 1, 1976 (commonly referred to as Tier III employees) and before September 1, 1983, to the return, at the time of termination of employment prior to the 10-year vesting period, of contributions to the New York State Employees' Retirement System made by them after July 1, 1976, and instead provides that such contributions will be refunded only when the member dies or reaches 62 years of age. Moreover, such employees terminated before achieving 10 years' service are entitled to return of contributions made on or after July 1, 1976, including contributions made after September 1, 1983; the right to the return of all contributions made in reliance on section 517 of article 14 of the Retirement and Social Security Law was constitutionally protected, notwithstanding that article 14 was enacted for a limited duration.

Civil Service -- Retirement and Pension Benefits -- Reduction of Tier III Member Death Benefits

2. Subdivision c of section 606 of article 15 of the Retirement and Social Security Law, which became effective September 1, 1983 (L 1983, ch 414, § 1) violates section 7 of article V of the New York State Constitution and is unconstitutional insofar as it reduces death benefits payable on the death of State employees hired on or after July 1, 1976 (commonly referred to as Tier III employees) and before September 1, 1983 compared to benefits previously authorized and computed for the beneficiaries of such employees pursuant to subdivision a of section 508 of article 14 of the Retirement and Social Security Law; the death benefit was a benefit of membership in the retirement system rendered contractual in nature by section 7 of article V, regardless of whether specific funds were earmarked for a death benefit fund or not.

 

124 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Shattenkirk v. Finnerty


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 949; 468 N.E.2d 53; 479 N.Y.S.2d 215; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4467


June 7, 1984, Argued  
June 29, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Compensation and Benefits -- Withholding of Salary Increase from Certain Employees

In a proceeding, converted to an action for a declaratory judgment, to annul a budget bulletin promulgated by the Director of the Budget which withheld salary increases from management/confidential State employees where any salary increase would bring them within 98% of their supervisor's salary (the "98%" rule) and from certain "exempt" management/confidential employees making more than $ 23,065 annually, an order of the Appellate Division, which modified a judgment invalidating the bulletin by declaring it to be valid and constitutional, is affirmed for reasons stated in the Appellate Division opinion, which concluded that petitioners' contention that chapter 460 (§ 7, subd 10) of the Laws of 1982, pursuant to which the budget bulletin was issued, was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority was without merit since there is no constitutional prohibition against the delegation of power, with reasonable safeguards and standards, to an agency or commission to administer the law as enacted by the Legislature, and the words "warranted" and "appropriate" set out a constitutionally permissible standard; that the "98%" rule was enacted pursuant to the legitimate State objective of avoiding salary compression; that the Budget Director's act of withholding the salary increases for only the highest paid management/confidential employees was rational and neither arbitrary and capricious nor violative of equal protection; and that the withholding of increases for exempt employees making more than $ 23,065 was not a violation of equal protection since it rationally related to the legitimate State objective of reducing the cost of government.

 

125 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gandolfi v. Yonkers


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 995; 468 N.E.2d 699; 479 N.Y.S.2d 517; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4484


June 7, 1984, Argued  
June 29, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Real Property Taxes -- Constitutional Limitation

In two actions [**6] challenging the validity of section 1262-b of the Tax Law, which authorized Westchester County to pay its share of sales tax revenue to the Cities of Yonkers, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon and to Levy an additional property tax in those cities for the amount of taxes so paid, and which was expressly made operative only "until such time as the real property tax limitations in the constitution of the state of New York with respect to cities are increased", an order of the Appellate Division, which modified two orders and judgments declaring section 1262-b unconstitutional and denying refunds of taxes paid to those who protested the additional levy, by granting refunds to those protesters, is affirmed for reasons stated in the opinion at the Appellate Division, which concluded that section 1262-b was intended to circumvent the 2% taxing limit contained in section 10 of article VIII of the State Constitution; that the statute was simply an attempt to disguise a city real estate tax, thereby violating the letter and spirit of the State Constitution; that Westchester County's increase of its real property tax was for the benefit of the City of Yonkers which could not itself levy the tax [**7] since it had already reached the 2% limit; that the fact that the Cities of New Rochelle and Mount Vernon had yet to reach their 2% limit did not require a different result since section 1262-b had the effect of enlarging the constitutional limitation, precisely the evil the State Constitution was designed to avoid, and, therefore, was just as invalid for those cities as it was for Yonkers; that, accordingly, there was no need to reach the equal protection and due process arguments, and that taxpayers who protested the increased levy were entitled to a refund of taxes paid, since, as a result of the decision in Hurd v City of Buffalo (34 NY2d 628), municipalities were put on notice that patent circumvention of the constitutional taxing limit would not be tolerated, and since, as reflected in the bill jackets, defendant county and cities were well aware of the potential challenges to the legislation.

 

126 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Subcontractors Trade Ass'n v. Koch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 422; 465 N.E.2d 840; 477 N.Y.S.2d 120; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4359


May 2, 1984, Argued  
June 14, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent subcontractors association challenged the executive order by petitioner mayor that mandated that 10 percent of all construction contracts were to be given to locally based enterprises.
