The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) reversed the dismissal of the complaint by the trial court and declared the order unconstitutional. The mayor appealed.


OVERVIEW: The executive order was adopted in an effort to promote the development of business and employment opportunities in economically depressed areas. The court framed the issue as whether the mayor was legally empowered to issue the order. The court stated that the subcontractors association was directly affected by the order and had standing to bring the action. The subcontractors association argued that the mayor legislated by fiat a policy for which there was no grant of legislative power and that the order was unconstitutional and invalid. The court agreed that the order represented an unconstitutional usurpation of legislative power. The general power to enter into contracts did not serve as a basis for creating a remedial plan for which the mayor never received a grant of legislative power. The executive order created a program at odds with existing legislative policy.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the finding that the executive order was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Standing -- Existence of Justiciable Controversy

1. Plaintiffs, 17 trade associations, have standing to bring a declaratory judgment action seeking invalidation of an Executive Order issued by the Mayor of the City of New York, mandating that a 10% share of all construction contracts awarded by the city be given to "locally based enterprises", since plaintiffs are subject to and directly affected by the order; an actual controversy is presented which the courts have power to resolve in a declaratory judgment action without the need to conduct a trial, since there are no factual questions to be confronted in deciding whether the Mayor had the authority to issue the Executive Order.

Municipal Corporations -- Executive Power of Mayor -- Unconstitutional Usurpation of Legislative Power

2. The Mayor of the City of New York may not, by Executive Order, lawfully mandate that a 10% share of all construction contracts awarded by the city be given to "locally based enterprises"; the order represents an unconstitutional usurpation of legislative power; there is no legislative authority permitting the Mayor to unilaterally initiate this type of program or the means for effectuating it.

 

127 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Stern v. Morgenthau


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 331; 465 N.E.2d 349; 476 N.Y.S.2d 810; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4321


April 30, 1984, Argued  
June 12, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the Administrator of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, appealed the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order denying the Administrator's motion to quash a grand jury subpoena duces tecum. The subpoena, issued by the district attorney, directed the Administrator to produce various documents related to judicial activities.


OVERVIEW: The district attorney of New York county, during an investigation of possible crimes of bribery among judges, served a grand jury subpoena duces tecum on the Administrator of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, seeking certain documents related to the Commission's investigation of the same charges. The Administrator moved to quash the subpoena, alleging that the records sought were confidential. The trial court denied the Administrator's motion, and the decision was affirmed by the lower court. The appellate court affirmed, but the court reversed, holding that the New York state legislature had exempted the Commission's confidential records from grand jury scrutiny.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the lower court upholding the denial of the Administrator's motion to quash the subpoena, and granted the motion to quash the subpoena.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury -- Subpoena Duces Tecum -- Confidential Records of State Commission on Judicial Conduct

A Grand Jury, acting in furtherance of a lawful investigation involving two Judges, may not subpoena confidential records of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct developed during an investigation into conduct of the Judges; the Legislature has the power to exempt certain records from Grand Jury scrutiny notwithstanding section 6 of article I of the New York Constitution, which states that "[the] power of grand juries to inquire into the willful misconduct in office of public officers * * * shall never be suspended or impaired by law", and it has exercised that power with respect to confidential records of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct (Judiciary Law, §§ 44, 45, 46). The legislation creating the Commission and defining its powers was not designated to thwart the powers of the Grand Jury, but instead established an independent investigatory body to maintain the integrity of the judiciary, and while the Commission's power may indirectly result in a diminution of the scope of the Grand Jury's inquiry, it does not deprive the Grand Jury of its power to investigate a Judge or any other public official and therefore does not constitute a violation of the anti-impairment clause. The Grand Jury's traditional investigative powers, although extensive, are not unlimited, and it may not violate a valid privilege, whether derived from the Constitution, statutes or the common law; and sections 44, 45 and 46 of the Judiciary Law, which establish a legislative scheme to insure the confidentiality of Commission records, were intended to prohibit disclosure to the Grand Jury; a specific provision prohibiting such disclosure was not required to accomplish that purpose.

 

128 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Marie B.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 352; 465 N.E.2d 807; 477 N.Y.S.2d 87; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4350


May 8, 1984, Argued  
June 12, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner county social services agency (agency) alleged that respondent mother violated the terms of an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal (ACD) order and sought the child's removal under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 1039(e). The family court dismissed the petition, determining that the statute was unconstitutional. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) affirmed. The agency appealed.


OVERVIEW: The family court entered a temporary order granting the agency temporary custody of the child, then issued an ACD order under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 1039. Conditions of the order included the mother's abstention from alcoholic beverages and acceptance of alcoholic treatment and counseling. Within two months, the agency removed the child from the mother's care because the mother was intoxicated. The agency filed a petition requesting permanent removal under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 1039(e). On appeal of the dismissal of the petition, the court held that § 1039(e) equated a violation of an ACD order with parental neglect but did not provide for a hearing or a finding of actual parental neglect. The court held that due process and protected privacy rights prohibited governmental interference in the rights of a parent except on a showing of overriding necessity. The court held that the mere violation of an ACD order did not necessarily amount to any constitutionally required predicate for removal of a child from his home. The court held that the provision of § 1039(e) authorizing the presumption of neglect without a finding of actual neglect was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the dismissal of the agency's petition for removal of the child.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Abused or Neglected Child -- Constructive Finding of Neglect upon Violation of Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal

That portion of subdivision (e) of section 1039 of the Family Court Act which provides that parental neglect shall be deemed to exist whenever a court finds that the parent has failed substantially to observe the terms of a previously ordered adjournment in contemplation of dismissal (ACD), of charges of parental neglect or has failed to cooperate with the supervising child protective agency, and that upon such a finding, regardless of whether the parental conduct actually constituted neglect or abuse, the court may proceed directly to a dispositional hearing and order the child removed, is unconstitutional; legislation authorizing the removal of a child from the parent without the requisite showing of abandonment, surrender, persisting neglect, unfitness or other like behavior evincing utter indifference and irresponsibility to the child's well-being, constitutes an impermissible abridgement of fundamental parental rights, and a constructive finding of neglect is a constitutionally inadequate justification for the drastic interference with parental rights permitted under the statute. An ACD is not a determination on the merits, but rather, leaves the question of parental neglect unanswered.

 

129 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Ford Motor Credit Co. v. Hickey Ford Sales


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 291; 465 N.E.2d 330; 476 N.Y.S.2d 791; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4317


May 7, 1984, Argued  
June 7, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order appealed from and prior order of the Appellate Division brought up for review affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) held that appellant creditor could not attach real property belonging to respondent property owners in an attachment proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6212 and that the property owners could not recover damages against the creditor for mental distress. Both sides appealed.


OVERVIEW: The creditor, an automobile finance company, discovered that one of its dealers had fraudulently obtained floor plan financing and failed to pay the purchase price for several vehicles. As a result, the creditor obtained an ex parte attachment order directing the sheriff of any county to levy upon property in which the debtor had an interest. The creditor filed a notice of attachment regarding real property that was at one time in the name of the debtor but that was subsequently conveyed to the debtor's wife. The wife then conveyed the property to the property owners who had no notice of the attachment. After the creditor attempted to have the land sold at auction, the property owners brought an action to vacate the attachment and notice of sale. The court held that where the moving papers did not contain any ground for attachment against the debtor's wife's property, the attachment was invalid. It also ruled that the record did not establish actual malice sufficient for an award of damages against the creditor where it showed no more than that the attachment was issued on behalf of its attorney.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment denying the validity of the creditor's attachment and denying recovery of mental distress damages to the property owners.


HEADNOTES

Attachment -- Damages -- Mental Distress

To sustain a warrant of attachment against the property of a defendant, the moving papers must establish both a cause of action and a ground for attachment as to that particular defendant; as to an attachment issued without ground, the owner of the property, though not a party to the underlying action, may, in a proceeding to CPLR 6212 (subd [e]), recover damages for mental distress upon a showing of actual malice. CPLR 6212 (subd [a]) provides that to obtain an attachment plaintiff "shall show * * * that there is a cause of action, that it is probable that the plaintiff will succeed on the merits, that one or more grounds for attachment * * * exist and that the amount demanded from the defendant exceeds all counterclaims known to the plaintiff"; that plaintiff must show the existence of a ground for attachment as to each defendant against whom he seeks a warrant necessarily follows. CPLR 6212 (subd [e]) authorizes an award of damages to property owners and others who had an interest in the property attached but were not defendants in the action in which the order of attachment was granted. Recovery for mental distress is not limited to situations involving outrageous conduct, and the award of damages under CPLR 6212 and 6221 is governed by the rules relating to an action for wrongful attachment; whether the action be denominated for trespass or conversion or for malicious prosecution through the wrongful use of civil proceedings, the action is closely akin to malicious prosecution, and damages for emotional distress of a kind normally expected to follow from the wrongful action are recoverable in such an action; however, evidence only that an attachment was issued on plaintiff's behalf by its attorney is insufficient to establish actual malice.

 

130 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Morse


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 205; 465 N.E.2d 12; 476 N.Y.S.2d 505; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4286


March 29, 1984, Argued  
May 17, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: In People v Covington, Vega and Johnson: Order affirmed.

In People v Morse: Order modified and case remitted to Supreme Court, Bronx County, for sentence in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.

In People v Frank: Order modified and case remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for sentence in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Five defendants appealed the decision of the Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York), which affirmed their various felony convictions and their receipt of an enhanced punishment pursuant to the second violent offender law or the persistent violent offender law pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law §§ 70.04 and 70.08.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were convicted of various felony convictions and were assessed an enhanced punishment under the second violent offender statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 70.04, and persistent violent offender law, N.Y. Penal Law. §70.08. Defendants appealed. The lower court affirmed, and appeal was taken. The court held that a sentence as multiple offender was not to be viewed either as new jeopardy or additional penalty for earlier crime but was stiffened penalty for latest crime, which was considered to be an aggravated offense because it was a repetitive one. Thus, the fact that a predicate crime was not designated as a violent felony offense at the time the predicate offense was committed did not render the application by defendants of statutes governing a second violent felony offender and persistent violent offender unconstitutional as imposition of an ex post facto law. The court held that where defendants pleaded guilty to two violent felony offenses on the same day and were sentenced on a single day to concurrent prison terms, defendants could not be sentenced under the persistent violent felony statute, even though the charges arose out of separate incidents.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed three defendants' felony convictions pursuant to the state's second violent offender law or the persistent violent offender law. Two defendants' convictions were modified by substituting, for the persistent violent felony offender adjudication, a second violent felony offense adjudication and were remitted for resentencing.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second and Persistent Felony Offenders

1. Both the second violent offender law (Penal Law, § 70.04) and the persistent violent felony offender law (Penal Law, § 70.08) require imposition of enhanced punishment upon conviction as a second or persistent violent felony offender, even though at the time of the prior conviction on which enhanced punishment is based the prior crime was not classified as a violent felony offense; section 70.04 (subd 1, par [b]) of the Penal Law makes it clear that the enhanced punishment provisions of sections 70.04 and 70.08 are to apply when the prior crime was committed between September 1, 1967 (the effective date of the present Penal Law) and September 1, 1978 (the effective date of the violent offender law). It is inconceivable that the Legislature intended to exclude from the predicate crime category crimes committed in New York between those dates but not the identical crimes prior to September 1, 1967 or committed in another State; that the predicate crime was not designated a "violent felony offense" when committed does not require a contrary conclusion so long as the elements of the crime when committed were the same as those of an offense now defined as a violent felony offense by subdivision 1 of section 70.02 of the Penal Law. Furthermore, there is no violation of the restriction against ex post facto laws contained in article I (§ 10, cl 1) of the United States Constitution; a sentence as a multiple offender is not to be viewed as either a new jeopardy or additional penalty for the earlier crimes, but is a stiffened penalty for the latest crime, which is considered to be an aggravated offense because a repetitive one. Accordingly, the convictions of three defendants sentenced as second or persistent violent felony offenders are affirmed even though the predicate convictions antedated the effective date of the statute classifying the crime on which the conviction was based as a violent felony offense.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Persistent Felony Offenders

2. The Legislature did not intend the persistent violent felony law (Penal Law, § 70.08) to apply unless each of the two or more predicate violent felony convictions other than the first was for a felony which occurred after sentence had been imposed for the conviction which preceded it; it was not intended that the two or more predicate violent felony offenses required as the predicate for enhanced punishment under the statute be determined individually, i.e., by the separate crimes committed without regard to the fact that convictions may have been jointly obtained. A legislative policy of sequentiality (i.e., the second offense, to be counted as a predicate, must be committed after sentence was imposed on the first) has been established for second felony offenders, persistent felony offenders, second violent felony offenders, and by cross reference for persistent violent felony offenders as well, and it was not intended that sequentiality should apply between the present and each of the prior convictions but not between the prior convictions themselves. Accordingly, persistent violent felony adjudications against two defendants who pleaded guilty to two violent felony offenses on the same day, the charges having arisen out of separate incidents, and who were sentenced on a single day to concurrent prison sentences, are vacated, and the cases are remitted for sentencing of the defendants as second violent felony offenders.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second and Persistent Felony Offenders

3. Where the predicate offense under the second violent offender law (Penal Law, § 70.04) and the persistent violent offender law (Penal Law, § 70.08) is only so classified because it occurs after a plea of guilty to a lesser included offense, there is no statutory infirmity in the failure to recite in the predicate felony information that the prior conviction was obtained upon a plea of guilty or any constitutional defect because the same offense would not be classified as a violent felony if conviction had been obtained after trial. There was no jurisdictional defect because the sentencing minutes include the Judge's statement that "there has been no jury connected with any of these prior criminal acts." Since the information stated the prior conviction to have been for attempted criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree and made specific reference to subdivision 1 of section 70.02 of the Penal Law, which refers to a lesser included offense as defined in CPL 220.20, it is clear that the offense could be a lesser included offense only when conviction is on a plea of guilty and not by verdict ( CPL 220.20, subd 2); therefore, the claimed missing allegation is sufficiently incorporated by reference. Defendant was aware when he entered his guilty pleas to the prior offenses that the offense to which he pleaded existed essentially only for the purposes of plea negotiation, reliance on the prior indictment is minimal, and the enhanced punishment imposed constitutes no violation of due process.

 

131 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Barnes


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 702; 465 N.E.2d 35; 476 N.Y.S.2d 528; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4306


March 22, 1984, Argued  
May 3, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court (New York), which affirmed the trial court's judgment convicting defendant of attempted resisting arrest.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of attempted resisting arrest and sought review. Defendant argued that N.Y. Penal Law § 60.35 and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 420.35, providing for the levying and collection of a mandatory surcharge following every criminal conviction, violated the equal protection clauses of the federal and state constitutions. On review, the court concluded that the statutes did not offend the equal protection clause by creating any irrational classification; the statute treated all convicted persons similarly, the court found, and no fundamental rights were at issue. The court found that since the challenged laws bore a reasonable relationship to some legitimate objective, such as raising revenues, it passed constitutional muster.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the lower courts affirming defendant's conviction for attempted resisting arrest and upholding the statutes providing for the levying of mandatory surcharges for criminal convictions.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Mandatory Surcharge

The mandatory penalty assessment law ( Penal Law, § 60.35; CPL 420.35) does not offend the equal protection clause by creating an irrational classification, since the statute treats all persons convicted of Penal Law offenses similarly, and it is of no moment that this group is singled out for this assessment. The "rational relationship" test sought to be applied by defendant would only be relevant if the State sought to treat similarly situated individuals in a different [***2] manner. Because these statutes do not employ suspect classifications or adversely affect fundamental rights, the only rationality test which must be passed is the determination of "whether the challenged classification bears a reasonable relationship to some legitimate legislative objective", and the penalty would appear to be related, at the very least, to the State's legitimate interest in raising revenues.

 

132 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Tommy & Tina v. Dep't of Consumer Affairs


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


62 N.Y.2d 671; 464 N.E.2d 988; 476 N.Y.S.2d 290; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4281


March 20, 1984, Argued  
May 1, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Licenses -- Common Show Licenses -- Video Games -- Proximity to School

In a proceeding to annul a determination of the Department of Consumer Affairs of the City of New York revoking petitioners' common show licenses for the operation of video games on their premises since they were located within 200 feet of a school in contravention [***3] of Department regulations, and that the 200 feet should be measured from building line to building line, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed a judgment denying the application, is affirmed for reasons stated in the memorandum thereat, which concluded that an administrative agency's construction and interpretation of its own regulations and of the statute under which it functions are entitled to the greatest weight; that the State Liquor Authority's 200-foot rule was irrelevant since the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law specifically requires the door-to-door measurement; that the concern of the Department is to keep the video games as far as is reasonably permissible from a school, and that minimization of the opportunity for children to enter stores where video games are available is reasonably related to the Department's responsibility to further consumer protection.

 

133 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Majauskas v. Majauskas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


61 N.Y.2d 481; 463 N.E.2d 15; 474 N.Y.S.2d 699; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4159; 6 Employee Benefits Cas. (BNA) 1053


February 20, 1984, Argued  
April 3, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff former husband sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), modifying the trial court's distribution of his vested but unmatured rights in a pension plan.


OVERVIEW: The former husband brought an action for divorce. The parties owned no property of substance other than the former husband's vested, but unmatured, rights in a police department's pension plan. The divorce was ultimately granted, and the trial court found the present value of the former wife's share of the pension and gave the former husband three options to pay the award; one option was for the former husband to pay one-half of his monthly pension payments to the former wife. On appeal, the appellate division modified the property division because the former husband had no present ability to pay the award and deleted the alternate forms of payment. The court affirmed the appellate court's order, holding that the trial court had the discretion to divide the former husband's vested but unmatured pension because it was acquired between the date of the marriage and the commencement of the divorce action.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order modifying the trial court's distribution of the former husband's vested, but unmatured, rights in a pension plan.


HEADNOTES

Husband and Wife -- Equitable Distribution -- Vested Rights in Noncontributory Pension Plan

1. Vested rights in a noncontributory pension plan are marital property to the extent that they were acquired between the date of the marriage and the commencement of a matrimonial action, even though the rights are unmatured at the time the action is begun; the matrimonial court in the exercise of the discretion vested in it by part B of section 236 of the Domestic Relations Law may order distribution to one spouse of an equitable portion of that part of the present value of the other spouse's pension rights earned during marriage, or may provide that upon maturity of the pension rights the recipient pay a portion of each payment received to his or her former spouse or may, if it determines that valuation or other problems make equitable distribution impractical or burdensome, order a distributive award in lieu of equitable distribution. To the extent that pension rights result from employment time after marriage and before commencement of a matrimonial action, they are contract rights of value, received in lieu of higher compensation which would otherwise have enhanced either marital assets or the marital standard of living and, therefore, are marital property; distribution of the pension does not diminish or impair it contrary to the State Constitution (art V, § 7) since the pension of the employee spouse is not diminished in the sense that the pension fund will pay any lesser amount.

Husband and Wife -- Equitable Distribution -- Method of Payment of Pension Rights -- Review by Court of Appeals

2. Whether marital property shall be distributed or a distributive award shall be made in lieu of, or to supplement, facilitate or effectuate a distribution of marital property are matters committed by section 236 (part B, subd 5) of the Domestic Relations Law to the discretion of the Trial Judge in the first instance; the authority of the Appellate Division is as broad as that of the Trial Judge, and absent an exercise of discretion so egregious that it can be characterized as an abuse as a matter of law, its exercise of discretion is not reviewable by the Court of Appeals. A change by the Appellate Division in the procedure of payment of defendant's portion of future pension payments received by plaintiff is thus beyond review in the Court of Appeals, and inasmuch as the Trial Judge had directed the use, as the numerator of the fraction by which the final average salary is multiplied, of the number of months the parties were married, by limiting the numerator to the number of months prior to the commencement of the action during which the parties were married, the Appellate Division simply conformed the judgment to the statutory definition of marital property as property acquired before commencement of the matrimonial action (Domestic Relations Law, § 236, part B, subd 1, par c).

Husband and Wife -- Alimony and Allowances -- Deletion of Provisions for Future Changes

3. It was not error for the Appellate Division to delete provisions contained in a judgment of divorce for future changes in maintenance and support; the husband, having argued before the Appellate Division that both modifications should be deleted, will not now be heard to say that, because the wife did not cross-appeal to the Appellate Division, deletion of the provision for future decrease of his maintenance payments was improper, and moreover, deletion of both the increase and decrease provisions was correct. The maintenance and support provisions of a matrimonial decree are discretionary determinations and to direct a future change on the occurrence of any given fact ignores the possibility of change in other factors affecting the computation; except when a judgment provides for an imminent and measurable change, or where statutory provision expressly requires otherwise, such a judgment should not include provision for increase or decrease upon the happening of a particular future event.

 

134 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Sims


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


61 N.Y.2d 349; 462 N.E.2d 370; 474 N.Y.S.2d 270; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4210


January 9, 1984, Argued  
March 29, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Determined sanction of censure rejected, without costs, sanction of removal imposed and Barbara M. Sims is removed from the office of Judge of the Buffalo City Court.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner attorney sought review of a decision by respondent State Commission on Judicial Conduct, which censured the attorney for certain acts of judicial misconduct, acts by which the attorney appeared to demonstrate favoritism to her husband, a fellow attorney, and his clients.


OVERVIEW: Several charges were brought against an attorney that was also acting as a city judge and the commission recommended her censure. On appeal, the attorney asserted that she was denied procedural and substantive due process during the investigation and was the target of a general inquest and fishing expedition by the commission. The attorney further claimed that the determination by the commission was arbitrary and capricious, and not supported by substantial evidence. The court found that the charges against the attorney were supported by the evidence and that censure was not enough and that the appropriate sanction was removal from office. The court ruled that the unmistakable impression from the conduct was that the attorney and her husband were acting as a team. The court found that because of the attorney's prior association with some of the defendants and because of her husband's relationship to her, special favor and consideration could have been obtained through retention of the attorney's husband. The court reasoned that removal was not normally to be imposed for poor judgment, even extremely poor judgment, but that the attorney's conduct transcended poor judgment.


OUTCOME: The court concluded that the charges against the attorney were established by the evidence in the record and that based upon the findings, the appropriate sanction was removal from office, not censure.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- Disciplinary Proceedings

Petitioner, an attorney and City Court Judge who signed a warrant for the arrest of a person involved in an automobile accident with her son, signed an order releasing from custody a defendant who was petitioner's former client, which defendant was thereafter represented by petitioner's attorney husband, and who signed releases in nine other instances for defendants in pending criminal cases, when she knew or should have known that her husband represented the defendant in criminal proceedings pending against them, is removed from office; petitioner's actions suggested favoritism to her family and her husband's clients, the actions extended over a period of two years, petitioner failed to acknowledge any appearance of wrong, and she granted some applications after a commission complaint had been filed and she knew she was being investigated. When a Judge acts in such a way that she appears to have used the prestige and authority of judicial office to enhance personal relationships, or for purely selfish reasons, or to bestow favors, that conduct is to be condemned whether or not the Judge acted deliberately and overtly.

 

135 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Council for Owner Occupied Housing, Inc. v. Koch


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


61 N.Y.2d 942; 463 N.E.2d 620; 475 N.Y.S.2d 279; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4182


February 13, 1984, Argued  
March 20, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Condominiums and Cooperatives -- Cooperative Conversion Plan -- Regulation by City of New York

In an action to declare unconstitutional, on the basis of State pre-emption, Local Law No. 70 of 1982 of the City of New York (Administrative Code of City of New York, § YYYY51-1.0 et seq.), which required sponsors of plans to convert residential apartment buildings into cooperatives or condominiums to establish a reserve fund for capital maintenance and to post housing code violations of the building undergoing conversion in an accessible place in the building, a judgment of the Supreme Court which dismissed the action is affirmed for reasons stated in the opinion thereat, which concluded that nothing in either section 352-e or 352-eeee of the General Business Law, which are in essence disclosure laws, or in the regulations promulgated thereunder compelled the finding that the State has pre-empted the area of cooperative or condominium conversion regulation; that silence by the State on the issue of establishing a reserve fund should not be interpreted as an expression of intent by the Legislature, since to interpret a statute in such a manner would vitiate the concept of home rule, and that Local Law No. 70 was a reasonable exercise of the legislative authority vested in the New York City Council to attempt to preserve the existing housing stock and to afford greater protection to tenants in buildings undergoing such conversions.

 

136 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lombardo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


61 N.Y.2d 97; 460 N.E.2d 1074; 472 N.Y.S.2d 589; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 3998


January 9, 1984, Argued  
February 21, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendant appealed a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which convicted defendant of first degree usury, pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 190.42, as well as one count of second degree usury.


OVERVIEW: At defendant's trial for criminal usury, one juror gave the trial judge a note stating that he felt it was impossible for him to render a fair verdict under the charge the jury was given. Subsequent to a revised charge, defendant was convicted. Defendant contended the trial court erred in denying the motion for a mistrial based on the juror's note. Defendant also argued that the usury statute under which defendant was convicted was unconstitutionally vague. The court held that the juror's note, without more, did not warrant a mistrial, and that the trial court acted properly in recharging the jury. Analyzing the usury statute, the court held the terms "scheme" and "business" were not impermissibly vague because the terms' substantive meanings could be readily imported from their normal dictionary definitions. The court then held sufficient evidence existed to convict defendant under the statute. Additionally, the court held that, although the trial court erred in denying a hearing to determine whether a conflict of interest was caused by the fact that defendant' s trial counsel had represented the State's chief witness, the court held the error did not require reversal.


OUTCOME: Judgment was affirmed because the statute under which defendant was convicted was not unconstitutionally vague, and the trial court's error in denying a hearing based on a possible conflict of interest did not require reversal.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Usury -- Criminal Usury in First Degree

1. Use of the terms "scheme or business of making or collecting usurious loans" in section 190.42 of the Penal Law does not render the statute unconstitutionally vague; in the context of the statute, it is clear that what is denoted is a series of transactions, multiple as to loans if not borrowers, which are usurious and are made by the same person under such circumstances that they can factually be found to be interrelated and to constitute parts of an integrated single operation. Further, the evidence was sufficient to sustain defendant's conviction of criminal usury in the first degree under said statute where there was evidence that, in order to provide the financial resources to ensure the continued operation of a club in which defendant had a substantial economic interest, he made two loans to one individual, followed by two more loans to the same individual for his personal use over a period of some eight months, all at usurious rates of interest, and made collections of such interest on all four loans over a period of some 12 months, and the jury was warranted under the instructions of the trial court, to which no exception was taken, to conclude that such conduct constituted a "scheme or business of making or collecting usurious loans".

Crimes -- Discharge of Juror -- Mistrial

2. A note from one juror, delivered to the Trial Judge during the course of jury deliberations, stating that the juror could not "render a fair and a just verdict in accordance with the Court's instruction", without more, did not mandate the declaration of a mistrial. Although inquiry of the juror might have elicited information warranting a mistrial in the absence of defendant's consent to the replacement of the juror ( CPL 270.35), defendant's contention that the Trial Judge should have questioned the juror before proceeding was not preserved for review in view of his counsel's failure to request such relief or to join in the prosecution's suggestion that such an inquiry be undertaken; as it was, on being reinstructed, the juror continued to participate in the jury deliberations and joined in the unanimous verdict of guilty.

Crimes -- Right to Counsel -- Conflict of Interest on Part of Defense Counsel

3. Although the trial court erred in failing to inquire of defendant whether he understood the risks of a potential conflict of interest on the part of his counsel, where defense counsel had previously represented the prosecution's chief witness on various criminal charges and the prosecution called this potential conflict of interest to the court's attention prior to trial; however, defendant is not entitled to a reversal of his conviction in view of his failure to demonstrate that there existed a conflict of interest or at least the significant possibility thereof in the circumstances of the attorney's conduct of his defense. Defense counsel's searching cross-examination of said witness on defendant's trial confirms that the attorney conducted the defense on the operational premise that he no longer owed any professional obligation to his former client.

 

137 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Barney's, Inc. v. Department of Finance


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


61 N.Y.2d 786; 461 N.E.2d 878; 473 N.Y.S.2d 392; 1984 N.Y. LEXIS 4067


January 5, 1984, Argued  
February 14, 1984, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- General Corporation Tax -- Taxable Investment  [***4] Income -- Adjustment of Income to Reflect Taxpayer Activity

In a proceeding challenging the constitutionality of subdivision 8 of section R46-4.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which permits the city's Commissioner of Finance, in computing a general corporation tax on business investment income, to adjust any investment allocation percentage which "does not properly reflect the activity * * * of a taxpayer within the city", a judgment of the Appellate Division, which confirmed a determination of the commissioner imposing a tax deficiency, is affirmed for reasons stated in the opinion thereat, which concluded that the statute in question was neither unconstitutionally vague nor an unconstitutional delegation of power; that the type of discretionary authority conferred upon the commissioner was common to all tax statutes involving situations where it is difficult or impossible for the Legislature to lay down a definite, comprehensive rule; that the statute did not give the commissioner unlimited discretion since its use of the word "properly" set a standard by which the administrative agency could operate, and that the method of adjusting the allocation percentage [***5] was specifically prescribed by statute.

 

138 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Barber v. Bullard


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


61 N.Y.2d 631; 459 N.E.2d 1287; 471 N.Y.S.2d 850; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3629



December 15, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Agriculture -- Apple Marketing Order -- Constitutionality

In an action brought by the Commissioner of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets to force an apple grower to comply with an Apple Marketing Order (AMO) imposing an assessment on his crop, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed an order granting the commissioner summary judgment, is affirmed for reasons stated in the opinion thereat, which concluded that the AMO was constitutional; that the import-export clause of the Federal Constitution was not applicable since the assessment was not a tax, since the assessment was not imposed on apples in interstate transit, and since the AMO would not impair the exclusive power of the Federal Government to all revenues from imports or impede the free flow of imports among the States; that there was no violation of the commerce clause since no burden was imposed upon growers, shippers or packers from other States, and since the assessment was not a tax but a measure whose proceeds were used to further a legitimate government purpose, and that there was no infringement on the grower's First Amendment rights since the State had an important governmental interest in protecting its economy, of which the apple crop was a significant part, since the assessment was used for a specific purpose and the alternatives advanced by the grower would hardly be less drastic nor would they accomplish the required purpose, and since the promotion of apple consumption was not an ideological message which rose to the level of an attempt to communicate an official view, but was merely a commercial undertaking without any political or social ideological overtones; moreover, the grower was free to disclaim any association with the advertisements.

 

139 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Aurora Corp. of Illinois v. Tully


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


60 N.Y.2d 338; 457 N.E.2d 735; 469 N.Y.S.2d 630; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3452


October 25, 1983, Argued  
November 29, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant petitioners sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the trial court confirming a determination of respondent New York State Tax Commission.


OVERVIEW: The Commission issued a notice of deficiency to petitioner, a foreign corporation, claiming that it owed an additional license fee based on a change in petitioner's capital structure. After its request for a redetermination was denied, petitioner commenced a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding for review. The trial court dismissed the petition and the appellate court affirmed. On appeal, the court reversed, holding that N.Y. Tax Law § 181 was unconstitutional because it impermissibly discriminated against foreign corporations in violation of the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution. The court found that § 181 imposed an actual burden on interstate commerce because if similar tax schemes were enacted in other states, a proliferation of insular trade areas providing economic advantages to domestic business would follow, resulting in a continuing need for corporations to relocate, fractionalize, or cease operations, which would substantially and impermissibly burden interstate commerce. The State of New York's excessive license fees on foreign corporations was an unlawful attempt to tax that portion of the petitioner's stock that had no nexus to New York.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's decision.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- License Fee on Foreign Corporations

 Section 181 of the Tax Law, which imposes a higher license fee on businesses incorporated outside New York than the organization tax imposed on domestic enterprises, impermissibly discriminates against foreign corporations and imposes an unlawful burden on interstate commerce in violation of the commerce clause of the United States Constitution (US Const, art I, § 8, cl 3). Accordingly, it was error for the State Tax Commission to sustain a notice of deficiency issued to petitioner, a foreign corporation licensed to do business in New York, on the ground that it owed an additional license fee for 1971 which was assessed upon a change in petitioner's capital structure pursuant to section 181. The statute is constitutionally defective in that it attempts to attract foreign corporations to locate in New York by imposing discriminatory and excessive burdens on those corporations in hopes of neutralizing advantages conferred by their home States thereby inducing them to abandon their present domiciles and incorporate in New York to avoid those excessive burdens; such discrimination is not justified because domestic corporations are subject to New York's organization tax on all of their authorized shares of stock while foreign corporations are taxed by New York only on issued shares employed in New York; petitioner must also pay organization taxes to its home State on all its authorized stock and, therefore, any attempt by New York to compensate for lower organizational taxes in other States by imposing an excessive license fee on foreign corporations is nothing more than an unlawful attempt to tax that portion of petitioner's stock which has no nexus to New York and is clearly unconstitutional.

 

140 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Wootan v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


60 N.Y.2d 353; 457 N.E.2d 743; 469 N.Y.S.2d 637; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3454


October 19, 1983, Argued  
November 29, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and judgment of Supreme Court, Albany County, reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner physician filed an action against respondent, Commissioner of Health of the State of New York (commissioner), to annul the commissioner's order that the physician be suspended from the practice of medicine. The trial court granted the physician's application. The physician sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which reversed the trial court.


OVERVIEW: The physician was licensed to practice medicine. The state charged the physician with gross negligence and incompetence first only in connection with the physician's home birthing practice and later in connection with his general practice. The commissioner issued orders that the physician discontinue the practice of medicine in any form for an initial period of 60 days and then two successive 60-day periods. The court reversed the order of the appellate court and reinstated the judgment of the trial court. The court held that: 1) N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 230(12) provided that the commissioner had the power to order a physician to discontinue the practice of medicine in any form; 2) § 230(12) limited the effectiveness of a suspension order to 60 days, except in narrowly defined circumstances; 3) the commissioner was justified in concluding that the practice of medicine by the physician posed a threat to the health of the public; but 4) circumstances did not exist to justify the commissioner's further orders and the commissioner was not authorized to issue orders continuing the initial suspension; and 5) the physician's application to annul should have been granted.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate court and reinstated the judgment of the trial court which granted the physician's application to annul the commissioner's order of suspension.


HEADNOTES

Physicians and Surgeons -- Suspension of License to Practice Medicine -- Summary Action

Pursuant to subdivision 12 of section 230 of the Public Health Law, which authorizes the Commissioner of Health of the State of New York (Commissioner) to suspend summarily a physician's license to practice medicine pending disciplinary hearings on charges of professional misconduct by the State Board for Professional Medical Conduct, the Commissioner has the power, if circumstances warrant, to order a physician to discontinue the practice of medicine in any form; however, the statute does not permit the Commissioner to continue such a suspension beyond the statutory 60-day period except in those situations expressly provided for in the statute. Accordingly, the Commissioner could properly suspend petitioner physician's license to practice medicine entirely for 60 days once allegations of professional misconduct and medical evidence against petitioner went beyond his obstetric practice to raise serious questions concerning his competence in general practice; however, since petitioner had already been suspended for a period in excess of 60 days, the Commissioner could not validly issue additional orders imposing successive periods of suspension where the narrowly defined circumstances justifying further suspension were not presented.

 

141 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Torres


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


60 N.Y.2d 119; 456 N.E.2d 497; 468 N.Y.S.2d 606; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3409


September 22, 1983, Argued  
October 27, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendant sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Second Judicial Department (New York), that modified and affirmed a judgment of the criminal court that denied defendant's motions to suppress and to dismiss pursuant to noncompliance with N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 580.20, and that convicted defendant for murder, robbery, and criminal possession of a weapon.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was incarcerated in one county when he was indicted for murder and robbery in another county. Defendant filed a request for final disposition of the second indictment pursuant to the Interstate Agreement on Detainers contained in N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 580.20. During that time, defendant also filed an omnibus motion with respect to charges in the first county. The second trial occurred after the 180-day period provided for in § 580.20. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss and a motion to suppress evidence, both of which were denied and defendant was convicted. The appellate division affirmed with a modification. On appeal, the court reversed and remitted, reasoning the lower court was incorrect in tolling the time in which the trial was to take place because the delay caused in prosecuting defendant was caused by respondent prosecutor, but remitted for a determination of whether there was excludable time attributable to defendant. The appellate court further determined that if the action was tolled by such time, a new trial was necessary because the denial of the motion to suppress was reversible error.


OUTCOME: Order of lower court reversed because lower court improperly concluded that respondent's time to prosecute defendant was tolled by defendant's detention in another county and remitted for a determination of excludable time that could be attributed to defendant. The court also determined that if whole period was chargeable to defendant a new trial necessary because denial of defendant's motion to suppress was reversible error.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Right to Speedy Trial -- Limit Imposed by Interstate Agreement on Detainers

1. The 180-day period for trial of charges against one who has served a request for final disposition thereof pursuant to the Interstate Agreement on Detainers ( CPL 580.20) is not tolled during the period of his detention in another county for prosecution on a charge pending in that county since a defendant is not thereby "unable to stand trial" within the meaning of the statute and is not to be penalized by application of the tolling provision when his unavailability is the consequence of the conduct of the public authorities; some of the period will be excluded, however, if it may properly be attributed to the disposition of an omnibus motion made by the defendant with respect to the charges in the first county, and the period to be excluded is not a normal time reasonably to be assigned to the disposition of a similar motion, but is rather the period of delay, if any, which in the individual case may be actually ascribed to consideration and determination of the particular motion.

Crimes -- Right to Speedy Trial -- Waiver of Rights Under Interstate Agreement on Detainers

2. The Interstate Agreement on Detainers ( CPL 580.20) provides for a 180-day period for the trial of charges against one who has served a request for final disposition thereof pursuant to it, and although the facts in a particular instance may warrant a determination that the defendant has elected not to assert or has abandoned his rights under the Agreement on Detainers and has chosen to proceed to disposition without reference thereto, such a determination is not warranted merely because the defendant takes steps to prepare for trial such as by way of a suppression motion, whether before or after the expiration of the statutory 180-day period; there is nothing necessarily inconsistent in proceeding to prepare for disposition by trial and in claiming the right to benefits under the Agreement on Detainers; and a defendant's exercise of the full panoply of his pretrial procedural rights should not be deterred by the risk that he may thereby jeopardize his rights under the Agreement on Detainers, there being no necessary interrelation between the two.

Crimes -- Confession -- Improper Admission of Statement Not Harmless Error

3. It was not harmless error to refuse to suppress a statement concerning the death of a victim of a homicide obtained from a defendant convicted of murder in the second degree, robbery in the first degree and criminal possession of a weapon in the second degree, in violation of his right to counsel and testified to at trial by the police officer who took the statement, when that statement, although in some respects similar to one made to and testified to by another witness, contains a more detailed and damaging account of the event as well as of defendant's incriminating conduct thereafter. Strikingly absent from the statement testified to by the other witness was any explicit admission of a robbery or attempted robbery at gunpoint or of defendant's possession and production of the weapon which brought about the victim's death, as well as of defendant's after-the-event conduct by way of disposing of the gun and leaving the country under an assumed name, all of which, taken with the fact that the police officer testified from a contemporaneous written record of the statement made to him, might well have weighed heavily with the jury in its determination of defendant's guilt of the crimes of which he was convicted.

 

142 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bower & Gardner v. Evans


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


60 N.Y.2d 781; 457 N.E.2d 782; 469 N.Y.S.2d 676; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3474


September 14, 1983, Argued  
October 25, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to respondent, in accordance with the memorandum herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a law firm and its clients, challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a ruling by the Supreme Court at Special Term, New York County (New York) that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 660.35 was not unconstitutional on its face. The appellate division also concluded that the rule was not unconstitutional as applied.


OVERVIEW: The law firm and its client filed an action seeking a declaratory judgment to challenge the mandatory pre-calendar conference rule effective in New York County. The rule established Special Term, Part 8-A, as the forum for all pretrial matters related to personal injury and wrongful death actions filed in the county.The appellate division held that the trial court correctly determined that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 660.35 was not unconstitutional on its face. The appellate division also held that the rule was not unconstitutional as applied because any errors in implementing the rule could be reviewed on a case-by-base basis through appellate review. The appellate division denied declaratory relief with respect to the contention that the statute was unconstitutional as applied. The law firm and its clients admitted that they had other pending cases. The court modified the order and dismissed the complaint. The court held that the appellate division should have dismissed the petition for declaratory judgment because the litigants were trying to obtain a prospective ruling in pending litigation thereby circumventing the normal appellate process.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order of the appellate division by dismissing the complaint, with costs.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Validity of Mandatory Precalendar Conference Rule

In a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of a mandatory precalendar conference rule (22 NYCRR 660.35) effective in New York County for all pretrial matters related to wrongful death and personal injury actions, an order of the Appellate Division, which modified a judgment declaring the rule constitutional on its face but unconstitutional as applied, by vacating so much of the judgment as declared the rule unconstitutional as applied, is further modified by dismissing the complaint. The Appellate Division correctly determined that any objections plaintiffs have to the application of the rule in a particular case may be considered in the normal course in the context of that litigation; however, the court should also have dismissed the complaint as to the challenge of the facial validity of the rule, since plaintiffs, as litigants in pending cases, were attempting to review a ruling or prospective ruling in pending litigation, thus circumventing the appellate process, and a declaratory judgment action may not be employed to avoid restrictions applicable to litigation in which the challenged rule is pertinent, except when the party seeking the ruling would otherwise have no right to appeal.

 

143 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Suffolk Outdoor Advertising Co. v. Southampton


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


60 N.Y.2d 70; 455 N.E.2d 1245; 468 N.Y.S.2d 450; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3386


September 19, 1983, Argued  
October 20, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant billboard owners sought review of an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the dismissal of their petitions for review of a determination by respondent town that ordered the billboard owners to remove their billboards.


OVERVIEW: In a prior declaratory judgment action by billboard owners, the court determined that Southampton, N.Y., Ordinance 26 was not unconstitutional and that neither the Federal Highway Beautification Act, 23 U.S.C.S. § 131, nor N.Y. Highway Law § 88 precluded the removal of billboards without just compensation to the billboard owners. The billboard owners applied for an extension of the amortization period as permitted under the ordinance and the town denied their applications. The billboard owners appealed and the trial court confirmed the town's determination and dismissed their petitions. The appellate court affirmed the trial court and the billboard owners appealed. The court affirmed the appellate court and held that amendments made to 23 U.S.C.S. § 131 shortly after the court's prior decision in the declaratory judgment action did not require payment of compensation. The town retained the power to require commercial billboard removal without compensation provided that a reasonable amortization period was allowed. Further, the amortization period was reasonable as applied to the billboard owners because they had fully recouped their investments and would not incur loss.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower court's order that required the billboard owners to remove their billboards.


HEADNOTES

 Municipal Corporations -- Regulation of Billboards

Notwithstanding the amendments of the Federal Highway Beautification Act of 1965 (US Code, tit 23, § 131), compensation need not be paid by a municipality which requires removal of outdoor advertising signs, provided a reasonable amortization period is allowed by the removal ordinance, and as applied to petitioners, a local ordinance enacted in May, 1972, which provided for the removal of nonconforming outdoor advertising billboards on or before June 1, 1975, but gave an owner the opportunity to apply to the town board for an extension of the amortization period prescribed by the ordinance, is not unreasonable. Neither Federal nor State law preempts the right of a town in the exercise of its police power to require removal of such commercial billboards, and the amortization period was reasonable as applied to petitioners' billboards since they had fully recouped their investments, substantially depreciated their billboards for income tax purposes, had relatively insubstantial lease and license obligations and thus would not incur any substantial financial loss; moreover, the town board's conclusion that the public benefit from removal of the billboards outweighed the detriment to petitioners was not arbitrary or capricious.

 

144 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


American Trucking Ass'n v. New York State Tax Comm'n


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


60 N.Y.2d 745; 457 N.E.2d 769; 469 N.Y.S.2d 662; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3440


September 21, 1983, Argued  
October 20, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Trucking Companies

 Section 184 of the Tax Law, which taxed gross receipts of trucking companies in the amount of .75% of a percentage of a company's gross receipts from all sources, with said percentage's numerator being the number of a company's revenue miles within the State and its denominator being the number of its total revenue miles, was properly declared constitutional by Supreme Court and its judgment is affirmed for the reasons stated by Special Term, which concluded that the statute was constitutional since it did not tax truckers on gross receipts having no nexus with the State, and since it apportioned gross receipts into those having a substantial nexus based upon actual revenue miles in the State and those receipts derived wholly from external sources, resulting [***4] in a 100% tax of gross receipts based upon State revenue miles and no tax based upon non-State revenue miles; that mileage apportionment of revenues had long been upheld as a permissible measure of taxation; that there was no showing that distortions in taxes due based upon different receipts for different types of goods carried occurred; that the statute was fairly related to services rendered by the State; that there was no requirement that the State use the proceeds of the tax for any specific purpose nor any proscription to the levy of more than one tax based upon highway use; that the statute did not discriminate against interstate commerce since it did not tax gross receipts derived from out-of-State sources, and that there was no equal protection violation where the increased tax burden had a rational justification in light of the increased costs to the State of providing highway and police services. Moreover, the statute empowered the tax commission to adjust the allocation formula with respect to a particular corporation to "fairly and equitably reflect gross earnings from all sources within this state" (Tax Law, § 184, subd 4, par [f]).

 

145 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Burns v. Kinley


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


60 N.Y.2d 40; 453 N.E.2d 1251; 466 N.Y.S.2d 962; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3289


August 31, 1983, Argued  
September 1, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner City Clerk challenged an order of the Supreme Court, Albany County (New York), which entered a judgment in respondent Board of Elections' favor in the City Clerk's declaratory judgment action in which he sought to compel the Board of Elections to include the offices of mayor and of president of the city's common council in the upcoming election and asserted that N.Y. Gen. City Law § 2-a was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The trial court determined in the City Clerk's declaratory judgment action against the Board of Elections that N.Y. Gen. City Law § 2-a did not violate the state constitution by allowing elected officials to serve beyond the current election year and that the former mayor's death did not require the inclusion of the offices of mayor and of president of the city's common council in the upcoming election. The court affirmed that judgment on appeal. The court concluded that there was no relation between N.Y. Const. art. XIII, § 3's statutory prescriptions and N.Y. Gen. City Law § 2-a(1), (2). The court noted that the constitutional provision addressed the filling of vacancies in public office and that the latter dealt with the automatic and instantaneous devolution of powers and duties of certain specified public offices. The court also held that the constitutional provision restricted the term only as to persons that were appointed to office and that the statutory provisions addressed elective offices' powers and duties.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed a judgment in the City Clerk's declaratory judgment action against the Board of Elections that held that a statute that provided for the automatic and instantaneous devolution of powers and duties of certain specified public offices did not violate a constitutional provision that restricted the term of persons that were appointed to a public office.


HEADNOTES

Public Officers -- Succession to Certain City Offices -- Death of Mayor during Term of Office

The provisions of subdivisions 1 and 2 of section 2-a of the General City Law relative to succession to certain city offices are not unconstitutional in consequence of the provisions of section 3 of article XIII of the New York Constitution relative to filling of vacancies in elective offices by appointment. Accordingly, no vacancy in the office of Mayor or President of the Common Council of the City of Albany requiring an election before the fall of 1985 was created by reason of the death in 1983 of the former Mayor during his term of office, the duties of said offices having devolved upon the former President and President Pro Tempore of the Common Council of the City of Albany, respectively, pursuant to the provisions of section 2-a of the General City Law.

 

146 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Wilson


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


59 N.Y.2d 461; 452 N.E.2d 1228; 465 N.Y.S.2d 900; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3192


June 2, 1983, Argued  
July 12, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, etc.

Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated appeals, appellants sought review of two orders. First, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) declared that decedent's trust was neither impossible to administer nor illegal. Second, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department, ordered the will of another decedent construed so as to permit gender-neutral scholarship awards.


OVERVIEW: The issue presented on appeal was whether the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment was violated when the trial court permitted the administration of private charitable trusts according to the testators' intent to finance the education of male students and not female students. The court concluded that when the trial court applied a trust law that neither encouraged, affirmatively promoted, or compelled private discrimination, but allowed the parties to engage in private selection in the bequest of their property, that choice was neither attributable to the state or subject to the Fourteenth Amendment. Although the restrictions in the trusts at issue arguably ran contrary to public efforts promoting equality of opportunity for women, that did not justify imposing a per se rule that gender restrictions in private charitable trusts violated public policy. The Fourteenth Amendment did not require the state to exercise the full extent of its power to eradicate private discrimination. It was only when the state itself discriminated, compelled another to discriminate, or allowed another to assume one of its functions and discriminate, that such discrimination was implicated.


OUTCOME: Accordingly, the order in the first appeal was affirmed; however, the order in the second appeal was reversed.


HEADNOTES

Trusts -- Gender-Based Classification of Beneficiaries

The equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution is not violated when a court permits the administration of private charitable trusts according to the testators' intent to finance the education of male students and not female students; when a court applies trust law that neither encourages nor affirmatively promotes nor compels private discrimination, but allows parties to engage in private selection in the devise or bequest of their property, that choice will not be attributable to the State. Accordingly, a court may properly reform a testamentary trust creating a scholarship fund to benefit male students selected by a local board of education by substituting a private trustee in place of the designated public trustee who is unwilling or unable to act according to the discriminatory terms of the trust; similarly, a court may reform a testamentary trust established for the benefit of those male students certified by the local superintendent of schools as having achieved the highest grades in certain subjects by eliminating the certification requirement and permitting students to apply directly to the bank named as trustee in the will.

 

147 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kamhi v. Planning Bd. of Yorktown


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


59 N.Y.2d 385; 452 N.E.2d 1193; 465 N.Y.S.2d 865; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3179


June 7, 1983, Argued  
July 7, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and the judgment of Supreme Court, Westchester County, reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner owner sought review of a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which reversed the trial court and dismissed the owner's complaint seeking to annul a condition in respondent's, planning board (board), approval of the owner's request to subdivide and develop his land, pursuant to N.Y. Town Law § 281(d).


OVERVIEW: The owner had property that he wished to develop. The board approved his proposal but conditioned its approval on the owner conveying 40 percent of his land to the town for park purposes. The owner filed a petition to annul the condition. The trial court found in favor of the owner and remitted the matter to the board to affix reasonable conditions short of an uncompensated grant. The lower court reversed and dismissed the matter. The court reversed the lower court and reinstated the findings of the trial court. The court held that N.Y. Town Law §§ 277 and 278 did not authorize the board to compel uncompensated grants from the owner. N.Y. Town Law §§ 277 and 278, which provided for the dedication or condemnation of land, did not contain language from which might be implied a legislative grant of power to compel conveyance of land for streets or park purposes without compensation, and N.Y. Town Law § 281 added nothing in that respect.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the findings of the lower court and reinstated the findings of the trial court.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Planning -- Deed of Park Land to Town

Subdivision (d) of section 281 of the Town Law does not grant respondent planning board the power to require, as a condition for the approval of petitioner's proposed "cluster" development of a residential subdivision, that he convey approximately 40% of the land to the town for park purposes without compensation; the power to condition ownership and use of land contained in the statute is a delegation of the power only to limit the transfer, development or subdivision of park property, not a grant of the power to compel an uncompensated conveyance to the town. Accordingly, Special Term properly granted a petition to annul said condition and remitted the matter to respondent planning board to affix reasonable conditions for the preservation of open space.

 

148 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Morrisette v. Dilworth


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


59 N.Y.2d 449; 452 N.E.2d 1222; 465 N.Y.S.2d 894; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3190


June 9, 1983, Argued  
July 7, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner police officer sought review of a judgment from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which confirmed a determination by respondent police commissioner that petitioner was guilty of violating a departmental regulation prohibiting fraternization with known felons.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner police officer was told that a person he associated himself with was a known felon. Petitioner questioned the felon and determined that the conviction was nearly 20 years old and the felon showed petitioner a certificate of relief from civil disabilities. Petitioner was later found guilty by respondent police commissioner of violating a department rule that prohibited police officers from fraternizing with known felons after he was observed in the company of the felon. A penalty of 10 days' forfeiture of accrued vacation time was imposed. The lower court confirmed respondent's determination. On review, the court affirmed the judgment from the lower court. The court found that the police department regulation that barred members of the police department from associating with persons known to have been convicted of any misdemeanor or felony was not unconstitutionally overbroad. The court held that the regulation effectuating as it did a valid governmental concern with the integrity of law enforcement had a broad legitimate sweep because the concern encompassed the public's perception of a police department's conduct as perceived through the conduct of individual officers.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that had confirmed a determination by respondent police commissioner that petitioner police officer was guilty of violating a department regulation that prohibited police officers from fraternizing with known felons. The court determined that the police department regulation passed constitutional muster and was not impermissibly overbroad because it insured the integrity of the police department.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Discipline of Police -- Fraternizing with Known Felon

A county police department's rule which bars members of the police department from associating or fraternizing with "persons known to have been convicted of any misdemeanor or felony under the laws of this state or any similar conviction under the laws of any other state or under the Federal Law" is not unconstitutionally overbroad, since the regulation effectuates a valid governmental concern with the integrity of law enforcement and has a broad legitimate sweep because the concern encompasses the public's perception of a police department's conduct as perceived through the conduct of the individual officers; any indication that the officers are corrupt or inclined to give preferential treatment will necessarily erode the public's belief in the integrity of its police officers and police department, and judged in relation to that legitimate purpose the regulation passes constitutional muster.

 

149 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Air Transport Ass'n v. New York State Dep't of Taxation & Fin.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


59 N.Y.2d 917; 453 N.E.2d 548; 466 N.Y.S.2d 319; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3240


June 6, 1983, Argued  
June 28, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Aviation Corporations
