In an action to declare unconstitutional subdivision 1 of section 184 of the Tax Law, which imposed a franchise tax of three quarters of 1% of gross earnings from all sources within the State on aviation corporations, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed a judgment declaring said statute unconstitutional, is affirmed for reasons stated in the opinion at the Appellate Division, which concluded that the State tax was prohibited by the plain terms of section 1113 of the Federal Aviation Act (US Code, tit 49, § 1513), which did not allow for a construction which permits a tax either directly or indirectly on gross receipts derived from air transportation; that legislative history supports that interpretation of the Federal statute, and that there was no merit to defendants' arguments that the measurement of the challenged tax by gross earnings was distinguishable from a direct tax on [**4] gross receipts.

 

150 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Heimbach v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


59 N.Y.2d 891; 452 N.E.2d 1264; 465 N.Y.S.2d 936; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3219


June 6, 1983, Argued  
June 16, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff individuals commenced an action to challenge chapter 485 of the Laws of 1981, which increased by one quarter of one percent the state sales and compensating use tax within the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District, a 12-county area served by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Plaintiffs alleged that chapter 485 was not a duly enacted law because it was not validly passed in the state Senate.


OVERVIEW: The court held that N.Y. Legis. Law § 40 provided that defendant presiding officer's certificate showing the date and requisite votes for passage of a bill shall be conclusive evidence that the bill was validly enacted. The statute, therefore, precluded judicial review of the propriety of the subject roll call vote to effect legislative action. In any event, based upon the court's respect for the basic polity of separation of powers and the proper exercise of judicial restraint, the court would not intrude into the wholly internal affairs of the legislature. Plaintiffs contended in the alternative that if the subject taxing statute were validly enacted, it was nonetheless violative of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because it had a disparate effect on certain regions of the transportation district. The court held that the statute had a rational basis and had to be upheld. Even a flagrant unevenness in application of the tax would not prevent the statute from passing constitutional muster.


OUTCOME: The order of the appellate court, reversing the trial court, was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Legislature -- Judicial Review of Internal Affairs

1. Section 40 of the Legislative Law provides that the presiding officer's certificate showing the date and requisite votes for passage of a bill shall be "conclusive evidence" that the bill was validly enacted; the statute, therefore, precludes judicial review of the propriety of the subject roll call vote to effect legislative action. In any event, based upon respect for the basic polity of separation of powers and the proper exercise of judicial restraint, the Court of Appeals will not intrude into the wholly internal affairs of the Legislature.

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes

2. Chapter 485 of the Laws of 1981, which increased by one quarter of 1% the State sales and compensating use tax within the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD), a 12-county area served by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA), is not violative of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because it has a disparate effect on certain regions of the MCTD; while it may be true that the statute has resulted in some such disparate treatment, it is undisputed that the residents of Suffolk and Orange Counties use MTA services which are available in those counties and which are subsidized, either directly or indirectly, by revenues generated by the subject tax. As such, the statute has a rational basis and must be upheld; even a "flagrant unevenness" in application of the tax will not prevent the statute from passing constitutional muster.

 

151 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Niagara Mohawk Power Corp. v. City School Dist.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


59 N.Y.2d 262; 451 N.E.2d 207; 464 N.Y.S.2d 449; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3123


April 16, 1983, Argued  
June 14, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, and question certified answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff electric utility sought to recover a portion of real property taxes paid to defendant school district. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, affirmed the trial court's denial of the school district's motion to dismiss the complaint but struck that portion of the trial court's order that permitted the electric utility to verify its letters of protest nunc pro tunc. The school district appealed.


OVERVIEW: The electric utility claimed the school district's levies were illegal because they exceeded the two percent constitutional limitation on taxation of real property. It alleged the taxes were paid under protest but it did not allege compliance with the provisions of N.Y. Educ. Law § 3813. The trial court denied the school district's motion to dismiss the complaint, and the appellate court affirmed. On appeal, the court affirmed. Taxes assessed and collected in violation of the constitutional authority were properly recovered by a plenary action for moneys had and received. Also, the complaint alleging the involuntary payment of a void tax could not have been properly dismissed for insufficiency because of the electric utility's failure to plead compliance with the provisions of § 3813. Because the action for the return of a void tax raised only a legal issue, there was no need for a prior notice of claim to allow for investigation, adjustment, or administrative action. The only purpose § 3813 served in such an action was to give the school district notice of a claim of illegality and a potential lawsuit, which was accomplished by the electric utility's involuntary payment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment denying the school district's motion to dismiss the electric utility's tax protest complaint.


HEADNOTES

Schools -- Notice of Claim -- Action to Recover Void Tax

Compliance with the notice of claim provisions of section 3813 of the Education Law is not required to sustain a cause of action against a school district to recover a void tax which was paid involuntarily. Accordingly, a motion by defendant city school district to dismiss the complaint in an action by plaintiff taxpayer to recover a portion of real property taxes paid to defendant was properly denied, where plaintiff alleges that the levies were illegal because they exceeded the 2% constitutional limitation on the amount of real property taxes to be raised for local purposes and that it paid the taxes under protest.

 

152 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Morgenthau v. Erlbaum


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


59 N.Y.2d 143; 451 N.E.2d 150; 464 N.Y.S.2d 392; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3111


April 27, 1983, Argued  
June 7, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent, a trial judge, and defendants, two alleged prostitutes, challenged an order of the Appellate Division of Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment granting petitioner district attorney's motion to convert a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding into a declaratory action, holding N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 340.40(2) constitutional, and denying the alleged prostitutes' entitlement to jury trials.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were two women accused of prostitution, which carried a three-month maximum sentence. Defendants contended that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 340.40(2) was unconstitutional because it directed that crimes not punishable by more than six months incarceration were to be heard by a trial judge. Respondent trial judge granted defendants' motion for a jury trial. Petitioner district attorney commenced an action to obtain a writ of prohibition, which was converted to a declaratory action. The special term court granted petitioner's motion and determined the statute was constitutional, and the appellate division affirmed. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment as modified. The appellate court determined the declaratory judgment attacking the criminal court's interlocutory ruling was properly granted because the validity of a statute was at issue, no questions of fact were involved, and the declaratory judgment would have an obvious effect on future cases involving the same questions. However, the declaratory action was improperly heard against defendants in the underlying criminal action.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment, declaring that conversion to a declaratory action was proper. However, it was an abuse of discretion to entertain an action for declaratory judgment where there was pending between defendants an action that would fully dispose the controversy. Thus, the order was modified by striking the declaration that defendants were not entitled to a jury trial and dismissing the petitions as to defendants.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Validity of Penal Statute

1. In rare instances when a criminal court makes an interlocutory ruling in favor of a defendant that will both affect fundamental rights and have implications reaching far beyond the immediate case, an independent action by the People for declaratory relief may be allowed where the controversy is purely a legal one involving the validity of a statute, where there is no immediate attempt to prevent the criminal court from proceeding on the course charted by its ruling and where the circumstances warrant permitting such an action. Accordingly, the People properly commenced an action for declaratory relief in Supreme Court against a Criminal Court Judge who ruled that CPL 340.40 (subd 2), which provides that crimes punishable by not more than six months' imprisonment be heard before a Judge, is unconstitutional as applied to defendants charged with prostitution in New York City; said ruling was based on a holding that prostitution is a "serious" crime and comes within the Sixth Amendment guarantee of trial by jury, notwithstanding that it carries a maximum sentence of three months' imprisonment. However, it was improper for the Supreme Court to have heard the declaratory judgment action as against the defendants in the underlying criminal action, since there is another action pending between the parties and the controversy has been decided.

Crimes -- Right to Jury Trial

2. CPL 340.40 (subd 2), which provides that crimes punishable by not more than six months' incarceration shall, in the City of New York, be heard before a Judge, does not violate the Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution as applied to defendants charged with prostitution, inasmuch as prostitution is not a "serious" offense within the meaning of the Sixth Amendment guarantee of trial by jury, being punishable by a maximum of three months' imprisonment.

 

153 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bakolas


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


59 N.Y.2d 51; 449 N.E.2d 738; 462 N.Y.S.2d 844; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 3025



May 5, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: On review of submissions pursuant to rule 500.2 (b) of the Rules of the Court of Appeals (22 NYCRR 500.2 [g]), order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed from the order of the Monroe County Court (New York), which reversed the city court's order dismissing an information charging defendants with disorderly conduct under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(2), and remitted the matter for further proceedings on the information.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with disorderly conduct, but the city court dismissed the informations, concluding that N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(2) was unconstitutional because it was overly broad and vague. The statute prohibited the making of unreasonable noise with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance, or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof. The county court reversed and remitted the cases for further proceedings on the informations. Defendants sought further judicial review, arguing that because noises were neither reasonable nor unreasonable, the term "unreasonable noise" was meaningless and vague. Further, they argued that § 240.20(2) was overbroad because it attempted to govern every possible situation, and thus, provided inadequate standards for enforcement. The court affirmed the judgment reinstating the informations, concluding that the term unreasonable noise was not undefined. Rather, it described a noise of a type or volume that a reasonable person, under the circumstances, would not tolerate. Similarly, the requirement that the noise be intended to cause, or recklessly create a risk of, public inconvenience, annoyance, or alarm, narrowed the definition.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the county court's judgment upholding the validity of the statute and reinstating the charges, holding, in a per curiam opinion, that the statute was not unconstitutional, either for vagueness or for overbreadth.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Disorderly Conduct Involving "Unreasonable Noise"

Subdivision 2 of section 240.20 of the Penal Law, which prohibits a person from making "unreasonable noise" is not unconstitutional for vagueness, since the term describes noise of the type or volume that a reasonable person would not tolerate under the circumstances, and the statute also requires that the noise be made "with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof", which narrows the definition of the prohibited conduct so that no inadvertently disturbing act may be punished; further, the prohibition against unreasonable noise is not on its face impermissibly overbroad, even when applied to protected speech, which may be restricted as to time, place and manner.

 

154 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 532; 449 N.E.2d 399; 462 N.Y.S.2d 619; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2982


March 21, 1983, Argued  
May 3, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant property owners and respondent city sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the trial court's computation of interest to be paid on condemned property.


OVERVIEW: The property owners asserted that the interest rate which the city proposed to pay for condemned property was not just compensation. The trial court set the interest rate to be paid based upon expert reports and the appellate division affirmed without opinion. On appeal, the court affirmed finding that six percent interest for the period from June, 1972 to December, 1977, and nine percent interest from January 1, 1978 to the date of payment was just compensation. The court determined that although the rate of six percent set by the legislature was presumptively reasonable, the property owners had rebutted the presumption for the period after January 1, 1978 because they introduced evidence of prevailing market rates which showed that the statutory rate was so unreasonably low that it deprived them of just compensation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the interest rates and compensation set by the lower court.


HEADNOTES

Eminent Domain -- Interest on Award

 Section 3-a of the General Municipal Law sets a rate of interest on condemnation awards against municipal corporations which is presumptively reasonable; however, a claimant may introduce relevant evidence of prevailing market rates to rebut the statutory presumption of reasonableness. Accordingly, claimants are entitled to interest on awards for fixtures at the statutory rate of 6% from the time of the taking in 1972 through 1977 (General Municipal Law, § 3-a, subd 2) and at a rate of 9% from 1978 through the time of payment of the award, since there is sufficient evidence to support affirmed findings of fact that an award at the statutory rate was adequate for the 1972-1977 period but was inadequate for the 1978-1981 period and that a median interest rate of 9% was necessary to meet the constitutional requirement of "just compensation" for the taking of private land by a municipality for public use (US Const, 5th Amdt; NY Const, art I, § 7).

 

155 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re District Attorney of Suffolk County


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 436; 448 N.E.2d 440; 461 N.Y.S.2d 773; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2937


February 15, 1983, Argued  
March 31, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) which reversed the order of the trial court which had denied respondents' motion to vacate an ex parte order authorizing appellant to utilize transcripts from a grand jury proceeding.


OVERVIEW: The trial court had signed an ex parte order allowing appellant to utilize grand jury minutes. Respondents had filed a motion before the trial court to vacate the order but it was denied. Respondents then sought review of the denial. The lower court granted respondents' motion and vacated the ex parte order. Appellant sought review of the order to vacate. The court affirmed. The court found that respondents had standing to challenge the ex parte order since all of the respondents were targets of the grand jury investigation and thus had a legitimate interest in maintaining the confidentiality of the grand jury proceedings. The court held that the secrecy of the grand jury proceedings was essential, and disclosure of the proceedings would only be allowed if the one seeking disclosure demonstrated a compelling and particularized need for access. The court held that appellant failed to demonstrate any compelling and particularized need for access.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the reversal of the order permitting disclosure of the grand jury minutes holding that respondents had standing to challenge the ex parte disclosure order and appellant failed to demonstrate a compelling and particularized need for the minutes to overcome the confidentiality of the grand jury proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Standing

1. The rule of secrecy of Grand Jury proceedings applies equally to one who gives evidence and one concerning whom evidence is given and, accordingly, respondents, who were all targets of a Grand Jury inquiry, had standing to challenge an order allowing disclosure of the Grand Jury proceedings to the District Attorney for use in connection with a civil action against them by the county, although some of the individual respondents did not testify because they would not waive immunity; further, those respondents whose Grand Jury testimony was allegedly perjurious or was subsequently found to be perjurious did not forfeit their legitimate interest in maintaining the confidentiality of any other accusations leveled against them. Finally, although some of the Grand Jury testimony was revealed in connection with intervening litigation after the initial disclosure order was issued, respondents' appeal has not become moot, since further disclosure and dissemination of Grand Jury testimony can be prevented.

Grand Jury -- Inspection of Grand Jury Minutes

2. An ex parte order granting an application by the District Attorney to utilize Grand Jury minutes in aid of a civil suit by the county to recover damages for alleged fraud on the taxpayers by respondents, who had been the targets of the Grand Jury inquiry into possible fraud and corruption in the construction of a sewer project, was properly vacated, since the District Attorney failed to make the requisite initial showing of a compelling and particularized need for access sufficient to overcome the presumption of confidentiality of Grand Jury proceedings ( CPL 190.25, subd 4); the District Attorney's conclusory allegation that access was required in order to pursue the litigation left the court without any rationale by which it could minimize any invasion of secrecy by narrowing the scope of the disclosure and did not indicate why the Grand Jury minutes were essential to the pursuit of the county's efforts to recover civil damages from respondents for the alleged fraud, e.g., nothing was offered to explain why discovery devices would not suffice.

 

156 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mahoney


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 475; 448 N.E.2d 1321; 462 N.Y.S.2d 410; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2954


February 10, 1983, Argued  
March 31, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed his conviction for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the second-degree. Defendant alleged that a "no-knock" entry by police to execute a search warrant was a violation of his constitutional rights.


OVERVIEW: Defendant appealed from his conviction for possession of a controlled substance in the second-degree. Defendant alleged that a "no-knock" search of his home violated his rights under the Fourth Amendment, U.S. Const. amend. IV. Defendant came under suspicion of the police for drug possession, and the police contacted a magistrate for a "no-knock" warrant to search the premises of defendant's home. Defendant's home was searched, and drugs were found after officers entered the premises by knocking down a side door. The warrant was never delivered, and the officers conducting the search were not in actual possession of the warrant at the time of the search. The court determined that although the officers lacked actual possession of the warrant, defendant was not denied the protection of the warrant requirement, because the police did go through the procedure to obtain the warrant, including evaluation of probable cause by a magistrate. The court therefore affirmed defendant's conviction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction. The court determined that although the officers that executed the search of defendant's property did not deliver the warrant, they complied with the procedure for obtaining the warrant, and their entry did not interfere with defendant's right to be free from unreasonable governmental intrusions.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Search Warrant

Police officers with knowledge that a warrant authorizing the search of a suspect's home has been issued and is en route may enter those premises before the warrant arrives. Accordingly, where a search warrant was obtained by the police from a magistrate who had determined that probable cause did exist to enter and search defendant's home, and it was not until the warrant designating the place to be searched and the contraband to be seized arrived that a search of the premises was conducted, the entry by the police prior to the arrival of a detective with the warrant did not violate defendant's constitutional rights against unreasonable search and seizure. Moreover, inasmuch as the warrant issued by the magistrate pursuant to CPL 690.50 (subd 2) authorized the police "to enter the premises to be searched without giving notice of your authority and purpose" and since the officers who initially entered defendant's house had been informed that a "no-knock" warrant had been issued, their unannounced entry was entirely proper.

 

157 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lee


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 491; 448 N.E.2d 1328; 462 N.Y.S.2d 417; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2956; 39 A.L.R.4th 661


February 10, 1983, Argued  
March 31, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Sullivan County Court (New York) that affirmed his conviction for possession of an open of container of alcoholic beverage in violation of Village of Monticello, N.Y., Code § 39-3. Defendant appealed on constitutional grounds.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested and charged with violation of Village of Monticello, N.Y., Code § 39-3, which prohibited possession in a public place of an open or unsealed container of an alcoholic beverage. Defendant pleaded guilty to the charge after the village justice court denied his motion to dismiss on the ground that § 39-3 of the code was unconstitutional, and the county court affirmed the judgment of conviction. After concluding that defendant was not precluded from appealing his conviction based on the unconstitutionality of the ordinance under which he was convicted, despite his guilty plea, the court held that the village's ordinance, which prohibited mere possession in a public place of an open or unsealed container of an alcoholic beverage, without requiring proof of any intent to consume, was an exercise of police power for which there existed no reasonable relation to the public good. The court reversed defendant's conviction because the ordinance was an unconstitutional infringement on an individual's freedom of action.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower courts' judgments, vacated the judgment of conviction, and dismissed the accusatory instrument.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Appeal -- Challenge to Constitutionality of Statute Following Guilty Plea

1. A defendant by a plea of guilty does not forfeit the right on appeal from the conviction to challenge the constitutionality of the statute under which he was convicted. Although a guilty plea constitutes an effective judicial admission by a defendant that he committed the acts charged in the accusatory instrument, such a plea is in no way inconsistent with the contention that, conceding commission of all the acts charged, the provision of statute or ordinance which proscribes the particular conduct as criminal is nonetheless unconstitutional.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Possession of Open Container of Alcoholic Beverage

2. A village ordinance prohibiting mere possession in a public place of an open or unsealed container of an alcoholic beverage, without requiring proof of any intent to consume, is unconstitutional. While reasonable regulation of the possession of alcoholic beverages might be upheld in the name of the police power, outright proscription as criminal of possession only of a container of an alcoholic beverage has not been shown to bear a reasonable relation to the public good; moreover, the condition of openness in itself in no way threatens the public good, and, while a container must of course be opened or unsealed to permit consumption, it cannot be presumed that every opening or unsealing is for the purpose of direct human consumption or least of all for the purpose of direct human consumption in a public place.

 

158 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Cass v. State


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 460; 448 N.E.2d 786; 461 N.Y.S.2d 1001; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2940


February 14, 1983, Argued  
March 30, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to respondents, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, County Court Judges, Family Court Judges, and Surrogates, challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which reversed and granted judgment in favor of respondents, State and Chief Administrator of the Courts, dismissed the complaint against the State, and declared the Unified Court Budget Act constitutional.


OVERVIEW: Judges claimed that the Unified Court Budget Act denied them equal protection insofar as it provided higher salaries for Judges of co-ordinate jurisdiction in certain counties in the New York City metropolitan area. Judges sought a declaration that they were entitled to retroactive salary increments to compensate them for the discrepancies. The court held that the State was a proper party to the challenge to the constitutionality of the statute and the motion to dismiss the complaint against the State for lack of jurisdiction should have been denied. The court held that there were State-wide disparities in population, caseload, and cost of living, which provided a rational basis for the Legislature to adopt price differentials for those serving in different areas of the State, and the statute passed constitutional muster under the equal protection challenge.


OUTCOME: The court reinstated the complaints against the State in order to declare in favor of the State as well as the other defendants, and as modified affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Proper Parties

1. Although claims against the State primarily seeking money damages should be brought in the Court of Claims, the State is a proper party to a declaratory judgment action in the Supreme Court because of its obvious interest in the right to be heard on the matters concerning the constitutionality of its statutes.

Judges -- Disparity in Judicial Salaries

2. A State budgetary act will not be struck as violative of equal protection merely because it creates differences in geographic areas; the Unified Court Budget Act (L 1976, ch 966; L 1979, ch 55; L 1980, ch 881) is not violative of equal protection insofar as plaintiff Judges residing in various counties across the State are provided lower salaries than those received by Judges of co-ordinate jurisdiction in certain counties in the New York City metropolitan area, since there are State-wide disparities in population, caseload and cost of living, which provide a rational basis for the Legislature to adopt price differentials for those Judges serving in different areas of the State. Nor does equal protection require that all classifications be made with mathematical precision, and, as such, the fact that the general statutory scheme, when applied on a State-wide basis, may produce some inequities for certain Judges within a particular class does not render the statute unconstitutional.

 

159 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Herkimer v. Axelrod


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 1069; 449 N.E.2d 413; 462 N.Y.S.2d 633; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2997


February 9, 1983, Argued  
March 30, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Hospitals and Asylums -- Modification of Hospital Operating Certificate -- Standing

A village which operated a municipal hospital and sought to overturn a determination by the State Department of Health, made pursuant to section 2806 of the Public Health Law, which modified the hospital's operating certificate to provide that it be certified to provide long-term care rather than acute care, lacks standing to argue that said statute is facially unconstitutional as its application would violate due process and equal protection, since the village was empowered by section 126 of the General Municipal Law to establish the subject hospital, which is, therefore, operated as part and parcel of the power delegated by the Legislature to the village as a a political subdivision, and political subdivisions of the State are powerless to challenge the constitutionality of an act of the Legislature which restricts the subdivision's governmental powers.

 

160 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Rochester v. Chiarella


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 316; 448 N.E.2d 98; 461 N.Y.S.2d 244; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2926


February 8, 1983, Argued  
March 29, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs, and question certified answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant subclass of real property owners sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court Appellate Division (New York) that reversed a judgment of the trial court that held that subclass of real property owners, who paid real property taxes to respondent City in excess of constitutional limitations, were entitled to a refund of the excess amounts despite the fact that they paid the taxes without protest.


OVERVIEW: City filed a defendant class action against its real property taxpayers in order to prevent a multiplicity of lawsuits concerning its prior levy of taxes in excess of constitutional limits. A subclass of real property owners argued that they were entitled to a refund despite the fact that they had not paid the excess taxes "under protest." The trial court found that the subclass of real property owners was entitled to a refund and the City sought review. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's decision, held that the subclass of real property owners were not placed under duress or coercion in paying the excess taxes so as to excuse the lack of a formal protest, and certified the question of the appropriateness of its decision for further review. In affirming the decision and answering the certified question in the affirmative, the court held that the payment of excess taxes by the nonprotesting taxpayers had to be considered voluntary because the payment was not necessary to prevent interference with the immediate possession of their property, and it was made after the same method of computing taxes had been declared to be unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision and held that subclass of property owners was not entitled to a refund of unconstitutional, excess taxes because their payment of the taxes without protest was voluntary.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Tax Refund Proceeding -- Payment under Protest

Real property owners whose property was assessed in excess of the tax limitations imposed by the New York Constitution are not entitled to refunds for excess taxes which were paid without formal protest and were made merely to avoid routine liens imposed for nonpayment and reasonable interest charged on delinquent accounts; under these circumstances, the payment of excess taxes by nonprotesting taxpayers must be considered voluntary, since it was not necessary to prevent interference with the immediate possession of taxpayers' property and, moreover, payment was made after the same method of computing real property taxes had been declared unlawful under a similar statute, putting all taxpayers on notice of the continuing possibility that taxes so levied were constitutionally infirm.

 

161 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Regan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 1005; 448 N.E.2d 799; 461 N.Y.S.2d 1014; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2949


February 9, 1983, Argued  
March 22, 1983, Decided


HEADNOTES

Schools -- State Aid

In an action to prohibit the Comptroller from withholding from State aid to a school district an amount equal to the sum which that district had borrowed from the Health Insurance Reserve Receipts Fund (HIRRF) and which it became obligated to repay upon its termination from the State employees' health program in accordance with an agreement it made with the Department of Civil Service pursuant to section 99-c of the State Finance Law, an [**5] order of the Appellate Division, which reversed a judgment granting the relief requested, and dismissed the complaint, is affirmed for reasons stated in the memorandum at the Appellate Division, which concluded that there was no repugnancy between section 99-c and chapter 71 (§ 8, subd b) of the Laws of 1977, which, inter alia, reduced State aid to those school districts participating in the HIRRF loan program; that there was no repeal by implication with respect to those two statutes, especially since they had been passed by the Legislature on the same day; that the statutes were part of a legislative plan to provide increased financial assistance to school districts in a year of budget austerity; that there was no language in chapter 71 which would indicate an intention on the part of the Legislature to relieve shool districts from their obligation to return the money they had received from HIRRF, and that plaintiff school district lacked standing to raise the equal protection issue since as a political subdivision it may not raise that constitutional challenge to the classification created by the Legislature.

 

162 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Uplinger


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 936; 447 N.E.2d 62; 460 N.Y.S.2d 514; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2895


January 4, 1983, Argued  
February 23, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State sought review of an order of the Erie County Court (New York) denying defendant male's motion to dismiss the charges against him and convicting him of loitering in a public place for the purpose of engaging in or soliciting another person to engage in deviate sex, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35, sub. 3, and reversing an order granting defendant female's motion to dismiss identical charges against her.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with loitering in a public place for the purpose of engaging in or soliciting another person to engage in deviate sex in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35, sub. 3. The court ruled that § 240.35 must be viewed as a companion statute to the consensual sodomy statute, N.Y. Penal Law §130.38, which criminalized acts of deviate sexual intercourse between consenting adults. Further, the court held that the State could not constitutionally prohibit sexual behavior conducted in private between consenting adults and that the object of the loitering statute was to punish conduct anticipatory to the act of consensual sodomy. Also, the court found that inasmuch as the conduct ultimately contemplated by the loitering statute could not be deemed criminal, there was no basis upon which the State may continue to punish loitering for that purpose. The court concluded that since § 240.35 was devoid of the requirement that the conduct proscribed be in any way offensive or annoying to others, the challenged statute could not be categorized as a harassment statute.


OUTCOME: Order was reversed and the charges against defendants were dismissed where the State could not constitutionally prohibit sexual behavior conducted in private between consenting adults, and the object of the loitering statute was to punish conduct anticipatory to the act of consensual sodomy.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Loitering to Solicit Deviate Sex

Subdivision 3 of section 240.35 of the Penal Law, which prohibited loitering "in a public place for the purpose of engaging, or soliciting another person to engage, in deviate sexual intercourse or other sexual behavior of a deviate nature", must be viewed as a companion to the consensual sodomy statute (Penal Law, § 130.38) and is intended to punish conduct anticipatory to the act of consensual sodomy; inasmuch as the conduct ultimately contemplated by the loitering statute may not be deemed criminal (see People v Onofre, 51 NY2d 476), there is no basis upon which the State may continue to punish loitering for that purpose, and the statute, therefore, suffers the same deficiencies as did the consensual sodomy statute; the challenged statute cannot be categorized as a harassment statute since it is devoid of a requirement that the conduct proscribed be in any way offensive or annoying to others.

 

163 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Loretto v. Teleprompter Manhattan CATV Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 143; 446 N.E.2d 428; 459 N.Y.S.2d 743; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2834


January 5, 1983, Argued  
February 17, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Upon reargument, following remand by the Supreme Court of the United States, order modified, with costs to appellant, and case remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff apartment building owner filed a class action against defendant cable television company for damages for trespass by the company when it placed cable television components on the apartment building. The judgment of the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the company. The owner appealed. The Court of Appeals (New York) affirmed and the United States Supreme Court reversed and remanded for further proceedings.


OVERVIEW: The company placed the components in accordance with N.Y. Exec. Law § 828. The Supreme Court did not question the court's holding that § 828 was a proper exercise of the police power but held that the otherwise valid regulation so frustrates property rights that compensation must be paid. It expressed no opinion on the amount of compensation due leaving that to the state courts. The court concluded that the judgment entered by trial court should be modified (1) to make clear that its declaration of the validity of § 828 is subject to the fixation of compensation by the commission upon application to it, (2) to declare the State Commission on Cable Television's regulation 598.3, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs, tit. 9, § 598.3 invalid, and (3) to retain jurisdiction for the purpose of reviewing whether the compensation fixed by the commission constituted just compensation within the meaning of the constitution, but to permit the owner, if she be so advised, to proceed with her action in trespass for the period between the date on which she took title to the property in question and the effective date of § 828. The court held that except as modified, the judgment was affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court modified the order of the court of appeals with costs to the owner and as so modified, affirmed it. The case was remitted to the trial court for further proceedings in accordance with the court's opinion.


HEADNOTES

Radio and Television -- Cable Television -- Compensation for Installation of Cable Television Facilities

 Section 828 of the Executive Law is not only a valid exercise of the police power, but also authorizes the payment of compensation for crossover and noncrossover installation of cable television facilities, as fixed by the Commission on Cable Television, subject to review. Section 828 (subd 1, par b) of the Executive Law authorizes the commission to limit by regulation the highest amount a property owner may receive, unless on application by the property owner to the commission that body, after a hearing, fixes a higher sum as the reasonable compensation for the particular property, and the commission's regulations are entirely consistent with its being so empowered, and are fully compatible with the usual process of adjudication; nor have section 828 procedures been superseded by the provisions of the Eminent Domain Procedure Law. Additionally, neither the Federal nor State Constitution proscribes determination for a taking by a commission rather than a court. Nevertheless, the commission's regulations providing a limitation upon presentation of a claim (9 NYCRR 598.3), framed in the context of a police power rather than a condemnation statute, could be construed by the commission to bar claims as to which an owner did not in fact have notice in time to comply with the regulation, and, as such, should be declared invalid.

 

164 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Felix


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 156; 446 N.E.2d 757; 460 N.Y.S.2d 1; 1983 N.Y. LEXIS 2835


January 3, 1983, Argued  
February 15, 1983, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought relief from sentence issued from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) sentencing him under N. Y. Penal Law § 70.02 (subd. 5, par [b]).


OVERVIEW: Defendant pled guilty to attempted robbery in the second degree, and the remaining indicted charges were dismissed. The court imposed a sentence of imprisonment for a term of one to three years under N. Y. Penal Law § 70.02 (subd. 5, par [b]). The statute allowed consideration for sentencing of the charges upon which the defendant had been indicted but which were dismissed as part of the plea bargain. The defendant sought a reduced sentence on the basis of mitigating circumstances. His application was denied on the ground that the circumstances did not, as required by section 70.02, bear upon the manner in which the crime was committed, and defendant sought relief. On appeal the court held that the statute did not violate due process because it did not involve a new finding of fact on a distinct issue as the basis for increased punishment. Instead the statute required a defendant who was indicted for an armed felony but pled to a lesser offense, to be sentenced to an indeterminate term, absent a showing of mitigation. The new facts presented during sentencing reduced, rather than enhanced, the sentence; and therefore the court affirmed the sentence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the sentence because the statute did not violate due process because it did not involve a new finding of fact on a distinct issue as the basis for increased punishment. Instead the statute required a defendant who was indicted for an armed felony but pled to a lesser offense, to be sentenced to an indeterminate term, absent a showing of mitigation.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Violent Felony Offense

There is no due process infirmity under either the Federal or the State Constitution in the requirement of subdivision 5 of section 70.02 of the Penal Law that a defendant who has been charged with an armed felony and permitted in satisfaction of the indictment to plead guilty to a class D violent felony must receive an indeterminate sentence of one to three years unless the court finds that factors specified in the section warrant imposition of less than an indeterminate sentence. The statute does not improperly subject defendant to enhanced punishment on the basis of the unproven charge that he was "armed" within the meaning of the "armed felony" definition since the statute does not give preclusive effect to the indictment's allegation that defendant was armed, notwithstanding the fact that there are differences in the sentencing discretion available when a defendant has pleaded guilty under an indictment charging an armed felony and what would be available had there been no armed felony charge. Nor does paragraph (c) improperly place upon the defendant the burden of proving one or more of the ameliorating factors referred to in subdivision (b) in violation of due process; by pleading to the class D violent felony, the defendant in effect admits for the purpose of sentence and subject to his right to a lesser sentence if the existence of one of the ameliorating factors be found by the court, that he was armed as charged, and any new facts found in the postplea presentence hearing can only reduce, not enhance, the punishment imposed; additionally, due process is not offended by the probability that in most cases establishment of an ameliorative factor will require that defendant come forward with proof.

 

165 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Evans


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 14; 444 N.E.2d 7; 457 N.Y.S.2d 757; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3875


November 9, 1982, Argued  
December 14, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed and case remitted to the Appellate Division, Second Department, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant district attorney challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department, New York, which reversed respondent's conviction for manslaughter and robbery, each in the first degree, vacated his guilty plea, granted his motion to suppress certain statements, and remitted case for further proceedings.


OVERVIEW: Respondent, with advice and in presence of counsel, voluntarily furnished appellant, district attorney, an incriminating statement prior to entering into a plea bargain and, subsequent to his guilty plea and conviction, voluntarily testified against a codefendant. Thereafter, respondent appealed his convictions for manslaughter and robbery, each in the first degree, seeking to preclude appellant from using those statements against him at a subsequent trial ordered by the Appellate Division following suppression of statements made by respondent at the time of his arrest. The appellate division reversed respondent's convictions, vacated his guilty plea, and granted his motion to suppress the statements. Appellant challenged. The court reversed, finding that the evidence did not need to be suppressed since the voluntary guilty plea provided insulating attenuation to the illegally procured initial statement, and neither the integrity of the plea bargaining process or fundamental fairness required suppression of the statements.


OUTCOME: Order was reversed and remitted; respondent could not retract plea bargain or suppress admissions made pursuant thereto because integrity of plea bargaining process and balanced fundamental fairness permitted use of evidence where appellant complied with plea bargain, and respondent failed to condition plea with non-admissibility of his future testimony against codefendant.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Confession

Defendant, who voluntarily made an incriminating statement to the District Attorney with the advice and in the presence of counsel before entering into a plea bargain initiated by defendant and, after his conviction upon his plea of guilty to reduced charges, voluntarily testified against a codefendant at two trials, was not entitled to suppression of the preplea statement or the in-court testimony at a new trial ordered by the Appellate Division following suppression of incriminating statements defendant made at the time of his arrest, where neither defendant nor his attorney expressed as a condition of the pleas that statements made pursuant thereto could be withdrawn upon a successful appeal of his motion to suppress the statements made at the time of his arrest; the evidence need not be suppressed as fruit of a poisonous tree, although the illegally obtained initial confessions preceded the preplea statement and the trial testimony, since the interposing of a voluntary guilty plea, based upon defendant's assessment of the case, provided insulating attenuation to the illegally procured initial statement. Furthermore, as a matter of policy and fundamental fairness, exclusion of evidence of defendant's original guilty plea provides all of the protection necessary to assure that the court's decision to allow defendant to withdraw that plea is a meaningful one as required by People v Spitaleri (9 NY2d 168).

 

166 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. McCray


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 542; 443 N.E.2d 915; 457 N.Y.S.2d 441; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3844


October 15, 1982, Argued  
December 14, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed defendant's convictions for robbery in the first and second degree. Defendant contended that the prosecution unlawfully used peremptory challenges to exclude jurors on the basis of race.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of robbing an art student at gunpoint, after he and several of his companions pushed the student into the vestibule of a building and took the student's money. During jury selection, defendant moved for a mistrial, contending that the prosecutor had unlawfully exercised her peremptory challenges to exclude all of the blacks and the only Hispanic prospective juror drawn from the jury pool. The trial court denied defendant's motion, and, after his conviction, defendant appealed. The intermediate court affirmed. Defendant appealed again, but the court affirmed the decision of the trial court. The court held that the prosecutor's motives for exercising a peremptory challenge were not subject to scrutiny for potential racial bias. The court further held that the New York constitution's requirement that defendant be tried by a jury of his peers did not offer broader protection to defendant than the scope of the federal Equal Protection Clause.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the trial court.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Voir Dire -- Peremptory Challenges to Prospective Minority Jurors

A prosecutor is not required to disclose his reasons for excusing prospective jurors in a particular case on the mere allegation by the defense that peremptories are being used to exclude minority jurors. Accordingly, a prosecutor's use of peremptory challenges ( CPL 270.25) did not violate defendant's constitutional rights where 8 of the 11 peremptory challenges exercised by the prosecutor were used to exclude all of the blacks and the only Hispanic prospective juror drawn.

 

167 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Kelley v. McGee


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 522; 443 N.E.2d 908; 457 N.Y.S.2d 434; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3843


November 11, 1982, Argued  
December 8, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of Kelley v McGee: Judgment affirmed, with costs.

In Matter of King v Amodeo: Order reversed, with costs, and judgment of Supreme Court, Dutchess County, reinstated.

In Matter of Harvey v Finnick: Orders affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs District Attorneys filed three separate actions against defendants three New York Counties seeking compensation in accordance with N.Y. Jud. Law §183-a. The Counties alleged that § 183-a was unconstitutional. The actions were consolidated.


OVERVIEW: Section 183-a required that District Attorneys in certain counties be paid at the same salary level as county court judges. A separate statute required that county court judge's' salaries be gradually increased. The Counties did not also gradually increase the District Attorneys' salaries. The Counties argued that § 183-a violated N.Y. Const. art. XIII, § 7, which provided that a state officer's compensation was fixed by law and was not to be increased or decreased during the officer's term of office and that N.Y. Jud. Law § 183-a violated N.Y. Const. art. IX that gave broad powers of home rule to local governing bodies. The court determined that the District Attorneys were not state officers but local officers, so that they were not subject to N.Y. Const. art. XIII, § 7. The court found that the adoption of N.Y. Jud. Law § 183-a did not violate the Counties' home rule authority because the home rule provisions did not restrict the legislature from acting upon matters of state concern. Maintaining the security and independence of the District Attorneys and assuring that persons of high standing and integrity remained in that position were matters of state concern.


OUTCOME: Section 183-a was not unconstitutional. The lower courts' judgments entered on behalf of the District Attorneys were affirmed. The judgment entered on behalf of the County was reversed.


HEADNOTES

District and Prosecuting Attorneys -- Statutory Compensation Plan

1. Section 183-a of the Judiciary Law, which divides counties into classes based on population and requires that full-time District Attorneys in counties with a certain population be paid the same salary as County Court Judges in their counties, is not in conflict with the home rule provisions of article IX of the New York Constitution, since the statutory classification is reasonable and the statute is related to a proper area of State concern, i.e., maintaining the quality and integrity of District Attorneys, who are responsible for enforcing the Penal Law and representing the people of the State in criminal matters arising within the counties; furthermore, section 7 of article XIII of the New York Constitution, which prohibits midterm increases in the salaries of State officers, does not bar such increases for District Attorneys, who should no longer be considered State officers within the meaning of said constitutional provision. Accordingly, petitioners, full-time District Attorneys in Clinton, Dutchess and Ontario Counties, are entitled to be compensated in accordance with the provisions of section 183-a prospectively and retroactively to the date at which the counties ceased paying salaries equivalent to those of the County Court Judges (Judiciary Law, § 221-d).

District and Prosecuting Attorneys -- Compensation

2. The power granted to local governments over the compensation of their officers under section 2 (subd [c], par [ii], cl [1]) of article IX of the New York Constitution is limited to the enactment of local laws which are not inconsistent with any general law relating to that subject. Accordingly, inasmuch as section 183-a of the Judiciary Law, which sets minimum salaries for full-time District Attorneys in certain counties, is a valid State enactment on this subject, it may not be superseded by conflicting local legislation.

District and Prosecuting Attorneys -- Compensation

3. Section 201 of the County Law, which places the authority to fix the salaries of officers paid from county funds in the board of supervisors, must be deemed impliedly repealed by the later enacted section 183-a of the Judiciary Law, which sets minimum salaries for full-time District Attorneys in certain counties, but only to the extent that the two laws are in conflict.

 

168 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


B. v. H.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 427; 442 N.E.2d 1248; 456 N.Y.S.2d 737; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3790


October 14, 1982, Argued  
November 18, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which reversed an order of the family court adjudicating respondent putative father to be the father of petitioner's child and dismissed the mother's petition.


OVERVIEW: The mother filed this paternity action more than six years after her child was born. The family court denied the putative father's motion to dismiss the matter as untimely under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 517(a). However, the lower appellate court granted the motion and held that the proceeding was barred because it was not commenced within 2 years of the last of the 39 separate support payments that the putative father made. On appeal, the court reversed the lower appellate court's order and reinstated the order of the family court in favor of the mother. The court held that, when a putative father acknowledged paternity either in writing or through the furnishing of support payments, the time within which a paternity proceeding had to be brought was not restricted by any statutory limitation. The court rejected the putative father's contention that the acknowledgement of paternity served only to start the two-year statutory period running anew.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the lower appellate court and reinstated the order of the trial court in favor of the mother.


HEADNOTES

Children Born out of Wedlock -- Filiation Proceeding

When a putative father has acknowledged paternity either in writing or through the furnishing of support payments, the time within which a paternity proceeding must be brought is not restricted by any statutory limitation. Subdivision (a) of section 517 of the Family Court Act, which establishes a general two-year limitation period for bringing such proceedings, expressly excepts situations when paternity has been acknowledged by the father, stating no new limit when the extension is founded upon this ground; in the absence of a legislative directive limiting the time within which the revived paternity proceeding must be brought, however, and in light of the strong public policy that obligates a parent to support his or her child, there exists no basis to hold that acknowledgment serves only to renew the statute of limitations; nor would a putative father be prejudiced by exposure to stale claims, because he may still seek the protection of the statute by controverting the basis for his payments, and recent advances in blood typing provide strong defenses; additionally, the father's affirmative acts of acknowledgment themselves argue against claims of surprise or prejudice.

 

169 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Tolub v. Evans


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


58 N.Y.2d 1; 444 N.E.2d 1; 457 N.Y.S.2d 751; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3874


October 7, 1982, Argued  
November 18, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant law assistants challenged an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a judgment of the New York County Supreme Court at Special Term (New York) in favor of respondents, court administrators and fiscal officers, declaring that the new salary system was not unconstitutional or a denial of equal protection.


OVERVIEW: The state assumed the law assistants' salaries under the Unified Court Budget Act of 1976. All clerks in trial level courts, whether previously paid by the state or city, were assigned a grade based on when they were admitted to the bar. The law assistants, previously paid by the city, received a lower salary than some prior state-paid clerks with the same length of service. The trial court concluded that respondents properly computed salaries and were not arbitrary or capricious, and it found no equal protection violation. The appellate court affirmed, holding that the state had a rational basis for the classification and finding that no one incurred any salary loss. On review, the court asserted that there was an adequate factual basis for different conversion methods to integrate court employees onto the unified budget. The court noted that individual evaluations that would otherwise be necessary were eliminated, and the former city employees retained superior benefits. The court concluded that where significant fiscal concerns and proper court administration existed, it would not strike legislation merely because it created geographic distinctions. The order was affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's order, which declared that the new salary system for law assistants was not unconstitutional, that the law assistants were not denied equal protection, that respondents did not act in an arbitrary or capricious manner or contrary to law, and that respondents were not required to pay the law assistants the increased salaries they sought. The petition was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Unified Court System -- Disparity in Salaries of Law Assistants

The provisions of sections 37 and 39 of the Judiciary Law, which establish the method of computing salaries for nonjudicial personnel serving in the Unified Court System, do not violate petitioners' right to equal protection of the law, although said provisions result in a disparity between the salaries received by petitioners, law assistants formerly paid by the City of New York, and some of the law assistants previously paid by the State with the same number of years of service, and although they also produce salary disparities among law assistants in different geographic areas; the fiscal restraints placed on the State provide a rational basis for the statutory classification, which provides a direct transition for State-paid employees into the incremental salary system based on years of service and incorporates employees formerly paid by local government by using their prior salary as a guide to placement in the incremental system. Furthermore, since respondent court administrators and fiscal officers acted in accordance with the dictates of section 39 of the Judiciary Law, which did not allow them any range of discretion on petitioners' salary increment assignments, it cannot be said that their actions were arbitrary or capricious.

 

170 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Crosby v. State, Workers' Compensation Bd.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 305; 442 N.E.2d 1191; 456 N.Y.S.2d 680; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3771


October 7, 1982, Argued  
November 16, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff worker sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which granted defendant Workers' Compensation Board's motion for summary judgment. The appellate division affirmed a lower court's ruling that dismissed the complaint that sought to declare N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law § 24 unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: A worker brought suit seeking a judgment declaring the fee restrictions of N.Y. Workers' Comp. Law § 24 unconstitutional because they effectively prevented her from retaining skilled legal counsel of her choice to pursue her compensation claim. The worker's counsel had been required to refund his retainer to the worker because such a fee arrangement was restricted by § 24. The court rejected the challenge, finding that requiring that attorneys' fees sought in connection with a claim arising under that law must have been approved by the board, was a reasonable regulation of the payment of attorneys' fees. The court reasoned that the law was enacted for the protection of the worker and did not violate the worker's constitutional rights to due process or equal protection. The court found that the worker's interest in entering into a particular fee arrangement or indeed, choosing a particular attorney to represent her was not the sort of personal decision encompassed within the "zone of privacy." The court further ruled that the challenged classification, burdened no suspect group and affected no interest deemed fundamental, needed only pass the constitutional test of rationality.


OUTCOME: The order dismissing the worker's challenge was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Attorneys' Fees in Compensation Cases

 Section 24 of the Workers' Compensation Law, requiring that attorneys' fees sought in connection with a claim arising under that law must be approved by the Workers' Compensation Board, is a reasonable regulation of the payment of attorneys' fees, enacted for the protection of the claimant, and does not violate a claimant's constitutional rights to due process or equal protection. Section 18 of article I of the New York Constitution, empowering the Legislature to enact laws to compensate injured employees, lays to rest all State constitutional attacks on the workers' compensation laws falling within its scope. Nor does section 24, in limiting plaintiff's ability to choose an attorney on her own terms, violate her constitutional right of privacy derived from the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by interfering in the "fundamentally private relationship" between attorney and client, since her choice of legal representation involves nothing more than an economic decision and is not the sort of personal decision encompassed in the "zone of privacy". Moreover, even though the fee restrictions are directed only to claimants and not to employers and compensation carriers, such a classification has a rational basis and is not violative of equal protection, inasmuch as the restriction on a claimant's choice of counsel is a reasonable method of furthering the legislative objectives of the Workers' Compensation Law by ensuring adequate economic relief to the employee or his family.

 

171 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. New York Trap Rock Corp.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 371; 442 N.E.2d 1222; 456 N.Y.S.2d 711; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3784


October 11, 1982, Argued  
November 16, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a corporation that operated a quarry, appealed a judgment from the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court, Second Judicial Department (New York), affirming defendant's conviction for violation of a local noise control ordinance.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted for violating a local noise control ordinance. The appellate court affirmed. On appeal, the court reversed, holding that the ordinance was unconstitutional for vagueness. The court determined that the ordinance was a ready candidate for discriminatory enforcement, and the ordinance's defects could not be remedied by narrowing the construction of the ordinance. The court determined that the ordinance's prohibition on loading or unloading any vehicle so as to create unnecessary noise within 300 feet of the boundary lines of a residential district during nighttime hours was vague, since it contained an additional phrase indicating that the prohibition was not limited to its specific language. The court concluded that the statute's 10 standards to be considered in determining whether unnecessary noise existed was vague, since it failed to provide guidance on terms, such as "intensity," "proximity," "duration," "time," and other subjective concepts.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's conviction for violation of the noise ordinance, since the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Noise Control Ordinance

1. A town noise control ordinance which imposes criminal liability upon violators is not pre-emptive of or inconsistent with State law (Penal Law, § 240.45); local governments have been given broad authority to adopt ordinances governing the safety, health and well-being of those within their jurisdictions (Municipal Home Rule Law, § 10) and, under subdivision 11 of section 130 of the Town Law, towns have received specific authority to regulate noise in their communities, indicating that the State did not intend to reserve the regulation of noise to itself.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Noise Control Ordinance

2. The Unnecessary Noise Control Ordinance of the Town of Poughkeepsie is unconstitutional, since the vagueness of the definitions of the conduct prohibited therein fails to provide a defendant with adequate warning of what the law requires and renders the ordinance susceptible to arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement. Accordingly, a judgment convicting defendant corporation, which owns and operates a quarry, of making "unnecessary noise", defined to include any "excessive or unusually loud sound or any sound which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of a person", and "loading or unloading * * * [a] vehicle * * * so as to create unnecessary noise at the adjoining property line" in violation of said ordinance, is reversed and the informations against defendant are dismissed.

 

172 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Davis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 382; 442 N.E.2d 1227; 456 N.Y.S.2d 716; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3785


August 30, 1982, Argued  
November 16, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of Davis and Matter of Dann: Order affirmed.

In Matter of Burke: Decree affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant executors sought review of the judgments from the Cattaraugus County Surrogate's Court and the Monroe County Surrogate's Court (New York) that found in favor of respondent, the Commissioner of Cattaraugus and Monroe County Departments of Social Services (Commissioners), and directed that appellant pay a claim of the Commissioners against their decedents' estates.


OVERVIEW: The decedents received Medicaid benefits while over the age of 65, but upon the death of each, the Commissioners sought recoupment of said benefits pursuant to N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 369(1)(b). The claims were rejected by the executors who contended that recoupment would constitute a denial of equal protection under both the federal and state constitutions, since Medicaid benefits paid to recipients under the age of 65 are not recouped. In affirming, the court held that § 369(1)(b) did not constitute a denial of equal protection. The court held that although there was no recoupment requirement with respect to benefits paid to those under the age of 65, the difference in treatment of the two groups had a rational basis and the two classes were circumstantially different in significant respects. Further, the court held that the "welfare article" of the New York Constitution, codified at N.Y. Const. art. XVII, did not mandate heightened scrutiny in all social services cases.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments from the lower courts, without costs.


HEADNOTES

Social Services -- Medical Assistance -- Recoupment of Medicaid Benefits

Section 369 (subd 1, par [b]) of the Social Services Law, which implements the permissive recoupment provisions of the Social Security Act (US Code, tit 42, § 1396a, subd [a], par [18]) and allows local social services departments to recoup Medicaid payments made to recipients at age 65 and older from their estates under certain circumstances, does not constitute a denial of equal protection (US Const, 14th Amdt; NY Const, art I, § 11), although there is no recoupment requirement for Medicaid benefits paid to recipients under the age of 65 (Social Services Law, § 366), since the difference in treatment between the two groups has a rational basis and, further, the two classes are circumstantially dissimilar in significant respects, e.g., to qualify for Medicaid a person under the age of 65 must be totally and permanently disabled, suffer a catastrophic illness, be blind or be eligible for public assistance, whereas a recipient who is over 65 may qualify for Medicaid without falling into one of those categories and may retain a home and other assets (Social Services Law, § 366); article XVII of the New York Constitution, the "welfare article", does not mandate heightened scrutiny in all social services cases.

 

173 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ferber


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 256; 441 N.E.2d 1100; 455 N.Y.S.2d 582; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3701


October 13, 1982, Argued  
October 21, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Upon reargument, following remand by the United States Supreme Court, order affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Promoting Sexual Performance by Child

Neither the First Amendment to the United States Constitution nor section 8 of article I of the New York Constitution prohibits the State from proscribing the promotion of a nonobscene sexual performance by a child under section 263.15 of the Penal Law. Furthermore, as applied to defendant bookstore owner, who was convicted of promoting a sexual performance by a child (Penal Law, § 263.15) and acquitted on charges of promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child (Penal Law, § 263.10) based on a sale of two films, which he allegedly depicted as "Kiddie Films", the statute does not violate the right to freedom of expression; accordingly, the judgment of conviction was properly affirmed.

 

174 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Beam


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 241; 441 N.E.2d 1093; 455 N.Y.S.2d 575; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3700


August 31, 1982, Argued  
October 19, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Orders affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought reversal of the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York) upholding two sodomy convictions.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested and charged with multiple counts of sodomy. After his arrest, he gave several incriminating statements to the police, which he unsuccessfully sought to suppress. He was then granted separate trials on each sodomy count, but at his trials evidence of the other alleged crimes was admitted. After his convictions were affirmed by an intermediate appellate court, defendant sought and was granted review by the state's highest court. That court also affirmed his convictions, reasoning as follows: (a) defendant's void-for-vagueness challenge to the sodomy statute was rejected because forcible compulsion was an unambiguous concept; (b) evidence of defendant's other alleged acts of sodomy were properly admitted to prove his identity because that identification was in dispute and because the jury was admonished as to limited purpose of the evidence; and (c) custodial statements were admissible because defendant had consulted with counsel prior to his interrogation and had voluntarily consented to speak with police.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of convictions. The sodomy statute was not unconstitutionally vague, the use of similar crimes evidence was permissible in order to show defendant's identity, and defendant's custodial statements were admissible because the statements were given after a valid waiver of rights and after consultation with counsel.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Identification of Defendant -- Proof of Other Crimes

1. Evidence of similar homosexual assaults allegedly committed by defendant was properly admitted, with appropriate limiting instructions, for the purpose of establishing defendant's identity at his trial on charges of sodomy, where the validity of the complainant's identification of defendant was challenged on cross-examination and through defendant's testimony, and defendant's modus operandi was sufficiently unique to tend to establish his identity, as each of the other four assault victims testified to the same initial ruse to lure him to an isolated area, three testified to being told the same story that defendant was from out of town and, with the exception of one man who managed to fight his assailant, each of them described the same pattern of French kissing, oral and anal sodomy during the actual assault; the fact that other identification evidence was introduced at trial does not bar evidence of similar crimes under the identification exception since the issue remained in dispute, and, although other homosexual attacks might follow the same scenario as those described, the pattern used by defendant was sufficiently distinctive to make evidence of the other attacks probative of the assailant's identity.

Crimes -- Right to Counsel -- Right to Remain Silent

2. The trial court properly denied defendant's motion to suppress statements linking him to the crimes charged, made after he agreed, on the advice of his attorney, to be questioned by police without the attorney present, and after this decision was confirmed in a telephone conversation between the interrogating officer and defendant's attorney, as defendant validly waived his right to remain silent on the advice of counsel; the police had no obligation to ensure that the initial communication between the attorney and his client, wherein defendant misinformed the attorney about the nature of the incident under investigation, was open and honest, or to seek some independent assurance that defendant's decision to waive his right to remain silent and to have his attorney present was based on good advice.
