Crimes -- Sodomy -- Forcible Compulsion

3. Subdivision 8 of section 130.00 of the Penal Law, which defines "forcible compulsion" as that term is used for purposes of establishing sex offenses under article 130 of the Penal Law, is not unconstitutionally vague; although forcible compulsion is an abstract concept, the statute cannot be termed ambiguous. Accordingly, defendant's convictions of sodomy in the first degree are affirmed, where there was adequate evidence in both cases that the defendant used physical force and intimidation to establish the requisite element of forcible compulsion.

 

175 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Corning v. Board of Elections


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 746; 440 N.E.2d 1326; 454 N.Y.S.2d 979; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3673


September 9, 1982, Argued  
September 10, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of Corning v Board of Elections of Albany County: Order affirmed, etc.

In Barone v Carey: Judgment, insofar as appealed from, reversed, etc.


HEADNOTES

Elections -- Primary Elections -- Polling Hours

In a proceeding brought to declare unconstitutional that portion of subdivision 2 of section 8-100 of the Election Law which provided for longer primary election voting hours in 10 selected counties of the State, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed a judgment declaring said statute unconstitutional and ordering all primary places to be open from noon to 9:00 p.m., and declared that the statute did not violate petitioners' equal protection rights, is affirmed for reasons stated in the opinion at the Appellate Division, which concluded that the case did not involve an abridgment of the fundamental right to vote so as to require a heightened level of scrutiny of the distinctions involved, but merely concerned the hours of primary voting, which may be the subject of valid State regulation; that the appropriate standard of review was the rational basis test, and that under such standard, the statute is constitutional since the Legislature's presumed consideration and evaluation of the voting problems in the 10 counties (i.e., overcrowding during the evening hours) provided a rational basis for the different voting hours, and petitioners failed to show that the underlying legislative judgment was irrational. In a similar case, a judgment of the Supreme Court, which declared the subject statute unconstitutional and ordered all primary polling places in the State to be open from 6:00 a.m. until 9:00 p.m., as in the 10 counties, is reversed and the statute declared constitutional.

 

176 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Barbara


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 727; 442 N.E.2d 60; 455 N.Y.S.2d 763; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3655



September 9, 1982, Decided


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence

An order of the Appellate Division, which modified a judgment convicting defendant of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first degree, criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree, and unlawful possession of marihuana, and sentencing him to concurrent terms of imprisonment of 6 years to life, 6 months and 15 days, upon his respective convictions, by vacating the sentence of 6 years to life (A-II felony sentence) upon the conviction of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first degree and remitting for imposition of a proper sentence (A-I felony sentence), is affirmed. The statutorily mandated sentence is not unconstitutional as applied to this defendant. ( People v Broadie, 37 NY2d 100; People v Jones, 39 NY2d 694.)

 

177 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Weissman v. Evans


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 458; 438 N.E.2d 397; 452 N.Y.S.2d 864; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3464


June 7, 1982, Argued  
July 2, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to plaintiffs, and case remitted to Supreme Court, Westchester County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff district judges sought a judgment declaring the salary disparity between them and judges of another district violated the equal protection provisions of the state and federal constitutions. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirmed the ruling that it did, but modified the date by which the disparity had to be eliminated. The judges and defendant state challenged the judgment.


OVERVIEW: An unfavorable salary disparity existed between the judges and the judges of the only other district in the state. The trial court ordered that the disparity had to be eliminated by October 1980 or the judges' equal protection rights would have been violated. The appellate court modified the judgment by making the target date April 1982 and affirmed the judgment. Both parties appealed from that ruling. The court modified the order to reinstate the earlier date and, as modified, affirmed the judgment. The court held that (1) while equal protection did not necessarily require territorial uniformity, a territorial distinction that had no rational basis would not support a state statute; (2) the historical differential between the salaries did not interdict the judges' equal protection claim; (3) there was no rational basis for the geographical classification used by the state to support its defense of the disparate judicial salaries; (4) the judges' rights accrued in October 1978 because deferral to a later date would vitiate the relief for those judges who retired on or after that date and the remedy had to be coextensive with the wrong it was to redress.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment to reinstate the earlier target date for eliminating the salary disparity, and as modified, affirmed the judgment.


HEADNOTES

Judges -- Disparity in Judicial Salaries -- District Court Judges

The wage disparity between plaintiff Judges of the Suffolk County District Court and the Judges of the only other District Court in the State, that of adjoining Nassau County, represents an unconstitutional impairment of plaintiffs' rights to equal protection of the laws (NY Const, art I, § 11; US Const, 14th Amdt), as there is no rational basis for the geographic classification on which the salary disparity is grounded. Furthermore, plaintiffs are entitled to judgment for the differentials between their salaries and those paid to Nassau County District Court Judges from October 1, 1978, which is the appropriate date from which to measure the accrual of plaintiffs' rights, since the Legislature acted on the subject of District Court Judges' salaries in 1979 in legislation that was retroactively effective to said date, but failed to eliminate the unconstitutional disparity in the salaries of Judges of the District Courts (Judiciary Law, § 221-f).

 

178 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re Guardianship of Nereida S.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 636; 439 N.E.2d 870; 454 N.Y.S.2d 61; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3593


May 11, 1982, Argued  
July 2, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order affirmed, without costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parents sought review of judgments of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed orders of the family court terminating the parental rights of the parents on the ground of mental illness, and vacated an order of the family court finding certain subdivisions of the Social Services Law unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Respondent guardians of children filed petitions for the termination of the children's parents' rights due to the parents' mental illnesses. The appellate division terminated the parental rights of one parent, determining that there was clear and convincing proof that he was presently and for the foreseeable future, by reason of mental illness, unable to provide adequate and proper care for his two children. The appellate division also determined that there was clear and convincing proof of mental illness that rendered a mother unable to provide adequate supervision and guidance to her children in the foreseeable future, and terminated her parental rights. The appellate division also concluded that N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law §§ 384-b(4)(c), 384-b(6)(a), dealing with mental illness and termination of parental rights, were not unconstitutionally vague and did not violate equal protection, procedural due process, or substantive due process. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment of the appellate division, finding no basis for disturbing the appellate division's findings that there existed mental illness sufficient to justify termination of parental rights.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments of the appellate division terminating the parents' parental rights and vacating the family court's determination of unconstitutionality.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights -- Mentally Ill Parent

In two proceedings to terminate parental rights pursuant to section 384-b (subd 4, par [c]) of the Social Services Law on the ground of mental illness, orders of the Appellate Division modifying orders which, in one proceeding, dismissed a petition to terminate the parental rights of respondent father and, in the other proceeding, denied a petition to terminate the parental rights of respondent mother, by declaring that section 384-b (subd 4, par [c]; subd 6, par [a]) of the Social Services Law is constitutional and terminating the parental rights of the father and mother on the ground of mental illness, are affirmed. There is clear and convincing proof that each parent is presently and for the foreseeable future unable, by reason of mental illness, to provide proper and adequate care for the children; consequently, there is no basis for disturbing the Appellate Division's findings that there exists mental illness sufficient to justify termination of parental rights. There is no merit to the parents' arguments that the statutory scheme violates rights of procedural and substantive due process and equal protection and authorizes termination of rights on the basis of a parent's status as mentally ill, since the statutes provide significant procedural safeguards for the natural parent's rights and authorize termination only when specific and definite criteria are met and when necessary in the best interest of the child, and it is the parent's conduct and relationship with the child, not his or her status per se, that forms the predicate for terminating parental rights.

 

179 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Bd. of Educ. v. Nyquist


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


57 N.Y.2d 27; 439 N.E.2d 359; 453 N.Y.S.2d 643; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3535


May 10, 1982, Argued  
June 23, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, boards of education (boards), students, officials, and taxpayers, sought review of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which modified the judgment of the trial court declaring that the state's system of financing public schools was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The boards and students filed a complaint challenging the constitutionality of the state's system of financing public schools. Other boards, the officials, and taxpayer's intervened. The challenged system permitted the expenditure at the local level of funds collected in each county through property taxes. The appellate division modified the judgment of the trial court, finding, in part, that the scheme violated the equal protection clause of the New York Constitution, but not that of the federal constitution. On appeal, the court modified and held that the system of local funding to public school districts was constitutional. The financing scheme did not violate the equal protection clause of either the New York State Constitution or the federal constitution because the preservation and promotion of local control of education was both a legitimate state interest and one to which the present financing system was reasonably related. Nor was the education article of the New York State Constitution violated. It provided only for a minimum level of education, not that all education facilities would be equal throughout the state.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment of the appellate division and held that the state's system of financing public schools was not unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Public School Financing System

1. The existing provisions for State aid to finance public education in this State do not violate the equal protection clause contained in the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution, notwithstanding disparities in per pupil expenditures among the State's school districts, resulting largely from the differences in the revenue available for educational purposes in consequence of unequal real property tax bases or unequal demands on local revenue. Applying the rational basis standard of equal protection review, no impermissible discrimination against pupils in the less property-wealthy districts is found, there being a rational relationship to a legitimate State purpose, here the permission and encouragement of participation in and control of public schools at the local district level. Nor does the present school finance system discriminate against large city school districts, since inequalities existing in cities are the product of demographic, economic and political factors intrinsic to the cities themselves, and cannot be attributed to legislative action or inaction.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Public School Financing System

2. The existing provisions for State aid to finance public education in this State do not violate the equal protection clause of the New York State Constitution (art I, § 11), notwithstanding disparities in per pupil expenditures among the State's school districts, resulting largely from the differences in the revenue available for educational purposes in consequence of unequal real property tax bases or unequal demands on local revenue. Applying the rational basis standard of judicial review, the present school financing system has not been shown to be without a rational basis, since the justification for such system, the preservation and promotion of local control of education, is both a legitimate State interest and one to which the present financing system is reasonably related; any legislative attempt to make uniform and undeviating the educational opportunities offered by the several hundred local school districts would inevitably work the demise of local control of education available to students in individual districts. Nor can the present school finance system be found to discriminate against large city school districts, since inequalities existing in cities are the product of demographic, economic and political factors intrinsic to the cities themselves, and cannot be attributed to legislative action or inaction.

Constitutional Law -- Education of All Children of State -- Public School Financing System

3. The present school financing system does not violate the education article (art XI, § 1) of the New York State Constitution. This article, requiring the Legislature to provide for maintenance and support of a system of free schools in order that an education might be available for all children, makes no reference to any requirement that the education to be made available be equal or substantially equivalent in every district; nor does it provide that districts choosing to provide opportunities beyond those that other districts might elect or be able to offer be foreclosed from doing so, or that local control of education, to the extent that a more extensive program were locally desired and provided, be abolished.

 

180 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Eaton v. New York City Conciliation & Appeals Bd.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 340; 437 N.E.2d 1115; 452 N.Y.S.2d 358; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3427


May 4, 1982, Argued  
June 17, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order reversed, with costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, tenants, challenged the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York), which held that determinations that the apartments owned and operated by a respondent, church, and rented to the general public were exempt from the rent stabilization laws.


OVERVIEW: Church owned and operated as landlord approximately 60 residential apartments. When church insisted that tenants enter into new leases at rents higher than those permitted by rent stabilization, tenants filed complaints. The court held that had the legislature intended to extend the exemption to religious institutions, it could have chosen to do so through appropriately worded legislation. The court held that in view of the legislature's failure to include religious institutions generally within the exemption provisions of the statute, an irrefutable inference arose that housing accommodations owned or operated by religious institutions were outside the scope of the statute. The court held that the issue involving tenant's claim for attorneys' fees should be remitted for further consideration as to whether the church's refusal to offer renewal leases in rent-stabilized terms constituted a failure to perform a covenant or agreement as was requisite to the application of N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 234.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remitted the case to the lower court for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation

Residential apartments owned and operated by a religious institution and rented to the general public are not exempt from the rent stabilization laws. Section 5 (subd a, par [6]) of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act, exempting from rent stabilization housing accommodations owned or operated by any institution operated exclusively for charitable or educational purposes on a nonprofit basis, contains no language which would permit an interpretation providing a similar exemption for institutions operated for religious purposes; nor does the statutory reference to monastery or convent serve to define religious institutions generally. Accordingly, the apartments in question being subject to rent stabilization, the matter must be remitted for a determination as to whether the landlord's refusal to offer renewal leases at rent-stabilized terms constituted a failure to perform a covenant or agreement so as to entitle petitioners to attorneys' fees pursuant to section 234 of the Real Property Law.

 

181 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


J.A. Green Constr. Corp. v. Fin. Adm'r of N.Y.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 369; 437 N.E.2d 1126; 452 N.Y.S.2d 369; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3431


May 11, 1982, Argued  
June 17, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and matter remitted to the Appellate Division, Second Department, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant shopping center owner and lessees, challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which reversed, on the law, so much of a judgment of the trial court, reducing assessments on certain real property and dismissing the petitions to review said assessments.


OVERVIEW: The court found that N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 720(3), under which the evidence was excluded, had no applicability to the case. Similarly, former statutes that expired during the pendency of the appeal were not applicable to the case, and thus, the common law was the basis of the court's ruling. The court held that the State Board of Equalization and Assessment rates were properly admitted at trial after the trial court found § 720(3), which barred their use, was unconstitutional. The appellate court reversal was predicated solely on its determination that § 730(3), expired at the time of the appeal, was constitutional. Finding that the opinion of the appellate court indicated that the appellate court did not pass on the validity of the trial court's determination of the property's fair market value or its computation of the proper assessments. Thus, the case was reversed and remitted to the appellate court to pass on those factual determinations.


OUTCOME: The order reducing the property assessment was reversed, and matter remitted to the appellate court for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- Evidence of Unequal Assessment

Equalization rates established by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment were properly admitted as proof of unequal assessment in a proceeding to challenge assessments against petitioners' real property in New York City, where judgment was entered therein prior to the effective date of the newly enacted version of subdivision 3 of section 720 of the Real Property Tax Law (L 1981, ch 1057), which restricts proof of unequal assessment in such a proceeding to selected parcels and comparable sales and bars the use of State equalization rates; predecessor statutes which similarly restricted proof of inequality, having expired during the pendency of appeals from said judgment, are not applicable thereto, notwithstanding the fact that they were in effect at the time of trial.

 

182 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Esler v. Walters


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 306; 437 N.E.2d 1090; 452 N.Y.S.2d 333; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3424


May 13, 1982, Argued  
June 15, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant residents challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), upholding the constitutionality of Town of Guilderland, N.Y. Law § 260(7), which provided that only town electors and landowners were entitled to vote in special elections on propositions to consolidate water districts.


OVERVIEW: The residents, who were ineligible to vote in a water district consolidation election because they were not landowners, argued that the statute precluding them from voting violated the equal protection guarantees of U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11. The trial court declared the statute unconstitutional, but the appellate court upheld the statute's constitutionality. The court held that the statute did not violate U.S. Const. amend. XIV because this special election related to a governmental body performing a special limited function having a disproportionate effect on a definable segment of the community. Because the landowners paid the water assessments, the impact of the election had a disproportionate effect on them. Similarly, the court found that the statute did not violate the public policy embodied in N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Limited Franchise in Special Election

In an election to consolidate two water districts within respondent town, limitation of the franchise to resident landowners within the districts, pursuant to subdivision 7 of section 206 of the Town Law, does not violate State constitutional provisions relating to the right to vote (NY Const, art I, § 1; art II, § 1), nor does it deprive nonlandowners of equal protection of the laws (US Const, 14th Amdt; NY Const, art I, § 11), since the purpose of the districts is limited to storing and delivering water to landowners in the districts and the effect of these activities on that segment of the population, whose property alone is subject to assessments and charges for the benefits conferred and to liens for delinquencies, is disproportionately greater than on those residents not permitted to vote.

 

183 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Holt v. County of Tioga


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 414; 437 N.E.2d 1140; 452 N.Y.S.2d 383; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3450


May 4, 1982, Argued  
June 15, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order, insofar as appealed from, reversed, with costs, and the second affirmative defense reinstated. Question certified answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county challenged an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which struck the county's affirmative defense claiming respondent injured party did not plead or prove compliance with Tioga County, N.Y., Local Law No. 2 of 1978, on the ground that Local Law No. 2 was unconstitutional. The injured party had filed a negligence suit for injuries sustained in a vehicle accident.


OVERVIEW: The injured party alleged the shoulder of the highway was defective, which caused her to lose control of her truck and strike a tree. She claimed the county was negligent in failing to repair the road. In reviewing the ruling that Tioga County, N.Y., Local Law No. 2 of 1978 was unconstitutional, the court held (1) there was a strong presumption that a local law enacted was constitutional, (2) under N.Y. Const., art. IX, § 2(c)(ii), cls. 5 and 6, counties were authorized to adopt local laws relating to the presentment of claims against them, (3) rights, powers, privileges, and immunities granted to local governments by N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 3(c) should be liberally construed, (4) Tioga County, N.Y., Local Law No. 2 of 1978 required prior notification to the county as a condition precedent to maintaining an action against it for negligent maintenance of county highways, (5) Local Law No. 2 was not inconsistent with N.Y. High. Law § 139, which imposed liability on counties for injuries caused by unsafe highways, (6) N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e(4) specifically allowed the enactment of prior notification statutes, and (7) Tioga County, N.Y., Local Law No. 2 of 1978 was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and reinstated the county's affirmative defense that had been stricken.


HEADNOTES

 Counties -- Prior Written Notice of Highway Defects

Tioga County Local Law No. 2 of 1978, which makes prior written notification of a dangerous condition or defect a condition precedent to maintaining a suit against the county, does not conflict with the general State law (Highway Law, § 139) which imposes liability on the county for injuries caused by unsafe or improperly maintained highways so as to be declared unconstitutional. Regarding the procedure necessary to commence an action pursuant to section 139 of the Highway Law, that statute defers to section 50-e of the General Municipal Law, subdivision 4 of which specifically allows for the enactment of prior notification statutes and requires compliance with such laws, making no distinction between general and local laws; similarly, section 139 of the Highway Law contains no provision limiting the applicability of section 50-e of the General Municipal Law or barring local laws which impose conditions precedent to maintaining an action against a county. Accordingly, the County of Tioga acted within its constitutionally mandated home rule powers in enacting Local Law No. 2 (see NY Const, art IX, § 2, subd [c], par [ii], cls [5], [6]).

 

184 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Freeport Randall Co. v. Herman


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 832; 438 N.E.2d 99; 452 N.Y.S.2d 566; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3462


May 3, 1982, Argued  
June 8, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants sought review of an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which modified and affirmed an order and judgment of the trial court in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to annul determinations of respondent reducing regulated rents for petitioners' apartments and to declare unconstitutional, subdivision b of section 9 of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners argued that as to leases they entered into with tenants prior to the adoption by the Board of Trustees of the Village of Freeport of a resolution declaring the existence of an emergency pursuant to subdivision a of section 3 of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974 (ETPA), the act, to the extent that it required a refund of so much of the rent paid prior to the date of adoption of the resolution as was in excess of the fair market rent determined after such adoption was an unconstitutional impairment of contract in violation of section 10 of article I of the United States Constitution. Petitioners argued further that they were entitled to a hearing on comparable rents as related to the establishment of the fair market rent for the housing units involved. On review, the court affirmed. The court held that neither argument withstands analysis. Each of the leases in question was made after passage of the ETPA. Every lease entered into after the effective date of the ETPA was, therefore, subject to the power of the state reserved by that provision to itself and to the municipalities to require that rent paid under such a lease be refunded.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order that modified and affirmed an order and judgment of the trial court to annul determinations of respondent reducing regulated rents for petitioners' apartments and to declare unconstitutional a portion of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation

In an action to declare subdivision b of section 9 of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974 (ETPA, L 1974, ch 576, § 4) an unconstitutional impairment of contracts to the extent that it required a refund of so much of rents paid prior to the adoption of a local resolution declaring the existence of a rental emergency, as were subsequently found to be in excess of the fair market rent, an order of the Appellate Division, which modified an order and judgment upholding the statute's constitutionality, but staying the enforcement of the rent refunds until a hearing on the issue of comparable fair market rents could be held, by striking the provision for a hearing and vacating the stay, is affirmed. Every lease entered into after the effective date of the EPTA, such as those at bar, was subject to the power of the State and those municipalities authorized to determine the need for emergency rent regulation, to require that the rent paid under such leases be refunded to the extent that the rent exceeded the fair market value since the challenged statute expressly provides that where the State housing agency has determined that a rent charged was "excessive", it shall order a refund of any excess paid after January 1, 1974 or the date of the commencement of the tenancy, whichever was later, and, inasmuch as petitioners' apartments were "an enterprise already regulated in the particular" to which they now object at the time the leases in question were made, the "retroactivity" which petitioners claim invalidates the refund requirement as to them under the contract clause of the United States Constitution simply does not exist; petitioners, landlords, were not entitled to a hearing as to the comparability of the "excessive" rents since they made no application for one within the 60-day limitations period set forth in subdivision a of section 9 of the ETPA.

 

185 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Hasenbein v. Siebert


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 853; 438 N.E.2d 877; 453 N.Y.S.2d 171; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3475


May 5, 1982, Argued  
June 8, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Banks and Banking -- Savings and Loan Associations -- Qualifications of Directors -- Antinepotism Statute

In an action to declare unconstitutional section 397 (subd 2, par [b], cl [3]) of the Banking Law, which provided that the spouse of a niece of a director of a savings and loan association could not be appointed a director of the same institution, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed an order granting plaintiff's motion for summary judgment, denied the motion and declared the statute constitutional as applied to plaintiff, is affirmed. The statute does not violate plaintiff's right of equal protection and due process of law; it does not interfere with his freedom to marry, because its focus is on marital relationships, not status. Nor, simply because it precludes him from sitting as a director of one savings and loan institution, does it interfere with his right to pursue his chosen profession; moreover, the statute is a rational exercise of the State's police power, reasonably calculated to achieve its goal of eliminating nepotism in the savings and loan industry.

 

186 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


In re M.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 77; 436 N.E.2d 491; 451 N.Y.S.2d 41; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3317


March 24, 1982, Argued  
May 18, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and matter remitted to the Family Court, Onondaga County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant parent sought review of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) which affirmed an order of the trial court that permanently terminated appellant's parental rights on the grounds that appellant was not fit to raise his child.


OVERVIEW: Appellant parent challenged the lower court's decision to affirm the trial court's determination that he was unfit to raise his child and claimed that his parental rights were improperly terminated. The court reversed the decision of the lower court and remanded the case to the trial court for further proceedings. The court held that appellant's unfitness simply was not one of the findings that would have supported an order of termination under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 384-b(4). Termination of appellant's parental rights had to be predicated upon one or more of the grounds specifically enumerated in § 384-b(4), none of which included unfitness, and therefore such termination was improperly based on a finding of unfitness alone. Appellee, Department of Social Services, needed to support its allegations through clear and convincing evidence of abandonment, inability to care for the child due to mental illness or retardation, permanent neglect, or severe or repeated child abuse.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the termination of the parental rights of appellant parent because the decision was improperly based solely upon a finding that appellant was unfit to raise his child rather than on grounds specifically provided for by statute that would have supported a termination order.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights

1. A habeas corpus proceeding to obtain custody of a child is not an appropriate substitute for a proceeding under section 384-b of the Social Services Law, which may be originated only by an authorized agency or foster parent who serves a petition on notice to the parent. Accordingly, a court may not properly adjudicate a termination of parental rights where the father's custody proceeding is the only proceeding before the court.

Parent and Child -- Termination of Parental Rights

2. Since the termination of parental rights must be predicated on one or more of the grounds specifically enumerated in section 384-b of the Social Services Law, none of which includes "unfitness" as such, it may not be based on a finding of the latter alone, but would instead require a finding of abandonment, mental illness or retardation, permanent neglect, or severe or repeated child abuse.

 

187 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kagan


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 193; 436 N.E.2d 1274; 451 N.Y.S.2d 672; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3328; 34 A.L.R.4th 540


April 1, 1982, Argued  
May 18, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In People v Kagan and Wolf: Orders reversed and indictments dismissed.

In People v Benestad: Order reversed, plea vacated and case remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings on the indictment.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, chairman of the board, senior manager, and director, were charged with felonies under N.Y. Banking Law § 673. The trial court convicted the chairman of the board and the senior manager of misapplication of bank funds and conspiracy. The director entered a plea of guilty to misapplication of bank funds. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, affirmed. The chairman of the board, senior manager, and director appealed.


OVERVIEW: The chairman of the board, senior manager, and director, on various occasions, authorized deposits of bank funds and extensions of credit to customers, which exceeded the limits imposed by N.Y. Banking Law §§ 103, 106. The bank did not suffer losses on any of the transactions, and none of the convicted bank officers made any profit on or otherwise had any personal pecuniary interest in the transactions. On appeal, the court reversed the convictions. The court held that there was no basis for the charges that the chairman of the board, senior manager, and director willfully misapplied the bank's funds and credit because they acted solely in their positions as officers and directors of the bank without any suggestion of personal profit. "Wilful misapplication" required some form of self-dealing or some benefit to the accused's commercial and material interests. For an individual to be convicted under N.Y. Banking Law § 673, the State was required to allege and prove some personal pecuniary interest in the transactions, which was more than the simple benefits flowing from the gratitude of a well-served client or owner of the bank.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the convictions and dismissed the indictments of the chairman of the board and the senior manager for misapplication of bank funds and conspiracy. As to the director who entered a guilty plea to misapplication of bank funds, the court reversed the conviction, vacated the plea, and remitted the case for further proceedings on the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Banks and Banking -- Misapplication of Bank Funds -- Criminal Liability

A bank officer or employee who, without more, extends to a bank customer credit in amounts exceeding civil limits is not guilty of feloniously misapplying bank funds within the meaning of section 673 of the Banking Law; wilful misapplication of bank funds, as that term is used in the statute, requires that the offender have a personal pecuniary interest in the transactions before criminal liability will attach. Accordingly, convictions of defendant bank officers and directors under an indictment charging that defendants knowingly violated sections 103 and 106 of the Banking Law in that, on various occasions, they authorized deposits of bank funds in other banks and extensions of credit to bank customers which exceeded the limits imposed by sections 103 and 106 of the Banking Law, are reversed, where the bank suffered no losses on any of the transactions, and none of the defendants made any profit on or otherwise had any personal pecuniary interest in the transactions.

 

188 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Holy Spirit Asso. for Unification of World Christianity v. Tax Com. of New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 512; 435 N.E.2d 662; 450 N.Y.S.2d 292; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3259


March 30, 1982, Argued  
May 6, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed, without costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, with directions to remand to the Tax Commission of the City of New York for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) that confirmed the report of the special referee and the determination of appellee that had denied appellant's application for property tax exemption.


OVERVIEW: Appellant applied to appellee, Tax Commission for the City of New York, for exemption from real property taxes. Appellee denied application. Appellant then sought judgment annulling appellee's determination. Lower court affirmed appellee's determination, and this appeal followed. Court reversed lower court, noting that it and appellee invoked erroneous legal principles. Court held error of lower court and appellee was that each asserted right of civil authorities to examine the creed and theology of appellant and to factor out what in its judgment were the peripheral political and economic aspects, in contradistinction to what was acknowledged to be essentially religious component. Court concluded that as a matter of law, primary purpose of appellant (much of whose doctrine, dogmas, and teachings and a significant part of whose activities are recognized as religious) was religious and determination of appellee to the contrary was both arbitrary and capricious and affected by error of law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the denial of tax exemption for appellant, holding the primary purpose of appellant was religious and that the determination of the lower court and appellee to the contrary was both arbitrary and capricious and affected by error of law.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Exemptions

In determining whether a particular ecclesiastical body has been organized and is conducted exclusively for religious purposes, the courts may not inquire into or classify the content of the doctrine, dogmas and teachings held by that body to be integral to its religion, but must accept that body's characterization of its own beliefs and activities and those of its adherents, as long as that characterization is made in good faith and is not a sham; on this principle it must be concluded that petitioner Holy Spirit Association for the Unification of World Christianity has religion as its "primary" purpose, inasmuch as much of its doctrine, dogmas and teachings and a significant part of its activities are recognized as religious, and petitioner in good faith classifies as religious the economic and political beliefs and activities which are essential to its theology. Accordingly, the judgment confirming a determination of respondent Tax Commission of the City of New York denying petitioner's application for exemption from real property taxes pursuant to section 421 (subd 1, par [a]) of the Real Property Tax Law for certain real property acquired by petitioner on the ground that the association is not organized or conducted exclusively for religious purposes within the meaning of said statute, is reversed and the case is remitted for remand to the Tax Commission for determinations with respect to whether said property is primarily used for purposes that would entitle petitioner to exemption under the statute.

 

189 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Connor v. Siebert


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 674; 436 N.E.2d 1316; 451 N.Y.S.2d 714; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3342


March 25, 1982, Argued  
May 4, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory Judgments -- Failure to Present Justiciable Controversy

In two actions for declaratory judgments challenging the constitutionality of the mandatory retirement provisions of section 246 (subd 1, par [c], cl [ii]) of the Banking Law, but not challenging a savings bank's by-law which was enacted pursuant to said statute and which affected the mandatory retirement of the bank's trustees as they reached age 75, orders of the Appellate Division, which reversed judgments declaring said statute unconstitutional and dismissed the complaints, are affirmed, since it was not an abuse of discretion as a matter of law for the Appellate Division to decline to entertain the actions on the ground that no justiciable controversy existed upon which the court could properly rule.

 

190 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Burns v. Robert Miller Constr., Inc.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 501; 435 N.E.2d 390; 450 N.Y.S.2d 173; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3234


February 18, 1982, Argued  
April 7, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION:  Order reversed, etc.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, mother of a posthumous child of a deceased worker and claimant child (mother and claimant), sought review of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed a decision of respondent Workers' Compensation Board (board) and denied the claimant death benefits.


OVERVIEW: The claimant was born after his father died in a job related incident. Through his unmarried mother, the claimant filed for death benefits. The mother disclosed her pregnancy to the deceased on the day of his death. The board denied the claim, finding that the claimant was not acknowledged by the decedent as his child and could not receive benefits. The claimant challenged the determination on the ground that N.Y. Work. Comp. Law § 2(11) was unconstitutional, contending that claimant was denied equal protection by virtue of the law's classification of children born in and those born out of wedlock. Only the latter were required to prove both dependency on and acknowledgment by the father. On review, the court reversed the decision. The court held that the law recognized such informal relationships. Further, proof of paternity and dependency accomplished the purposes of the statutory scheme. The court held that children born out of wedlock claiming death benefits under N.Y. Work. Comp. Law were required to prove only paternity and dependency and that it was unconstitutional to require the additional proof of acknowledgment as a prerequisite to approving the child's claim.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the appellate division.


HEADNOTES

Workers' Compensation -- Death Benefits -- Unacknowledged Child Born out of Wedlock

Inasmuch as no legitimate State interest is substantially furthered by the requirement that a child born out of wedlock be acknowledged by the father in order to receive death benefits under section 16 of the Workers' Compensation Law upon the death of the father in a job-related accident, subdivision 11 of section 2 of the Workers' Compensation Law, which includes within the definition of children entitled to receive such benefits "a posthumous child, a child legally adopted prior to the injury of the employee; and a stepchild or acknowledged child born out of wedlock dependent upon the deceased", unconstitutionally denies equal protection to children born out of wedlock; children born out of wedlock claiming death benefits under section 16 of the Workers' Compensation Law should be required to prove only paternity and dependency. Accordingly, a claim filed for workers' compensation death benefits on behalf of a child born out of wedlock afer the death of his putative father, who never acknowledged claimant as his child, is reinstated; posthumous children born out of wedlock, such as claimant, are not "posthumous" children within the meaning of the statute and must establish their entitlement to benefits as would any child born out of wedlock.

 

191 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Tucker v. Tucker


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 378; 434 N.E.2d 1050; 449 N.Y.S.2d 683; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3192


February 15, 1982, Argued  
April 6, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to defendant, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed. Question certified answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant wife and cross-appellant husband both challenged a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York). The decision reversed the trial court's decisions to grant the wife's motion to discontinue and refile her divorce action and allowed the husband to amend his answer provided he stipulated that the wife's rights would not be affected if she were found guilty of misconduct.


OVERVIEW: The wife contended that the appellate division erred in holding, as a matter of law, that the trial court could not exercise its discretion to grant her application to discontinue the action she began for divorce before the Equitable Distribution Law became effective, which provided for a more liberal distribution of property. The husband challenged the trial court's authority to condition amendment of his answer on the stipulation described above. The court modified the order of the appellate division, deleting the granting of the husband's motion to amend his answer, and, as so modified, held that a plaintiff who has commenced a matrimonial action prior to the effective date of the Equitable Distribution Law may not discontinue that action for the purpose of instituting a second action after that date in order to obtain benefits under the broader provisions relating to distribution of marital property applicable in actions commenced after the statute became effective. The wife was not entitled to receive the benefits of the Equitable Distribution Law by discontinuing her suit and refiling.


OUTCOME: The court modified the appellate division's order. The court affirmed the reversal of the order granting the wife's motion to discontinue. The court reversed the order that granted the husband's motion to amend his answer.


HEADNOTES

Husband and Wife -- Equitable Distribution of Marital Property

1. A plaintiff who has commenced a matrimonial action prior to the effective date of the Equitable Distribution Law may not discontinue that action for the purpose of instituting a second action after that date in order to obtain benefits under the broader provisions relating to distribution of marital property applicable in actions commenced after the statute became effective (see Domestic Relations Law, § 236, part B); in view of the clear intent expressed in the statute as to the applicability of its two, quite different, constituent parts, there is no room for the exercise of judicial discretion to vary what has been prescribed by the Legislature.

Husband and Wife -- Divorce -- Equitable Distribution of Marital Property

2. In an action for divorce brought by the plaintiff wife prior to the effective date of the Equitable Distribution Law (Domestic Relations Law, § 236, part B), it was error to condition the grant of the defendant husband's application to amend his answer to plead counterclaims for divorce on a stipulation by him that plaintiff wife's rights would not be affected if she should be found guilty of misconduct; the plaintiff's right to alimony would be cut off if the husband established her misconduct by proof offered in support of his counterclaims for divorce based on cruel and inhuman conduct and on abandonment (see Domestic Relations Law, § 236, part A) and the condition was thus imposed for the purpose of averting any prejudice to the wife. A court is not at liberty, in granting the husband's application to interpose counterclaims for divorce in his wife's part A action, to require his consent to a variation of the substantive provisions which by legislative fiat are applicable to that action.

 

192 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Valladares v. Valladares


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 388; 434 N.E.2d 1054; 449 N.Y.S.2d 687; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3193


February 15, 1982, Argued  
April 6, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs. Question certified answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant wife appealed the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) that affirmed a determination that the wife could not have amended her answer to add claims for equitable property distribution under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 236, part B, in the plaintiff husband's divorce action.


OVERVIEW: The husband commenced a divorce action in April 1980. The wife filed an amended answer in October 1980 that incorporated a claim under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 236, part B., the Equitable Distribution Law, which had been enacted on July 19, 1980. The court affirmed the denial of the wife's attempt to add the claim. The court reasoned that the legislature was meticulous in its setting forth the applicability of part B, in contrast to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 236, part A. The court observed that the legislature stated that part A, was applicable to divorce actions commenced prior to its effective date, while part B was effective as to such actions commenced after July 19, 1980. In making that determination, the court rejected the wife's claim that under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 203(c) and (e) the applicability of part B was when her claim was interposed, because the court noted that the legislature had not elected to use such language, but rather had designated commencement of the divorce action as the critical event. Further, given the intense political debate, the court did not believe that the legislature's choice of words had been inadvertent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that precluded the wife's amended answer that brought a claim for equitable property distribution because the explicit language of the Equitable Distribution Law disallowed claims under it that were part of divorce actions commenced before its enactment date.


HEADNOTES

Husband and Wife -- Equitable Distribution of Marital Property

In an action for divorce commenced prior to the effective date of part B of section 236 of the Domestic Relations Law, which provides for the equitable distribution of marital property in a matrimonial action, defendant wife's application for leave to amend her answer after that date to demand property distribution in accordance with the statute as an incident to a counterclaim for divorce set out in the proposed pleading was properly denied; part B of section 236 of the Domestic Relations Law was expressly made "controlling with respect to any action or proceeding commenced on or after [its] effective date" and the determinative time for this purpose is not when the counterclaim was imposed but when the action in which it was interposed was commenced.

 

193 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Westinghouse Electric Corp. v. Tully


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 364; 434 N.E.2d 1044; 449 N.Y.S.2d 677; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3191


February 9, 1982, Argued  
April 1, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified, with costs to the State Tax Commission, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent Tax Commission of New York (commission) appealed a judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial Department (New York), which in a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 annulled a determination of the commission sustaining the imposition of corporate franchise tax assessments against petitioner corporation pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 9-A.


OVERVIEW: The corporation filed its New York franchise tax returns without charging itself with any portion of the "accumulated" income of its subsidiary, a domestic international sales corporation (DISC) that did not do business in New York. The department of taxation and finance assessed a deficiency against the corporation on that basis, finding that the corporation had failed to comply with N.Y. Tax Law § 28(9). The commission sustained the assessment. The corporation argued that subjecting such income to state taxation would impose an undue burden on interstate and foreign commerce in light of the federal tax preference on such income, and on the ground that New York lacked sufficient contacts with the DISC and the income it generates to permit the imposition of the tax. The appellate court found that the imposition of a tax on "accumulated" DISC income by New York violated the commerce clause, but sustained the tax on "deemed distributed" income. The court held that the imposition of the franchise tax on the DISC income did not violate the commerce clause because the federal legislation did not preempt the field and New York had sufficient nexus to permit the imposition of the tax.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's judgment by reinstating the determination of the commission and affirmed it as modified.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Income of "DISC" Subsidiary

1. The imposition of a franchise tax by New York State on corporate income emanating from the accumulated income of a subsidiary "domestic international sales corporation" (DISC) (Tax Law, § 208, subd 9, par [a], cl [1]), which income is not taxable to DISC shareholders under Federal law, does not violate the commerce clause, since the Federal legislation was not intended to pre-empt the field; moreover, since only that portion of the DISC income allocable to New York is subject to taxation, New York has a sufficient jurisdictional nexus to permit the imposition of such a tax on accumulated DISC income in the hands of a parent corporation that does business in New York, even where neither the DISC nor any of the parent's affiliates for which the DISC acts as export commission agent engage in business in the State or have other New York contacts.

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Income of "DISC" Subsidiary -- Credit for New York Export Earnings

2. The fact that the accumulated income of a "domestic international sales corporation" (DISC), taxable to DISC shareholders in New York under section 208 (subd 9, par [a], cl [1]) of the Tax Law, is subject to a tax credit under section 210 (subd 13, par [a]) of the Tax Law of a percentage of the taxpayer's accumulated DISC income allocable to New York as in-State earnings, is not inconsistent with due process mandates, since it relates to that part of the taxpayer's income that has a jurisdictional nexus with the State; furthermore, any effect the credit has on interstate commerce by providing an incentive to in-State export activity that is not available to non-New York based exporting is too indirect to run afoul of the commerce clause.

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Income of "DISC" Subsidiary

3. The imposition of a New York State franchise tax on the "deemed distributed" income of a "domestic international sales corporation" (DISC) in the hands of its New York parent corporation under subdivision 9 of section 208 of the Tax Law is not a violation of due process, even where neither the DISC nor any of the parent corporation's affiliates acting for which the DISC acts as export commission agent conducts business in New York or has other New York contacts, since, inasmuch as only that portion of the DISC income allocable to New York is subject to taxation, New York has a sufficient jurisdictional nexus to permit the imposition of such a tax; furthermore, although New York does not impose a franchise tax on a parent corporation doing business in New York for corporate income emanating from a non-DISC subsidiary, it is not irrational or a denial of equal protection clause for the State to tax the parent on the deemed distributed income of its wholly owned DISC subsidiary (Tax Law, § 208, subd 8-A, par [b]), since the subsidiary would otherwise file a combined tax report with the parent and there is nothing to indicate that the tax liability of the parent corporation resulting from a combined report would be less than that imposed under the statutory scheme for the taxation of DISC income.

 

194 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


D. Lambert Railing Co. v. County of Suffolk


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


56 N.Y.2d 516; 434 N.E.2d 1341; 449 N.Y.S.2d 963; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3208


February 8, 1982, Argued  
March 23, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Lambert Railing Co. v County of Suffolk, affirmed.

Royal Guard Fence Co. v County of Suffolk, affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Bids and Bidders -- Price Adjustments on Contracts for Steel Products

In two actions brought by suppliers of steel products seeking extra compensation for goods delivered to a county pursuant to a contract,  [**3] on the grounds that chapters 944 and 945 of the Laws of 1974 mandated the State and local governments to authorize increases in contract prices for petroleum derivative and steel products, an order of the Appellate Division, which reversed two judgments in favor of the suppliers and dismissed the complaints, is affirmed for the reasons stated in the opinion at the Appellate Division, which concluded that the language employed in said statutes unambiguously demonstrated a legislative intent to vest discretion in the various governmental contracting agencies, and, therefore, such authorizations of extra compensation were not mandatory, and that the discretion of the local agency was not improperly exercised since the facts reasonably could be conceived to sustain the county's resolution which limited the class of extra compensation recipients to suppliers of petroleum products.

 

195 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Di Raffaele


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 234; 433 N.E.2d 513; 448 N.Y.S.2d 448; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3540


January 15, 1982, Argued  
February 23, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, conviction vacated, plea withdrawn and case remitted to Supreme Court, Suffolk County, for further proceedings on the indictments.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction of the crime of criminal usury in the second degree from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the conviction without opinion.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with 12 counts of criminal usury in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 190.42. The first trial ended after the trial court granted defendant's motion for a mistrial. Defendant filed a proceeding to prohibit a second trial, but it was denied. Defendant pleaded guilty to criminal usury in the second degree on the condition that he could reserve the right to appeal with respect to the rulings denying his motion to suppress records and to dismiss the indictment. The court found that the assurance on which defendant's plea was predicated was ineffectual and, therefore, defendant could withdraw his guilty plea. Further, the court found that defendant did not have any expectation of privacy in the telephone records and that defendant's constitutional double jeopardy claims were barred by res judicata for any further judicial consideration.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order, vacated defendant's conviction, withdrew defendant's plea, and remitted the matter to the supreme court for further proceedings on the indictments because defendant's plea was premised on an ineffectual assurance that he could reserve his right to appellate review.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Appeal -- Plea of Guilty

1. Defendant's explicit reservation of the right to appeal four rulings, with the express consent of the prosecutor and the court, as part of his plea of guilty to criminal usury in the second degree under section 190.40 of the Penal Law, is ineffectual: (1) review of the ruling denying his suppression motion is statutorily preserved ( CPL 710.70, subd 2); (2) the denial of his application to dismiss the indictment on constitutional former jeopardy grounds is also appealable without regard to the guilty plea or the purported reservation; (3) his plea of guilty renders irrelevant his contention that the criminal proceedings preliminary to trial were infected with impropriety and error, and (4) he lacks standing to challenge the constitutionality of section 190.42 of the Penal Law, the statute under which he was indicted, since he was not convicted thereunder. However, defendant is permitted to withdraw his plea of guilty, and, accordingly, his conviction is vacated and the case is remitted for further proceedings on the original indictments.

Crimes -- Unlawful Search and Seizure

2. Release to the District Attorney of telephone billing records of calls made by defendant on his phone and that of a friend did not violate defendant's right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures (US Const, 4th Amdt; NY Const, art I, § 12), since defendant had no legitimate expectation of privacy in the records maintained by the telephone company with respect to either his own telephone or that of his friend, and said records were not obtained in violation of his constitutional privilege against self incrimination, inasmuch as the records were owned by and obtained from a third party and the release thereof entailed no testimonial compulsion against defendant; furthermore, defendant lacks standing to argue that the records should have been suppressed on the ground that they were obtained pursuant to void subpoenas, since defendant has no possessory or proprietary interest in the records.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Matters Appealable

3. On appeal to the Court of Appeals, defendant may not raise his claim that certain telephone billing records should have been suppressed at the trial of a criminal action against him on the ground that they were sought for prosecution under what he asserts was an unconstitutional statute, where this ground for suppression is raised for the first time in the Court of Appeals and was not raised below in support of the motion to suppress ( CPL 470.35, subd 1).

Crimes -- Former Jeopardy

4. On appeal from a judgment of conviction entered upon his plea of guilty, defendant is foreclosed, under the doctrine of res judicata, from raising the issue of whether constitutional former jeopardy principles preclude his retrial following a mistrial in the original criminal action against him, since this claim was fully litigated in his article 78 proceeding to prohibit a second trial; the relief sought was denied on the merits in the Appellate Division and his appeal therefrom was dismissed by the Court of Appeals on the ground that no substantial constitutional question was directly involved.

 

196 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Gurnee v. Aetna Life & Casualty Co.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 184; 433 N.E.2d 128; 448 N.Y.S.2d 145; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3087


January 12, 1982, Argued  
February 18, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Gurnee v Aetna Life & Cas. Co.: Order reversed, with costs, and defendants' motion to dismiss the complaint denied.

In Weinreich v State-Wide Ins. Co.: Order reversed, with costs, and defendants' motions to dismiss the complaint denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In two actions, appellant insureds sought review of the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed an order granting respondent insurers motion to dismiss the insureds' complaint for failure to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The insureds were both injured in separate automobile accidents and claimed lost wages and received $ 800 per month from the insurers. Following a decision that under N.Y. Ins. Law § 671, a covered person injured in a motor vehicle accident who sustained lost earnings of more than $ 1000 per month could have recovered actual lost earnings up to a maximum of $ 1000 per month, both insureds sought to recover the maximum allowed. On appeal of the lower court's dismissal of the insureds' complaints, the court held that the decision interpreting § 671 to allow for a $ 1000 recovery should have been accorded full retroactive effect. The court found that that no new principle of law had been established and the decision merely construed the language of a statute that was already in existence. The court determined that a balancing of the equities dictated that the insureds, as injured parties, not be made to bear the burden of foregoing part of the recovery to which they were statutorily entitled. The court concluded that the retroactive application effected no constitutional unconstitutional taking of property without due process.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment granting the insurers motion to dismiss the insureds' complaint for failure to state a cause of action. The court denied the insurers' motion to dismiss the insureds' complaint.


HEADNOTES

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Maximum Recovery for Lost Earnings

A decision of the Court of Appeals (Kurcsics v Merchants Mut. Ins. Co., 49 NY2d 451), holding that under section 671 of the Insurance Law a covered person injured in a motor vehicle accident who sustained lost earnings of more than $ 1,000 per month could recover as first-party benefits 80% of actual lost earnings up to a maximum of $ 1,000 per month rather than the $ 800 per month previously mandated by Insurance Department regulations, should be applied retroactively as to all claims not time-barred by the Statute of Limitations. Such retroactive application of Kurcsics is mandated since that case established no new principle of law, but merely construed the language of a statute that was already in existence; the purposes of the no-fault insurance legislation would be furthered by retroactive application, and, finally, a balancing of the equities dictates that the injured parties not be made to bear the burden of foregoing part of the recovery to which they were statutorily entitled. Moreover, such retroactive application neither impairs the obligation of contracts nor effects an unconstitutional taking of property without due process.

 

197 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Legum v. Goldin


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 104; 432 N.E.2d 772; 447 N.Y.S.2d 900; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3073


January 12, 1982, Argued  
February 16, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee appealed from an order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), denying an application to declare unconstitutional the provisions of respondent city's charter requiring the employee to pay an amount by which a city resident personal income tax calculated on his income exceeded the amount of taxes imposed on him for the same taxable period.


OVERVIEW: The employee worked for the city, and as a condition of his employment he signed an agreement pursuant to the city charter wherein he promised that if he was or later became a nonresident he would pay to the city an amount by which the city resident personal income tax calculated on his income exceeded the amount of any city earnings tax and city personal income tax imposed on him for the same taxable period. The employee brought a petition seeking to declare the provision of the city charter related to the agreement unconstitutional and void as an improper tax. The city brought a motion to dismiss the petition. The trial court granted the motion, and the employee appealed. The court affirmed the order dismissing the petition, ruling that the facts of the case did not present a situation in which the city exercised its sovereign authority to impose a tax on the employee without his consent, but instead presented a situation in which the employee agreed by contract to pay a certain amount to his employer, the city. The court concluded that the mere fact that the debt incurred pursuant to the contract of employment was owed to the city did not transform it into a tax.


OUTCOME: Order dismissing the petition was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Contracts -- Employment Agreement

Section 822 of the New York City Charter, which provides that every person seeking employment with the City of New York sign an agreement as a condition precedent to such employment to the effect that if he is or becomes a nonresident, he will pay to the city the amount by which the resident income tax calculated on his income exceeds the amount of any city earnings tax and city personal income tax imposed upon him for the same taxable period, does not impose an income tax on nonresident employees of the city. Accordingly, petitioner, a nonresident New York City employee who voluntarily signed such an agreement as a condition of his employment, incurred liability pursuant to the contractual provision in question and enjoyed the benefits of the other provisions of the contract; the funds paid to the city under such an agreement are not in the nature of a tax, imposed in invitum by the sovereign, but are owed pursuant to a contractual agreement between petitioner and the city.

 

198 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


American Sugar Refining Co. v. Waterfront Com. of New York Harbor


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


55 N.Y.2d 11; 432 N.E.2d 578; 447 N.Y.S.2d 685; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3041


November 16, 1981, Argued  
February 11, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, the Waterfront Commission's motion for summary judgment granted, plaintiffs' and counterclaim-defendants' cross motions for summary judgment denied, and judgment granted in favor of the Waterfront Commission in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor challenged the judgment of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed the judgment denying the Commission's motion for summary judgment and granting declaratory judgment to plaintiff companies and counterclaim defendant association in a case involving the award of certain benefits to longshoremen.


OVERVIEW: Four steamship companies and 26 other companies, all of which were members of the association, brought a declaratory judgment action against the Commission. They sought a declaration (1) that assessment by the Commission on the vacation and holiday benefits and guaranteed annual income (GAI) benefits was unauthorized and unconstitutional and (2) that the formula by which the Commission proposed to allocate to the respective companies a portion of the obligation for benefit payments previously made by the association's vacation, holiday, and GAI funds was arbitrary and invalid. The Commission later appealed from a judgment against it. On appeal, the issue was whether the payments made from the funds were subject to Commission assessment under the provision of a bi-State compact approved by Congress. The court reversed, finding that payments made through trust funds established pursuant to federal law covering the benefits in question were part of the gross payroll payments subject to assessment. The court also found that the trust funds making such payments were "employers" within the meaning of the Compact assessment provision.


OUTCOME: The order of the lower court upholding the denial of the Commission's motion for summary judgment was reversed. The Commission's summary judgment motion was granted, and the cross-motions of the companies and association for summary judgment were denied.


HEADNOTES

Waterfront Commission -- Payment of Commission Expenses -- Assessment upon Industry

1. The Waterfront Commission Compact provides for the payment of commission expenses, to the extent not covered by Federal grant, by an assessment upon the industry computed upon gross payroll payments at a rate not in excess of 2%, any amount over the total thus available to be financed by appropriations made by the New York and New Jersey Legislatures in proportion to the gross annual payments made to longshoremen for work in each State within the Port of New York district; payments made through trust funds established pursuant to Federal law covering vacation and holiday benefits and guaranteed annual income benefits are part of the gross payroll payments subject to assessment and the trust funds making such payments are "employers" within the meaning of the Compact's assessment provision, as also are direct employers of longshoremen. The assessment was enacted as a fee for the cost of administration in lieu of a license fee and not as a tonnage tax, with the purpose of imposing upon the industry the cost of eliminating unsavory and illegal employment and labor practices, and the legislative intent was to encompass in the words "gross payroll payments" the labor costs of the industry however incurred.

Appeal -- Court of Appeals

2. In a declaratory judgment action against the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor brought by 30 companies which employ longshoremen in the Port of New York area, seeking a judgment declaring that assessment by the commission on vacation and holiday benefits and guaranteed annual income benefits paid through trust funds established pursuant to Federal law is unauthorized and unconstitutional and that the formula by which the commission proposes to allocate to the respective plaintiffs a portion of the obligation for benefit payments previously made by other funds is arbitrary and invalid, the Court of Appeals can consider the contention that the Compact imposes not a tax but an assessment, although it was not advanced in the courts below, since it is not a contention that could have been obviated or cured by factual showings or legal countersteps, turning as it does on legislative intent.

Statutes -- Construction

3. Construction of an interstate Compact is a matter of Federal rather than State law.

 

199 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


People v. Arroyo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


54 N.Y.2d 567; 431 N.E.2d 271; 446 N.Y.S.2d 910; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3040


November 20, 1981, Argued  
January 19, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which affirmed his conviction for assault holding that admission of the preliminary hearing testimony of the witness at defendant's trial did not violate defendant's right to confrontation.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of assault and sought review arguing that the court erred in reading a witness's preliminary hearing testimony into evidence at trial. Specifically, defendant argued that the People's efforts to obtain the victim's personal presence at trial did not meet the due diligence requirements pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 670.10. The court concluded that the trial and appellate court's finding, that the People exercised due diligence, was supported by the evidence, as a matter of law. Therefore, the People established the witness's unavailability. Further, the witness's testimony was reliable, and defendant's right to cross-examination at the hearing was not frustrated in any meaningful way. The court concluded that the People not only met the test of trustworthiness posed by the confrontation issue, but the prior testimony served as a basis to uphold the conviction.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed because the People exercised due diligence in attempting to secure the witness' presence at the trial and admission of her preliminary hearing testimony was not erroneous.


HEADNOTES
