Crimes -- Right of Confrontation -- Admission of Witness' Prior Testimony

Admission of the preliminary hearing testimony of an unavailable witness, who was the victim of the assault with which defendant was charged and the sole identifying witness at defendant's trial, did not constitute an unconstitutional application of CPL 670.10 in violation of his right of confrontation (US Const, 6th Amdt; NY Const, art I, § 6), where the witness, defendant's estranged "common-law wife", disappeared on the eve of trial and could not be found despite diligent efforts by police to contact her or find a lead as to her whereabouts and where defendant was represented by counsel at the hearing, at which substantially the same subject matter was explored as was developed at trial, and he was furnished the opportunity to cross-examine the witness, who testified under oath, and, further, it was not error for the trial court to deny defense counsel's application to delete all of her preliminary hearing cross-examination of the witness, since this testimony was not the testimony of defendant and was no less an integral part of the testimony than that adduced on direct examination ( CPL 670.20); finally, the prior testimony so admitted required no corroboration and, under the circumstances, is legally sufficient to support defendant's conviction.

 

200 of 2465 DOCUMENTS


Colt Industries, Inc. v. Finance Adm'r of New York


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Court of Appeals of New York


54 N.Y.2d 533; 430 N.E.2d 1290; 446 N.Y.S.2d 237; 1982 N.Y. LEXIS 3038


November 18, 1981, Argued  
January 7, 1982, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Matter of Colt Inds. v Finance Administrator: Order modified, without costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed. Question certified answered in the negative.

In Matter of Equitable Life Assur. Soc. of v Finance Administrator: Order modified, without costs, in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed. Question certified answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In separate actions against respondent city, petitioner property owners filed a motion to consolidate seven proceedings, a motion for partial summary judgment declaring N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 720(3) unconstitutional, a motion for discovery of sales data listings, and a motion for reargument of a prior order. The supreme court at special term denied the motions. The appellate division (New York) affirmed, and the property owners appealed again.


OVERVIEW: The property owners commenced proceedings to review the tax assessments on their properties, arguing the assessments were erroneous by reason of inequality prior to December 3, 1981, the effective date of N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law § 720(3). The special term found New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 166-1.0 controlled in such proceedings, and it authorized a classified system of assessment within the city, upon which the charge of inequality must be based. Accordingly, because the special term found the state equalization rate was not admissible on the issue raised, it did not reach the question of the constitutionality of former N.Y. Real Prop. Tax Law §§ 307 and 720(3). After the appellate division affirmed, the court found Admin. Code § 166-1.0 authorized the property owners to present proof of inequality by showing the particular assessment was made at a higher proportionate valuation than the assessment of other real property of like character in the same ward or section, or the assessment was made at a higher proportionate valuation than the assessment of other real property on the assessment rolls of the city for the same year.


OUTCOME: The orders were modified, without costs, and matters were remitted for further proceedings and, as so modified, affirmed. Questions certified were answered in the negative.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Assessment -- State Equalization Rate

1. Section 166-1.0 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which governs the procedure for review of tax assessments in the City of New York, authorizes taxpayers who challenge the assessment of their property as unequal to present proof of inequality with respect to property of similar character in the same ward or section and/or with respect to the city-wide assessment rolls; the statute is not a legislative authorization for a classified system of assessments in the City of New York. Furthermore, if inequality with respect to city-wide assessment rolls is asserted, the State equalization rate may not be introduced in proceedings where no evidentiary hearings were held and no interlocutory determinations were made therein prior to December 3, 1981, the effective date of subdivision 3 of section 720 of the Real Property Tax Law (L 1981, ch 1057), although the proceedings were commenced before said date, since the new statutory provision, which effectively forecloses the use of State equalization rates in inequality proceedings within the City of New York and Nassau County, applies thereto.

Constitutional Law -- Assessment -- State Equalization Rate

2. Subdivision 3 of section 720 of the Real Property Tax Law (L 1981, ch 1057), which permits the use of the State equalization rate on the issue of whether an assessment is unequal, except in special assessing units with populations of one million or more, i.e., the City of New York and Nassau County, is procedural in nature and is constitutional; the provision does not deny equal protection to taxpayers within the special assessing units, since the Legislature had a rational basis in drawing the distinction, based on the size of the population within municipal units, and in restricting the admissibility of State equalization rates in such units, and, further, the legislation does not, on its face, constitute a denial of due process to taxpayers who challenge assessments on property within New York City and Nassau County as unequal, although parcel selection and proof of actual sales, the remaining, authorized measures of proof of inequality available to them, are more cumbersome and expensive.
